              <div about="/magazine/meet-7-most-disgusting-animals-africa" class="publisher-1333 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content" id="node-5485" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document">
               <div class="title-shim">
                Meet 7 of the Most Disgusting Animals in Africa
               </div>
               <img alt="" class="section-txt" src="http://www.nightjartravel.com/" title=""/>
               <h1>
                Meet 7 of the Most Disgusting Animals in Africa
               </h1>
               <span class="rdf-meta element-hidden" content="Meet 7 of the Most Disgusting Animals in Africa " property="dc:title">
               </span>
               <span class="rdf-meta element-hidden" content="0" datatype="xsd:integer" property="sioc:num_replies">
               </span>
               <a class="article-strip" href="http://www.getaway.co.za" style="background-color: #243741" target="_blank">
                <img src="http://www.nightjartravel.com/sites/default/files/getaway_0.gif"/>
               </a>
               <div class="content clearfix">
                <div class="zest-gallery">
                 <div class="stage">
                  <img/>
                 </div>
                 <div class="imgs">
                  <img alt="" src="http://www.nightjartravel.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_gallery/public/images-article/Disgusting%20LIST%20%26%20MAIN%20%20Africas-most-disgusting-hippo.jpg?itok=vXgJD15u" title=""/>
                 </div>
                </div>
                <div class="paging">
                 <div class="mag-shares">
                  <div class="g-plusone" data-annotation="none" data-href="http://www.nightjartravel.com/magazine/meet-7-most-disgusting-animals-africa" data-size="medium">
                  </div>
                  <div class="fb-like" data-height="20" data-href="http://www.nightjartravel.com/magazine/meet-7-most-disgusting-animals-africa" data-layout="button_count" data-send="false" data-show-faces="false">
                  </div>
                  <a class="pin-it-button" count-layout="horizontal" href="http://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=http://www.nightjartravel.com/magazine/meet-7-most-disgusting-animals-africa&amp;media=http://www.nightjartravel.com/sites/default/files/images-article/Disgusting%20LIST%20%26%20MAIN%20%20Africas-most-disgusting-hippo.jpg&amp;description=Meet 7 of the Most Disgusting Animals in Africa ">
                   <img border="0" src="//assets.pinterest.com/images/PinExt.png" title="Pin It"/>
                  </a>
                  <a class="twitter-share-button" data-count="none" data-text="Meet 7 of the Most Disgusting Animals in Africa " data-url="http://www.nightjartravel.com/magazine/meet-7-most-disgusting-animals-africa" data-via="nightjartravel" href="https://twitter.com/share">
                   Tweet
                  </a>
                  <div class="email-button nightjar-email-button" data-title="Meet 7 of the Most Disgusting Animals in Africa " data-url="http://www.nightjartravel.com/magazine/meet-7-most-disgusting-animals-africa">
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <div class="mag-date">
                  Jun 2013
                 </div>
                 <p>
                  By Tyson Jopson
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Theres a scene in Disneys The Lion King that captures the majesty of Africa with all the reverence and hyperbole weve come to associate with life on this wild continent. Illuminated in the dusty light of sunrise, herds shuffle, predators stand regal and everything from beast to bird revels in our immaculate perception of another perfect day in Africa  and then Pumbaa the warthog lets out a ripper that could melt the bark off a mopani tree.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  For all the awe-inspired gazing and gushing that takes place this side of your binoculars, theres a rather indecorous and oft-gross side to some animals, and a farting warthog doesnt even begin to hold a (precariously positioned) candle to some of them.
                 </p>
                 <h2>
                  THE JACKAL
                 </h2>
                 <p>
                  <img border="0" height="386" src="/sites/default/files/2013-1/Disgusting%201%20Africas-most-disgusting-jackal_1.jpg" style="color: #656565; font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.5;" width="578"/>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  These sub-Saharan scavengers will gladly munch on decomposing or diseased flesh, even if its been rotting for days. But old meat isnt the only thing on the jackals menu: aside from carrion, they eat bones, small mammals, berries, grass, insects and even reptiles. On the west coast of Namibia, jackals have been known to survive entirely on marine life, occasionally even chowing down on sea birds. Their stomachs adapt to the predominant food supply available in a survival tactic that allows jackals to exist as predators (on small game), scavengers or even purely on insects and rodents. Perhaps unbelievingly, theres a plus side to their foul-flesh fetish: by eating rotting leftovers, jackals actually contribute towards the control of disease.The jackal might just be the ultimate Fear Factor teammate. Regardless of whatever vile concoction nature conjures up, whack it on a plate and start counting the prize money because theres nothing these opportunistic omnivores wont gobble down. And much like a hungover, blurry-eyed varsity student in front of the fridge, they also have a knack for completely ignoring the sell-by date.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Is that shrivelled piece of boerie in your refrigerator from last weeks braai suddenly looking tasty again?
                 </p>
                 <h2>
                  THE DUNG BEETLE
                 </h2>
                 <p>
                  <img border="0" src="/sites/default/files/2013-1/Disgusting%202%20Africas-most-disgusting-dung-beetle_0.jpg"/>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Not only do they roll animal faeces, they also lay their eggs in it and hang around to watch as their young hatch and immediately go about feasting on the poo pie. In fact, these beetles are so passionate about dung that some, known as tunnellers, hide their smelly stash in the ground as if it were treasure. Others, called rollers, have been known to steal balls of poo from one another by shoving their heads under another beetle and flipping it into the air.The dung beetle is an obvious choice. These master poo rollers spend their days diligently cleaning up after the rest of the animal kingdom, all without a glimmer of career progression. Even after years of taking k*k from the big man (a.k.a. elephant) you wont suddenly find this beetle rolling a disco ball down Krugers H1 flaunting its well-toned calf muscles.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Still, dung beetles dont just do all this for the fun of it; their intricate antics play an important part in the environment  by burying dung they improve nutrient recycling and build soil structure and through eating it theyre effectively protecting larger mammals by removing dung that could provide a habitat for pests.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  It might be a dead-end job in a malodorous workplace, but with an eye on the big picture the dung beetle has certainly earned its right to dabble in the disgusting.
                 </p>
                 <h2>
                  THE FULMAR
                 </h2>
                 <p>
                  <img border="0" height="385" src="/sites/default/files/2013-1/Disgusting%203%20Africas-most-disgusting-fulmar_0.jpg" width="578"/>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Youd think that living on a moated fortress inaccessible to most land predators would make the fulmar carefree and quite laid-back. It doesnt  especially not for the chicks.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  The young birds are left alone in their breeding colonies off the southern coast of South Africa for hours while their parents take long, fanciful fishing trips far offshore. And much like Home Alones Macaulay Culkin with unsupervised time on his hands, fulmar chicks have devised an extraordinarily messy way to deal with unwanted visitors. They brew up a vile stew of fish oils, made up of indigestible fatty acids and triglycerides in their stomach, and then vomit it over anyone who comes too close to their nest. Its a less-than-charming defence tactic that not only smells hideous, its also dangerous: the blast of vomit is highly acidic and can damage predatory birds plumage, causing hypothermia or even drowning.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  While the usual threat is other birds, the fulmar will barf on pretty much anything that comes within spitting distance, which is an impressive two metres. Their unwitting victims include climbers, many of whom claim its the most disgusting thing theyve ever smelled. For those of you who have ever taken it a little too far on a heavy night out, this curious habit gives a new meaning to the term tactical chunder, doesnt it?
                 </p>
                 <h2>
                  THE HAGFISH
                 </h2>
                 <p>
                  <img border="0" src="/sites/default/files/2013-1/Disgusting%204%20Africas-most-disgusting-hagfish_0.jpg"/>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  The eel-like hagfish is almost blind, toothless and spends most of its time moving slowly along the ocean floor. If youre thinking, thats not disgusting, thats just an old timer waist-deep in water at the beach, then get a load of this: the hagfish is also one of the slimiest creatures in the world.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  They produce up to eight litres of mucus in one go by firing protein pellets out of their glands. These swell as they come into contact with water to form an impenetrable slime barrier around their bodies. Hagfish produce a goop so thick it can suffocate predators that come too close and even hungry birds find this fish too slimy to swallow. Its a defence tactic that has allowed the hagfish to survive for more than 300 million years, making it one of the oldest species on the planet.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  To avoid the same vile fate, the hagfish slips off its slimy coat by passing a knot down its body. If thats not enough of a bowl full of gross, hagfish have been known to feed on dead and still-living fish by entering any orifice and feasting on the animal from the inside out.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  With no sight, no teeth, a gratuitously gooey body, an affliction for dead flesh and creepy way of getting it, the hagfish has to be one of the most disgusting creatures on the planet.
                 </p>
                 <h2>
                  THE HIPPOPOTAMUS
                 </h2>
                 <p>
                  <img border="0" height="385" src="/sites/default/files/2013-1/Disgusting%205%20Africas-most-disgusting-hippo_0.jpg" width="578"/>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Whether you take your bath with bubbles, aromatic oils or a little toy boat, youll agree that the purpose is to come out smelling fresh. The hippo didnt get the memo on this one.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  These water dwellers have an affinity for emerging from their mud baths only to fling a mixture of urine and faeces at one another. With a quick swirl of their tail, male hippos will launch a disgusting cocktail of excrement in every direction, not dissimilar to a Catherine wheel. While this behaviour may seem disgusting and juvenile it is, in fact, a very effective method of marking territory as well as a neat party trick to impress the ladies.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  But thats not all: when hippos are out of the water they sometimes appear to be covered in what looks like a thin film of blood, a little like Freddy Kruger. However, this mechanism is an incredibly useful one that acts as a sunblock as well as an antibiotic. The pigment inhibits the growth of bacteria, which protects against infections from terrible cuts and wounds they incur during fierce territorial battles.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  When you consider the amount of time they spend in the sun and sometimes less-than-pure river water, suddenly a natural antibiotic and sunblock comes across as a very useful thing to have, even if it does look a little like they sweat blood.
                 </p>
                 <h2>
                  THE AFRICAN WILD DOG
                 </h2>
                 <p>
                  <img border="0" src="/sites/default/files/2013-1/Disgusting%206%20Africas-most-disgusting-wild-dog_0.jpg"/>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Times are tough and were all scrimping and saving as best we can, but even our best efforts to curb our wastefulness seem paltry in comparison to the African wild dogs prudent, definitely disgusting, habit. While its common for many animals to regurgitate food to feed their young until theyre able to hunt for themselves, the wild dog takes this concept to a whole new level.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  They regurgitate food not only for their biological pups, but also for every other member of the pack, from other mothers children to adult companions (particularly those which are sick or injured) who feel like a bit of silver service. Related or unrelated, it doesnt matter, this second-hand dinner dance is a feast for all, with the same bit of delicious steak often going around more than once. This regurgitative behaviour is most commonly seen during the denning season when pups and their adult babysitters stay close to home and therefore need to be fed by some other means than hunting.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  In their defence, field studies have shown wild dogs are highly intelligent and social animals and, like most predators, they play an important role in eliminating sick and weak animals, thereby helping to maintain a natural balance. While theyre not the most amicable dinner guest, the waste-not-want-not eating habits of these colourful, bushy-tailed hunters is in the interest of the pack and the survival of a species thats very much endangered.
                 </p>
                 <h2>
                  THE HAIRY FROG (ALSO KNOWN AS THE HORROR FROG)
                 </h2>
                 <p>
                  <img border="0" height="363" src="/sites/default/files/2013-1/Disgusting%207%20Africas-most-disgusting-hairy-frog_0.jpg" width="578"/>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  The hairy frog, also known as the horror frog, is a real-life version of the X-Men comic-book hero Wolverine, minus the charm. With tufts of hair growing in places only your doctor would know about and claws that pierce through its skin, this Central African species of frog earns its place on the gross list with its strange self-flagellating defence mechanism and even stranger breeding habit.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  When attacked, the hairy frog produces a set of claws by breaking the bones at the tips of its toes and contracting a muscle attached to those bones, thrusting them out through its flesh. What you have left is a highly intimidating, not to mention stomach-curling set of claws. When they breed, male frogs grow long strands of skin and arteries that resemble hair. Researchers believe this might bring in more oxygen.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Whatever the reason, the combination of claws and hair make this aptly named amphibian an abhorrence that does as bad a job at keeping its skeleton inside its body as it does looking good for the ladies.
                 </p>
                 <h2>
                  AND THEN THERE IS YOU
                 </h2>
                 <p>
                  While poking a bit of fun at the weird antics in the animal kingdom is a lot less harmless (to both parties) than poking them with a stick, its interesting to note that all of the habits above ultimately achieve a goal, whether its for survival or preservation. Despite the poo-flinging, rotten-leftover eating and spine-curling vomit, the seemingly disgusting habits of our animal counterparts all serve a vital purpose.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  However, when it comes to humans the same thing cant be said. Those dishes youve left in the kitchen sink for days, that little fart you cupcaked into a fist and quietly lifted up to your nose and the chocolate wrapper you nonchalantly tossed on the pavement dont contribute anything to the preservation or evolution of our species  in fact, its often counter-intuitive.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  For a species that seems to have foregone evolution in favour of social definition, in the eyes of the animal kingdom our habits must come across as even grosser, weirder and ultimately pointless. I imagine them standing around in their herds, groups and troops wondering how exactly humans ever came so far as a species.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Source:
                  <a href="http://magazine.getaway.co.za/featured-articles/disgusting-animals-africa/" target="_blank">
                   Getaway Magazine
                  </a>
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <div class="author">
                <a href="http://www.getaway.co.za" target="_blank">

                </a>
                <h2>
                 Getaway
                </h2>

one of the most interesting trips of my life&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Cycle the Karoo - one of the most interesting trips of my life  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Cycle the Karoo - one of the most interesting trips of my life\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Cycle%20Karoo.jpg?itok=YACs3MDd\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycle-karoo-one-most-interesting-trips-my-life\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycle-karoo-one-most-interesting-trips-my-life\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycle-karoo-one-most-interesting-trips-my-life&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20Cycle%20Karoo.jpg&amp;description=Cycle the Karoo - one of the most interesting trips of my life\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycle-karoo-one-most-interesting-trips-my-life\" data-text=\"Cycle the Karoo - one of the most interesting trips of my life\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycle-karoo-one-most-interesting-trips-my-life\" data-title=\"Cycle the Karoo - one of the most interesting trips of my life\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jul 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Elizabeth Schaerer from Gaborone, pics Dave Marsh&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It was at a 60th birthday party that the concept of a cycle tour through the Karoo was first bandied about. It sounded like a great idea; after all, our thoughts of the Karoo were of wide open spaces and flat terrain, perfect for cycling, and it was something new for a group of us who were trying to prove that age doesn\u2019t stand in the way of a challenge. So 8 of us made a vague agreement to this plan and proceeded to get on with our everyday lives, lives that did not include cycling!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cycle%20Karoo%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Learning to ride again.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It was only when we needed to make a commitment to David Southey of Great Karoo Cycling that the memory of an energetic holiday idea resurfaced. It still didn\u2019t prompt any major moves towards real training. We were woken up from our complacency a couple of weeks prior to departure when the final itinerary was sent to us. Suddenly the reality loomed that we had to ride about 200 kilometres over four days. Our organiser desperately asked if gel seats would help a bunch of amateur cyclists accomplish this. The answer was a very firm message from David Southey that we must not think of this as a \u201cSunday afternoon tea party\u201d. Wow, that certainly got the nervous energy flowing! The average age of our group was 57. Only the youngster of 41 owned a bicycle, the rest of us hired them through a rental company in the Karoo.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We scrambled off to buy the gel seat covers and proper cycling attire. Some of us spent a bit of time on exercise bikes or riding around the block. Real fear reigned the night before departure, especially amongst the four ladies. Would our bums be too sore to attempt the second day? Could we keep up with the others? Would the non-cycling years result in undignified falls?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cycle%20Karoo%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;There are six different routes. Colesberg is the start of the Gariep trail.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Colesberg was the starting point for what was to become one of the most interesting trips of my life, full of awesome surprises. We were warmly welcomed at the Lighthouse where our enthusiastic hostess distributed the hired bikes and suggested riding up and down the main street as a warm-up. No one fell off so we decided we were ready and spent the rest of the afternoon doing a walking tour of the very interesting old town. This generated a healthy hunger, satisfied by a lavish Karoo-style dinner which include new delicacies such a sheeps' tails.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On Day 1 our introduction to the \u201cTour de Karoo\u201d was \u201cHeartbreak Hill\u201d. It didn\u2019t take long to discover that the Karoo is NOT flat. We\u2019d barely got onto the dirt road outside Colesburg when we had our baptism of fire! Obviously the compensation of going uphill is the relieving downhill on the other side, but sometimes the \u201ctop\u201d is an illusion and there are several climbs before you reach the easier bits.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cycle%20Karoo%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Only two cars were seen on the first day once we left Colesburg.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It was at this point that we started appreciating having signed up. There\u2019s just the sweeping landscape of the Karoo, flawless blue skies and no cell phone signal, so we could simply enjoy the nothingness. Yes, there are the occasional homesteads with their broad stoeps and of course you see the famous Karoo sheep. Then you might get lucky, as did one of our group, in racing a duiker which overtook him as he reached 37 kilometres per hour.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Day one\u2019s cycling ended in a brunch where we were to stay at Karoo Nights Country Lodge. One of the things we learnt quickly is that the \u201cKaroovians\u201d aim to fill you up. The snacks along the way, I thought was the brunch. Diets were soon forgotten. Main meals on the tour usually included succulent Karoo lamb, vegetables, yes fresh ones locally grown, followed by scrumptious puddings. And the homemade rusks are irresistible. All \u201ceaters\u201d are catered for whether gluten intolerant or \u201cBanting\u201d. Any weight that we hoped to lose cycling, was soon put on with all the amazing meals. Our hostess at Karoo Nights, Marine, is a cooking enthusiast and in true Karoo-style hospitality, gave us a goat\u2019s cheese making demonstration the afternoon we were there.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cycle%20Karoo%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Stories about actor Patrick Mynhardt of Herman Charles Bosman fame.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Something I learned about the Karoo \u2013 it\u2019s full of history. The people are the friendliest, most hospitable you could wish to meet and go back generations. They\u2019re proud of their heritage and full of good stories to tell. Homes we visited are full of relics, like a bible we saw dating back to the 1700s and a massive twenty-seater dining room table. The gardens are lovingly cared for and equally full of charm. Among the rolling plains are reminders of the Anglo Boer War Concentration Camps and there are monuments to Boer heroes, but then you\u2019ll also find a 1950s Chev in the veld, now used as a shelter for lambs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Day two of our \u201ctour\u201d saw us tackling a more technical section for cycling. What this meant was some stoney and rocky roads and a few more rutted sections on jeep trails. These are, however, navigable and it\u2019s no disgrace to walk the extra steep parts. In any case there are plenty of stops and sustenance plus the reassurance of a back up vehicle.This was a day we had some bike troubles \u2013 brakes sticking, a pedal falling off, stiff gears etc. We had a spare bike and managed to overcome the problems, but it was a lesson that you cannot fully enjoy a cycling trip if your equipment isn\u2019t functioning properly.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cycle%20Karoo%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Some interesting vintage cars now used for shade for lambing.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bethulie, location of our third and fourth nights looks to consist of unassuming houses typical of a Free State dorpie, but we were told some were the homes of famous missionaries, actors, and ghosts. Our host and owner of the fascinating Royal Hotel, is a marvellous raconteur and tour guide. His tour of the town ended with a piano recital by an internationally recognised concert pianist! Another stunning surprise.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On days 3 and 4 we cycled through the Oviston Game Reserve then the Gariep Game Reserve, becoming part of a unique vista. The plains around the Gariep Dam are simply teeming with game. There are great herds of a variety of antelope, wildebeest and zebra, often thundering along at great pace. Move over Serengeti! The spectacle of these species in such numbers and cycling along behind the clouds of dust left by the hammering hooves, made us feel absolutely part of the landscape.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It was a real pity to leave these special areas and head back out onto the tar. Our compensation was a ride over the impressive Gariep Dam wall and a stay at Waschbank, a beautiful retreat on the banks of the Orange River.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cycle%20Karoo%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;A private recital by concert pianist Benjamin Fourie was one of many highlights in Bethulie.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our final day of cycling once again involved a variety of terrains, from rather steep tarred sections to negotiating very rocky inclines. By now, we were so blas\u00e9 about our cycling skills that the challenges were something of a pleasure. The end of the trip saw us wend our way around the local Bethulie Dam before finally enjoying a well-deserved bottle of celebratory champagne.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Yes, we had cycled 185 kilometres through the Northern Cape, the Eastern Cape and the Free State. And yes, it\u2019s perfectly possible for a group of multi-generational amateur cyclists to accomplish this feat. We had all come through the trip exhilarated and unscathed.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Notes about cycles and cycling:&lt;\/strong&gt; 1) David Southey has bought new bikes to remedy the unreliability problem of hired bikes. 2) From experience, a gel seat cover gives cyclists improved comfort. 3) Rusty cyclists will enjoy the trip more if they prepare by getting a bit cycling fit as well as getting some practice handling a real bike if they usually train on an exercise bike.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cycle%20Karoo%208.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Farmer Jacques van Rensburg and his wife Suzette invited us into their fascinating home filled with the unexpected.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: First published on &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.tourismupdate.co.za\/Home\/Detail?articleId=49931\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;SA Tourism Update&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-10102\" class=\"publisher-1335 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/east-coast-odyssey\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;East Coast Odyssey&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    East Coast Odyssey  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"East Coast Odyssey\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #222222' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/cl.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/East%20Coast%20Odyssey%201.jpg?itok=W0J-BP9J\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/east-coast-odyssey\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/east-coast-odyssey\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/east-coast-odyssey&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/East%20Coast%20Odyssey%201.jpg&amp;description=East Coast Odyssey\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/east-coast-odyssey\" data-text=\"East Coast Odyssey\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/east-coast-odyssey\" data-title=\"East Coast Odyssey\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jul 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words and pics &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.keri-harvey.com\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Keri Harvey&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Captain Abdul Shakuru has saltwater in his veins and a depth finder deep in his brain. He\u2019s been sailing this stretch of the East African coastline for more than 20 years, most recently as the captain on bespoke dhow safaris from Ibo Island. Life for him has always been about tides.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Before becoming dhow captain, he skippered boats carrying sea cucumbers to Tanzania and electronic equipment back to Mozambique. He says an old man taught him to sail when he was a youngster, and now he feels more comfortable on the ocean than on land.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=\"float-left\" src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/East%20Coast%20Odyssey.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"270\" height=\"338\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Waiter Jordan Jamali serves us a full English breakfast on the beach at Matemo, before we head out in the direction of Mogundula Island.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We\u2019re just an hour into our three-day dhow safari from Ibo to Matemo, Mogundula and Medjumbe islands in the Quirimbas archipelago in far northern Mozambique.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The tiny islands of the archipelago \u2013 there are 32 in all \u2013 have skirts of bright turquoise Indian Ocean. The sea here is tepid and twinkling, home to magnificent, tropical marine life, including dolphins and turtles that are protected by law.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The massive cotton sail has been hoisted by the nimble crew of six, and the dhow cuts through the water in silence, but for the whish-whish of sea lapping at the sides of the boat. The capable crew of vice-captains Challi and Amissi, assistant manager of Ibo Island Lodge, Harris, along with helpers Richard, Jordan and Anli, is reclining on the deck. Life jackets are threaded on a pole in the centre of the deck and rustle softly as the dhow tilts gently in the water.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Crafted in Kenya by master-dhow builders in the traditional East African style, the 14-metre dhow is made entirely of wood and is sturdy and stable, carrying cargo of up to 20 tons. Everything you can imagine for comfort is on board \u2013 all the supplies for the trip, a fridge, stove, water, diesel and petrol for Zazu the tender boat trailing behind us \u2013 and solar panels to power the lights and electrics on board.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Perched on a high stool with one hand on the wheel, Captain Shakuru has a mischievous face and a distant look as he scans the ocean. \u201cWe\u2019re about halfway to Matemo,\u201d he says staring straight ahead, \u201cwe\u2019ll be there for sunset. The tide will be low and it will be beautiful.\u201d For the next hour we are gently rocked and lulled. The dhow creaks as we tilt and the captain smiles and reads our minds. \u201cNo, it\u2019s in perfect condition. It has to move a little.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A big boat that\u2019s rigid is not good.\u201d It seems that just a minute later the crew is dropping sail and rolling it up on a horizontal mast. Captain Shakuru edges the dhow closer to Matemo Island. The dhow needs just three metres of water and he\u2019s getting as close as he can to land.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He switches on his depth finder to double check himself. We\u2019re at three metres exactly, but he knew that all along and simply wanted to reassure us.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Into Zazu we step, carrying just our day bag and camera, and putt our way slowly to shore. The tide is low and it soon becomes too shallow even for Zazu, so we walk the last stretch through warm water. Matemo is a big island with working villages. In the old days it was a stop over for slave trading in East Africa, but now life is serene and lived according to the tides. Locals are fishermen and palm farmers; tomorrow we\u2019ll venture to the village and meet them.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/East%20Coast%20Odyssey%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;A fishing dhow from the deck of ours, with Ibo Island in the background.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the dhow safari guests do nothing but enjoy themselves. So we watch the natural theatre of sunset and light a fire of palm fronds on the talcum powder beach that is sprinkled with delicate white pansy shells. In the background, tents are pitched and dinner is prepared without fuss. It\u2019s seafood, Mozambique style \u2013 fresh, fire-fried and finger-licking.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Fishermen are up early next morning and we meet them returning to sell their catch. Some spearfish using ingeniously handcrafted masks, and snorkels of inner tubing and plastic piping. When we arrive in the coral rag village of neat huts in the sand, the day\u2019s catch is already available for sale from twig racks under the palm trees. Trade is swift and prices always fair.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For us the day will be spent sailing to Mogundula Island, stopping en route to snorkel from the dhow. Marine life in the Quirimbas is vibrant and typically tropical. As we bale off the back of the anchored dhow, we\u2019re greeted by rainbows of marine life just below the surface. A mask and snorkel is enough to be transported into a world of wild colour and curious creatures. It\u2019s playland down there.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Mogundula is unusual. It\u2019s an elevated island with the welcome mat of a sandspit at low tide. At high tide, waves meet each other head on exactly where we\u2019d strolled on dry sand just hours before. After a short climb past a little beach strewn with starfish, bamboo-lined paths edged with giant conch shells welcome us as we reach the highest point. Our views are forever, and tucking in to fresh seafood, under a sky of a million stars, is what awaits.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For the past two days we have been sailing between the mainland of Mozambique and the islands, roughly 5km from shore. Sailing is easy in these calm waters, with land in sight. Today Inshallah \u2013 \u2018God willing\u2019 in Arabic \u2013 will head out into open sea en route to the remote and tiny Medjumbe Island. It\u2019s a swathe of white sand 800m by 350m and marked on the tip by a derelict lighthouse. And with it comes a barefoot luxury lodge experience hard to match \u2013 and the ultimate way to finish up an East African sailing odyssey.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Anantara Medjumbe Island Resort &amp; Spa has a lodge with a handful of idyllic beach villas that offer a luxurious Robinson Crusoe existence, living by the tides, swimming and snorkelling in the warm ocean \u2013 or dipping in your private plunge pool with sea views. We plan to swing in the deck hammock, secluded and cocooned with a good book \u2013 between enjoying fresh seafood prepared by superchef Lino. But first we have a day of sailing to do.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In open ocean, the dhow tilts a little more and we lie back against giant cushions and enjoy the ride. \u201cI can hold my breath for a minute,\u201d says Captain Shakuru breaking the silence. \u201cUnderwater.\u201d And then he tells us of his spearfishing escapades with giant kingfish. \u201cI have a wife and seven children at home,\u201d he says with a smile, \u201cand they like eating fish.\u201d As he says this we cast our eyes seawards and a cloud of newborn flying fish break the ocean\u2019s surface like a shower of crystals \u2013 and drop back into the water. We\u2019re still open-mouthed when the captain points in the opposite direction and says,\u201cSuki. Look.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Swimming alongside the dhow are dolphins, or suki in local lingo, seemingly escorting us to Medjumbe. \u201cThey\u2019re late,\u201d says Shakuru, smiling. \u201cThey almost missed us.\u201d But they didn\u2019t. Playfully the dolphins circle the boat as we drop anchor off Medjumbe and wait for high tide and to jump ship to the idyllic tropical island, that\u2019s a mere punctuation mark of sand in the Indian Ocean.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s here, in remote and scattered islands, that the soul of the Indian Ocean lives. Far from mainland madness and close to the tides. Listening for news carried along on the trade winds.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za\/subscribe\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Country Life&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/CL%20Cover_8.jpg?itok=mzneeGTq\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Country Life&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9988\" class=\"publisher-2376 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/spectacular-lake-kivu\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Spectacular Lake Kivu&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Spectacular Lake Kivu  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Spectacular Lake Kivu\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/wheels-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Kivu%201.jpg?itok=X6cDeneE\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/spectacular-lake-kivu\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/spectacular-lake-kivu\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/spectacular-lake-kivu&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Kivu%201.jpg&amp;description=Spectacular Lake Kivu\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/spectacular-lake-kivu\" data-text=\"Spectacular Lake Kivu\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/spectacular-lake-kivu\" data-title=\"Spectacular Lake Kivu\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jul 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Andrea Dijkstra, pics Jeroen van Loon&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The banks on the Rwandan side of Lake Kivu are marked by picturesque villages and dozens of wooden fishing boats in spectacular bays, but the views over the lake and the lush green mountains on the Congolese side are even more breathtaking. Andrea Dijkstra and Jeroen van Loon drove around the immense lake \u2013 and entered the war zone.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Smooth tarmac roads are appearing all over mountainous Rwanda. Though this development is very positive, we were more interested in the Congo Nile Trail \u2013 a dirt road (in Rwanda) along the eastern shore of Lake Kivu that has recently been marked by the Rwandan government.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The route\u2019s name is derived from \u201cthe real source of the Nile\u201d, located in the nearby Nyungwe Forest, and the trip takes two to three days. A map can be downloaded using the link at the end of this article. You will definitely need it, as it isn\u2019t always available at the tourist office in Musanze.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Just outside of the beach town Gisenyi, on the northernmost tip of Lake Kivu, we turned onto a dirt road marked by a big signboard saying \u201cCongo Nile Trail\u201d. This is where we left modern Rwanda behind.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Small children dressed in rags ran behind our car, laughing and screaming. Women carrying large bunches of branches on their heads stared at us. For hours we hardly encountered any other vehicles.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We crossed a patchwork of gently sloping farmlands with corn, cassava, sugar cane, coffee and banana palms. In a more forested area, we encountered a spectacular waterfall right beside the road, allowing us to take amazing pictures.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our Land Rover suddenly felt quite big in the very narrow main street of the dusty village of Nkora, passing only inches away from a hairdressing salon, a brick mosque and a crowded market place. The people seemed to like our car. They were clearly not used to seeing tourists, and enjoyed the interest we showed in their way of life.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kivu%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The \u201cNile Trail\u201d signboards had been placed all along the route, except for the places where we really needed them. And asking locals for directions didn\u2019t help much. Apparently the government had not informed the local population about this scenic route, and we were invariably directed towards the tar highway dozens of miles away.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thankfully the campsites, or so-called \u201cbase camps\u201d, have been marked properly. Rwanda is too densely populated for bush camping, so we decided to stay in a \u201cbase camp\u201d halfway up the route. Unfortunately, the camp was nothing more than a messy lawn next to a coffee plantation. The young \u201ccamp manager\u201d told us that camping on the lawn cost US$10 a night, and showed us the toilet and shower facility. It had not been cleaned in years. Because it was getting dark we decided to stay, but refused to pay until the toilet had been cleaned. When the camp manager said we now had to pay $20 as he needed to pay a woman to clean the toilet, we laughed and asked him why he couldn't do it himself. The manager just stood there, unable to respond.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next morning, we drove through a green valley where men, women and children were cutting grass with small scythes. With the increasing altitude the landscape became drier, the road dustier and the number of begging children greater.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Coffee plantations gave way to a plush carpet of tea fields, but soon the dirt road widened and the presence of Chinese road workers indicated that this stretch would undoubtedly be tarred soon. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;That evening we camped for $10 again, but this time in the gardens of the Tshana Beach Motel, with stunning views over Lake Kivu.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;What we had feared became a reality the next day. The dirt track turned into a smooth tarmac road. Still, we recommend the Congo Nile Trail, especially the northern part, starting at Gisenyi. This is a beautiful, unspoiled part of Rwanda.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Vacation time was over for us and since we were taking on several assignments in eastern Congo it was time to enter the country at Bukavu \u2013 as soon as we could resolve a \u201csmall\u201d problem. Our Congolese translator told us at the last minute that we absolutely had to have a valid international driver\u2019s licence, otherwise corrupt police would keep demanding bribes from us. We both had international licences, but they had expired and since nobody ever asked for them, we hadn\u2019t thought of renewing them. Because we could only get new licences in the Netherlands, we were very worried. How could we obtain driving licences in a small border town in Africa?&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kivu%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After staring at the beige documents for a while, we hit on an idea. Why not just forge them? Who would know? After some creative \u201cscrap-booking\u201d, we were ready to go.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Once at the border, we met Honeur, a friendly Congolese man whose sister turned out to be an immigration officer working at the border post. We had heard stories about corrupt Congolese border officials, so meeting Honeur was a blessing. His sister stamped our passports, and after paying just $30 for a car permit and road tax, we entered the Democratic Republic of Congo. The crossing had taken only ten minutes, and turned out to be the easiest of our trip!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bukavu is a beautiful African city. Because the border town is spread across several rolling peninsulas, at every corner you have a different view over Lake Kivu. And thanks to its high altitude (1500m), it has a more pleasant climate than the rest of the country.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bukavu was apparently a favourite holiday destination for Belgian colonists. Their influence is still visible in the architecture. In contrast to other African cities, many of the colonial buildings haven\u2019t been replaced by shopping malls \u2013 yet.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bukavu has a big Catholic cathedral, and in one of the lakeside bays we discovered an old dock that had been built in 1941 and is still in use today.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We filled most of our time in Bukavu by hopping from one ministry to the other to collect dozens of stamps and signatures we needed to visit a \u201cconflict free\u201d tin mine backed by the Dutch government. After three days we had all the paperwork we needed and, accompanied by a translator, resumed our journey on a rocky dirt road, heading for Goma. The locals, walking along the road, were clearly amazed at the spectacle of two whites and a Congolese travelling in a Land Rover with Dutch number plates. Although this is the only road between Bukavu and Goma, hardly anybody uses it because it is in such bad condition. And, of course, there is the very real risk of rebel attacks.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kivu%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As we passed a heavily armed convoy of UN soldiers, we started to feel a bit nervous.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the same time, we were overawed by the beautiful landscape. Although eastern Congo has been trapped in violence for more than two decades, costing the lives of millions of people and infamous for the combatants' terrible reputation for rape, it looks like paradise on earth.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the hamlet of Kalehe we collected more stamps and signatures. When we returned to our car, we found that our right rear tyre was flat, having probably been sliced by the sharp rocks on the road. Thankfully we had two spares and quickly changed the wheel in front of a curious Congolese crowd.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We finally reached the mining town of Nyabibwe after two more hours of driving. After a final round of collecting stamps and signatures, we were allowed to descend into the 100m-deep mine pit. Wearing rain boots, we walked through the flooded tunnels, anxiously watching the electrical wires hanging in the water.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Miners were using steel hammers and pins to remove rocks, while sweat ran down their mud-smeared faces. Although a noisy compressor was blowing oxygen into the tunnel, it was quite stifling in there. Working in that environment must be difficult.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Heading back to Bukavu, we suddenly heard a loud hissing sound. Yet another puncture! We quickly put a jack under the car as an amused crowd gathered.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the moment that Jeroen began to crawl under the car to boost up the jack, the vehicle fell from it, nearly crushing him. To our dismay, the crowd howled with laughter. Fortunately Jeroen wasn\u2019t hurt, but were not impressed by the actions of the crowd. It took more than an hour to change the wheel in the difficult circumstances, using our hi-lift jack.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We continued on our way, now driving without any additional spare tyres. Every sharp rock was now a dangerous obstacle. When we finally reached the tar after two hours, we breathed a sigh of relief. It was now dark and our translator mumbled, \u201cIf you run into anyone, continue to drive as fast as possible, otherwise people will lynch us.\u201d Fortunately we made it to Bukavu without facing such a dire situation!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The following week we again took the harsh dirt road, but this time all the way to Goma, hundreds of kilometres away. We camped about halfway there at a missionary compound run by nuns at Minova.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kivu%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next morning, soldiers stopped us at a checkpoint. With arrogant smiles and raised eyebrows, they walked around the car and told us that they wanted to check it. We handed over our fake international driving licence. It was carefully studied, but ultimately accepted.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Unfortunately, though, the recently issued car permit had already expired. Customs officials at the border hadn\u2019t told us that it would only be valid for two weeks. (In most countries such a permit is valid for a month.)&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The soldiers triumphantly told us that our only option was to go all the way back to Bukavu as we could not pay a fine in Minova. After we had haggled and pleaded for ten minutes, the commander said he would let us go for $50, though the permit would have cost only $15. We eventually settled on a \u201cfine\u201d of $25.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As soon as we were back on the road, we added a few days to the date on the permit, so we wouldn\u2019t have to pay any more fines. We were quickly becoming master forgers!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In Goma, we stayed with a rich Congolese family who owned two large passenger boats on Lake Kivu. They suggested we take a ride in their speedboat. Slightly astonished, we took our seats in their white, luxurious boat.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A short while later, our mouths dropped open when we docked at a festival where a band was playing live music to which hundreds of young people were dancing. We definitely hadn\u2019t expected this in Goma. It was still a war zone, after all.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But fighting between the rebels and the army flared up again a few days later, just 14km from the city. We wanted to write a story about the new UN intervention force, so we decided to go to the front. Ideally, we would have gone with the UN forces but they had been brushing us off for more than a week, so we decided to make a go of it on our own.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kivu%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With mixed feelings, we stuck A4 pages with the word \"PRESS\" on all sides of our car. Just outside the city we passed many army tanks, and our translator instructed us to stop close to one group of Congolese soldiers. He went over to talk to them.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cFollow that motorbike,\u201d he shouted as he jumped back into the car, pointing at a soldier on a rickety bike. Following him, we went through countless deserted streets with empty, bullet-scarred houses.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In a more forested area, we suddenly came across dozens of soldiers, resting. We got quite a fright, but they were very friendly. All they wanted was to have their pictures taken with the Land Rover.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Suddenly there were deafening explosions. We dropped to the ground, but the soldiers just laughed.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThese are our shots, not theirs,\u201d said a commander named Moses, pointing to some trees a few hundred metres away. There were more soldiers, firing grenades at the rebels, who were apparently close by.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As Commander Moses was telling us that the UN often assisted the Congolese Army, two white helicopters showed up and, to our astonishment, started firing at the ground.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cDon\u2019t worry, they are bombing the militants, not us,\u201d laughed Moses.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We were hardly reassured. How stupid had we been, travelling to the front line in our own 4x4?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When the commander asked if we would like to join some soldiers who were about to carry out an attack, we quickly shook our heads.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A few days later, we had to leave Congo because our visas were expiring. (No thoughts about forging this time!)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We drank a beer in the Rwandan border town of Gisenyi, celebrating our successful four weeks in the Congo. Unfortunately, the eastern Congo just isn\u2019t a suitable tourist destination at the moment. This is a real shame, because at a peaceful time it really would be heaven on earth.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Link to the map of the Congo Nile Trail&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"https:\/\/responsiblenomad.files.wordpress.com\/2013\/08\/img_7354.jpg\"&gt;https:\/\/responsiblenomad.files.wordpress.com\/2013\/08\/img_7354.jpg&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kivu%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"463\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/travel-stories\/spectacular-lake-kivu\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Leisure Wheels&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/1505_LW.jpg?itok=v72PMdgI\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Leisure wheels&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-10262\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/three-wheels-my-wagon\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Three Wheels On My Wagon&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Three Wheels On My Wagon  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Three Wheels On My Wagon\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/1.%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg?itok=hemaknCa\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/three-wheels-my-wagon\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/three-wheels-my-wagon\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/three-wheels-my-wagon&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/1.%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg&amp;description=Three Wheels On My Wagon\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/three-wheels-my-wagon\" data-text=\"Three Wheels On My Wagon\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/three-wheels-my-wagon\" data-title=\"Three Wheels On My Wagon\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Matthew Holt, Pics Matthew Holt, Mandy Ramsden&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Passing villagers paused to inspect the brightly-painted auto-rickshaw, with amusement verging on incredulity. With no oncoming traffic, potholes or cows in the road, it wasn\u2019t immediately obvious how the vehicle came to be down in the ditch, suspended in a bush. As the responsible driver, I duly shrugged and smiled, though I was quite anxious how we were going to reach Kanyakumari.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For the discerning traveller, each place has its quintessential mode of travel. In California, it\u2019s a convertible, in Venice a gondola, in the Caribbean a yacht and in India an auto-rickshaw. Known elsewhere as a \u2018tuk-tuk\u2019 or \u2018moto-taxi\u2019, this two-stroke, three-wheeler is the backbone of India\u2019s public transport system.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%202.%20Rickshaw%20and%20sacred%20cow%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Rickshaw and sacred cow.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As I stood contemplating our stricken vehicle and my co-pilot disassociated herself from the embarrassment, a small truck pulled alongside. Gesticulating that I should stay put \u2013 though I had few other options - the driver returned after five minutes with a rope, which he hitched around my vehicle and tied to his tow bar. And when several villagers in flip-flops slithered down into the foliage and started to push, I felt obliged to clamber into the cockpit and steer. With much grunting, revving and tyre spinning, the rickshaw was hauled back onto the road and, after a round of handshakes, we were on our way again.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%203.%20Maps%20were%20of%20limited%20use%20%28MandyRamsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Maps were of limited use.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We were taking part in an auto-rickshaw rally, over nine-days and covering some 1200km, depending how badly you got lost. The starting point was Chennai, formerly Madras, where in 1639 the East India Company set up a small shop that morphed into the British Empire, punkah wallahs, tiffin and G&amp;Ts. The small colonial fort looked lost amidst the congested, chaotic sprawl of India\u2019s fourth largest city, with the only remnant of the Raj being an obsession with cricket.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%204.%20Visiting%20Thanjavur%20temple%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Visiting Thanjavur temple.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The day before the rally started, we attended a practice session on the outskirts of the city. The founder and organiser, of sorts, Aravind Bremanandam, gave us the keys to our vehicle plus some tips on cultural etiquette and survival. My co-pilot, Mandy, was bereft of mechanical and navigational skills, but she did have a penchant for fancy dress and our rickshaw looking resplendent in South African colours. While neglecting to bring a tool kit or GPS, Mandy had remembered makarapas and vuvuzelas.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Handling the rickshaw took some getting used to. Excepting the brake pedal, everything was operated by hand, including the all-important horn and manual windscreen wiper. Nonetheless, after a cursory driving test - which we passed despite stalling - we were declared roadworthy.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%206.%20Rural%20roads%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Rural roads.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next morning, all the teams gathered in the hotel parking lot.&nbsp;While I didn\u2019t spot Lewis Hamilton or Fernando Alonso, there was a German team calling themselves the \u2018Shawmachers\u2019; two Aussie bodybuilders dressed as superheroes and both named Bob; a pair of Scots sporting kilts and hangovers; three European girls in tight-fitting, red overalls branded \u2018Masala\u2019; Santa and his elf; a couple of ducks; and a trio of languidly-spoken English public schoolboys, who were to leave a trail of destruction and hush money. In total, there were 21 teams, each comprising two or three members. One by one, we climbed aboard, yanked our ignition levers, revved our wailing engines and \u2013 accompanied by camera flashes and ironic cheers - kangaroo-hopped down the hotel driveway into the maelstrom of Chennai\u2019s rush hour traffic.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%207.%20The%20scenic%20route%20to%20Tuticorin%20%28Matthew%20Holt%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;The scenic route to Tuticorin.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The first hour was, quite frankly, traumatic. The triple carriageways carried at least eight lanes of traffic, plus occasional vehicles coming the wrong way, pedestrians, goats and cows. Meanwhile, the only law of the road was Darwinian, with articulated trucks as the apex predators, travelling flat out, horns blaring, forcing everyone else into the gutter. Cyclists and pedestrians were supposedly beneath us in the hierarchy, but we\u2019d been warned to avoid any collisions since, as \u2018&lt;em&gt;feringhis&lt;\/em&gt;\u2019 we\u2019d be to blame. It was a fraught hour before we escaped the city and found the more sedate coastal road towards Puducherry.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%208a.%20On%20the%20main%20road%20to%20Manapad%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;On the main road to Manapad.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The rally wasn\u2019t an all-out race as such, with teams required to make each day\u2019s destination before a cut-off time, earning points by visiting obscure landmarks along the way. The daily stages were typically around 150km, which - allowing for a cruising speed of 50kph, fuel stops, breakdowns and navigational blunders \u2013 generally took us six to eight hours. While we weren\u2019t too bothered about winning, the event was an ideal way to explore the birthplace of four major religions, yoga, the Kama Sutra and vindaloo.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%208b.%20Bemused%20cyclist%20in%20Manapad%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Bemused cyclist in Manapad.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Over the next eight days, we travelled south through the heart of Tamil Nadu, past intricate temples, abandoned forts and flooded paddy fields, where women in elegant saris worked up to their ankles in mud. In the former French colony, Puducherry, we boisterously celebrated surviving the first stage; at the next overnight stop, Thanjavur, we crashed into a bollard and knocked over a row of motorbikes like dominoes; and in Madurai, we spent New Year\u2019s Eve visiting the ancient temple.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%209.%20Race%20action%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Race action.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At Thiruchendur, we were blessed by a rheumy-eyed, old elephant, which took our 10 rupee donations in his trunk and passed them to his handler, before deftly patting us on our crowns. In Tuticorin, we stayed down by the harbour, which had an unhealthy fishy pong; in Tirunelveli I spent the night sweating and shivering with fever; and in Kanyakumari, we watched the sun set into the confluence of the Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea and Indian Ocean.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%2011.%20Traffic%20jam%20in%20Tirunelveli%20%28Matthew%20Holt%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Traffic jam in Tirunelveli.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There\u2019s a saying, \u2018If you don\u2019t hate India, you haven\u2019t spent enough time there,\u2019 which eventually might prove true, but our experience was just the opposite. The longer our journey went on, the more we enjoyed it. Initially, we\u2019d been terrified at the prospect of breaking down. After the second day, however, when our rickshaw had stuttered to a halt and we\u2019d been ushered to a back-street garage where they stripped and cleaned our engine, and offered us lunch - all for US$ 4 - we almost looked forward to technical mishaps and the ensuing social interactions.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%2011b.%20As%20ferringhis%2C%20we%20even%20had%20to%20give%20way%20to%20cyclists%20%28Matthew%20Holt%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;As 'feringhis', we even had to give way to cyclists.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Similarly, we got used to being hopelessly lost. With road maps of limited assistance, the only means of navigation was to stop and ask directions from locals, who would invariably smile, say \u2018Yes\u2019 and wobble their heads.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We even became cavalier about regular near-fatal collisions, dismissing them with a sanguine shrug. Four teams rolled their rickshaws during the rally, with the English public schoolboys managing to do so three times, shatter their windscreen twice and collide head-on with a motorcyclist. On reflection, it was a miracle nobody was maimed, or perhaps it was due to visiting all those temples.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%2012.%20Roadside%20repairs%20on%20the%20way%20to%20Kanyakumari%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Roadside repairs on the way to Kanyakumari.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The final stage from Kanyakumari into Kerala took us past green hills, coconut trees, hyacinth lakes and sandy white beaches. Reaching Trivandrum, we pulled up at St Joseph\u2019s Cathedral, where all the teams eventually gathered, save for the English public schoolboys who\u2019d reportedly crashed again. From the cathedral, we\u2019d been requested to proceed in convoy to a hotel just around the corner, where the local media was assembled to record our triumphant arrival. Competitive spirits got the better of us, however, and the procession quickly became a mad-cap race, cutting each other up, squeezing through gaps and jumping traffic lights. We screeched up the hotel drive on two wheels, only to find the press had gone to the wrong venue.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%2013.%20Now%20how%20did%20that%20get%20there%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Now how did that get there?&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Later that afternoon, over a tub of iced beers, Aravind declared the winners to be the three shapely girls from Team Masala, who received a free entry into the next rally. Reluctantly surrendering our keys and bidding farewell, we caught a taxi along the coast to Varkala. As our taxi driver darted between cars and swerved round trucks, we didn\u2019t even flinch. We were veteran Indian road hogs ourselves now. The next few days were spent lounging in cliff top bars, dining on pesto tuna and quaffing mojitos, which was very pleasant, if hardly the real India. You need an auto-rickshaw to experience that.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rickshaw%2014.%20Welcome%20to%20Kerala%20with%20a%20%20speeding%20fine%20%28Mandy%20Ramsden%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Welcome to Kerala with a &nbsp;speeding fine.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-10106\" class=\"publisher-1651 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/robertson-round\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Robertson Round Up&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Robertson Round Up  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/goodtaste.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img
