Round Up\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/robertson-round\" data-text=\"Robertson Round Up\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/robertson-round\" data-title=\"Robertson Round Up\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Karen Rutter, pics Tracey Derrick&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;\u2018The problem with the Robertson Wine Valley is there is just so much to do. One needs to spend quite a few sundowner sessions in the area to get a fair grasp of things\u2019&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cShake. Sniff. Slurp. Swallow.\u201d These are the rules for olive oil tasting. Clive Heymans shows us with such infectious enthusiasm we\u2019re soon slurping away like professionals. Who would have thought a shot glass of oil could be so delicious?&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But then, we\u2019re getting all sorts of surprises on this road trip through the Robertson Wine Valley. &lt;strong&gt;The MARBRIN OLIVE FARM&lt;\/strong&gt; is one of them. Clive\u2019s partner, Briony Coetsee, explains that her dad bought the land in the 1990s and started planting olive trees, much to the scepticism of his grape-growing neighbours. But more than a decade later they have 8 000 trees spread over 25 hectares, and have picked up several awards for their oil. The family-run boutique farm now also holds tastings and tapas sessions, where they explain the olive growing process. \u201cWe use three different cultivars - Frantoio, Coratina and Mission - and two-phase decanter technology. This basically means our oil is extra virgin, and has a unique flavour,\u201d explains Briony. She and Clive pour bowls of the honey-coloured nectar and encourage us to soak up the taste with bread. Later, we sample different tapenades and green fig preserve, and are splashed with a tot of homemade Limoncello to \u201cfreshen the palate\u201d. When we finally leave, we feel we are gliding...&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Robertson%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Marbrin forms part of a horseshoe route known as the &lt;strong&gt;KLAASVOOGDS MEANDER&lt;\/strong&gt;, which leads off the road to Ashton. Here you can find the upmarket &lt;strong&gt;ROSENDAL WINERY AND WELLNESS CENTRE&lt;\/strong&gt;, &lt;strong&gt;KRANSKOP WINES&lt;\/strong&gt; and &lt;strong&gt;MO AND ROSE BISTRO AND GUESTHOUSE&lt;\/strong&gt;. And there are also other gems that add to the surprise factor - such as the 65-year-old &lt;strong&gt;SHEILAM CACTUS AND SUCCULENT GARDEN&lt;\/strong&gt;, boasting around 2 000 species of plants. You can take a stroll through prickly swathes of cacti, succulents and cycads, some with the most beautiful bright flowers and others with evocative names such as \u201cMother in Law\u2019s Chair\u201d and \u201cHorse\u2019s Teeth\u201d. Johanna Geduld, who has worked here for several decades, helps us choose a small selection of baby cacti to buy, while owner Minette Schwegmann tells us international clients are among her biggest customers for seeds. \u201cEspecially the Japanese,\u201d she says. \u201cHowever, we are very careful about what we export and how - the rules are very strict.\u201d Minette, who has a Botany degree, says she often gets emails or calls from people if their succulents are ailing. \u201cI\u2019m like a kind of botanical Agony Aunt,\u201d she laughs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Further up the road, different plants are cultivated for different reasons at &lt;strong&gt;OWL\u2019S REST OLIVE AND LAVENDER FARM&lt;\/strong&gt;. Martha Hattingh holds demonstrations of lavender harvesting and the steam distilling process that produces lavender water and essential oils. She creates a whole range of bubble baths, natural soaps, lip balms and more out of purely natural elements. Martha shows us her simple but effective method of extraction using a home-built distiller that includes a kettle she \u201cborrowed\u201d off her husband Jack\u2019s yacht (they plan to sail to the Caribbean at some point). Martha explains the many advantages of lavender water, ranging from being an anti-bacterial agent to an asthma retardant. \u201cAnd people with birds use it to stimulate feather growth in their parrots and budgies,\u201d Martha smiles. Later, sitting chatting in her heavenly-smelling workshop, she pours us a drink of rose geranium cordial mixed with sparkling water. \u201cCome sundowner time, you can add gin or vodka,\u201d she says with a twinkle in her eye.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Robertson%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The problem with the Robertson Wine Valley is there is just so much to do. One needs to spend quite a few sundowner sessions in the area to get a fair grasp of things. We are lucky enough to spend one evening at the five-star &lt;strong&gt;ROBERTSON SMALL HOTEL&lt;\/strong&gt;. Situated in what was one of the original Robertson houses\u2014complete with wrap-around stoep and beautiful broekie-lace filigrees - the boutique hotel has expanded to include several pool-side rooms, stable rooms and a honeymoon suite. The accommodation is state-of-the-art comfortable, but with only ten rooms in all, there\u2019s a warm, intimate feel. The service is outstanding, and the menu at their on-site &lt;strong&gt;REUBEN\u2019S AT THE ROBERTSON&lt;\/strong&gt; restaurant is stylishly divine. The Ragout of Field Mushrooms with Basil Butter and Onion Soubise is worth driving all the way to Robertson for.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s the little touches and gestures - including homemade chocolate fudge and a specially printed-out Emily Dickinson poem on my pillow when I go to bed - that make the place memorable.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There is plenty of accommodation both in town and on neighbouring farms and estates, which makes an extended exploration of Robertson relatively easy. There are various different routes stretching spider web-like out of the hub of the town itself, leading to Ashton, Montague, Bonnievale, McGregor and the R62 back to Cape Town. On the latter road we are very amused to see a massive red chair perched on the side of the road at &lt;strong&gt;ROOIBERG WINERY&lt;\/strong&gt;. We stop to look, and a sign informs us it is the \u201cbiggest chair in Africa\u201d, which, at nine metres tall, is easy to believe. There\u2019s also a \u201clove wall\u201d where romantic partners are encouraged to affix a padlock and then throw away the key, symbolising their eternal love. PR and Export Manager Marianne Lochner, says people really like having their pictures taken with the chair. \u201cWe have queues when there are special occasions, like during the Wacky Wine Weekend,\u201d she smiles.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We also explore the onsite restaurant and bakery, which is exuding irresistible wafts of all things non-Banting. Marianne says the two young men responsible for the croissants, breads and pastries on display were initially working on the Rooiberg wine farm. They expressed an interest in baking, were trained, and now Neville Olckers and Wilfred Jacobs have a reputation that stretches all along the R62.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Also along the stretch is the eco and art-conscious &lt;strong&gt;GRAHAM BECK WINES&lt;\/strong&gt;; the estate, named Madeba, is known not only for its award-winning ranges but for the conservation work being done on its private nature reserve. These efforts have in turn inspired the Game Reserve Range, seven wines which are individually named after animals which are endemic to the region - with beautifully illustrated labels for each. The Graham Beck tasting room also has to be one of the most visually pleasing venues, not only for its sprawling view of the vineyards and mountains, but for the selection of artworks from Graham Beck\u2019s private collection that grace the space.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you venture down a different strand of the Robertson web, you hit the R317 to Bonnievale. The road winds through a plethora of vineyards and wine farms, making it very difficult to choose a place to stop. There\u2019s &lt;strong&gt;SPRINGFIELD&lt;\/strong&gt; and &lt;strong&gt;CLOVERFIELD&lt;\/strong&gt;, &lt;strong&gt;BON COURAGE&lt;\/strong&gt; and &lt;strong&gt;DE WETSHOF&lt;\/strong&gt;, for tastings. And then there are alternative activities, such as taking a picnic cruise at &lt;strong&gt;VILJOENSDRIFT&lt;\/strong&gt;, where you can stock a basket at their deli and then float down the Breede River while sipping something cool. For the more adventurous, there\u2019s the Fish Eagle Biodiversity Hiking Trail at &lt;strong&gt;VAN LOVEREN&lt;\/strong&gt;. The 7,5km route starts and ends at the cellar, and offers beautiful views as well as educative signposts along the way.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We push on a little further to &lt;strong&gt;WELTEVREDE&lt;\/strong&gt;, a wine farm that has been in the Jonker family for over four generations. Here, PR Manager Elzette Steyn has something special in store\u2014a walk through some of the original underground wine cellars, which cover more than a hectare of ground. She\u2019s lit candles to guide our way through the narrow passageways, some of which are lined with thousands of bottles of sparkling wine, waiting their turn to be declared ready to drink. \u201cThey\u2019re in here for four years,\u201d explains Elzette. She leads us to a small chamber where she and her team usually have group wine tastings. It\u2019s dark, but the candles provide a warm glow and there\u2019s a pleasing, faint, musty smell of old wine. Sometimes couples request the cellar tour, for a special romantic occasion, says Elzette. \u201cBut then I try to hang in the background - it\u2019s embarrassing to get in the way,\u201d she grins.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We wind our way back to the centre of Robertson and find yet another surprise, this time one suggested by the friendly staff at the Robertson Small. We find &lt;strong&gt;ART METAL WORKS&lt;\/strong&gt;, the premises of Pieter Heunis, a steel and metal-worker. He has become somewhat famous in the town\u2014and further afield\u2014because of his sculptures, made out of hundreds of horseshoes. \u201cI used to fix horseshoes for the local farrier, and for some reason I got this idea to try and make a horse,\u201d says genial Pieter, when asked how he started. \u201cThis was about three years ago - I never had any art training, but I always liked drawing, and I like music, so maybe that counts. I did the one horse, and then somebody wanted me to make another, and so it has gone,\u201d he says modestly. Pieter\u2019s sculptures can now be seen as far away as KwaZulu Natal, and he has been featured on the &lt;em&gt;Mooiloop&lt;\/em&gt; TV programme. \u201cBut this one here I won\u2019t sell,\u201d says Pieter, patting the neck of a pretty horseshow horse with a metal flower in her mane. \u201cHer name is Blommetjie, and she\u2019s the legacy I\u2019ll leave for my family,\u201d he explains.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Robertson Wine Valley has so much to offer - from the established beauty of a family wine farm and quirkiness of a cactus garden to the graceful opulence of a five star hotel. Then there are the many things to do, from hiking and canoeing to mountain biking and beyond. And you still have to make time for olive, wine, grappa and cheese tasting. We\u2019ll be back, that\u2019s for sure.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;hr&gt;&lt;h3&gt;Famous for Its Festivals&lt;\/h3&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Robertson Wine Valley has a festival for every season. Make sure to mark down at least one of them on your calendar this year.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Hands on Harvest, 7 Feb - 29 March:&lt;\/strong&gt; Held over the two-month harvest cycle, this festival takes the format of a boutique event that offers wine aficionados and budding vintners a chance to experience the magic of harvest for a day.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Wacky Wine Weekend, 4-7 June:&lt;\/strong&gt; Seen as South Africa\u2019s biggest regional wine festival, it has close to 40 wine farms and boutique producers taking part.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Robertson Slow, 7-10 August:&lt;\/strong&gt; Wineries and guesthouses from Ashton, Bonnievale, McGregor and Robertson welcome visitors into their homes, to their dining tables and onto their farms for a food and wine experience.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Mmm McGregor, 25-27 September:&lt;\/strong&gt; McGregor links its creativity to a celebration of comestibles, in its mmm...McGregor festival of food and drink.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Wine on the River, 16-18 October:&lt;\/strong&gt; Held on the banks of the Breede River, you can taste over 300 wines from 42 wineries. Add to that live music, great food, kids activities, boat trips, tutored tastings, local produce and more.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;hr&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.goodtaste.co.za\/Winelands\/Robertson-Round-Up\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Good Taste&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2038\"&gt;Mo and Rose at Soekershof&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2036\"&gt;Sheilam Cactus Garden&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/7854\"&gt;The Robertson Small Hotel&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2046\"&gt;Viljoensdrift Ferry&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div Seattle\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.travelideas.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #f69220' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/wide-awake-seattle\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/wide-awake-seattle\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a Awake in Seattle\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/wide-awake-seattle\" data-text=\"Wide Awake in Seattle\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/wide-awake-seattle\" data-title=\"Wide Awake in Seattle\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Franki Black&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Seattle is like a friend who is somewhat surprised and completely over the moon when you choose to visit her. She is modest, she oozes quiet confidence and she\u2019s a bit of a hipster. In fact, when you meet her you\u2019ll be tempted to think that she sparked the global hipster movement. She delights you around every corner and soon you discover that she is, after all, your best friend.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This northwestern American city is famously known for its rainy winters. It is far from gloomy, however. The benefits of rain are in fact substantial: it encourages people to turn to creative outlets such as theatre, music, museums and markets. Seattle ticks all of these boxes and, to top it off, it has spectacular forest trails, waterfalls and a vast bay where you can spot passing pods of orcas. If you\u2019re still not convinced, opt to visit in summer when its weather is said to be glorious.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Seattle%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Surprisingly, the city remains relatively undiscovered by tourists. It was only in the 1990s that Seattle\u2019s widespread underground music scene pushed the city into the limelight. The \u201cgrunge\u201d movement, spearheaded by Nirvana and Pearl Jam, took off around the world and it all started here. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I landed at the airport late at night and met my taxi driver. He set the tone, \u201cSeattle is by far the best city in America \u2013 you\u2019re in for a treat.\u201d I was ready to get active.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Evergreen Escapes&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next morning, I joined an orientation tour with Evergreen Escapes, a regional tour company that specialises in adventure tourism for small groups. Our starting point was Pioneer Square, the oldest part of the city. &nbsp;Face-brick buildings were covered in green ivy and streetlamps embellished with wrought-iron twirls. It felt like a time-warp. Shana, our guide, led the way down a flight of stairs. We entered an underground world centered around book stores, artisan workshops and coffee cafes. Large parts of Seattle are apparently built on the remains of an underground city that existed in the mid-1800s.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Seattle%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Above ground, we continued to the Tlingit Indian Totem Pole, a tall wooden shaft that honours Native American culture in Washington State. \u201cThroughout North America, Native American tribes use these totem poles to connect to the spiritual world,\u201d explained Shana, as we looked up at painted faces of carved bears, monkeys and owls.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our next stop was West Seattle, a popular suburb that is home to people like Eddie Vedder - lead singer of Pearl Jam. En-route, Shana pointed out the headquarters of Starbucks and impressive views of the harbour, one of the biggest and deepest ports in the west. Ships, containers and cranes were moving around like worker ants. The driver dropped us at a neighbourhood park for a walk through the forest. It was like something out of a fairy-tale. Giant, furry trees soared above me, dew drops shimmered from flowers and the sound of a woodpecker knocking on wood resonated throughout the forest.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Seattle%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;My morning with Evergreen Escapes came to an end at West Seattle\u2019s promenade with homemade muffins and freshly-brewed coffee. A vast bay, known to be a sailing and kayaking mecca in summer, stretched out in front of us like a sheet of navy-blue ice. I bid Shana and her team farewell and navigated my way to one of Seattle\u2019s most popular attractions for locals and tourists.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Pike Place Market&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Pike Place Market is the thumping heart of Seattle. Locals say that it\u2019s the glue that keeps the city together and if you ever find yourself in Seattle, you will naturally gravitate towards it. This vibrant market is the longest continuously-operated farmer\u2019s market in the USA and it encapsulates Seattle\u2019s enterprising spirit better than any other place. I joined a tour, offered by Savor Seattle, for a taste of the market\u2019s best. All Savor Seattle employees have musical and theatrical backgrounds, and to my delight, our guide Bridget periodically broke into song.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Seattle%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cWho wants to catch a fish?\u201d asked Bridget animatedly. We were standing in front of the Pike Place Fish Company and there were mounds of mussels, clams and silver fish on show. Confident mongers were trying to lure the crowds closer for a taste. A hesitant bride-to-be in our party was pushed forward by her friends to \u201ccatch the fish.\u201d She steadied her feet and waited as a fishmonger threw a large, quivering Alaskan salmon from behind a counter, through metres of air into her hands.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We continued past rows of colourful tulips and vegetable stalls filled with purple artichokes, Fiddle Head Ferns and morel mushrooms. Guitar players, violinists and singers entertained throngs of people pouring into the market. &nbsp;In between all the action, we stopped at different stalls for tastes of clam chowder, dried fish, macaroni and cheese, and doughnuts. The tour ended near the market at a bubblegum-covered wall, known to be one of the world\u2019s most unhygienic tourist attractions!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Seattle%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The EMP Museum&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;In 2000, Paul Allen\u2019s (co-founder of Microsoft) love for rock music led him to open the EMP Museum, a space that focuses on all things pop-culture related. I hopped on a bus and made my way to what has to be one of the most eccentric buildings imaginable. Architect Frank O. Gehry designed the EMP Museum with the intention of portraying the evolving rock \u2018n roll experience. The result is a multifaceted, futuristic building - made largely from aluminum and steel \u2013 that looks more like a silver-and-pink space station than a museum.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the inside, I walked through a series of exhibitions of Kurt Cobain (Nirvana), Jimi Hendrix, and myths and magic. Letters exchanged between Cobain and his bandmates, and Hendrix\u2019s psychedelic outfits were some of the items on show. In the middle of the museum, I watched classic rock performances screened on an IMAX screen. A highlight was the interactive section where visitors can step into technology-driven booths and learn how to play the keys, drums and guitar. For aspiring singers, there is a mini recording studio and a stage, set in front of a pseudo audience.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Seattle%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The Space Needle&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The EMP museum is situated within walking distance from the Pacific Science Centre, a glass sculpture exhibition, a children\u2019s museum and the Space Needle - my next stop. Soaring above the city like a gigantic mushroom, this observation tower is the most prominent feature on Seattle\u2019s skyline. Instead of walking up its 848 steps, I squeezed into an elevator and shot up to an elevation of 184 metres in a matter of seconds. At the top, I looked out over spectacular views of skyscrapers, faraway lakes and the Pacific.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Hidden Treasure&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;A South African architect urged me, before I left for America, to visit the Seattle Central Library. He described it as one of the most revered buildings on earth. &nbsp;With a few hours spare, I plotted the library on a map and made my way there. It proved to be worth every step. Designed by Rem Koolhaas and Joshua Prince-Ramus, its hard-edged exterior is made of glass and steel, whilst its interior is finished in woods and surfaces tinged in reds and butter yellows. Elevators and a four-floor spiral walkway lined with a bookshelf, led me to the 11th floor where generous rays of natural light flooded through large, angular glass panels. People were reading, studying and browsing. &nbsp;It felt more like a home than a public library. A few hours later, when I was sitting on a plane homeward-bound, I realised that Seattle enchanted me until the very end.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Seattle%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Make it Happen!&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Where to Stay:&nbsp;&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The Sheraton Hotel:&lt;\/strong&gt; Situated in the heart of downtown Seattle, the Sheraton Seattle Hotel is a contemporary urban retreat that offers state of the art facilities. Transformed by the expansion of the 25-story Union Street Tower, this stylish hotel is perfect for leisure and business travellers. Discover a vibrant destination with innovative hospitality and warm Seattle personality that will inspire you to play, relax, and connect in the Emerald City. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.sheratonseattle.com\"&gt;www.sheratonseattle.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Getting Around:&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Emerald City Trolley - Hop on\/ Hop Off 1-pass city trolley:&lt;\/strong&gt; This downtown trolley connects you to attractions like the Seattle Centre, Space Needle, Pike Place Market, Pioneer Square, Seattle Waterfront and Argosy Cruises. You can also connect to the Overlook &amp; Locks Trolley that connects you to the Woodland Park Zoo, Ballard Locks and Lake Union. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.emeraldcitytrolley.com\u00a0\"&gt;www.emeraldcitytrolley.com\u00a0&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Getting There:&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Fly South African Airways:&lt;\/strong&gt; SAA operates two daily flights from South Africa to the United States as well as operating the only direct flight from Johannesburg to New York City on the Airbus A340-300.In addition to direct flights to New York, you can get daily SAA flights direct to Washington Dulles Airport from Johannesburg on the Airbus A340-600. This long haul flight has a brief stop in Dakar, Senegal. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.flysaa.com\u00a0\"&gt;www.flysaa.com\u00a0&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Recommended American Airline:&lt;\/strong&gt; United Airlines, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.united.com\"&gt;www.united.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Top Local Event:&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The Seattle True Independent Film Festival (hosted in May):&lt;\/strong&gt; STIFF was started ten years ago and since then it has delighted film enthusiasts with underground films. Over 100 short films are screened during the 8-day festival and attendees can also look forward to an exciting line-up of networking events. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.trueindependent.org\u00a0\"&gt;www.trueindependent.org\u00a0&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Local Tour Operator:&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Evergreen Escapes&lt;\/strong&gt; is the ideal tour operator for adventure lovers. Each tour is led by expert naturalist guides and customised packages are available in and around Portland, Seattle, Northern California and British Columbia. &nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.evergreenescapes.com\"&gt;www.evergreenescapes.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Fast Fact:&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Mexican Wave originated in Seattle.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Tip Box:&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;Visit the Olympic Sculpture Park situated along Seattle seafront. &nbsp;Here you can see cutting-edge outdoor art.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.travelideas.co.za\/subscribe.php\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Travel Ideas&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.travelideas.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/TI%20cover.png?itok=RlqWM3pw\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Travel Ideas&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9946\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/it%E2%80%99s-boy-fat-and-free-not-so-empty-quarter\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;It\u2019s a Boy! Fat and free in the not so Empty Quarter&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    It\u2019s a Boy! Fat and free in the not so Empty Quarter  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"It\u2019s a Boy! Fat and free in the not so Empty Quarter\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Empty%20Quarter.jpg?itok=Oq1JEvKZ\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/it\u2019s-boy-fat-and-free-not-so-empty-quarter\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/it\u2019s-boy-fat-and-free-not-so-empty-quarter\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/it\u2019s-boy-fat-and-free-not-so-empty-quarter&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20Empty%20Quarter.jpg&amp;description=It\u2019s a Boy! Fat and free in the not so Empty Quarter\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/it\u2019s-boy-fat-and-free-not-so-empty-quarter\" data-text=\"It\u2019s a Boy! Fat and free in the not so Empty Quarter\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/it\u2019s-boy-fat-and-free-not-so-empty-quarter\" data-title=\"It\u2019s a Boy! Fat and free in the not so Empty Quarter\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Alex Harris&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In February of 2013 I led a small team across the Empty Quarter. Our goal was to be the first to walk cross this stretch of sand unsupported and unassisted. It was a suffer fest from first to last. Weeks were spent trapped in a prison of self-deprecation and dwindling food. Somewhere, in the midst of that misery a rather pleasant thought took root. To return, and do it all on a Fatbike.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I suppose I fell in love with the sand. Truth is, having spent 40 days walking across it, I knew it well. And so, almost a year later, in the company of two other adventure-hungry riders, I set off from the edge of the Arabian Sea.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From Salalah in Southern Oman, I thought 12 days would be enough time to cycle 1200km north across the desert to Dubai. In retrospect, this was unrealistic. Nic Jordan, Justin Mcleod and I were riding: Humood from Oman, and Dino De Angelis from our South African office provided vehicle support. Dino was the general dog\u2019s body and scapegoat if things went pear-shaped.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Day 1 saw us climb up into the Dhofar Mountains and eventually reach Wadi Arun. It was a good introduction to Fatbikes as the first 50km were tar. How these bikes with wider wheels were going to work was still a question. But for now we were content to put some miles between the ocean and us. Early into Day 2 we turned onto a remote military track where we had our first encounter with the Oman army. They were intrigued with our bikes but happy to let us go on, as long as we turned right at the fork. Left would take us towards the very remote Yemen border and potential trouble. We had no problem turning right.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Once on the other side of the Dhofar Mountains, we were technically on the edge of the Empty Quarter. We were now in an area called the Nedj. Miles and miles of open gravel plains led to the sands proper. Progress was fast during these first few days with the vehicles occasionally getting lost. They were not always able to go where the bikes went and would sometimes take a detour that would leave us thirsty and hungry for hours. By day 6, however, things were more complex. The previous day we had entered an area of closely linked dunes and soft sand, dotted with countless saltbushes. In fact, the previous year when we walked through the area we dubbed it Wurglewood, home to the notorious Wurgle monster. The soft sand and constant punctures were almost our downfall and we struggled at a snail\u2019s pace for four days before we were at last free.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This time I headed further north from the small village of Mughshin before turning north west, hoping to avoid most of the mayhem. Now, once again, Wurglewood was casting its disastrous spell. We had cycled about 50km that day before we got the call that both our Landcruisers were stuck in soft sand. Fortunately, we had ridden past a Polish seismic survey camp and they rescued our support crew. The night was spent in the company of the Poles swopping whisky and war stories.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We set off the next morning feeling a little under the weather but mindful that we needed to somehow make up time. We followed a track towards the Saudi border and into the heart of nowhere proper. It was a glorious day even if the wind continued to pound our resolve. We were now in big dune country and around us the majestic red sands soared and swayed as far as the eye could see. We were buoyed by the fact the Fatbikes were working better than we could ever have hoped. Whether it was the small dunes of Wurglewood or the endless soft sand plains between the bigger dunes, there was not much we were unable to ride. But it was grueling stuff.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;And then came Day 8: one of those bittersweet days - sweet, in the sense that the dunes were now a glorious red, but bitter as it would be our last day in them. We were now basically following military tracks close to the Saudi border, and half the time rode on them and half the time off. Why you might ask? Well the tracks were mostly hard, bumpy gravel, and while the going was faster, it was hard on the legs and rump! The gravel plains between the dunes always offered a softer passage, but inevitability at the cost of speed or energy. And so we mixed it up, constantly trying to find the best line.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Just before lunch I decided to ride about 100m off the track and visit one of our campsites from the previous year. It brought back deep memories of that special but desperate time. However, what totally stumped me was the complete lack of any evidence that we had ever been there. Not a sign, not a print in the sand, nothing. It was like we were never there.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Shortly after we stopped at an army base to refuel, we were picked up by the army again and ordered to accept an armed escort for about 120km. It turned out that just the previous week ago the Oman army had caught a group of smugglers trying to sneak across the Saudi border, right here in this very remote part of Oman. As a consequence, they worried for our safety and felt personally responsible for us. No amount of explaining that we were trying to be the first people to ride the entire way across the desert would dissuade them. We were left with few options. It was now almost 6pm and time to call it a day. They said we were quite welcome to ride on through the night with the escort to a base about 160km away. Or we could jump into their jeeps. We simply could not camp where we were. We had already ridden 115km, in about 10 hours, our biggest day yet. To ride on for another 160km was simply not tenable. And so, resigning ourselves to whatever fate lay ahead, we sadly climbed in.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Two hours later we were dropped in the middle of nowhere. We made a call to drive on to the town of Ibri, spend the night there and then decide in the morning as to what we should do. The next day dawned with dissention in our ranks. Nic was keen to bail and felt that if we could not achieve the world first and ride all the way, there was no point continuing. Justin was in the middle. I was adamant we should press on.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After much debate it was decided that we would return to a point roughly where the army had said it would be safe for us to continue, and carry on from there. Of course this meant a late start, but we pressed on into what had now become a pounding wind. That day sand got into every exposed part of our body. We rode 70km before finally crawling into camp for some sandy but delicious chicken. It was a tough day for all, both physically but also emotionally. It\u2019s hard enough to psyche yourself up for something grueling if there is the promise of glory at the end. But it\u2019s even harder when all that waits is a step into obscurity.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Preparing for our longest day yet, we rose early and in the faint light pedalled off into a surprisingly cold morning. Dino and Humood had to drive back to Muscat and drop off one of the vehicles while we cycled 140km to the border. Here we would change over into another vehicle and meet Mahmood on the UAE side. We knew it was going to be a long and complicated day as we left Oman and entered the United Arab Emirates. The first 60km was the now familiar desperate, rutted and bumpy gravel road that took us past a Petroleum plant. Stopping for some water we were pleasantly surprised to be welcomed in and given a buffet lunch! This seemed to galvanize Nic and Justin. W pedalled off with renewed vigour. Finally, just as the sun was setting we arrived at the Oman\/U.A.E border and begun the formalities of crossing over.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Once on the other side it was dark. It had been a long day for everyone and no one was too keen to camp. Dino mentioned there was a Hilton in Al Ain, a town about 20kms away. And so, with a frenzy not unlike a swarm of hornets, we pedalled like mad to this newfound oasis. All told that day we rode for 13 hours and 160km. A record we were not about to break any time soon.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Hilton served as an elixir of sorts and as we rolled out of town the next morning everyone was chirpy. A tar road added to the enthusiasm. I had a most unusual but very pleasant surprise sneak up on me out of the blue. Nadia, my wife, had been toying with the idea of finding out the gender of our unborn child. She was seven months pregnant. It was going to be a surprise but the last month or so she had been contemplating giving in. I got an sms the night before to such effect, but I thought it was the usual banter and so said, as I had before, \u2018just go find out\u2019. I didn\u2019t think more of it. Now, two hours into Day 11, my phone suddenly beeped. When I casually turned it on, I read \u201cIt\u2019s a boy!\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I was stumped. Shocked almost but I let out a yelp and with teary eyes shouted out the news to Justin and Nic who were a short way up the road. Buoyed along by the news, we upped the pace until, finally, late that day, we had to cross a few kilometres of short sand dunes. It was arguably the most fun yet with the Fatbikes making short work of the ups and downs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Just 50km from Dubai we settled on an area that was suitable for our final night camping out in the sands. As Dino and I went about making a fire, Mahmood was called out time and again on rescue missions to pull stranded expats from Dubai out of the sand. It was the weekend and many had made their way out into the nearby desert with \u2018normal\u2019 cars. Mahmood told us the next morning that he rescued the same group of German girls three times the previous night! Hmmm\u2026&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A thick, damp mist lay low over the sand as we made our way onto a tar road and off towards the mayhem that is Dubai. Two hours later we faced what would be unquestionably the most dangerous part of the expedition, crossing Dubai\u2019s nine-lane highways. Mahmood followed close behind to try and give us some relative safety but it was still a nightmare. Luxury vehicles sped past at 150km\/hr, completely oblivious to our presence and totally indifferent to our plight. Finally, at around 11am we rolled into the reception of the Park Hyatt on the old Dubai creek and completed our crossing. All told it was an epic journey of 1130km and 12 days. Unfortunately though, we missed those crucial 120km that would have allowed us to claim a world first.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As Thesiger said, the sand makes its way into a man\u2019s bones. And while it is true that in our case it made its way into absolutely everything, not just our bones it did so in a lasting and powerful way. The sand of Arabia is a lonely and forgotten sand; humble and quietly spoken that whispers of an age past when people lived with nothing more than each other and their dreams and aspirations. Sadly, it also speaks of a time past. We were privileged, just for a while, to be part of this very special place. I have no doubt that our tracks are no more, gone with the wind and covered by the inexorable flow of the sand. What is left in us is lasting. Something to take back to the hectic hustle and bustle of a known world, and remind us that even as strangers in an unknown world, it is possible to come alive!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.xplorethisworld.com\"&gt;www.xplorethisworld.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Empty%20Quarter%2011.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9935\" class=\"publisher-1338 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/paula-radcliffe-running-sensation\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Paula Radcliffe - A Running Sensation&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Paula Radcliffe - A Running Sensation  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Paula Radcliffe - A Running Sensation\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #d22127' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/din.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Paula%20Radcliffe.jpg?itok=EUNwgm89\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/paula-radcliffe-running-sensation\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/paula-radcliffe-running-sensation\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/paula-radcliffe-running-sensation&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20Paula%20Radcliffe.jpg&amp;description=Paula Radcliffe - A Running Sensation\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/paula-radcliffe-running-sensation\" data-text=\"Paula Radcliffe - A Running Sensation\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/paula-radcliffe-running-sensation\" data-title=\"Paula Radcliffe - A Running Sensation\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Elana Meyer, pics Shutterstock&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are many gifted athletes with loads of talent all over the world. Of those talented athletes you will see some that come and go, and then you get those who stick around to become the sporting icons who shift beliefs of what is possible.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For decades, the belief was that women were not physically strong enough to race over distances longer than 800 m. However, history was to change, albeit very slowly, at the 1972 Olympics, when the 1,500m was added for the first time. It took another 12 years to add the 10,000m and marathon for women. And then Paula Radcliffe came along and redefined what women are capable of when she ran the marathon in a time of 2 hours 15 minutes and 25 seconds, setting the current women's &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/List_of_world_records_in_athletics\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;world record&lt;\/a&gt;.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the age of 41 and after a 25-year long-distance running career, Paula Radcliffe ran her farewell race at this year\u2019s London Marathon.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;So what did Paula, undoubtedly the greatest female marathon runner ever, do to take her from good to great?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Paula had talent and did really well as a junior, however she was often beaten by athletes with an explosive kick over the last 400m. Then in 1998, Paula started working with Irish physical therapist Gerard Hartmann, who played a major role in turning her into the running machine she was.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Paula%20Radcliffe%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Paula Radcliffe breaking record at Great North Run, 2003. Photo credit: Wikimedia Commons&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But it was not just her talent and therapist that saw Paula dominate the ladies in marathons, her incredible work ethic, commitment and professionalism took her to a whole new level. The saying, \u201cTalent will only take you so far in your journey to excellence, but hard work will separate you,\u201d was never truer than for Paula.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Testament to this is what was said by Hartman, who has worked with many Olympics champions over the years, \u201cI\u2019ve seen plenty of athletes with much more talent than Paula Radcliffe. The uniqueness of Paula is that her success defies the talent. She had respectable cross-country talent, but she wasn\u2019t your thoroughbred athlete. She needed to train at 110 percent as opposed to 90. She had to run 150 miles a week, but it wasn\u2019t the mileage, it was the intensity and the pain she endured. Her talent, if she didn\u2019t train hard, would have got her to 31:50 or 32:00 for 10K; to run 30-flat, 2:15 [marathon], took extraordinary will power, extraordinary mind set, extraordinary preparation, an excellent support structure, to be fastidious about every aspect of her nutrition, working with a dietitian, a homeopath, an exercise physiologist, physical therapist, osteopath, and collaborating all of that with her husband, Gary, and her coach.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Although Paula is the holder of the ladies marathon world record, her true legacy is that she\u2019s proof that athletes can break records by abiding by the rules. Furthermore, she is also a great example that it can take years to develop into a champion.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are so many talented athletes (and parents) out there who can learn from Paula. Ultimately though, it is not about the talent spotted at a tender age, but rather the long-term commitment, exceptional inner drive and ability to overcome setbacks.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I salute Paula Radcliffe on a phenomenal career that we can all aspire to.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Paula%20Radcliffe%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Paula Radcliffe, winner of the 2007 New York City Marathon, photographed at Mile 14. by Ed Costello from Brooklyn, NY, US&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;More about Paula Radcliffe&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;Paula Jane Radcliffe, born 17 December 1973, is an English &lt;a href=\"&lt;http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Long-distance_runner&gt;\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;long-distance runner&lt;\/a&gt;. &lt;br&gt;\u2022 She is a three-time winner of the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/London_Marathon\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;London Marathon&lt;\/a&gt; (2002, 2003, 2005), three-time &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/New_York_Marathon\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;New York Marathon&lt;\/a&gt; champion (2004, 2007, 2008), and won the 2002 &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Chicago_Marathon\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Chicago Marathon&lt;\/a&gt;. &lt;br&gt;\u2022 Radcliffe is a former world champion in the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Marathon\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;marathon&lt;\/a&gt;, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Half_marathon\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;half marathon&lt;\/a&gt; and &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Cross_country_running\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;cross country&lt;\/a&gt;. &lt;br&gt;\u2022 She has also been European champion over &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/10,000_metres\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;10,000 metres&lt;\/a&gt; and in cross country. &lt;br&gt;\u2022 On the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Track_running\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;track&lt;\/a&gt;, Radcliffe won the 10,000 metres silver medal at the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/1999_World_Championships_in_Athletics\" target=\"_self\"&gt;1999 World Championships&lt;\/a&gt; and was the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Athletics_at_the_2002_Commonwealth_Games\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;2002 Commonwealth&lt;\/a&gt; champion at &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/5000_metres\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;5000 metres&lt;\/a&gt;. &lt;br&gt;\u2022 She represented &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Great_Britain_at_the_Olympics\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Great Britain at the Olympics&lt;\/a&gt; four times consecutively (1996 to 2008), but did not win a medal on the Olympic stage. &lt;br&gt;\u2022 Radcliffe is an asthma sufferer who has campaigned against the use of&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Drugs_in_sport\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;drugs in sport&lt;\/a&gt;. &lt;br&gt;\u2022 Her running has earned her a number of accolades, including the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;BBC Sports Personality of the Year&lt;\/a&gt;, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Laureus_Awards\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Laureus World Comeback of the Year&lt;\/a&gt;, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/IAAF_World_Athlete_of_the_Year\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;IAAF World Athlete of the Year&lt;\/a&gt;, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/AIMS_World_Athlete_of_the_Year\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;AIMS World Athlete of the Year&lt;\/a&gt; (three times) and a &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Member_of_the_Order_of_the_British_Empire\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Member of the Order of the British Empire (MBE)&lt;\/a&gt;. She has also been nominated for World Sportswoman of the year on several occasions. In 2010, she was inducted into the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/England_Athletics_Hall_of_Fame\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;England Athletics Hall of Fame&lt;\/a&gt;. &lt;br&gt;\u2022 She ended her competitive running career at the 2015 London Marathon. &lt;br&gt;\u2022 She is married to her coach, Gary Lough, and has two children.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source material: Wikipedia&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Paula%20Radcliffe%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"866\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Paula Radcliffe Airborne @ Mile 14. Photo credit: Wikimedia Commons&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/content\/paula-radcliffe-running-sensation\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;DO IT NOW&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/cover39_2_1_0.jpg?itok=NWStvgW8\" \/&gt;\n &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9934\" class=\"publisher-1813 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/thaba-trails\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Thaba Trails&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Thaba Trails  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Thaba Trails\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.ride.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #E31933' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/ride-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Thaba.jpg?itok=wxr5D4iP\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/thaba-trails\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/thaba-trails\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/thaba-trails&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20Thaba.jpg&amp;description=Thaba Trails\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/thaba-trails\" data-text=\"Thaba Trails\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/thaba-trails\" data-title=\"Thaba Trails\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Andrew Steer, Ride magazine&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thaba Trails in the south of Johannesburg was started in September 2011 when the passion of trail builder Wendell Bole outgrew the offerings for trail-building available at his first love child, the Rietvlei Cycle Park. Andrew \u201cAverage Andy\u201d Steer didn\u2019t need an excuse to revisit them in the new year\u2026&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Just around the corner in the Klipriviersberg Nature Reserve, Wendell secured a 10-year lease to build his own trails on 450 hectares of pretty, pristine, privately-owned bushveld. Thaba Trails was born, and over the years \u2013 largely through Wendell\u2019s endless passion \u2013 it has built up a bit of a cult following while serving as host to numerous XCO races, 12 and 24hrs, the Thaba Toughee and even the odd Enduro and Downhill race. In need of shedding some Christmas excess, I headed out towards Alberton to sample this playground once again.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Thaba%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The riding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thaba has rightfully built up a reputation as having some of the toughest trails around, but if you bite off the right bits and build up your strength and skills appropriately on each visit, it will take your cycling and enjoyment thereof to new levels. There is something for everyone: An entry level 6km Yellow route, the more challenging 17km Green route with its guaranteed game sightings &nbsp;(its shortened 10km route is also a popular option for the not too fit) and the master track that is the 30km Blue route, a challenge for riders of pretty much any level. You can take on this challenge in smaller bits, though, as many of the technical sections are loops that branch off the main track.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Yellow Route&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Aimed very much at beginners, the 6km yellow route is a very simple undulating route suitable for riders of any fitness or skill level. Although a good chunk of it is still singletrack, it\u2019s very easy and smooth riding and a great little route for kids and newbies alike. The fun switchbacks through the forest at the finish will put a smile on most people\u2019s dial.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Green Route \u2013 10 &amp; 17km&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For most riders, this is their bread and butter at Thaba. The main 17km loop is made up mainly of singletrack and is a relatively challenging, but highly enjoyable loop around much of the park. The main thing with Thaba on a whole, is that it\u2019s just never really flat, you are either going up, or coming down one of the many koppies that litter the area. The green route for the large part sticks to the friendlier gradients, but there are still some little challenges (and some not so little ones \u2013 Wendell\u2019s Way!) that will nudge you out of your comfort zone.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The toughest sections are avoidable towards the western side of the park and there is also a shorter 10km route on to which riders with leg and lung failure can cut short their ride if required. The 17km route as a whole is great fun, with a bit of everything in terms of riding challenges, while the game viewing is always a special bonus.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Blue Route&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The blue route, at 30km in length, is a tough challenge for pretty much any cyclist. After doing a few of the little loops off the main path, it\u2019s obvious to see why this is such a popular training ground for the more serious XC racers. When I say tough, though, it\u2019s not as technically challenging as one might think, the biggest challenge is without doubt the gradients. Your heart rate is likely to be up near max most of the time and your legs will be screaming as you scramble for gears yet again. Yes, the course builder is a track cyclist of some serious pedigree.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s singletrack 90% of the time, and while the full 30km isn\u2019t achievable by all cyclists in one bite (this one in particular), it\u2019s great to push yourself by adding extra sections each time you ride the park, or even just alternating the challenges you take in from week to week. Another serious plus is that the Blue route, in Wendell\u2019s own words, is never finished. He upgrades, adds and removes sections all the time to ensure the best possible experience for the riders.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Most of the little loops, varying in length from 600m to 2km (read the signs) (Prince, Lawrence, Yafta, Kudu, Mzuzu, etc) are made up of steep descents followed by equally steep climbs. Some of the rocky descents have been brilliantly crafted and as much as I suffered on some of the climbs (even walked), it was seldom not worth it!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The climb up Wendell\u2019s Way (also part of the green route, although I am sure it gets skipped by most) is a real long slog, but the fast descent to the fun fire station section, makes it all worthwhile. And if the suffering ever gets too much for you and you\u2019re feeling a little sorry for yourself, just remember: Wendell rides this route daily\u2026 and um, he\u2019s well into his 60's!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Thaba%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Overall Experience&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thaba has a huge amount to offer, the passion of the owner and his trail builders can be seen throughout the 30km of pristine, hand-built, largely singletrack trail that they have prepped and fine-tuned into one of South Africa\u2019s finest and toughest offerings. The terrain has a great mix of everything, the bushveld is beautiful and it\u2019s often hard to believe you are still in the city \u2013 and game sightings, well, it\u2019s not bad to see wildebeest, impala, zebra, blesbok and even a springbok on your morning ride. Not to mention the littering of porcupine quills you will be dodging along with the centipedes out on the track. The neat shop for coffee afterwards is most welcome and if you\u2019re looking for a bite, the Two Trees Bakery (in the same brickyard) is a great spot to refuel while the kiddies enjoy the great play facilities.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Cycling hours&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Open seven days a week, the trails are open from 6.30am to 5pm&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Weather&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Most of the trails hold up pretty well to the rain, but after typical Johannesburg thunder storms, you can expect some mud out on the course which can make some of the blue sections, in particular, extra challenging. Apart from that, sunscreen is a must during the warmer months as you will get pretty exposed out there.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Rates&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;R35 per rider, per visit. Just sign in at the small shop\/kiosk and you will be issued with a number board.&lt;br&gt;Annual passes available.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Thaba%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Get There&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;101 Klip River Drive&lt;br&gt;Mulbarton&nbsp;(entrance via the Southern Brickyard)&lt;br&gt;GPS: S 26\u00b0 18' 02.5\" \/ E 28\u00b0 02' 56.3\" \/&nbsp;26.301206S, 28.048804E&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Directions&nbsp;to Thaba Trails:&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Directions from Johannesburg:&lt;\/strong&gt; From the CBD, take the M1 south-bound. Just after Gold reef City, take the Xavier street offramp. Head south down Xavier until you hit the N12. Head east and at the next offramp, Kliprivier, take the exit and head south. Travel south down Kliprivier road until you see the entrance to Thaba Trails and the brickyard on your right (you will have a shopping centre on your left).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Directions from Roodepoort:&lt;\/strong&gt; Take the N1 south and take the east split at the N12. Go past Southgate until you reach Kliprivier offramp. Travel south down Kliprivier road until you see the entrance to Thaba Trails and the brickyard on your right (you will have a shopping centre on your left).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;&lt;span style=\"font-size: 1.143em; font-weight: inherit; color: #656565; line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Contacts&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Thaba Trails&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;Email: &lt;a href=\"mailto:bole@icon.co.za\"&gt;bole@icon.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;Phone: 011 867 8047&lt;br&gt;Web: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/thabatrails.webs.com\"&gt;http:\/\/thabatrails.webs.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;Facebook: Thaba Trails&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Other Attractions&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Trail running&lt;br&gt;Downhill&lt;br&gt;Enduro&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Facilities&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Basic bike shop\/kiosk (full bike shop at Rietvlei)&lt;br&gt;Ablutions&lt;br&gt;Showers&lt;br&gt;Bike wash&lt;br&gt;Coffee, juice and snacks&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Accommodation&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Thaba Eco Hotel&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;Impala Road&lt;br&gt;Klipriviersberg Nature L\u00fcderitz\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\"         &lt;a
