L\u00fcderitz\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/ludicrous-l\u00fcderitz\" data-text=\"Ludicrous L\u00fcderitz\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/ludicrous-l\u00fcderitz\" data-title=\"Ludicrous L\u00fcderitz\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Andrew Brukman&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I think now would be a good time to come out the closet. You see, we all enjoy cross-dressing and somewhere stuffed in the back of the Landy, tucked in-between my rusty trumpet and Zanne\u2019s drying panties, is a bag we bought especially for dressing up\u2026 for practical reasons of course. Among the various thrilling outfits are a tutu, silver sequin dress and a full on transgender gorilla suit (gender bending depending on whether a male or female is wearing it). And for extra &lt;em&gt;pizzazz&lt;\/em&gt;, and security, we had two wigs, dubbed Auburn and Shaniqua, which, when positioned on the seat headrests whenever we weren\u2019t in the car, looked like seated occupants. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Luderitz%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"323\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We had just crossed over the border into Namibia at Onseepkans and decided to follow the Orange River as far west as we could go. It\u2019s an amazing route that follows the river\u2019s rocky flow. Occasional green patches of cultivated land characterise much of the immediate riverbank. I remember looking out away from the river at the harsh baked earth and feeling comforted; that no matter what we had water. This appreciation for water, we later realized, would take on an almost religious awareness.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Noordoewer was the first town on the road. Paul decided to give Auburn a go. Much to the amazement of the locals, he donned the wig while we stocked up our bar\/pantry with the essentials.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Luderitz%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The river eventually carries on to the west coast while the road turns up north toward Aus, running parallel to Sperrgebiet, a barren old mining area, meaning \u201cRestricted Area\u201d in German. As we turned northwards the landscape opened up and we were surrounded by vastness. That evening we pulled off the side of the road just before Aus and, still without a proper tent, managed to construct a pitch tent on the side of our Landy. The wind picked up as we huddled inside, covering holes where the howling wind sang through and giggling at the awesomeness of nature all through the night.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next morning we woke up psyched from the wildness of the previous night. We decided that we would walk, so set off into the desert. After an hour we identified a random mountain far in the distance. Walking towards it was freedom at its best; nothing but sand around us for miles.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Luderitz%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The perpetual motion of our feet reminded me of the opening paragraph of a National Geographic article by Paul Salopek, who embarked on a seven-year global trek. He writes:&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;Walking is falling forward.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;Each step we take is an arrested plunge, a collapse averted, a disaster braked. In this way, to walk becomes an act of faith. We perform it daily: a two-beat miracle\u2014an iambic teetering, a holding on and letting go. For the next seven years I will plummet across the world.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The hike took us the whole day and we came back heavy-footed, ready to head to the coast at L\u00fcderitz.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Luderitz%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;L\u00fcderitz &lt;em&gt;is&lt;\/em&gt; beautiful, but you really have to squeeze your eyes and look hard to realize it. Approaching the town from a distance, with the sun setting in the horizon, is amazing. The old German Lutheran church, the town\u2019s famous landmark, peaks out of the rolling hills in a series of salty silhouettes. The town itself is a pastiche of German architectural prowess and grey-cemented Namibian modernism. &nbsp;On the slopes, the buildings seem to hang on to each other in a bric-a-brac manner, almost like a seaside &lt;em&gt;flavela&lt;\/em&gt;, just less crowded. It has a certain lure to it; maybe it\u2019s because of the history of the port town (Bartholomew Diaz stumbled upon the bay in 1487) or the fact that it is a largely isolated town on an extremely inhospitable coastline.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Luderitz%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our fiendish thirst for alcohol kicked in when darkness fell and the full moon rose. We headed to a local tavern called Gold Coin Hotel \u2013 actually a dingy motel with slot machines, pool table and soccer on a TV. As the evening progressed to the rhythm of the slot machines \u2013 &lt;em&gt;ching ching, doo doo dooop ching ching ching&lt;\/em&gt; - we met a fleet of people including a group of &lt;em&gt;buchtermeisies&lt;\/em&gt;, \u2018&lt;em&gt;buchter&lt;\/em&gt;\u2019 being a colloquial term for bay and \u2018&lt;em&gt;meisies&lt;\/em&gt;' Afrikaans for girls. They had attitude: the girl gang out on the town that evening. With Ice, a Herero from northern Namibia who was working as a charter pilot in L\u00fcderitz, we watched soccer and talked about the difference between north and south Namibians.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Luderitz%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Eventually the night crawlers came out and we sparked up a conversation with two Romanian sailors who had sheepishly emerged from \u201cout back\u201d of the motel. They were great and, through broken English and interpretive hand-dance conversation, we became friends. They invited us back to their ship that evening (which we declined) and the following day (which we gladly accepted).&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Exploring L\u00fcderitz\u2019 coast was also interesting. There are many coves, locally called fjords, which are scattered around the peninsula and a cool beach called Agate ten minutes north of town.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Luderitz%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Get it on a hot day and the sun will warm you up as you lie on the agate-speckled sand. The water is refreshing, but close your eyes, squeeze hard and you\u2019re in Mauritius!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The last night was spent having sundowners on Seal Island, which offers a view back onto the harbour and town. We squatted next to the lighthouse at the top, sleeping under the stars with a machete under the pillow for security. I\u2019ve experienced a few breathtaking sunsets and still evenings, but this was something special; all through the night a warm breeze blew on to the lighthouse while we looked onto a beautifully lit harbour. A hum emanated from the gigantic ships docked at bay. From our epic vantage point, snuggled up in our sleeping bags we felt like we were on the craziest, wildest coast on Africa.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Luderitz%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9932\" class=\"publisher-2809 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/riebeek-valley-talking-about-revolution\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Riebeek Valley - Talking About a Revolution&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Riebeek Valley - Talking About a Revolution  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Riebeek Valley - Talking About a Revolution\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.hsm.co.za\/magazines\/details\/cape-etc' target='_blank' style='background-color: #ffffff' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/capeetclogo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Riebeek.jpg?itok=RunrK5GP\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riebeek-valley-talking-about-revolution\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riebeek-valley-talking-about-revolution\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riebeek-valley-talking-about-revolution&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20Riebeek.jpg&amp;description=Riebeek Valley - Talking About a Revolution\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riebeek-valley-talking-about-revolution\" data-text=\"Riebeek Valley - Talking About a Revolution\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riebeek-valley-talking-about-revolution\" data-title=\"Riebeek Valley - Talking About a Revolution\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Jade Cooke, pics &lt;a href=\"hsmimages.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Kendall-Leigh Nash&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another fertile valley full of wine, olives and history? Well, yes. But the Riebeek Valley is so much more than the sum of its cookie-cutter parts, home to maverick winemakers, a thriving restaurant scene and yes, an olive or two&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On a 35\u00baC day in Riebeek-Kasteel, the only correct thing to do at the stroke of five o\u2019clock is to answer the siren call of a gin and tonic at The Royal Hotel.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It may be politically incorrect to say it, but I\u2019ve never felt so colonial as I do at this moment, stretched out in a wicker chair on this historical terrace, which the hotel proudly (and somewhat comically) claims to be the longest stoep south of the Limpopo. Potted palms wave in an occasional and treasured breeze, while overhead what are possibly the world\u2019s most ineffectual fans rotate lazily as though they, too, have had enough of the afternoon\u2019s heat. It all feels very Old Cataract Hotel circa &lt;em&gt;Death on the Nile&lt;\/em&gt; \u2013 which is just lovely an hour outside of Cape Town and in 2015.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riebeek%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;And so it should have a sense of history, the last structural change to the hotel having been the addition of its arched terrace in 1927. But even this grande dame is but a debutante compared to Riebeek-Kasteel itself, which numbers among South Africa\u2019s oldest towns. Named, of course, for Commander Van Riebeeck, upon whose instruction a hinterland expedition that led to its settlement was conducted, Riebeek-Kasteel today provides an excellent base from which to make your own discovery of the surrounding Riebeek Valley.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Known for its wine and olives, the valley has a wonderful ability to make you feel far from the madding crowd while still being less than 90 minutes from the Mother City\u2019s various amusements and beaches. It\u2019s hemmed in by the Kasteelberg, Porseleinberg and Paardeberg mountains, and there\u2019s a rural, bucolic feeling to the landscape thanks largely to the wheatfields stretching from horizon to horizon as you approach from Malmesbury, golden in summer and a rich green come Cape Town\u2019s wet winter.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riebeek%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Riebeek-Kasteel is perhaps the best known of the valley\u2019s three little villages, its sisters being Riebeek West, a stone\u2019s throw of but five kilometres away, and tiny, elevated Hermon.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A wander around the three or so blocks that comprise its central business district doesn\u2019t take too long, but there\u2019s plenty to carry back home with you. While away some time with a tasting at The Wine Kollective, a homage to local winemakers with cellar-door prices. If garagiste olive oil hasn\u2019t featured in your life up until now, don\u2019t miss The Olive Boutique either, where a selection from this valley\u2019s other notable industry is available for tasting. Poke around the rest of the doorways and you\u2019ll find everything from fine art and vintage treasures to biltong, handmade chocolate, natural soap, homeopathic remedies and clothing a friend who lives in the village has aptly termed \u2018Swartland tannie chic\u2019.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riebeek%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The market square is mostly used for parking day to day, but stop to snap a picture of the solemn red ox erected in 1938 to commemorate The Great Trek, and a VOC (Dutch East India Company) cannon as a tribute to Riebeek-Kasteel\u2019s founding fathers. You\u2019ll also find a large topiary elephant here, though its presence appears to be more whimsical than historical. For a more detailed record of the town\u2019s Voortrekker past, head to De Oude Kerk, a beautiful church completed in 1856 that now houses the Valley Museum.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Riebeek-Kasteel may have all the hallmarks of a small, South African town, but the pervading spirit is far from small-town South African mentality. Beneath the heat, beneath the quaint charm, beneath the fiercely preserved history, there is the tremor of a beat from a drum that\u2019s anything but ordinary.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For a start, there\u2019s Kobus, or at least I\u2019m assuming that\u2019s the name of the man often spotted zooting around town in a golf cart with a licence plate bearing that legend. There\u2019s little to no chance that plate comes from a municipality office, but we\u2019ll let it slide, Kobie.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riebeek%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Then there\u2019s the secret garden, hidden just behind the Kasteelberg Country Inn &amp; Bistro on the square. An insider tells me to stop by that evening to hear a travelling musician who\u2019s just arrived in Riebeek-Kasteel on his bicycle to treat us to a guitar serenade.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Can we talk about Riebeek-Kasteel\u2019s cuisine for a second too? The catch-all \u2018traditional country fare\u2019 hardly does it justice. Bar Bar Black Sheep in Short Street still has Capetonians trotting up for lunch to enjoy the likes of kudu carpaccio, viskoekies, goat stew in Jamaican curry and pork loin in a thyme and rum gravy.Next door, Eve\u2019s Eatery and Bar offers rustic Italian dishes, while for pizza you\u2019re going to want to order a few to share at Mama Cucina. For brunch, tuck into the signature Egg Nest on the vine-shaded terrace of Beans About Coffee, or enjoy salmon scrambled eggs in the courtyard of Caf\u00e9 Felix beneath a 150-year-old oak tree.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riebeek%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But perhaps most representative of the Riebeek Valley\u2019s non-conformist spirit is Swartland Independent, a collective of maverick winemakers who have come together to revolutionise the area\u2019s wine industry. What these guys are all about is making wines that are a true expression of their origin. A number of criteria must be met before a bottle can bear the now coveted Swartland Independent logo. Chief among these is that grapes must be grown entirely in the Swartland, as well as vinified, matured and bottled here. Another biggie is holding to natural production methods, which means minimum manipulation in the vineyard and cellar, with no supplements, added tannins, or chemical or technological processes of any kind.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you have limited time, plan your visit around the wine farms of Eben Sadie (Sequillo), Hein and Adi Badenhorst (AA Badenhorst Family Wines) and Callie Louw (Porseleinberg). Together with Chris and Andrea Mullineux (who recently \u2013 and sadly \u2013 moved their operation out of the valley) these guys are the original revolutionaries. And while they take Swartland wine seriously, to be sure, you won\u2019t find a more entertaining, light-hearted group of winemakers out there. One evening in the company of Adi \u2018The Personality\u2019 Badenhorst on his farm, Kalmoesfontein, was enough to convince me that you can taste the geniality and passion he\u2019s known for in his end product.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riebeek%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Tastings at most SI farms are by appointment, which seems like a hassle until you realise that means you invariably get to taste the wines with the very person responsible for making them \u2013 infinitely more personal and detailed than a large-scale tasting room staffed by Elsenburg students.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But back to happy hour and that Royal Hotel gin and tonic. Let me tell you, a bow-tied barman hovered over it for some time. We may be at colonial central, but this creation is out of left field, traditional lemon, lime and cucumber being joined by strawberries, pomegranate seeds and passion fruit syrup. It\u2019s refreshing, it\u2019s delightful and it has that perfect Riebeek-Kasteel collision of old world and new ideas, history and reinvention.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There\u2019s a beat here that\u2019s anything but ordinary, and people are marching to it.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riebeek%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;WHERE TO STAY&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Kloovenburg Pastorie&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;This impeccably restored Victorian manor house is the former residence of De Oude Kerk\u2019s pastor. Today it offers three luxury, air-conditioned, en-suite bedrooms, a dining room and lounge, plus enviable views over Riebeek-Kasteel and the valley. On a hot summer\u2019s day, it\u2019s not easy to drag yourself away from the lovely pool area. Please note, on a Sunday the Kloovenburg Pastorie is transformed into the Kloovenburg Wine &amp; Olive Estate\u2019s tasting room, open from 10:30 am.&lt;br&gt;022 4481 635, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.kloovenburg.com\"&gt;www.kloovenburg.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Old Oak Manor&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;Named for two venerable oak trees on the property, this restored farmhouse dates back to 1856. Spend the night in one of the four French Provencal-style bedrooms of the guest house, or book into the loft (popular with honeymooners) or sweet garden cottage, surrounded by lavender. Room service is available from the popular Caf\u00e9 Felix right next door.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;022 448 1170, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.cafefelix.co.za\"&gt;www.cafefelix.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riebeek%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;HOW TO GET THERE&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Take the N1 from Cape Town, then the N7 to Malmesbury. Take the R45 turn-off, head through Malmesbury, turning left at the third set of traffic lights and taking the R46 to Riebeek-Kasteel, over the Bothmanskloof Pass.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;RIEBEEK VALLEY TOURISM 022 448 1545, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.riebeekvalley.info\"&gt;www.riebeekvalley.info&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;LINGER LONGER&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Stay a little longer in the valley to truly appreciate its myriad delights.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Go gourmet at the Riebeek Valley Wine and Olive Festival&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;One of the Cape\u2019s most popular foodie festivals, this three-day affair from 1 to 3 May, showcases the best olives and wine of the region, plus the local characters behind them. You can also pick up fresh cheese, pickles, bread and jam,&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Take a day trip to Bartholomeus Klip&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;This working farm and 4 000 ha game reserve just outside of Hermon is home to buffalo and quagga breeding programmes. Visit these creatures on a nature drive, while keeping an eye out for the reserve\u2019s other inhabitants, including the rare geometric tortoise, bat-eared fox and herds of eland, springbok and wildebeest. Day visitors are welcome, but must book nature drives in advance.&lt;br&gt;022 448 1087, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.bartholomeusklip.com\"&gt;www.bartholomeusklip.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Go to market&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Funky Fresh Market takes place on the first Saturday of each month just off Riebeek West\u2019s main road. Now in its 15th year of operation, this is the place to pick up fresh treats and handmade crafts.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Hit the trails&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;Stop in at Riebeek Valley Tourism off the square in Riebeek-Kasteel to get permits and maps for the Pieter Cruythoff and Carl Thunberg hikes, and the Kasteelberg and Valley Farm Road cycling trails. These scenic routes offer spectacular views of the Swartland for those energetic enough to tackle them.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h4&gt;Tick off the Swartland Birding Route&lt;\/h4&gt;&lt;p&gt;This popular birding route includes the land between the towns of Malmesbury, Darling, Moorreesburg and Riebeek-Kasteel, taking in some 250 species. Twitchers will enjoy ticking the rare black harrier and South Africa\u2019s endangered national bird, the blue crane, off their checklists (available for download from the Swartland Tourism website).&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;022 487 2989, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.swartlandtourism.co.za\"&gt;www.swartlandtourism.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/apphau5.com\/e-editions\/e-reader\/1163\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Cape Etc&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2399\"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2399\"&gt;Bar Bar Black Sheep&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/7382\"&gt;Bartholomeus Klip Farmhouse&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3219\"&gt;Pieter Cruythoff Trail&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.hsm.co.za\/magazines\/details\/cape-etc\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/cape%20etc%20cover.jpg?itok=_WnPbSL0\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Cape Etc&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-10101\" class=\"publisher-1651 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/oceans-options\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Oceans of Options&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Oceans of Options  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Oceans of Options\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.goodtaste.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #ecdd44' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/goodtaste.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Cruising%201.jpg?itok=6M4rXxWW\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/oceans-options\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/oceans-options\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/oceans-options&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Cruising%201.jpg&amp;description=Oceans of Options\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/oceans-options\" data-text=\"Oceans of Options\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/oceans-options\" data-title=\"Oceans of Options\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Carrie Hampton&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;\u2018South Africans love cruising just for the sake of it, European and American clientele like to be occupied with port excursions and on-board entertainment\u2019&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Cruising the southern hemisphere means bobbing about on great expanses of ocean. A small island may be the only landmark punctuating vast stretches of water. Seafaring journeys to places such as St Helena, Antarctica and across the Pacific take you into waters sailors undertake with trepidation, yet you can visit them in luxury.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Antarctica\u2014Like No Other Place on Earth&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Almost exactly 100 years ago, Shackleton undertook an expedition to one of the harshest places on the planet\u2014Antarctica. The fact that we can reach this once almost impossible destination with the likes of Silversea and Crystal Cruises\u2014and do so in utter luxury\u2014is in stark contrast to Shackleton\u2019s explorations of 1914-1916. Stuck firmly in ice, the &lt;em&gt;Endeavour&lt;\/em&gt;\u2019s crew abandoned ship and lived on floating ice while Shackleton set off to find help. Amazingly, not one member of the expedition died.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Naturalists and marine experts Chris and Monique Fallows of &lt;em&gt;Apex Shark Expeditions&lt;\/em&gt; in Cape Town, say Antarctica is their favourite place on earth. They\u2019ve returned from guest lecturing on the 18-day Amazing Antarctic Crystal Symphony positively glowing from the experience. \u201cThe enormity of the place is difficult to describe,\u201d says Monique, \u201cit\u2019s an out-of-this-world landscape where scenery and wildlife provide constant stimulation.\u201d Chris shares his in-depth knowledge of great white sharks and illustrates talks on Antarctic wildlife with his photographs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You must be prepared to travel through monstrous seas to get to Antarctica and notch up some formidable points on the map, such as Cape Horn, the Falkland Islands and Drake Passage. But once you get to the deep south, you are rewarded with the sight of massive icebergs and huge mountains up to 3 000 metres high. It ticks all the boxes for passionate wildlife enthusiasts, penguin lovers, intrepid travellers, adventure history buffs and those wanting to clock up a new continent on their record of world travels.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cruising%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Pre-cruise reading has to include Endurance: &lt;em&gt;Shackleton's Incredible Voyage&lt;\/em&gt; by Alfred Lansing\u2014the definitive account of this audacious expedition. And &lt;em&gt;The Last Place on Earth&lt;\/em&gt; by Roland Huntford, examining the great South Pole race of 1912 between Britain\u2019s Robert Scott and Norway\u2019s Roald Amundsen. On the return trip Scott dies along with four of his men, and only 11 miles from his next cache of supplies, while Amundsen completes the race, returns alive and remains largely forgotten.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Britain\u2019s Last Colonial Outposts&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another distant journey attracting like-minded, but somewhat more frivolous passengers, is the 17-night return trip from Cape Town to St Helena and Ascension Island on &lt;em&gt;RMS St Helena&lt;\/em&gt;. This Royal Mail Ship, with room for just 150 passengers, visits these islands to deliver mail and cargo to what\u2019s left of Britain\u2019s colonial outposts. It also transports islanders and curious travellers seeking unusual stamps in their passports. Ascension has long been a strategic military base in the middle of the South Atlantic, reachable by air and en-route\u2014but not exactly anywhere near\u2014to the disputed Falkland Islands. The other dot far off the African west coast is St Helena, accessible only by sea, until now. This little volcanic island, that serves as the first stop for sailors from Cape Town en route to Brazil, is about to jump into the 21st century with an air strip and a 4-star hotel, both due to open in 2016. Tristan da Cunha\u2014the third island in this territorial grouping of British protectorates\u2014is no longer visited by RMS St Helena. But don\u2019t let that stop you from reaching the world\u2019s most isolated community and obtaining one of the rarest passport stamps on the globe. You can still take the six-day sea voyage from Cape Town on a cargo or fishing vessel with other eccentric travellers and some grungy fishermen.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Flirting with the Tropic of Capricorn&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;But let\u2019s talk of warmer climes and tropical islands. Cruises out of Durban to Maputo, Inhaca and Portuguese Islands of Mozambique - flirting with the waters of the Tropic of Capricorn - account for most of MSC\u2019s 44 departures during the forthcoming South African summer season. MSC Cruises have cornered the South African market with their discounted prices and family specials, achieving an astounding 99.9 per cent average occupancy for MSC &lt;em&gt;Opera&lt;\/em&gt;\u2019s final season here.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cruising%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Come November 2016, the &lt;em&gt;Sinfonia&lt;\/em&gt; will replace the &lt;em&gt;Opera&lt;\/em&gt; and cruise from Genoa down through the Panama Canal, along the Gulf into the Indian Ocean to Durban via Seychelles, Mauritius and Reunion. A sensational 25-night trip. But she won\u2019t be the same &lt;em&gt;Sinfonia&lt;\/em&gt; we\u2019ve known in the past. She\u2019s undergoing a most extraordinary re-design at a shipyard in Palermo, Italy. The 13-deck vessel is being split into two halves and a new 24-metre long entire mid-section is being added. It all seems quite impossible.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is all because South Africans can\u2019t get enough of this previously inaccessible style of holiday and are queuing up to book the extra 193 cabins with more balconies, extended public areas, additional restaurants and new clubs and play areas for youngsters.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Are You a Pollywog or a Shellback?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;How about starting your cruise mid-ocean among the atolls of the Maldives on Silversea\u2019s &lt;em&gt;Silver Discoverer&lt;\/em&gt;? You quickly sail south passing the invisible equator\u2014a significant event, which should be marked. Perhaps not quite in Navy style with King Neptune presiding over some messy rituals, like cracking a raw egg over your head. Such rites act as the precursor for Pollywogs (those who have yet to cross the equator at sea) to achieve the status of Shellback (those that have crossed the equator). Once across the equator, it\u2019s full steam ahead to several ports in the Seychelles, then hitting the coast of Africa at Mozambique and taking a northerly amble up to Zanzibar. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Paradise in the Pacific&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;If it\u2019s islands you love then Fiji has 333 of them, with only 110 inhabited. Fiji is paradise in the Pacific and visited by Princess Cruises on an 11-night round trip from Sydney or Brisbane. When Captain Cook first met the Fijians in the late-1700s, he described them as \u201cformidable warriors and ferocious cannibals, builders of the finest vessels in the Pacific, but not great sailors.\u201d Today, Fijians aren\u2019t known for eating their neighbours in Tonga or Samoa, but for big smiles and a rich culture infused with mythology and folklore. Their prowess at fire walking is no myth and you may get to see this extraordinary feat. Would you ever try it yourself?&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cruising%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;While South Africans love cruising just for the sake of it, European and American clientele like to be occupied with port excursions and on-board entertainment. You may have thought cruising is about peace and quiet, but you can\u2019t help but watch every cabaret show, burn the midnight oil at blackjack tables and re-live your youth in the disco. Late night feasts expand the waistline, which grows ever bigger even though you visit the gym, dance with the hosts, sample Nordic walking and take lessons in yoga, pilates, salsa and golf. You\u2019ve put on a few kilos but don\u2019t make any excuses; you\u2019ve over-indulged and had a flipping good time doing it.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;hr&gt;&lt;h3&gt;Antarctica Photography Tips from Chris &amp; Monique Fallows&lt;strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/h3&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Wake up early in the morning\u2014be first on deck&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Overexpose for the snow\/white conditions&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Use a polarizer&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Stay up late to get softer colours&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Protect your gear from sea spray&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;If you are going ashore, shorter lenses are more practical than big, long lenses: 16-35 mm, 70-200 mm, 100-400 mm&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Learn how to take star trail images because the night sky is incredible&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;hr&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source - &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.goodtaste.co.za\/Subscribe-to-Good-Taste.html\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Good Taste&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.goodtaste.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/GT%20cover_0.jpg?itok=r9dSI9j8\" \/&gt;\n class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/island-end-rainbow\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;The Island at the End of the Rainbow&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    The Island at the End of the Rainbow  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"The Island at the End of the Rainbow\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Likomo%20M.jpg?itok=jxcN8ZYA\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island-end-rainbow\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island-end-rainbow\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island-end-rainbow&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Likomo%20M.jpg&amp;description=The Island at the End of the Rainbow\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island-end-rainbow\" data-text=\"The Island at the End of the Rainbow\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island-end-rainbow\" data-title=\"The Island at the End of the Rainbow\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Bridget Hilton Barber&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Ancient rocks, creamy clouds, the sigh of the tide. There are only a handful of places to stay on Likoma Island and one of them is the very sexy Kaya Mawa.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We were flying north east over Lake Malawi in a teeny-weeny little Cessna. Ahead of us was Tanzania, to the right, Mozambique, to the left, Zambia, and below and behind, Malawi. Not that we could really tell which was water, land or sky when suddenly, like magic, this rainbow stepped out and showed her gorgeous technicolour leg.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Rainbow! I shouted, but the pilot just smiled.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Likomo%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the end of the rainbow lay Likoma Island, a tiny, charming spot in the north east of Lake Malawi. We landed gently at the \u201caerodrome\u201d as they rather quaintly call it here, offloaded into the blazing heat and a 4x4 and went bumping off down a dirt track, past baobabs and palm trees, past goats and schools and slow-walking men with umbrellas \u2013 and ended up with the most incredible views of the lake.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ancient rocks, creamy clouds, the sigh of the tide. There are only a handful of places to stay on Likoma Island and one of them is the very sexy Kaya Mawa, a series of designer houses on the lakeshore. Kaya Mawa means \u2018maybe tomorrow\u2019 in the local Chichewe language, and was so named in the building of the lodge and the African-style logistics that came with getting building materials from a mainland to an island. For example, when will the bricks be arriving? Kaya mawa, maybe tomorrow. When will we get that last bag of cement? Kaya mawa, maybe tomorrow.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Likomo%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Kaya Mawa today is a fabulous place. So very fabulous it was voted one of the planet\u2019s 10 most romantic destinations by Cond\u00e9 Naste. The d\u00e9cor is amazing \u2013 driftwood, stone, local craft and fabrics. Each house overlooks the beach and lake, there\u2019s a gorgeous bar, lounge and restaurant with lake views, and a sensual little spa that is set on the edge of the beach, over the rocks.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Nearby is Mango Drift, the beach side backpacker joint, named after the many, many mangoes trees of Likoma Island. Mango Drift has a simple reed-and-thatch bar-lounge that looks out across the lake of stars, and has a series of rustic stone chalets tucked into the hillside. A giant baobab guards the kitchen and is home to hundreds of very chatty yellow weavers.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Likomo%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Mango Drift is a cool hang out place, the kind you book for a couple of days and end up staying for a month. We met assorted people at Mango Drift \u2013 a teacher from Hillbrow, a retired journalist, a psychologist from Denmark, two young queens from Milan. We met a pilot called Jan Malan and a Dutch man called Bert who worked for a soft drink company called Squirt.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The main activities on Likoma, wherever you stay, are water related. Snorkelling, scuba diving, kite surfing, swimming, sunset gazing\u2026. Both Kaya Mawa and Mango Drift organise all types of water action, and if you want to just kick back, relax with a book and a Carlsberg green (local beer, very good) that\u2019s also fine.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Likomo%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you\u2019re after &lt;em&gt;la couleur locale&lt;\/em&gt;, there\u2019s a market in Likoma village during the week that sells fresh food and clothes and stuff; and there are plenty of bar lounges where you can hang out with the locals drinking ice cold beer and watch soccer on tiny television sets. The Malawian people are ridiculously friendly, polite and gentle. The country has long been branded \u201cthe warm heart of Africa\u201d and it\u2019s not just a tourism clich\u00e9.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Likomo%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You can visit a magic tree in the middle of the village, where a strangler fig has completely overtaken a baobab and its middle is hollowed out. And you can stroll to St Peters, which is the third largest cathedral in central Africa and was built in 1903. It\u2019s very well kept and still in use, and you can do a guided tour for a small fee. The cathedral was built by missionaries of course. &nbsp;Along with colonials, sailors, traders and war refugees, the history of this tiny little island off the coast of Mozambique is er, colourful to say the least.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Likomo%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;For more information
