Hunt\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/scavenger-hunt\" data-text=\"Scavenger Hunt\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/scavenger-hunt\" data-title=\"Scavenger Hunt\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Miriam Mannak, pics supplied&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s blistering hot in Thakadu Bush Camp, situated in western Botswana\u2014leaving even the normally eardrum-shattering cricket orchestra struggling with the swelter.&nbsp;The Land Cruiser, however, doesn\u2019t seem fazed by soaring mercury levels, and effortlessly ploughs its way over the sand &lt;img class=\"float-left\" src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Scavenger%20Hunt.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"270\" height=\"360\"&gt;path, with overhanging camel thorn branches leaving&nbsp;the occasional grasshopper behind on the bonnet.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A red-billed hornbill flies up from the ground and into a tree, mocking us for disturbing its rendezvous with a companion.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Suddenly, the air starts to fill itself with the pungent stench of rotting flesh, a foulness that becomes more and more pronounced as we go along. Then the car stops. On the right side, scattered amid the trees, lie dozens of livestock carcasses in various stages of decomposition. Some are bloated, which indicates a relative freshness, while others are nothing but a messy, dried out heap of leathery skin, hooves and bones.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the not so far distance, in between shrubbery so typical of this region, half a dozen white-backed vultures are ferociously feasting on the remains of a brown cow. As the birds bury their razor-sharp beaks into the decomposing flesh, pulling it out from underneath the hide, others are watching closely from the treetops. The vultures abruptly abort their luncheon when one of them spots the vehicle. One by one, they spread their enormous wings and join their mates in the trees.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cWelcome to our vulture restaurant,\u201d says Hanri Ehlers, co-founder of Kanabo Conservation Link (KCL). Born and bred in South Africa, she heads the organisation\u2019s research camp at Thakadu. For the past few years, KCL has supported various conservation projects in South Africa, Namibia and Botswana. Other activities include finding ways to involve local communities in nature conservation initiatives, and raising awareness around the plight of various threatened and vulnerable species\u2014vultures included. The research camp at Thakadu and the vulture restaurant form part of that.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThis is not for everyone,\u201d says Ehlers with a smirk. \u201cIt looks a bit like a war zone at the moment. However, one must remember that vulture restaurants play a crucial role in vulture conservation.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Over the past years, various studies have shown that African vulture populations have plummeted across the continent, particularly since the 1980s. While the figures vary, the overall message is clear: Vultures in Africa, like they are elsewhere, are under threat. According to a coalition of nature conservation organisations, including Raptors Botswana and the Endangered Wildlife Trust, the number of western African vulture species has dropped by as much as 97% over the past three decades. Their southern African counterparts have shown a decline of 50% to 60% in that very same period.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;One of the culprits is diclofenac, an anti-inflammatory often used in the livestock sector to treat lameness and fever. The drug causes acute kidney failure in vultures, which they ingest after feeding on deceased cattle. Says Ehlers, \u201cWhile these birds are incredibly strong and are able to break down diseases, rabies and anthrax in their gut, they are also highly sensitive to, for instance, diclofenac.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A prime example of the drug\u2019s destructive impact on the well-being of these carrion-loving raptors is India, which saw its vulture population drop from some 60 million to an estimated 40 000 within a decade. \u201cIn South Asia, the populations of the endemic Oriental white-backed, slender-billed and long-billed vultures have declined by more than 95% since the early 1990s,\u201d states a 2008 paper by the World Organisation for Animal Health.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While the Indian government and farmers were aware of the problem, no one realised what the reason was. In 2003, an international team of scientists came with a conclusive answer: diclofenac. Since then, India and various neighbouring countries including Nepal and Pakistan have banned the local manufacturing of the substance in livestock.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;BirdLife International\u2019s African branch estimates that diclofenac is used in over a dozen African countries. It is, however, uncertain to which extent. This is where the KCL vulture restaurant comes in, Ehlers explains: \u201cThe carcasses we give them are donated by local farmers from the Ghanzi region and Kentrek Feedlot. These are free from diclofenac and other substances that are lethal to vultures.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;She adds that the initiative has another benefit: \u201cIt enables scientists and nature conservationists to study vultures in their natural habitat. We need to know more about vultures in order to be able to protect them.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Some 270 kilometres southeast from Thakadu, near the dusty Kalahari town of Kang, Beckie Garbett from Raptors Botswana has her eyes firmly locked on a handful of circling vulture silhouettes. Using the thermals, the birds effortlessly hover through the sky, their wings outstretched and their heads aimed at the ground.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Garbett has been studying Botswana\u2019s vultures for the past year, with a strong focus on the lappet-faced species. With a wingspan of up to 3m, it\u2019s one of the largest vultures in southern Africa. It is also one of the most vulnerable: BirdLife International estimates the population of the lappet-faced vulture at 5 700 mature adults. This is the lowest out of all southern African vulture species.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Focusing on the birds\u2019 conservation status, flight patterns and nesting behaviours as well as threats and survival rates, Garbett hopes to get better insight into the animals\u2019 general ecology. This data is crucial to the development of much-needed protection strategies.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Regular vulture captures, aimed at any species, form a central part of Garbett\u2019s research. The birds are caught by using a net and bait. \u201cAfter drawing some blood, taking a feather and giving them a wing tag, we release them,\u201d she explains. \u201cThe procedure takes three minutes and is painless.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A select few birds are fitted with a GPS transmitter the size of a small mobile phone. \u201cThese devices enable us to monitor the vulture\u2019s movements,\u201d Garbett says. \u201cOver two hours or so, the transmitter gives us the location of the animal. We have, for instance, found out that lappets can cover 800km per day\u2014we didn\u2019t know that before.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While diclofenac is a key threat to vultures, poisoning is a much bigger concern, she notes. \u201cSome farmers revert to poisoning of deceased livestock to keep large predators, such as cheetah, at bay. In the process, they end up accidentally poisoning vultures because they feed off these carcasses,\u201d Garbett explains, nothing that Botswana\u2019s national parks are not hermetically fenced off as in South Africa. This results in incidental wildlife\u2013human conflict.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThe upside is that farmers are approachable and willing to listen to us, as they tend to like the vultures. The birds, after all, clean up dead animals and prevent the spread of disease. Most farmers don\u2019t realise that what they are doing is hurting the birds.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Poachers are a much bigger concern, Garbett says. \u201cThey poison because they deliberately want to kill vultures, to protect themselves and their illegal activity. Poachers are afraid that the birds\u2019 circling in the sky, after they have killed something, draws the attention of anti-poaching patrols. Sometimes there can be 200 vultures in the sky after something has died.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;One of the biggest poisoning episodes ever recorded dates back to July 2013, when elephant poachers deliberately poisoned some hundreds of vultures in the Namibia\u2013Botswana border region north of the Caprivi Strip. An estimated 700 birds died after feeding on one single elephant carcass laced with, most likely, carbofuran. Marketed as Furadan and Curater, this agricultural substance is considered one of the most toxic carbamate pesticides on the market.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Garbett\u2019s own research has been affected by poisoning. \u201cThree of the 14 lappet-faced vultures we fitted with GPS transmitters have died as a result of it,\u201d she says. \u201cOnce a transmitter stops moving and gives us the same location day after day, we know we have a problem.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While poisoning by poachers is a huge problem, it\u2019s difficult to give an idea of the real scope, Garbett says: \u201cThe southern African region is so vast. There could be a hundred percent more poisoning episodes than we know about, simply because we can\u2019t get to them.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A third important threat are the traditional healers. \u201cVulture bones allegedly give someone clairvoyant powers. In Botswana it is not such a big problem, but it is in South Africa and western Africa,\u201d Garbett says. She stresses that this doesn\u2019t mean Botswanan vultures are safe from sangomas. \u201cLappets can, after all, fly 800km per day. This makes them vulnerable elsewhere, even if they are safe in Botswana.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Why save vultures?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Protecting vultures is important\u2014for the birds, people and even the economy. Take the Indian vulture crisis: As the vulture population in India got wiped out, the prevalence of human and animal rabies and other diseases increased. Researcher Anil Markandya estimates the costs of the Indian vulture crisis at $34 billion (about R396 billion) as a result of up to 48 800 additional rabies deaths.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Feathery facts&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022 Of the total 23 vulture species in the world, 11 are endemic to Africa and 14 are considered vulnerable, threatened or endangered.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022 Of the nine species in South Africa, seven are facing a certain degree of threat of extinction. The Egyptian vulture is one of two bird species in South Africa listed as \u2018regionally extinct\u2019.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022 A group of vultures is called a \u2018kettle\u2019 when in flight; a \u2018wake\u2019 when feeding on a carcass; and \u2018committee\u2019, \u2018volt\u2019 or \u2018venue\u2019 when resting in trees.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022 Many vultures have bare necks and heads, preventing the bacteria of rotting flesh to stick to their feathers and cause infections. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022 The highest vulture flight recorded was by a R\u00fcppell\u2019s vulture in 1973. The bird was allegedly spotted from a plane at 37 000 feet (about 11 200m) above sea level\u2014higher than Mount Everest (8 848m).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022 The diet of bearded vultures (lammergeiers) consists of 70% to 90% bone and marrow. Stomach acid with a pH of 1 allows them to do so. (Human stomach acid has a pH of 1.5 to 3.)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;The Intrepid Explorer&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/IE%20Cover.jpg?itok=zEES3iR9\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;The Intrepid explorer&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9929\" class=\"publisher-1340 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/5-star-luxury\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;5 Star Luxury &lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    5 Star Luxury   &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"5 Star Luxury \" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\/wild_magazine.htm' target='_blank' style='background-color: #b7cb35' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/wild.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Kruger.jpg?itok=J1Ayc5eM\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/5-star-luxury\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/5-star-luxury\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/5-star-luxury&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20Kruger.jpg&amp;description=5 Star Luxury \" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/5-star-luxury\" data-text=\"5 Star Luxury \" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/5-star-luxury\" data-title=\"5 Star Luxury \"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By Wild editor Romi Boom&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It was mid-afternoon and hot as a furnace. The elephant herd was slowly moving toward us, grazing amongst the reeds of the Sabie River. There were babies everywhere, unafraid of tumbling down the river bank. We couldn't hear them, way down below us, but we had a prime lookout. We could see perfectly how the little ones would get distracted, lag behind, then run on wobbly legs to catch up with their older siblings, moms and aunts.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A wildlife spectacle, from the cool bliss of our private plunge pool. The best tickets in the house! We were at Narina Lodge, sheltered by century-old trees, in one of only nine suites, which are connected by wooden walkways. We might as well have been in a treehouse and could have been as Narina, one of the private concessions in Kruger National Park, and its sister establishment, Tinga Lodge, do in fact offer guests the option of a luxurious treehouse stay, unique in the Kruger gamut of experiences.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As bush bedrooms go, it doesn't get any more romantic than Tinyeleti treehouse (meaning \u201cmany stars\u201d). A happy camper, I have slept countless nights under the Milky Way and shooting stars, but the securely constructed platform, with all the creature comforts you could wish for, simply blew my mind. Completely disconnected from other people, any wildlife enthusiast will be impressed by this way of immersing yourself in the bush as you sit high above the ground and watch the animals quenching their thirst from the river.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kruger%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The 50m2 deck can accommodate four people, and children are welcome. Guests arrive at sunset, to spend the dusk hours enjoying a picnic dinner by the glow of lanterns. When night falls, you blend with the wild animals, armed only with a torch and a radio for communication with your field guide. Absolute peace, except for your own excited heartbeat, until you are collected the next morning.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Safari luxury is synonymous with teak floorboards, dreamy mosquito nets, slipper baths, outdoor showers, raised timber walkways and ancient jackalberry trees. Kruger's private concessions, the \"Golden Kudus\", also offer the opportunity to venture off-road. This does not entail breaking the rules, but it allows rangers the leeway to improvise, for example to enjoy sightings from really close. If you have a particular tick on your wishlist, as I did, this is your best chance of success, as the rangers are in constant communication with each other and have intimate knowledge of animal movements on the concession.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;So when I explained to our guide at Lukimbi Safari Lodge that I had been looking for wild dogs for more than a decade, Chris was all ears. He hadn't seen them for weeks, he confessed, but would keep his ear to the ground. On our afternoon game drive, we hit the jackpot: a group of at least 10 dogs, resting right alongside the road, playing and posing for photographs in the golden twilight. My cup of contentment spilled over.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kruger%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Lukimbi is situated in the very accessible southern section of Kruger, and about 50 per cent of the guests are South African. For me it proved a very lucky destination indeed. Earlier that day, a few hundred metres before we arrived at the lodge, a sexy leopard was sprawled in a marula tree, affording us a private sighting at close range overhead. Krrrrr went my camera\u2019s motor drive, and each image was worthy of a calendar. Thirty minutes later, at check in just before lunch, we shared our good luck with management and showed off the photos. \"That's Nula,\" we heard, and immediately a safari vehicle was commandeered for some overseas guests, in the hope that the precious Nula would not have left her perch, despite having two cubs nearby.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bounded by three major river systems, the extensive 15 000 hectare area offers a diverse array of habitats. On our morning game drive, there were rhino everywhere, both white and black, and three cheetah wannabe models. Imagine a scene in which two of the most endangered species on Earth stand cheek by jowl. Talk of good karma!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In this class of accommodation, private decks with riverside views are par for the course. An unusual setting is Camp Shawu, which overlooks Mpanamana Dam. A satellite of Shishangeni Private Lodge, Camp Shawu was named after the famous tusker. It accommodates only 10 guests in five outsize tented suites, constructed around buffalo-dung walls. Hippo pods have colonised the dam and, believe me, they make an incessant and eventually exasperating racket as they claim their territory. The payoff is that from your ringside seat you'll shoot that iconic photo of a yawning hippo, while waiting for predators and prey to come to you.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kruger%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Shishangeni's second intimate retreat is Camp Shonga in the foothills of the Lebombo Mountains, near the Mozambican border. The camp has minimal impact on the surrounding habitat and blends so well with the bushveld that you would not guess it was there until you stumbled upon it. This is how the wilderness must have seemed to the explorers of yesteryear.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If it's the spirit of ancient Africa that you're hoping to find, look no further than Imbali Safari Lodge, built on the site of a 400-year-old Tsonga settlement. The soil has yielded evidence of an ancient culture and artefacts such as clay pots, bone tools and grinding stones are on display. Imbali's 12 suites, with either a private spa or plunge pool in a riverine forest, cosy up to a canopy of jackalberry and tamboti trees overlooking the seasonal Nwaswitsontso River.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Imbali is situated on Mluwati Concession, one of Kruger's first private concessions, and has been dedicated to the sustainability of this pristine wilderness from the start. Together with Hoyo Hoyo Safari Lodge, with its ethnic theme, and Hamiltons Tented Camp, which recreates the Out of Africa style, Imbali is all about indulgence amidst the sounds and smells of the bush. The lodges are located on an ancient elephant route, so imagine our double delight at breakfast when first we watched a relaxed rhino drinking at the waterhole on the far side of the river, followed by a breeding herd of ellies. Does a safari get any better?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Light Footprint&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Kruger's luxury concessions have been hugely effective in generating revenue and support for conservation. In line with the objectives of sustainable ecotourism, the lodges touch the earth lightly and minimise their footprint through a philosophy of \u201cfewer beds in larger areas\u201d.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Trip Planner&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The drive from Johannesburg to Kruger's concessions takes about five hours.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Tinga and Narina Lodges&lt;\/strong&gt; are accessed from Paul Kruger gate. Narina is 8km from the gate. &lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.lionsands.com\"&gt;www.lionsands.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Lukimbi Safari Lodge&lt;\/strong&gt; is 26km from Malelane Gate, on the Crocodile River road. It accommodates 32 people, making it a popular wedding and function destination. &lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.lukimbi.com\"&gt;www.lukimbi.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Shishangeni Private Lodge&lt;\/strong&gt; is about 15km from Crocodile Bridge gate. Guests are transferred from the lodge to Camp Shonga and Camp Shawu. &lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.shishangeni.com\"&gt;www.shishangeni.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Imbali Safari Lodge&lt;\/strong&gt; is 42km from the Orpen Gate. &nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.imbali.com\"&gt;www.imbali.com&lt;\/a&gt; &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.hamiltonstentedcamp.co.za\"&gt;www.hamiltonstentedcamp.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.hoyohoyo.com\"&gt;www.hoyohoyo.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\/blog.htm?action=view-post&amp;id=4662\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Wild magazine&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3292\"&gt;Kruger National Park (South and Central)&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\/wild_magazine.htm\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/wild3%20winter2015_med_300x2000q100.jpg?itok=AexQqRii\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Wild&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;Article provided from WILD - Wildlife, Environment and Travel Magazine.&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9606\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/opening-blue-door\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Opening the Blue Door\t&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Opening the Blue Door\t  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Opening the Blue Door\t\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Tunis%20MAIN%20Roman%20Baths.jpg?itok=t61BUTXu\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opening-blue-door\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opening-blue-door\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opening-blue-door&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Tunis%20MAIN%20Roman%20Baths.jpg&amp;description=Opening the Blue Door\t\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opening-blue-door\" data-text=\"Opening the Blue Door\t\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opening-blue-door\" data-title=\"Opening the Blue Door\t\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Lize de Kock&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The history and scenery around Tunis is both exotic and exciting. Not only does it make for a break full of daydreams and gastronomic feasts, but there is also much to learn from the richness of culture that the city has absorbed through the ages.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s a carefree blue, the blue of Tunis, Tunisia\u2019s capital city. The kind of blue that makes me draw lots of fresh sea air into my lungs and breathe out everyday worries onto the breeze.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After just a few hours in Sidi Bou Said I feel like I have been on holiday for weeks. Surely it must be those blue doors, set off against whitewashed walls with wrought iron balconies and mirrored in the African sky above and the Mediterranean Sea beyond.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tunis%202%20Old%20and%20new.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;My fellow travellers and I try to avoid the cruise ship masses that have descended on this little town outside Tunis today. Since it can become a bit of a tourist trap, it is worth seeking out the shops in the side streets where souvenir prices can be as much as three times less than right at the bus stop and around the main areas of interest.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;A kaleidoscope of tiles and scenery&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ceramics are the order of the day at the souqs. It reminds me of what is on offer in Morocco, although the colours and designs are softer, rounder; more peaceful. The same is true of the people. They are gentle and kind, with more than an earful of travel advice and historical insights for those who are keen to listen.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tunis%203%20Carthage.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We walk along the cobbled streets and spot a yellow door in between all the blue ones. Our curiosity reveals a charming hotel, complete with Phoenician mosaics and a typical blue door leading into each room. The receptionist tells us that Hotel Sidi Boufares used to be a Sufi school, no wonder then that the serene atmosphere has us in relax mode.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In typical tourist style we click away on our cameras and keep walking until we find a sheesha bar with a view of the foothills of the Atlas Mountains on the other side of the bay. Here travellers and locals are lazing about on the cushions, enjoying their hubbly-bubbly pipes in the sunshine. The smell of flavoured tobacco lingers in the air. We order almond tea, which arrives in tiny glasses and tastes just like the sickly sweet Moroccan mint variety. The almonds are floating on top with a few fresh mint leaves. It is not my favourite but in the spirit of this day I enjoy it immensely.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tunis%204%20Tunisia%20074.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From here we take a taxi to the ruins of Carthage. Before I get in the car a local lady lures me into her shop with some jasmine oil. I buy a hand made perfume bottle to save the oil in - for those days when I want to smell like the white flowers and open the blue door in my mind.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Walking in the footsteps of Hannibal&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;On our way we pass several ancient looking walls as well as the ruins of a palace. In between these remains stand luxurious modern villas, which confirm that the rich still dwell here. On top of this hill called Byrsa, once stood the beautiful city Carthage. The infamous war leader Hannibal called it home. I think of all the bloodshed that was staged here and the wind sends an extra chill down my spine.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;According to legend Carthage was founded in 8 BC by the Phoenicians under Queen Dido. It became a rich and enviable sea port that was eventually destroyed by the Romans because they saw it as a threat to their regional power.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tunis%205%20View.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The view from here is exquisite: lush green, a wide sea and inky mountains beyond. Today the city of Tunis decorates the natural backdrop. I live a thousand lives as I take in this important historical site. All the legends become real to me now.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Historians know little about the original city because most of the culture and records were destroyed during this time. No wonder most of the stories about Carthage and Hannibal are based on legends.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Romans eventually reconstructed the city, which became one of the largest and most influential cities around the Mediterranean. Even when Rome came to a fall in the 5th century, Carthage prospered.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We visit the Antoinine Thermal baths, a short drive from the ruins of the original city. It is situated right on the shore and from the ruins it is clear that it was a great and royal structure. I later read that these Roman baths were one of the largest built under the rule of the Roman Empire.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tunis%206%20Tunisia%20155.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After many wars, Carthage was only completely destroyed when the Arabs arrived and beheaded all the Roman statues. What the vandals didn\u2019t destroy, says our guide, the Arabs did when they finally took control of the area.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;An exotic city borne from history&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;A lack of building materials in the vicinity meant that the ruins were used to build new cities in the area such as Tunis. So although the foundations of the Phoenician as well as the Roman cities are still visible, most of the rest has been scavenged.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Today Carthage is a suburb of Tunis. During the Summer Festival, the reconstructed Roman theatre is still used for shows. We test out the acoustic from the metallic stage.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cLadies and gentlemen, welcome to our show\u2026\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tunis%208%20Tunisia%20167.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Even when we say it softly our friends in the \u2018audience\u2019 can hear every word. It seems that nothing and everything has changed here in Carthage.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After the serenity of Sidi Bou Said and the richness of history and culture in Carthage, our stomachs are calling us back to reality. Our taxi driver suggests dinner in La Marsa or La Goulette. Do we feel like seafood or Italian?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We opt for a seafood restaurant just off the beach in the La Goulette area. The waiter brings a platter of fresh whole fish for us to choose from and we end up with a feast of mussels, prawns and fish on our table, served with thin fries, the way the French do it.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;That night I sleep well for the first time in weeks and wake up refreshed, ready for a breakfast of fresh fruit and almond tea as my daydreams float away on the breeze. Aaah. That blue.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tunis%207%20Tunisia%20163.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9969\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/eden-addo-great-corridor-hike\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Eden to Addo Great Corridor Hike&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Eden to Addo Great Corridor Hike  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Eden to Addo Great Corridor Hike\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Great%20Corridor.jpg?itok=wOrLZg8M\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/eden-addo-great-corridor-hike\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" to Addo Great Corridor Hike\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/eden-addo-great-corridor-hike\" data-text=\"Eden to Addo Great Corridor Hike\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/eden-addo-great-corridor-hike\" data-title=\"Eden to Addo Great Corridor Hike\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jun 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Back in 2006, the NGO Eden to Addo was created. Objective: make it possible again for elephants to walk from Addo to the Garden Route without any obstacle. In order to see this dream come true, the organisation puts efforts in the development of ecological corridors between different protected areas by finding private investors, getting in touch with local farmers and managing concerned lands.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Great%20Corridor%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Eden to Addo Great Corridor Hike stretches all along the areas Eden to Addo has interest in, from the Garden of Eden to Addo Elephant National Park, and including Tsitsikamma National Park and the Baviaanskloof World Heritage Site. Between these protected areas, you will have the opportunity to hike through beautiful private landscapes, which are exclusive to Eden to Addo hikes.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Great%20Corridor%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Such a journey takes you on a more than 400km hike, achieved within 20 days of self-envelopment in nature. Going through five of South Africa\u2019s seven biomes (forest, fynbos, succulent karoo, nama karoo and thicket), thousands of floral species and following leopard, bush buck or red hartebeest\u2019s spoors, our hike invites you in the most bio-diverse area on the planet.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Great%20Corridor%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You will share the hike with 20 other passionate hikers, with an average age of 55; our all-time dean was 70, and outran us all! The hike is demanding, but passion and training will make it easy to you. Our guides will show you the best paths and tell you about the work we do in the very areas you hike in. Some hikers enjoy the adventure so much they come back!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Great%20Corridor%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the end of the daily hike, relax yourself in the already-mounted camp thanks to our logistics team. Take your shoes off, meet people and share delicious meals around a campfire or under the simple but magnificent sky without any light pollution.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Great%20Corridor%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The cost of a hike is R24,000, directly funding Eden to Addo\u2019s heavy work on Eastern Cape\u2019s biodiversity. Tents and sleeping bags are carried for you so that you can pack only the essential during the day. Meals are provided. The Great Corridor Hike 2015 will take place from 3rd to 23rd of September, and is limited to 20 hikers.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Hiking, slackpacking, 400 to 450km&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Website:&lt;\/strong&gt; edentoaddo.co.za&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Phone:&lt;\/strong&gt; 044 533 1627&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Email:&lt;\/strong&gt; &lt;a href=\"mailto:admin@edentoaddo.co.za\"&gt;admin@edentoaddo.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9926\" class=\"publisher-1785 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/rock-ages\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;The Rock of Ages&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    The Rock of Ages  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"The Rock of Ages\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.zigzag.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/zigzag_0.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Cave%20Rock.jpg?itok=lTkdDxWI\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rock-ages\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rock-ages\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rock-ages&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20Cave%20Rock.jpg&amp;description=The Rock of Ages\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rock-ages\" data-text=\"The Rock of Ages\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rock-ages\" data-title=\"The Rock of Ages\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Will Bendix, pics Greg Ewing&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The wall lies in a crumpled heap on the sand, a blanket of brick and cement folded over the crushed words that used to adorn its surface: \u201cIf you don\u2019t live here, don\u2019t surf here.\u201d A trail of rubble leaks down the beach on to the foot of the tidal pool that has framed the coveted waves of Cave Rock for decades.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You know Cave Rock. The Rock. South Africa\u2019s answer to Backdoor Pipe. Its wide-open tubes and perfect backdrop made it the poster child for surfing magazines the world over. Lavish spreads were dedicated to its carnivorous barrels with the pro of the day stuffed deep inside its belly. But beyond the sheet of sandstone reef and lush green hill that has framed so many of those perfect photo opportunities lies a very different picture.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Cave Rock sits on the Bluff, a finger of land that juts out into the Indian Ocean before curving abruptly into the deep bay that makes up Durban. The British immediately recognized the strategic potential of this natural harbor when, it\u2019s claimed, they were given the land by Shaka in 1824. Today it is the largest port in southern Africa and the bustling harbour drives a wedge between the Bluff and the gentrified suburbs of Durban proper. On the leeward side are the \u201ctownies\u201d or \u201ctown clowns\u201d as Bluff surfers have long called locals from the stretch of piers that dot Durban\u2019s beaches. And on the other side, facing directly into the brunt of the southwesterly swells are the surfers who hail, as the saying goes, \u201cRough \u2018n tough and from the Bluff\u201d.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cave%20Rock%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThe Bluff\u2019s always been the wrong side of the tracks,\u201d says lifelong local, Ross Solomon. \u201cThe guys grow up a bit harder here. A lot of the older guys were total nutcases back in the day. Localism was really heavy back then and they demanded respect. This has just been passed on from generation to generation. I think the waves we have, this place\u2026it breeds these extreme personalities.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;37-year-old Solomon lives in a modest cottage on the beach with his wife, child, a few surfboards and their dog. He works as a freelance building contractor, taking jobs mostly overseas where the money is good and the schedule allows him to be home for winter to surf Cave Rock without distraction. He never got shoved in \u2018the hole\u2019 when he was younger, an initiation rite where older locals would catch, strip and bury a grommet in the sand and then \u201cpiss and shit and do whatever vile things they could think of with your head\u201d. But he has paid his dues and nowadays enjoys his share of set waves out front.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A kay or two inland from the honey-coloured beach where Solomon spent his youth is a sprawling artery of factories and railway lines, oil refineries and smokestacks that power the industrial heart of Durban. And the manpower to run this colossus has historically come from the Bluff.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cave%20Rock%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThere are a lot of railway houses just over the hill and there was always a strong blue collar community on the Bluff,\u201d says Solomon. \u201cThere still is, and a lot of guys who surfed came from this background too.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As Durban boomed in the middle of the 20th century, the Bluff evolved from a quiet residential outpost to include a railway village servicing the port and the whaling station located on its northern flank. Huge sperm whales were slaughtered and hoisted up the beach along the concrete slipways well into the 1970s. Around the same time, across the bloodstained channel, the legendary Bay of Plenty was laying the blueprint for professional surfing in South Africa. Future world champions like Shaun Tomson and later Martin Potter were bred in the shadow of the piers where competitiveness was encouraged and rewarded. But on the other side of the harbour, the Bluff was breeding the archetypal anti-hero. The isolation and raw power of the waves, along with its working class roots, nurtured a tight-knit crew where localism became the norm. Surfing contests or hanging out in town was deemed uncool at best, and a betrayal at worst.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThey were town clowns, and you just did not want to be associated with them in any way,\u201d recalls Clyde Martin, who grew up surfing the Bluff\u2019s most notorious peak, Garvies, during the early 1980s.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cave%20Rock%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Although Cave Rock has always taken centre stage, the Bluff is home to a series of formidable waves that sit shoulder-to-shoulder, much like the North Shore. The most well known of these is Cave Rock and then Garvies, with Ansteys \u2013 or \u2018Corner\u2019 \u2013 wedged in the middle.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;\u201cThe first locals at Garvies were a pretty core bunch of guys. And then there were the guys at Corner, we used to call them the \u2018Corner Skates\u2019,\u201d says Martin. \u201cThey used to hang out on the grass by the toilets and smoke joints and pop Mandrax tablets. They were just a mean fucking bunch of guys that used to hang out there. They wouldn\u2019t feel anything to get into a fight. At Garvies it was the same and that\u2019s just what we learnt from day one. There was a rivalry between Ansteys and Garvies as well, a huge rivalry, although if there was any ever problem from the outside, we\u2019d all stick together.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Martin is blunt when asked where the fierce territorialism came from. \u201cI\u2019ve got no idea. It\u2019s just something we grew up with,\u201d he replies. \u201cBut I do know for a fact that my group of locals, we took the localism thing to another level completely. We pushed it way out of control.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He recalls a few facebrick duplexes that still line the dunes at Garvies, the last one standing next to the carpark. \u201cOriginally there were going to be 21 of those houses going right down the beach towards Cave Rock,\u201d he says. \u201cThings started to get really gnarly when they started to build those houses. I was still in high school and we decided that we just couldn\u2019t have this at our beach and we literally stopped them building those houses. Every single night we\u2019d go in and rip all the stuff out. We\u2019d saw out the rafters and make bonfires with the wood. They\u2019d get security guards and we\u2019d beat the security guards up and when they got to the last house, the one in the carpark, the guy behind the development decided he just couldn\u2019t do it anymore.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cave%20Rock%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;By the time Martin finished school, his crew owned the beach, but South Africa was in a state of emergency. Everyone was soon called up for compulsory military service. \u201cPeople don\u2019t understand how heavy the situation in the country was,\u201d he says. \u201cWhen I finished the army in 1986, a lot of my friends worked for private security companies and then we were all pretty much armed and dangerous. People would come to the beach with shotguns and 9 mils and baseball bats and just cause shit. That\u2019s when Garvies was just absolutely out of bounds.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;By this stage the Bluff\u2019s reputation preceded itself and anyone coming from the outside knew to tread very lightly. Yet, somehow, Cave Rock avoided the brunt of this vicious closed-door policy.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThe locals at Garvies were always pretty gnarly, and at Ansteys. But the Rock was different,\u201d says Martin. \u201cThe road goes right past the Rock and there were always town guys out, so it was never as localised as Corner and definitely not as localised as Garvies. They\u2019d come to the Rock, surf the Rock and they\u2019d go. It was kinda just accepted.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Martin and friends would even begrudgingly watch the \u2018townies\u2019 trade barrels with standout locals like Gavin Spowart and Rudy Palmboom at the end of the road. \u201cWe just sat there and bit our lips going, \u2018These guys are good\u2019. You learn from watching better surfers. And we learnt a lot.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cave%20Rock%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This didn\u2019t stop them, however, from going out on \u201cbashes\u201d where they\u2019d load into a couple of VW kombis with baseball bats on the weekend and head into town and look for fights.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ironically, it was competitive surfing that changed the course of Martin\u2019s life.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cI was in my twenties when I realised surfing was a way of getting out of the downward spiral I saw all my other friends in \u2013 the drugs and the violence and the fighting. Some of those people just never got out of that. I saw surfing as an excuse to get off the Bluff in a way, and at the time there was a nice, healthy competitive scene in South Africa.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Martin began competing on the ASP, did well, and later found himself in Europe where he was offered the job as Director of ASP Europe - a position he held for nearly 15 years after he relocated to Spain. Nowadays he is candidly trying to come to terms with his roots and \u201cthe stupid shit we did\u201d.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cI never really took drugs, but if you didn\u2019t take drugs or drink or fight, you didn\u2019t fit in, so you were almost forced into that lifestyle on the Bluff,\u201d he says. \u201cThat\u2019s just the way it was.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cave%20Rock%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Rudy Palmboom has different recollections. At 54 years of age Palmboom is built like a sailor, barrel chested with arms like two oars. To witness him surf Cave Rock is to watch an intimate dance that has been refined over decades of devotion to this stretch of reef. Like Lopez and Pipeline, he is synonymous with the wave and can still be found fading deep, snapping under the lip and getting more tube time than most pros half his age.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;\u201cI was oblivious to heavy violence, but there were definitely a few self-inflicted fatalities due to drugs and alcohol,\u201d he recalls of the time.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Palmboom\u2019s memory of localism is far more amicable. Policing the lineup was deemed necessary and transgressors were dealt with, preferably in a non-violent way, but if you minded your manners and paid your dues, you\u2019d be okay.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cCave Rock\u2019s similarity to Backdoor Pipe always attracted lots of visiting surfers and foreign pros,\u201d he says. \u201cEspecially the pros, when they would escape the contest scene at the Gunston 500 to come sample the Rock. It was also a cool show for the Bluff locals.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Palmboom revelled in the competitive rivalry that developed between the Cave Rock locals and visitors. Contests helped break the ice and laid the foundation for competitive friendships. His fondest memory remains a week in the early winter of 1978. \u201cIt was six to eight foot and on fire for a solid week, just barrel after barrel. It was cool surfing the whole swell with Shaun Tomson, who was training for Hawaii at the time.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cave%20Rock%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Unlike the more localised corners of the Bluff, Palmboom says the heaviest threat at Cave Rock has always come from the waves. Swells generated by the Roaring Forties strike Cape Town with unimpeded force. As they scrape up the east coast of South Africa they decay in size but grow in power. The shallow reef that fringes the tidal pool sucks up these long period swells from deep water and folds them into concrete-lipped tubes.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cJust the paddle out through the impact zone on low tide is sketchy at best,\u201d he says. \u201cWhen it\u2019s six foot plus, the wave is purely barrel and breaks below sea level.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As with any wave of this magnitude, there are consequences. There have been fatalities, severe injuries and countless near-death experiences. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cIf you surf out here, it\u2019s just a matter of time. You\u2019re going to get beaten properly,\u201d says Ricky Basnett. \u201cIt\u2019s the closest thing to Hawaii, the power behind it. When the Rock is on, it rivals anything in that league.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Basnett grew up with a bird\u2019s eye view of the wave from his family home on the hill. He admits he had it easy compared to the generations before him but still took a lot of flak from both sides when he started to compete at an early age. \u201cIt was hard because town always had its own clique, so you were always an outcast,\u201d he says. \u201cIt made you surf a hell of a lot better though, competing against the town guys.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cave%20Rock%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Even before Basnett qualified for the World Tour in 2006 he had a constant procession of fellow pros coming to stay with him every winter during the Mr Price Pro. Since the contest moved to Ballito an hour north, however, the stream of celebs coming to surf Cave Rock has dried up, ending a decades-long tradition that started when the event was still the Gunston 500. Which suits Basnett just fine. \u201cI get to surf Cave Rock with fewer pros out now,\u201d he laughs. \u201cAnd the Rock will always be the Rock.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He points out the crumpled wall with its cautionary message that lies slumped on the sand. \u201cThe Bluff is not really what it used to be localism-wise. But it still garners that respect because of the people who surf here. It\u2019s a weird place. You drive through this shitty industrial area, past the matchbox houses, and then you\u2019re on Marine Drive and you see mansions the size of those in Orange County. Rich, poor, there\u2019s all kinds of people here. But it doesn\u2019t matter which side you\u2019re from, people here are proud to be from the Bluff.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.zigzag.co.za\/magazine\/subscribe\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Source: Zigzag Surfing Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n about=\"\/magazine\/winners-0\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;The Winners&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    The Winners  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"The Winners\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #09906f' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/A%202015%20logo%20s.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M_NJA2015%202.jpg?itok=v0JeiF-A\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/winners-0\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/winners-0\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/winners-0&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M_NJA2015%202.jpg&amp;description=The Winners\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/winners-0\" data-text=\"The Winners\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/winners-0\" data-title=\"The Winners\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;After another year of thrilling adventures, we are proud to announce that the title of Nightjar Adventurer 2015 was awarded to Bernie Theron for his solo unsupported trek across Iceland.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In support of future expeditions, Bernie received a MSR Superfly stove, a PowerMonkey Classic, a PowerMonkey Explorer, a PowerTraveller PowerChimp, and a R2 000 Adventure Voucher from Cape Union Mart.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/0%20BernieTheron.png\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"486\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The title of Readers\u2019 Choice went to Cameron Bellamy for his part in the Guinness World Record fastest row across the Indian Ocean. Cameron received a R2 000 Adventure Voucher from Cape Union Mart, and we hope to hear about more of his adventures soon!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;All of the expeditions for the title were in attendance, and contenders received Buff and Sea to Summit gear. They thrilled the audience with personal memories from their expeditions, while the setting at the Cape Union Mart Canal Walk Adventure Centre made the perfect adventurous backdrop.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Every year, we are amazed by the achievements of South African adventurers, the miles they\u2019ve trekked and the heights they\u2019ve conquered. To say that this year was no exception would be an understatement. The determination and courage displayed has been beyond inspirational, and we wait with bated breath to see what our local adventurers will come up with next.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Looking back at the year, we feel that there has been a beautiful expression of the spirit that we hope to embody as a nation. A spirit that looks forward with determination and perseveres through hardship to achieve our aspirations. Each of the expeditions nominated this year faced significant challenges, and rose to them.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/0%20Cameron%20Bellamy.png\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"485\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What do you do when you spend a year planning an expedition to travel halfway around the world and trek across a continent, and your funding and your partner disappear with mere months to go?&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/kai-fitchen-kape-atacama\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ask Kai Fitchen&lt;\/a&gt;. He jumped on a boat with a bunch of strangers and a bit of money from friends and family, and conquered South America regardless.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What do you do when you have to swim in tropical waters where both sharks and crocodiles are a risk factor, and you can\u2019t convince a single other person to join you?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/jean-craven-and-swimmings-big-6\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ask Jean Craven&lt;\/a&gt;. He prepared what he could, and hoped that determination would take care of the rest.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What do you do when the mountain you want to climb is classified by NASA as being the closest thing on Earth to the surface of Mars?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/karen-hauptfleisch-and-mountains-sahara\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ask Karen Hauptfleisch&lt;\/a&gt;. She measured the risks, and the sacrifices she would have to make, and found them wanting compared to achieving her lifelong dream.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What do you do when your most important means of communication breaks after a disastrous hit by a big wave, 20 days into a multi-month rowing expedition from mainland to mainland across the Atlantic?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riaan-manser-and-vasti-geldenhuys-morocco-new-york-rowing-expedition\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ask Riaan Manser &amp; Vasti Geldenhuys&lt;\/a&gt;. They assessed the situation, decided they could make the best of what they had, and got on with the adventure.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What do you do when there are no maps to guide you, and you have to take full responsibility for your route up an uncharted Antarctic peak?&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/unlimited-twin-peaks-expedition\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ask the Unlimited&lt;\/a&gt;. They trusted in the years of planning and preparation they had done, took the necessary safety precautions, and ultimately triumphed.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What do you do when you know there are sharks in the water, but it is your responsibility to take the barnacles off the hull of the boat?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cameron-bellamy-and-his-magnificent-indian-ocean-crossing\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ask Cameron Bellamy&lt;\/a&gt;. He knew there was a risk, and it scared him, but he also knew what needed to be done, so after checking the water very carefully, he did the job in front of him.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What do you do when your gear sled breaks down irreparably, and you still have to walk across the entirety of Iceland?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bernie-theron\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ask Bernie Theron&lt;\/a&gt;. &nbsp;He repacked everything into his backpack and, even though he was now carrying around 45kg, he set his mind to finishing his amazing journey.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We feel that there is a clear message here. The next time you are stuck in a rut, glance out a window and look to the horizon. Somewhere between here and there, resting on a ledge or riding a wave, diving in or climbing up, is a fellow South African - buckling down, moving forwards. As our adventurers have told us numerous times, the most important thing is believing in yourself, and if they can do it, so can you.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/0%20NJA2015%20Contenders.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"353\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n
