      &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9928\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/last-chance-visit-oranjezicht-city-farms-market-villa-zille\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Last chance to visit Oranjezicht City Farm&#039;s Market at Villa Zille&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Last chance to visit Oranjezicht City Farm&#039;s Market at Villa Zille  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Last chance to visit Oranjezicht City Farm&#039;s Market at Villa Zille\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20OZCF.jpg?itok=ezq4l7LV\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/last-chance-visit-oranjezicht-city-farms-market-villa-zille\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/last-chance-visit-oranjezicht-city-farms-market-villa-zille\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/last-chance-visit-oranjezicht-city-farms-market-villa-zille&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20OZCF.jpg&amp;description=Last chance to visit Oranjezicht City Farm's Market at Villa Zille\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/last-chance-visit-oranjezicht-city-farms-market-villa-zille\" data-text=\"Last chance to visit Oranjezicht City Farm's Market at Villa Zille\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/last-chance-visit-oranjezicht-city-farms-market-villa-zille\" data-title=\"Last chance to visit Oranjezicht City Farm's Market at Villa Zille\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Fiona McIntosh, pics Shaen Adey, Elsje Schoeman and supplied&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This Saturday is the last chance to visit the Oranjezicht City Farm Market at Villa Zille before the market day relocates to its winter premises at Granger Bay in the V&amp;A Waterfront. If you haven\u2019t been to the current location at the premier\u2019s residence at Leeuwenhof you\u2019ve missed out. With straw bales out on the lawn, pony rides for kids and a whole load of passionate stallholders peddling their wares, the vibe is amazing. Make a date to check it out this Saturday, 30 May.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/OZCF%202_0.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cPeople from all over the world have been amazed that our Premier opened up her residence to the community for OZCF Market Day\u201d says Sheryl Ozinsky, a founding volunteer of the Oranjezicht City Farm. \u201cThey say that there is no politician in the world that would do such a thing. &nbsp;We agree. &nbsp;It\u2019s been the most amazing place to host a market - the setting is unbelievable \u2013 an oasis of green in the middle of Cape Town. People bring dogs, swim in the Premier\u2019s pool and play on the tennis courts. Now we take shelter for the winter at Granger Bay in V&amp;A Waterfront. &nbsp;It\u2019s going to be a good move and an opportunity for OZCF to broaden its mission and reach. We're ready.\"&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/OZCF%203_0.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The scheduled move is due to wet winter conditions that make the use of the lawns and parking area at Leeuwenhof untenable from June to October. But the new location is also an opportunity to find additional partners and new infrastructure that will help increase the availability of fresh, healthy, locally-grown produce for City Bowl residents and to provide more support for the local small-scale organic farmers that supply the market.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Granger Bay site is near The Lookout event venue. A tented precinct for the market will be created for the winter, providing a cosy atmosphere, easy access, great views, protection from inclement weather and a safe, child-friendly set-up. There will be affordable parking for more than two hundred cars, with plenty of overflow parking in the area.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/OZCF%204_0.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With more than 60 traders and approximately 2 500 visitors every Saturday, Market Day has a direct economic impact estimated in excess of R25 million per annum, supporting nearly 200 jobs and 75 entrepreneurial small businesses including local farms.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Trading every Saturday from 9am \u2013 2pm, the market is a true farmer\u2019s market with a majority of the offering being fresh, locally-grown vegetables, fruit, herbs and other ingredients and pantry items such as bread, cheese, nuts, olive oil, spices, yoghurt, honey, ethically sourced meats, biltong, fish and even fresh oysters.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/OZCF%205_0.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is supplemented with artisanal food traders selling breakfast and lunch fare to eat at the market or for takeaway, as well as coffees, teas, juices and smoothies. Vegan, banting, gluten-free, sugar-free and other dietary preferences are catered for and you can also buy plants, compost and micro-green trays and bean sprout starter kits to create your own urban garden at home.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThe Oranjezicht City Farm\u2019s Market Day is as much a connection for urban farmers to a local consumer as it is a great offering for Capetonians,\u201d says David Green, CEO of the V&amp;A Waterfront. \u201cBy supporting this initiative we are reaffirming our commitment to growing small business. A fresh food market and organic foods will be a wonderful addition to our winter offering.\u2019\u2019&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/OZCF%206_0.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"323\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;MORE ABOUT OZCF&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Pick your own harvests are on the first Wednesday of each month at OZCF itself. Subscribe to the newsletter or watch the OZCF Facebook group (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/OZCFarm\"&gt;www.facebook.com\/OZCFarm&lt;\/a&gt;) for details.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Oranjezicht City Farm is open every day (except Sunday) from 08h00 to 16h00. If you want to wander around on your own, you are very welcome. Dogs on leashes on welcome too.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/OZCF%207_0.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9662\" class=\"publisher-1333 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/guide-prince-albert\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Guide to Prince Albert&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Guide to Prince Albert  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Guide to Prince Albert\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #243741' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/getaway_0.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/L%20M%20Prince%20Albert%202%20Ouma-Maggie-knits.jpg?itok=MF5_LSpu\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/guide-prince-albert\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/guide-prince-albert\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/guide-prince-albert&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/L%20M%20Prince%20Albert%202%20Ouma-Maggie-knits.jpg&amp;description=Guide to Prince Albert\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/guide-prince-albert\" data-text=\"Guide to Prince Albert\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/guide-prince-albert\" data-title=\"Guide to Prince Albert\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Toni Younghusband, main pic Toni Younghusband&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the age of 104, Ouma Maggie wasn\u2019t anticipating starting a career, especially not as the \u2018poster girl\u2019 for &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.google.com\/maps\/place\/Prince+Albert,+South+Africa\/@-33.3345335,22.1854198,8z\/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x1dd5aa331ba91e05:0xa757339eee46222e\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Prince Albert&lt;\/a&gt;, but she\u2019s adapted to her new role with a great deal of good-humoured enthusiasm. The star attraction of Prince Albert\u2019s new cultural tourism route, it is Ouma Maggie\u2019s job to help visitors bridge the gap between the town\u2019s better-known white settlement and the coloured community that in the 1960s was forcibly removed from Rooikamp in the centre of the town to North End, a purpose-built township.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ouma Maggie conducts business from her tiny bedroom, its teal-painted walls offering a backdrop as colourful as her stories. My concerns that she might feel exploited by the gawkers who crowd the room are brushed away.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018This is an important job,\u2019 she tells me earnestly. \u2018I tell them what the town used to look like, where the shops were and how people lived.\u2019&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Virtually bedridden, she loves the company too.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018I enjoy the conversation. I ask the foreigners just as many questions as they ask me. We laugh a lot.\u2019&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Though she never learnt to read or write, Ouma Maggie is a talented herbalist (she offers to fix my childlessness with one of her special concoctions) and a gifted storyteller, though don\u2019t expect sugar coating: farm life was exceptionally tough on her sheep-shearer father and his children who were expected to plough and plant as four-year-olds.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Prince%20Albert%204%20Drum-Magazine-covers.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Old Drum Magazine covers, taken by Jurgen Schadeberg, at the gallery. Photo by Jeanine Groenewald.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As she tells stories about the farms, Prince Albert\u2019s now stilled water mills, the old tobacco factory where young women earned extra money rolling tobacco leaves and the butcher who also sold bread, her daughter, 71-year-old Bettie, bakes&nbsp;&lt;em&gt;roosterkoek&lt;\/em&gt;&nbsp;for visitors on a braai grid in the dusty yard.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next stop on the tour is a local tavern, then a nursery school, then back to \u2018white\u2019 Prince Albert to the few remaining buildings that were once part of Rooikamp. The cultural tour is the brainchild of local resident Anton Joubert, who has also developed the only integrated online booking system for a town in South Africa. At &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/paonline.biz\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;paonline.biz&lt;\/a&gt; you can book and pay for accommodation, excursions and restaurants in the town before leaving home.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Though Prince Albert has a thriving tourist trade aided in part by its location at the foot of the magnificent Swartberg Pass and the preservation of its Victorian and Karoo-style architecture, residents like Anton and his wife Ellen are acutely aware of the need to keep the town\u2019s heart beating. The Karoo is littered with towns dead and dying, crippled by the decline in agriculture.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018Part of the secret to our success,\u2019 says Ellen, \u2018is that we are still a working farming community; the town has a very rural feel.\u2019&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is also a town peopled with professors and experts in botany, anthropology, astronomy, gastronomy, art, filmmaking and photography who all contribute to the many enthralling tours and excursions the town has to offer. There are art, olive, book and film festivals; there is an R8 million theatre; there is a winter school for aspirant jewellers, artists, writers and chefs; and there are hundreds of acres of wide-open spaces to be explored by bike or on foot. Fresh produce is in abundance: export-quality figs, cheese, wine from four vineyards, extra virgin oil from three sizeable olive producers, and of course free-range Karoo lamb at prices so reasonable city folk have been known to ditch their luggage for an extra coolbox packed with chops.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Prince%20Albert%206%20Gays-Dairy-selection-of-cheeses.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Gay\u2019s Dairy is renowned for its Guernsey milk and selection of cheeses. Photo by Jeanine Groenewald.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While it has managed to retain its rural charm, Prince Albert has a level of sophistication that puts urbanites at ease. There are more than half-a-dozen quality restaurants and caf\u00e9s, a wide range of accommodation options to suit all tastes and pockets and &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.showroomtheatre.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;The Showroom Theatre&lt;\/a&gt; attracts some of the country\u2019s best-known performing artists.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is partly because of the town\u2019s residential profile: large numbers of professionals from Cape Town, Johannesburg, the Eastern Cape and the UK have set up home here and they\u2019re not just retirees. The town\u2019s private school, Prince Albert College, follows the Cambridge international curriculum and is prized for its maths and science results.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There is no denying the town\u2019s natural attractions though, and it\u2019s these that draw the largest number of visitors: such as the ancient leiwater channels that carry water from the mountains to the town\u2019s gardens and orchards. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/gaysguernseydairy.yolasite.com\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Gay\u2019s Dairy &lt;\/a&gt;is a favourite; fill your own container with milk still warm from a Guernsey cow or get your children to help bottle-feed orphaned lambs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Climbers, hikers and cyclists head for the russet-coloured mountains, wine lovers catch sunsets from rock perches above the valley floor, and for the more adventurous there is the descent into the valley of Die Hel, a 150-year-old farming settlement formally named Gamkaskloof, virtually cut off from the world until the 1960s when a steep switchback road was carved into the Swartberg.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source:&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\/travel-ideas\/destinations-travel-ideas\/guide-prince-albert\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;This article &lt;\/a&gt;originally appeared in the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\/magazine-issues\/october-2014\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;October 2014 issue of Getaway Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/6430\"&gt;&lt;br&gt;The Showroom Theatre&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3713\"&gt;Ou Tol Circuit Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3154\"&gt;Swartberg Pass MTB Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/776\"&gt;Swartberg Nature Reserve&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3975\"&gt;Swartberg Nature Reserve 4x4 Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2006\"&gt;Die Hel (Gamkaskloof)&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n id=\"node-9658\" class=\"publisher-1338 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/crossing-africa-vespa\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Crossing Africa on a Vespa&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Crossing Africa on a Vespa  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Crossing Africa on a Vespa\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #d22127' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/din.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Vespa.jpg?itok=qOs_RDas\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/crossing-africa-vespa\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/crossing-africa-vespa\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/crossing-africa-vespa&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Vespa.jpg&amp;description=Crossing Africa on a Vespa\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/crossing-africa-vespa\" data-text=\"Crossing Africa on a Vespa\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/crossing-africa-vespa\" data-title=\"Crossing Africa on a Vespa\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words: Jayde Coombes&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Just a man, his Vespa and the open road. It\u2019s this simple appeal that inspired Johannesburg resident, Mike Strauss, to undertake a solo journey on his faithful Vespa GTS 300 Super Sport all the way from SA to Milan, Italy.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Strauss and \u2018Victoria\u2019 the Vespa set off on 1 May 2014 and rode straight into seven months of stunning encounters with nature, challenging roads and refreshing solitude. \u201cJust the idea of such a trip is astonishing to most, but Mike and his Vespa made it an epic reality,\u201d says Managing Director of Vespa SA, Andy Reid.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Vespa spirit&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;For Strauss, one of the defining factors of the trip was the spirit of humanity as countless helping hands were selflessly extended to him throughout the journey. Starting with a send-off by the local Vespa community where about 60 riders turned up to accompany Strauss on the ride out of town. \u201cThis is where the spirit of Vespa really comes alive,\u201d says Reid. \u201cA Vespa gives the rider the opportunity to journey alone with only nature and the open road for company, but simultaneously brings the rider into the fold of a tight-knit community that shares a passion for riding.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Apart from the camaraderie with Vespa riders, Victoria gave Strauss the opportunity to meet interesting people across the continent. He was overwhelmed by the generosity of complete strangers who helped with repairs at no charge, offered him free lodging, or gave him and Victoria a hand in the middle of the night.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Trusty steed&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Prior to his departure, Strauss worked with engineers to modify Victoria to carry supplies and essentials for several months \u2013 weighing in at 50kg. Vespa SA Director, Louw du Toit, worked closely with Strauss to prepare his Vespa for the long journey and to give Strauss a working understanding of the mechanics involved in keeping Victoria going for the long haul \u2013 and she really held her own.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It took Strauss 189 days to cover 23 530 kilometres and 13 border crossings \u2013 including some very rough terrain. Amazingly, he managed the whole trip without a single puncture and just one hiccup with a disintegrated ball bearing that was repaired in less than three hours. It took an impressive 15 030 kilometres for Victoria\u2019s rear tyre to lose its grip, and by the end of the journey the front tyre was still going strong. Strauss changed the oil filter three times on the journey, the engine oil four times, the transmission oil once, and the spark plugs twice.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Journey of a lifetime&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;On his incredible journey, Strauss discovered that Ethiopia has the best coffee of all, that Sudan has the cheapest fuel and that \u2018No Vespa No Life\u2019 is now a motto he lives by. His trusted Vespa gave him the experience of a lifetime \u2013 taking him to places he\u2019d never experienced before. He discovered the beauty of Vespa ownership, in both its freedom and solitude. His Vespa was not just a mode of transport, but his sole and trusted companion for the entire journey.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For more about Strauss\u2019 epic journey, visit &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.soloscooterist.com\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.soloscooterist.com&lt;\/a&gt;. To learn more about the Vespa lifestyle and to join the burgeoning rider community, check out Vespa SA on Facebook or visit &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.vespa.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.vespa.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; to book a test ride.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/content\/crossing-africa-vespa-incredible-journey-solo-scooterist-0\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;DO IT NOW&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/cover39_2_1.jpg?itok=QAp5DYAk\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Do it Now&lt;\/h2&gt;\n Growth Opportunities  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Growth Opportunities\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/L%20M%20Green%20Spots%20View%20from%20Intaka%20Island.jpg?itok=_PNu8RxR\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/growth-opportunities\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a Opportunities\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/growth-opportunities\" data-title=\"Growth Opportunities\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words and pics &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/nancyvrichards.wordpress.com%20\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Nancy Richards&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;ZIPZAPPED&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thank the lord it\u2019s not me. A negative sentiment, true \u2013 but exactly what I felt as Jason and Signonne from New York plunge down 300m of steel cable off one narrow platform smack onto another on the opposite cliff face, 1000m up from sea level. I\u2019ve had the zipline experience, so am more than happy just to witness this time. Much easier to appreciate the drama of the surrounding mountain ranges and fynbos infinity without the distraction of rushing adrenalin. The Cape Canopy tour in Grabouw about an hour from Cape Town and in business since August last year, is in the heart of a pristine, previously inaccessible part of the Hottentots Holland Nature Reserve. It\u2019s also within the Kogelberg Biosphere Reserve, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, so you want to be looking around you. But if you\u2019re ziplining, you also want to be concentrating \u2013 gloved hand above the pulley, watch for the safety block, breathe, enjoy. There are eleven slides, between thirteen precipitous platforms, a swaying suspension bridge crossing a double waterfall - all the rush you can handle. \u2018You sure get to confront your fear\u2019 says Ellen from London, white knuckling on the bumpy truck ride back down to base camp.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Green%20Spots%20Cape%20Canopy%20tour%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;LINE &amp; SINKER \u2013 getting ready to fly on the Cape Canopy zipline.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Some hours later Jason and Signonne return &nbsp;as well exhilarated if exhausted. Over tea, conservationist in charge Ryan Larkman explains the low environmental impact of the zipline. \u2018We could dismantle the whole thing tomorrow and you wouldn\u2019t know it\u2019s been there.\u2019 But if you\u2019d done it, you sure wouldn\u2019t forget. Nor the view neither.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;WHERE:&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;Hottentots Holland Nature Reserve &nbsp;capecanopytour.co.za &nbsp;021 300 0501&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;HERITAGEABLES&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;On my way through the Company\u2019s Garden, headed for the city\u2019s latest honey pot \u2013 the recently upgraded restaurant, I detour through the smart new burgeoning veg patch. Not quite leaning against his pitchfork but very relaxed, was John Jonkers, one of a handful of gardeners seeing to the area designed to evoke the Dutch East India Company\u2019s original 17th century \u2018VOC\u2019 vegetable garden. \u2018It\u2019s all about heritage,\u2019 he says, affectionately tweaking a leaf. &nbsp;It\u2019s been developed jointly by City Parks and the Heritage Resources Management Dept. But it\u2019s not just a nod to history. Manager and horticulturalist Rory Phelan says, \u2018it\u2019s to promote the idea of urban agriculture to a wider audience.\u2019 Under nets against &nbsp;squirrels and Egyptian geese, there are healthy Peter Rabbitesque rows of lettuce, chives, chillies etc as well as old timers like artichokes and beetroot, but long term the plan is to source \u2018heirloom\u2019 seed that pre-date the days of hybridisation and have \u2018inherent immunity to disease.\u2019&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Green%20Spots%20Company%27s%20Garden.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;GOOD COMPANY \u2013 old methods of new growing.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The layout is a miniaturised version of the original quadrilateral design and as in the past, watering is done with a leiwater irrigation system from a Table Mountain spring. There\u2019s a berry garden, orchards of good old fashioned quinces, apples, pears, peaches and plums grown espalier style as well as beds of indigenous medicinal plants. \u2018When the settlers came here they didn\u2019t have any medical supplies, so they had to take a leaf out of Khoisan tradition.\u2019 There are lots of green lessons to be learned here. In partnership with Woolworths, there are plans to run educational courses and if you fancy sampling the wares, there\u2019s also talk of a \u2018garden table\u2019 at the Company\u2019s Garden Restaurant so you can choose your own salad. In the meantime, refurbished by the Madame Zingara team who have a feel for Cape Town\u2019s pulse, the restaurant is pulling the crowds. Not just for their menu (a big improvement on the old Tea Room\u2019s toasted sarnies) but for the eco-playground toys in the yard \u2013 giant nests, basket swings and carved giant tortoises. What\u2019s not to love!&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;WHERE:&lt;\/strong&gt; The Company\u2019s Garden capetown.gov.za\/en\/park 021 436 1357&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Green%20Spots%20Company%27s%20Nest.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"323\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;NESTING INSTINCT \u2013 playground toys at the Company\u2019s Garden Restaurant.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;SPOTTING AND SHOPPING&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019d steeled myself to do some shopping at Canal Walk in Century City. A throbbing temple of consumerism where I did what I had to do, quickly. This left time for an exploratory visit to Intaka Island, a 16ha nature reserve and wetland minutes away from the Babel of buying in the midst of a seriously commercial landscape. Although they pay for it in levies, it\u2019s a treasure for those who live and work in the area, but for most of us who haunt the malls or thunder past on the freeway it\u2019s a well kept secret. Accessed from a wooden bridge from the mainland, the island is a serene network of walk and waterways. Back in 1996 when Century City was a just a twinkle in the developer\u2019s eye, it was the result of an Environmental Impact Assessment recommendation and has been born out of the original pans and sandplains.But nearly twenty years on it feels like more than just a compliant tick box.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Green%20Spots%20Intaka%20Island%20ferry.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"323\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;FERRY COOL \u2013 take a ride on the waterways around Intaka Island.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For the droves of birds who hang out there it\u2019s a five star destination with reed beds, endless nesting opportunity, two custom-built heronries for roosting and breeding and a playground of purified water \u2018polished\u2019 by a natural filtration system. It scores as a people pleaser too \u2013 resting benches, shady viewing spots, an educational centre, swathes of indigenous fynbos including 24 red data species and &nbsp;two bird hides trained on waders, kingfishers, darters and coots. In one a twitcher and his zoom lens were settled &nbsp;in for the long haul. You can walk all or some of the 45 minute nature trail by yourself or go with a guide, you can also get the best of both worlds by taking the hop-on hop-off ferry that plies the canals \u2013 and takes you back to the shops if you get withdrawals. &nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;WHERE:&lt;\/strong&gt; Century City intaka.co.za 021 552 6889&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;SUNSPOT&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There\u2019s a running group that once a year organises a special trot down from Signal Hill and up to Tafelberg Road on Table Mountain. Bit of a killer, especially the return journey. But what it offered this year was the opportunity to see the SunStar up close. This angular artwork has been mired in controversy. \u2018Blight on the skyline\u2019, \u2019is it art if it\u2019s sponsored\u2019, \u2019is it art anyway', \u2019.....\u2019 You know how Capetonians like to whinge. But what is it?&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Green%20Spots%20Sunstar.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I circled it a number of times, took some pics, put my nose into the shipping container supporting the 21 solar panels and dozen or so batteries and read the inspiring message on the side: \u2018.... beacon of hope forged from the repurposed fence that used to surround Robben Island.\u2019 None the wiser, later I called designer Christopher Swift for the back story. \u2019The intention was to invite people to see challenges from a different point of view.\u2019 He quotes Einstein to the effect, \u2018We can\u2019t solve our problems with the same thinking we used to create them...\u2019 His own thinking is that the day of the costly, solid granite monuments dominating precious space is over, that art can be a moveable, flexible feast and that it should be free and accessible to all. It can also be lighter on the earth if it\u2019s made out of reclaimed materials.&nbsp;Back in 2009 Swift took possession of some fencing from Robben Island that was on its way to the landfill. \u2018I wanted to use it to create something positive \u2013 jobs, art, hope. \u2018 Sunstar uses some of that fencing, it also uses geo-screws to pin it to the ground so that it can be dismantled without leaving an environmental footprint. It\u2019s lit by solar powered long-lasting LED lights. \u2018The original idea\u2019, says Swift, \u2018was that when its time was up, those lights could be donated to homes where they\u2019d be useful.\u2019 But since the artwork was adopted by Sun International, those decisions and its long term journey are out of his hands. Jacques de Bruin project manager of Sunstar picks up the message, \u2018It\u2019s all about having vision, looking \u2018beyond the fence.\u2019 SunStar will stay on Signal Hill till May, maybe longer \u2013 watch that space.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;WHERE:&lt;\/strong&gt; Signal Hill suninternational.com\/sunstar&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Green%20Spots%20Soil%20for%20Life.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;GARDEN PATH \u2013 the abundant gardens at Soil for Life.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;WELL SOILED&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s not every day you get an invitation to an annual general meeting of Home Gardeners, so I was honoured to attend the one at Soil for Life\u2019s headquarters in Constantia sandwiched between the Waldorf School and Peddler\u2019s the pub. It was a bright, sunny day and delegates squeezed into the boomklass, chalet style multipurpose centre up next to the greenhouses, for the speeches and awards ceremony. Proceedings are led by growth guru Pat Featherstone, founder of Soil for Life, an organisation that promotes and teaches the principle of healthy soil for healthy vegetables for healthy people . SFL\u2019s own gardens epitomise the success of the principle. Flourishing would be an understatement. Vegetables burst out of creative beds, climb and creep across soil that has been fed, built and nurtured to be the very best.nThe creativity doesn\u2019t stop at the growing, there are benches, gazebos, a sundial, sculptures carved and constructed out of reclaimed wood and innovative growth experiments in progress. At the shop you can buy compost, vegetables, plant boxes, literature and more \u2013 but the inspiration is absolutely free.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;WHERE:&lt;\/strong&gt; Stables Lane, Brounger way, Constantia soilforlife.co.za 021 794 4982&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3116\"&gt;The Company's Garden&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/1354\"&gt;Century City&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9612\" class=\"publisher-1335 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/herd-act-follow\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;A Herd Act to Follow&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    A Herd Act to Follow  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"A Herd Act to Follow\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #222222' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/cl.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Wildlands%20M_0.jpg?itok=zR0F2wyV\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/herd-act-follow\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/herd-act-follow\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/herd-act-follow&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Wildlands%20M_0.jpg&amp;description=A Herd Act to Follow\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/herd-act-follow\" data-text=\"A Herd Act to Follow\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/herd-act-follow\" data-title=\"A Herd Act to Follow\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Andrea Abbott, pics Andrea Abbott and Supplied&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;High on remote Dartmoor we find a pastoral scene: a herd of Nguni cattle, their coats of many patterns lending contrast to the green landscape. Bright-hued, newborn calves, secure in the 188-strong crowd, peep out uncertainly as we mingle with the bovine throng.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In their midst, big daddy Stallone, a muscular, wide-horned fellow with not just a chip but a hell of a bump on his shoulder, holds us in his disconcerting gaze. \u201cHe won\u2019t charge, will he?\u201d I ask Donna Lay, manager of Dartmoor which, in case you\u2019re wondering, is not in England but is part of the 3 275ha Karkloof Nature Reserve in the KZN Midlands. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Stallone, I\u2019m reassured, has a stare far worse than his charge. Still, Ngunis are known for extreme protectiveness of their young and for their herd loyalty. \u201cIt\u2019s not easy to separate them,\u201d Donna says. This is evident when herdsmen and mounted rangers join forces and attempt to isolate a calf that requires an injection.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In a trice, the one-for-all and all-for-one principle kicks in. Tightly packed, shoulder to shoulder, the herd morphs into an impenetrable wall of muscle that surges this way and that, all the while bellowing oaths at the perceived assailants. I feel as if I\u2019m caught up in a Wild West movie. Eventually, calf is caught, muti administered, and he\u2019s released to join the herd that, insulted, hotfoots it down the hill to other pastures.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wildlands%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Donna Lay, manager of Dartmoor Farm, with her all-important herd of cherished Ngunis.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ngunis, South Africa\u2019s indigenous breed of cattle, are very much the in thing these days, their colour patterns making them a popular subject for artists, writers, interior decorators and photographers. But the Dartmoor herd is about more than pretty faces and eye-catching coats. They\u2019re a key part of the latest project by the Wildlands Conservation Trust, a KZN-based NGO that, in just a decade, has grown to become a major force in the national arena of biodiversity protection and community-based, poverty-alleviation programmes.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Their projects are many and varied and range from fitting rhinos with tracking devices to providing a platform for \u2018tree-preneurs\u2019 in impoverished communities to grow indigenous trees and trade them for goods such as food, building materials, bicycles, solar panels, and rainwater tanks.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Dartmoor Nguni project falls within the organisation\u2019s recently established Farming the Wild intervention, whose purpose is to develop viable businesses on conservation land in ways that help protect the ecological integrity of that land. In the case of the rich, biodiverse Dartmoor farm that Wildlands bought in 2010, to expand the Karkloof reserve.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cAn important area of Midlands mistbelt grassland is protected there,\u201d says Kevin McCann, the organisation\u2019s deputy director of conservation SPACE (Species, People and Conservation of the Environment). \u201cThis grassland type has lost 80 per cent of its original extent in other areas of the province. Those irreplaceable grasslands aside, Dartmoor is also important as a water-catchment area. It lies in the upper catchments of two provincially strategic river systems, the uMngeni and uThukela. Both have a large number of downstream users, including the major urban centres of Hillcrest, Pinetown and Durban.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wildlands%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Now that the veld at Dartmoor is improving, Wattled Cranes are returning to the area.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Other significant environmental assets are extensive wetland areas and a variety of threatened species. These include the endangered oribi antelope and Wattled Crane, and some increasingly rare wild flowers, among them &lt;em&gt;Watsonia canaliculata&lt;\/em&gt;, &lt;em&gt;Dierama luteoalbidum&lt;\/em&gt; and &lt;em&gt;Cryptocarya myrtifolia&lt;\/em&gt;.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As happens in nature, all these various elements are interconnected, and without one another might vanish. This is where the Ngunis come in. Their role is not so much to generate income (although they do that too), but to perform the vital ecological function of keeping the grasslands intact. Cattle as conservation tools might seem a far-fetched idea, but it\u2019s not unheard of. \u201cIt\u2019s the first time Wildlands is using cattle in this way,\u201d Kevin says, \u201cbut the project is not unique to Dartmoor. Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife and SANParks have in the past explored and used cattle in protected areas as a conservation-management tool. \u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The idea pivots on the fact that regular grazing keeps grasslands in good shape. At Dartmoor, a key grass species is the highly palatable (when young) red grass, &lt;em&gt;Themeda triandra&lt;\/em&gt;, which is one of the most important grazing grasses in Southern Africa. As a decreaser grass it\u2019s abundant in good veld but decreases when the veld is under- or overgrazed.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cWhen we began managing Dartmoor three years ago,\u201d Donna says, \u201cour focus was on removing countless snares, including gin traps, and stamping out illegal dog hunting \u2013 factors that had virtually decimated the oribi population as well as other grazers.\u201d Too few oribi and other antelope meant the red grass was not being utilised properly. This created a vicious cycle: ungrazed, the grass continued to grow while decreasing in palatability, to ultimately become moribund and thus lost.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Then, because of the accrued mass of combustible material, the risk of hazardous runaway fires increased significantly. In fact, late in 2014, on the eve of the arrival of the Ngunis, a massive fire swept through Dartmoor and neighbouring farms, destroying about 1 500 hectares of veld.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019d heard of the intensive grazing, no-burn approach that claims to perform wonders such as prevent desertification, and capture carbon and store it in grassland soils for thousands of years. But I\u2019d also heard opposing views, for example that such claims are unfounded and also that the trampling impact of mobs of heavy-hoofed cattle is detrimental to soils, water storage and plant productivity. Controlled burning, the latter camp argues, is the way to go.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Donna explains that managed burns will be done at Dartmoor, but that the Ngunis play a complementary role. A smaller breed than most other cattle, they\u2019re lighter on the land and, being indigenous, are well adapted to the conditions. \u201cThey\u2019re hardy, economical, resistant to tick-borne diseases, and easier to manage than other breeds,\u201d Donna points out.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another benefit is that regular grazing, in keeping the grass short, helps with controlled block burns, and therefore fire management. Essentially, then, the Ngunis are taking on the role of the oribi and other grazers that once occurred in healthy numbers on these mistbelt grasslands. And so, a link in the ecological chain has been more or less restored. Still, how tragic that the true connection has been severed, those dainty antelope almost wiped out, and other naturally occurring species also in decline.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But the story promises a happy ending. The Ngunis may be standing in for the oribi for now but, as the veld improves, habitats will begin to recover, beckoning once more the cranes (all three species \u2013 blue, grey crowned, and wattle \u2013 occur in the area) and other grassland dwellers, including the special flora. The snaring problem, now also under control thanks to the efforts of Donna and her hand-picked team, means that the once hunted \u2013 the oribi, reedbuck and other gentle grazers \u2013 can also start to return (already, there are indications of an increase in numbers) and, when they do, they\u2019ll find abundant grazing and, along with the Ngunis, will play their rightful part in protecting the biodiversity of the Midlands mistbelt grasslands. One for all, and all for one.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za\/a-herd-act-to-follow\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Country Life&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/CL%20Cover_7.jpg?itok=32bpdl5w\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Country Life&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9618\" class=\"publisher-1813 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/%C3%A0-bient%C3%B4t-avianto\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;\u00e0 bient\u00f4t, Avianto!&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    \u00e0 bient\u00f4t, Avianto!  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"\u00e0 bient\u00f4t, Avianto!\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/ride-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Avianto%20LM.jpg?itok=DVvytiR-\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/\u00e0-bient\u00f4t-avianto\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\"
