bient\u00f4t, Avianto!\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/\u00e0-bient\u00f4t-avianto\" data-text=\"\u00e0 bient\u00f4t, Avianto!\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/\u00e0-bient\u00f4t-avianto\" data-title=\"\u00e0 bient\u00f4t, Avianto!\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Andrew \u201cAverage Andy\u201d Steer&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Looking for the perfect marriage of mountain biking and hospitality? And convenience? And safety? Try the Tracker RideFree Avianto Bike Park in Muldersdrift. We did.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Avianto, in Muldersdrift in the Cradle of Humankind, is probably best known to the greater public as a world-class wedding and conference venue, but over the past few years it has rapidly risen to prominence as one of the best mountain-biking venues in Gauteng. The trails have been going for a couple of years now, but over the last year things have certainly kicked up a notch with the expansion of the park to add much-needed mileage by including sections in Phambili and the Syringa ruins.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Along with this, Avianto has partnered with Tracker since May 2014 in setting it up as a RideFree Bike park. Just like the Modderfontein RideFree Bike Park, that means exceptional route marking, good maintenance of the trails and lots of value-adds for the riders such as bike washes, Biogen hydration stations, standby medical emergency assistance (on Sundays) and even monthly skills clinics.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Avianto%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The Riding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;A lot of people will recognise the venue and trails at Avianto from the Eqstra Spring Classic and USN Cup races that are held there annually, along with the numerous trail runs that they host throughout the year. A large part of its popularity is the relatively easy access from both Johannesburg and Pretoria, and the superb facilities on offer. This, coupled with the recent expansion and upgrade of the trails, now leaves riders spoilt in terms of options and enjoyment.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Red Route&lt;\/strong&gt; \u2013 The red route, at 2.5km in length, is aimed mainly at the kiddies and offers a fun, safe little trip on the bike around the eastern side of Avianto. There is nothing technical and all the road crossings are avoided.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;White Route&lt;\/strong&gt; \u2013 Formerly the green route, this 6km route on the eastern side of the park is aimed at riders new to the sport and a bit short on fitness. The route again is very rider-friendly, featuring mainly jeep track and dirt roads, and with gradients that never get too severe. There is a little bit of climbing in parts, but the fun switchbacks and berms to be enjoyed on the way down will leave you smiling.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Green Route&lt;\/strong&gt; \u2013 Made up of two 12km sections on either side of the Crocodile River, this great little 24km route offers a nice option for fitter riders not too confident in the rougher stuff. There is still plenty of fun factor, with loads of singletrack, switchbacks, berms, climbs and descents littering the route. You also traverse a wide variety of terrains, passing dams, koppies, rivers, horse kraals and forests, all the while taking in some great views of the Cradle of Humankind.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Blue Route&lt;\/strong&gt; \u2013 The main event is the Blue route, again divided into two 17km sections on either side of the Crocodile River. The 34km total will give even the fit guys a great workout, as there is very little in the way of flat terrain in the area. It\u2019s basically just an extension of the Green route, with the additional mileage coming in the form of slightly tougher terrain and often harsher gradients. While it definitely is a grade up from the Green in most parts, we found the sections very rideable for us weekend warriors.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Black Route -&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;The Black is made up of occasional small sections that branch off the Blue and Green routes and offers the more serious riders a proper technical challenge, in terms of both skill and endurance. It\u2019s aimed at advanced riders, and you need to be strong and technically competent to take on these little sections, as the steep gradients and rocky nature of most of them will certainly leave you a little worse for wear should you come a cropper.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Overall Experience&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The partnership with Tracker in making this a RideFree Bike Park certainly adds to the professionalism of the whole experience. The trails are really well marked and the routes a breeze to follow.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Although there isn\u2019t a map as yet, with so many options available, and the routes broken down into so many sections, the options are limitless and can easily be tailored to suit riders\u2019 or groups\u2019 physical and technical abilities. All the routes\u2019 branching off one another also allow families and friends of different levels to enjoy part of their day out together.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The riding on the Eastern Avianto side is pretty tight and compact, owing to the smallish area available, but apart from a little switchback sandwich at the start (having also run these may slightly distort my view), you seldom get the feeling of \u201cmaking up the distance\u201d.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The riding to the west over the Crocodile River is, however, a slightly different beast, and the terrain opens up a bit more, with some longer climbs, great singletrack and great vistas in and around Phambili and the old Syringa ruins.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;And when you\u2019re finished, grab a beer, cool down in the pool and enjoy a well-earned meal within the confines of one of Gauteng\u2019s most luxurious estates. Is there a better place to get the whole family on to their bikes and enjoying their Sundays together?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Avianto%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Cycling hours&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trails are open every day of the week from 6am to 6pm. During the quieter week times, trail passes (bands) can be bought from the main Avianto Reception (500m away from the trail head, just across the river), or else during peak times (weekends and public holidays), they are available for purchase from the Avianto clubhouse, from which all the trails start.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Weather&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trail is pretty exposed in most parts, so protection from the sun is pretty much a necessity all year round. The course holds up fairly well to rain, so apart from the occasional slippery rocks in the technical sections and the odd muddy patch, our famed Highveld thunderstorms don\u2019t hinder the riding conditions too badly.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Riding Rates&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;R40 for a single entry&lt;br&gt;Multiple pass cards to be implemented in the near future.&lt;br&gt;R700 for a yearly pass&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Get there&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Avianto Estate Clubhouse, Villa Street, 2067 Muldersdrift, Gauteng, South Africa&lt;br&gt;GPS: S 26 01\u2019 35\u201d and E 27 50\u2019 40\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Directions to the Avianto Club House&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;From Johannesburg:&lt;\/strong&gt; Turn on to the M5 Beyers Naude (away from Northcliff towards Honeydew). Carry on straight for approximately 12km, passing Garden World on your right. Look out for a left turn onto the R114 Muldersdrift. Pass Carnivore restaurant on your right. Take the first road right (St Antonio\u2019s), then first left into Villa Street, and go under the bridge. Turn right at the circle, then turn left at the first gravel road.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;From Pretoria:&lt;\/strong&gt; Take the R28 towards Krugersdorp, pass the Lanseria\/Randburg &nbsp;and Zwartkop\/Randburg off-ramps, take the Muldersdrift\/Driefontein off-ramp at the bottom of a long hill. At the four-way stop, go straight. Then take the first left into St Antonio\u2019s, the next left into Villa Street, and go under the bridge. Turn right at the circle, then turn left at the first gravel road.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;From Roodepoort:&lt;\/strong&gt; Travel west down Hendrik Potgieter until Cradlestone mall. Turn right after the mall onto the N14. Take the first off-ramp, signboard Muldersdrift\/Driefontein. Turn right straight away to head back under the highway. Turn left at the four-way stop, then first left into St Antonio\u2019s, next left into Villa street and go under the bridge. Turn right at the circle, then turn left at the first gravel road.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Other Attractions&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Trail running&lt;br&gt;Tennis courts&lt;br&gt;Squash courts&lt;br&gt;Footgolf&lt;br&gt;Swimming pool&lt;br&gt;Picnic areas&lt;br&gt;Braai facilities&lt;br&gt;Unique functions and markets&lt;br&gt;Hotel&lt;br&gt;Caf\u00e9 Cielo&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Facilities&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;You\u2019ll struggle to find better facilities at any MTB venue in SA. There is ample parking, a beautiful clubhouse with great views, a pool to cool down in, showers to clean up in, a fully licensed bar, the option to picnic by the river or strike up a braai and even a kiddies\u2019 play area. And if the trails have taken too much out of you, you can just order some scrumptious grub from Caf\u00e9 Cielo while sipping a beer and taking in the great view. Over weekends there is a bike wash and hydration station, and on Sundays there is even full medical support from ER24, courtesy of Tracker.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Contacts&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Avianto Tracker RideFree Bike Park&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;Cell: 083 600 1289&lt;br&gt;Email: &lt;a href=\"mailto:richard@ilumin8.co.za\"&gt;richard@ilumin8.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;Website: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.ilumin8events.com\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.ilumin8events.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;Facebook: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/aviantotrails\"&gt;www.facebook.com\/aviantotrails&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/TrackerRideFree\"&gt;www.facebook.com\/TrackerRideFree&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;Twitter: TrackerRideFree&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Avianto&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Telephone: 011-668-3000&lt;br&gt;Email: &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@avianto.co.za\"&gt;info@avianto.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;Website: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.avianto.co.za\"&gt;www.avianto.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.ride.co.za\/training\/where-to-ride-rides\/a-bientot-avianto\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ride Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.ride.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/2342.png.png?itok=CoLDB6n4\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Ride&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9760\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/iron-ways-hikes-and-ferrata-italian-dolomites\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Iron Ways - Hikes and Via Ferrata in the Italian Dolomites&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Iron Ways - Hikes and Via Ferrata in the Italian Dolomites  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Iron Ways - Hikes and Via Ferrata in the Italian Dolomites\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Dolomites.jpg?itok=gmeII812\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/iron-ways-hikes-and-ferrata-italian-dolomites\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/iron-ways-hikes-and-ferrata-italian-dolomites\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/iron-ways-hikes-and-ferrata-italian-dolomites&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20Dolomites.jpg&amp;description=Iron Ways - Hikes and Via Ferrata in the Italian Dolomites\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/iron-ways-hikes-and-ferrata-italian-dolomites\" data-text=\"Iron Ways - Hikes and Via Ferrata in the Italian Dolomites\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/iron-ways-hikes-and-ferrata-italian-dolomites\" data-title=\"Iron Ways - Hikes and Via Ferrata in the Italian Dolomites\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics James Rushforth&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The peaks of the Dolomites are characteristically steep, with huge faces and towering summits often breaching 3000m in altitude. These stunning spires of alpine limestone are located south of the Austrian \/ Italian border and the mountainous area extends for 80km east of the town of Bolzano.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Whilst on first appearances the landscape may appear a little intimidating, the area is actually surprisingly accessible. Well-marked and clearly defined paths weave between the Dolomite monoliths, whilst iron cables or \u2018via ferrata\u2019 provide access to some of the world\u2019s most striking summits, allowing you to move quickly over technical ground that would normally require a rope.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Venice airport provides the most common means of access to the Dolomites from outside Europe; this beautiful and unique city is a worthy destination in itself and definitely worth combining with a trip to the Dolomites. Once there, there are many possible accommodation options in the various towns and hamlets offering a unique mix of Italian and Austrian culture. Corvara in the Val Badia and Cortina d\u2019Ampezzo are two of many possible bases, offering a range of amenities, amazing scenery and superb access to some of the best walking and via ferrata in the area.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Dolomites%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Here are a few route recommendations that can easily be accessed from either of the two towns:&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Hiking recommendations&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The hiking in the Dolomites is exceptionally accessible with well-marked and clearly defined paths, offering a nearly unlimited supply of possible routes. Here are a few of my favourites:&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Cinque Torri&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Nestled between the Falzarego and Giau Passes the famous five towers of Cinque Torri are a worthy holiday destination in their own right, offering some of the best walking and scenery in the area. Walks usually start from Rifugio Bai de Dones and the Cinque Torri chairlift car park situated on the Falzarego pass. From here a beautiful walk up through woodland (or chairlift ride) leads to the towers themselves. You can then follow a series of First World War Trenches with much historic interest between the towers themselves before returning back down to the pass by one of a number of possible descents. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Dolomites%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Lago di Sorapiss&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Sorapiss Group forms a horseshoe of steep rock walls that are only open to the north. At their base lies the beautiful Lago di Sorapiss, one of the most striking lakes in the Dolomites with its amazing turquoise colour. The walk up from the Giau pass to much-needed refreshments at Rifugio Vandelli is long and demanding but scenically stunning. For those keen to explore this area further it is possible to complete three consecutive via ferrata around the lake using Bivacco Slataper or Bivacco Comici for an overnight stay. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Tre Cime&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The famous trinity of the Tre Cime is the iconic symbol of the Dolomites and much coveted by people from all over the world. By taking the toll road up from Misurina to Rifugio Auronzo you can remove much of the height gain. An anti-clockwise circuit of the towers via Rifugio Lavaredo provides stunning views of the north faces, the central of which, Cima Grande, forms one of the six classic north faces of the Alps. The circuit can then be completed by walking under Cima Ovest back to Rifugio Auronzo. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Dolomites%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Padon Ridge and the \u2018Viel dal Pan\u2019&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Padon Ridge separates the Fedaia and Pordoi passes and is rich in history. The path running parallel to the ridge was once an ancient traders\u2019 route known as the 'Viel dal Pan', used to transport flour between the local valleys. Towards the end of the 19th century the route was rediscovered by the German Karl Bindel, thus giving rise to its second name, \u2018Bindelweg'. Today it is possible to follow the old trade route along the ridge starting from the top of the Pordoi Pass and traversing to Rifugio Luigi Gorza and the Arabba Portavescovo cablecar station, from where you can descend easily to the village. Throughout the walk you get spectacular views of the north face of the Marmolada, the highest peak in the Dolomites at 3343m.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Lago di Lagacio \/ Fanis&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Fanis Massif is a spectacular and rarely frequented group to the east of the Val Badia and west of Cortina. Departing from Rifugio Capanna Alpina just outside of Armentarola it is possible to ascend the dramatic Fanis Valley before descending a steep pass between Cima del Lago and Cima Scotoni down to the superbly situated Lago di Lagacio. The descent then continues down to Rifugio Scotoni (offering some of the best food in the area), before returning back to Capanna Alpina. &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Dolomites%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Via Ferrata and route recommendations&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;A via ferrata in its most basic form is a metal (originally iron - now more commonly steel) wire that runs up the mountain, allowing climbers to attach themselves to it for safety and also providing a means of artificial aid to assist with difficult sections. There are also ladders, unlikely suspension bridges, stemples (large staples in the rock), steps and walkways to further assist upwards progression. The term 'via ferrata' originates from 'via attrezzata', which means 'fully equipped road \/route\u2019 whilst common English translations cite 'iron way', 'iron road' or 'iron path\u2019. Whilst there are some via ferrata that predate 1914 the majority of the routes were established during the First World War providing a hugely historic significance to the routes enjoyed today.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Dolomites are particularly famous for their via ferrata, boasting the highest concentration of routes in the world. There are simply too many to create a \u2018best of\u2019 list, however here are a few recommendations if you\u2019re in the area:&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Piz da Cir V (VF2A)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A short but interesting via ferrata that is ideal for those looking for a half day out or to try a via ferrata for the first time. Despite being relatively short in via ferrata terms, because it departs from the top of the Gardena Pass, it still reaches an impressive height of 2500m. This affords spectacular views into the Val de Chedul, across to the Sella and of the impressive nearby Sassolungo group. The rock quality is excellent and provides interesting climbing at a consistent level.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Dolomites%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Brigata Tridentina (VF3B)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A fantastic via ferrata and the extremely popular classic of the Val Badia and Gardena area. During peak season it is worth getting on the wire very early or waiting until the afternoon if you want to avoid the crowds. The rock is good and the climbing varied. The hardest moves come towards the end, before the spectacular bridge crossing between Torre Exner and the Mur de Pisciad\u00f9.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Sentiero Massimiliano \/ Laurenzi-Molignon (VF2B \/ VF4C)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This remote pair of via ferrata will appeal to those looking for a bit of solitude and can be combined with an overnight stay in the lovely Rifugio Alpe di Tires. Sentiero Massimiliano is an easy and fairly unprotected ridge scramble above the Alpi di Siusi plateau, whilst Laurenzi-Molignon follows the seldom frequented Molignon ridge just north of the Catinaccio group, with some difficult down climbing. &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Marmolada West Ridge (VF3D)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This via ferrata is fairly unique in the area in that it crosses the Ghiacciaio della Marmolada, as such requiring a reasonable amount of alpine experience. The route is graded VF3D, indicating a moderate technical difficulty whilst being serious in nature. The cable ascends the superbly situated west ridge up to the summit of Punta Penia, the highest peak in the Dolomites at 3343m, offering tantalising glimpses down the huge south face as you progress.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Dolomites%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Via delle Trincee\/La Mesola (VF4B)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This historic route (way of the trenches) is an unusual via ferrata, taking the form of a traverse along the Padon ridge and developing on conglomerate rock as opposed to the surrounding limestone and dolomite. The views down to the village of Arabba and across to the Marmolada North Face are superb; throw in some atmospheric tunnels and even an original canon dating back to the First World War and you have a superb itinerary.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Punta Anna (VF5B)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is one of my favourite via ferrata and follows a ridge system north from Rifugio Pomedes, over the top of Punta Anna and to the summit of Tofana di Mezzo (3244m), the third highest peak in the Dolomites. The climbing is aesthetic on solid rock, whilst the situations and exposure are fantastic. The views are such that it feels like you can see the entire Dolomites on a clear day, not to mention a good amount of Austria. However given that much of it takes place above 3000m in a remote environment, the route should not be underestimated. The climbing is also fairly strenuous with some big exposure, particularly on the several traverse sections.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Dolomites%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Ski Club 18 (VF5B)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This via ferrata was equipped in 2009 and is one of the hardest in the area, being of comparable difficulty to Cesare Piazetta and Magnifici Quattro. The climbing is steep and sustained, requiring good fitness. Being such a new via ferrata there are still sections that need cleaning, but the flip side of this is a wonderful lack of polish. With the aid of the Faloria cable car the approach is relatively short and the descent non-existent, making it an ideal half-day out from Cortina.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Multi day trekking&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;For those seeking a longer and more demanding experience there are eight \u2018Alta Via\u2019; the Haute Routes of the Dolomites weave their way through the range incorporating high walking trails, sections of protected paths and via ferrata. Combined with overnight stays in the region\u2019s beautiful rifugios they provide a unique way in which to experience the Dolomites, taking you on a traverse through this beautiful and unique mountain group.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;James Ruthforth is the author of &lt;em&gt;The Dolomites : Rock Climbs and Via Ferrata&lt;\/em&gt;, which can be purchased online at &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.rockfax.com\/climbing-guides\/all\/the-dolomites-rock-climbs-and-via-ferrata\"&gt;www.rockfax.com\/climbing-guides\/all\/the-dolomites-rock-climbs-and-via-fe...&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Dolomites%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"800\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9851\" class=\"publisher-4076 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/land-shipwrecks-and-farms\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Land of Shipwrecks and Farms&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Land of Shipwrecks and Farms  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Land of Shipwrecks and Farms\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.travelideas.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #f69220' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Travel%20Ideas%20s.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Strandveld%20M.jpg?itok=K4Gi0jmi\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/land-shipwrecks-and-farms\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/land-shipwrecks-and-farms\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/land-shipwrecks-and-farms&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Strandveld%20M.jpg&amp;description=Land of Shipwrecks and Farms\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/land-shipwrecks-and-farms\" data-text=\"Land of Shipwrecks and Farms\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/land-shipwrecks-and-farms\" data-title=\"Land of Shipwrecks and Farms\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Franki Black&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Conrad Vlok, winemaker and manager of the Strandveld Winery, doesn\u2019t understand how it\u2019s possible for anyone not to know their neighbour. In the Strandveld, where he comes from, neighbours sample wine together, they fish together and they celebrate catch of the day by opening another bottle of top-notch wine. Dirk Human, Conrad\u2019s friend who lives five kilometres down the road, sums it up perfectly, \u201cWhen a newcomer moves to the area, we arrange a party so that he or she can meet everyone.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The low-lying Strandveld is situated between Gansbaai, Cape Agulhas and Bredasdorp. Its soil is fertile, its koppies overflow with springs and it offers country living coupled with coastal wonder. Perhaps the most remarkable part of the Strandveld is its history. Since the 1400\u2019s ships have been wrecked along its treacherous coastline and legends about castaways, heroes, salvage missions and the odd ghost abound. Nearby towns like Struisbaai, Cape Agulhas and Hermanus have modernized (often undesirably) at an astonishing rate and over December it is hard to buy bread at the local shop. Venture a few kilometers inland to the Strandveld and you\u2019ll find quiet wine farms, walking trails, historic cottages and the Black Oystercatcher, a restaurant that prides itself on serving cuisine sourced within a 50-km radius. The Strandveld is so close to the sea that you can wake up on a farm, drive 20-minutes and spend the day on the beach.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Strandveld%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The Strandveld Winery&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We leave Cape Town on a Friday afternoon and two and a half hours later, we arrive at Africa\u2019s southern-most winery, Strandveld. It\u2019s pitch dark outside. Conrad emerges from a cottage dating back to the 1800\u2019s with a torch and a warm welcome. Good company and a traditional farm dinner await. \u201cFishing is big in these parts,\u201d says Conrad with a knowing smile. It\u2019s hard to imagine that we\u2019re so close to the sea, but freshly-caught mussel-cracker sizzles on the braai. Fishing is Conrad\u2019s third love. His first is his wife Suzan and their two children, and his second is winemaking. \u201cWe started making wine here in 2005. At the time it was a bit of a gamble, as no one had made wine in the Strandveld before,\u201d Conrad explains as he fills our glasses with delicious Shiraz Ros\u00e9. Local conditions proved perfect for winemaking - fertile soil, a cool climate and a hefty ocean breeze \u2013 and since humble beginnings, Conrad has gone on to win a Veritas Double Gold medal, as well as a Gold medal at the International Wine &amp; Spirit Competition for his 2010 Strandveld Sauvignon Blanc. Both his Sauvignon Blanc and his 2009 Strandveld Adamastor received 5-star ratings in Platter\u2019s South African Wine Guide.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The evening turns merry, as Suzan presents a spread of traditional goodness: venison pie, freshly-baked bread, lamb chops, broccoli in white sauce, followed by flamb\u00e9ed pancakes. \u201cYou have to choose a fatty chop,\u201d recommends Conrad. \u201cHere in the Overberg we have the best lamb chops in South Africa.\u201d Conrad and Suzan have lived on the farm for ten years and they still think it is heaven. The conversation turns to shipwrecks. \u201cTomorrow I\u2019ll take you to the top of a koppie \u2013 you\u2019ll be able to see where the Atlantic and Indian oceans meet,\u201d Conrad says. He tells us about a three-day shipwreck trail that passes close to his farm. On this route hikers can see the remnants of ships like the Mishu Maru 38, a fishing trawler that sank near Cape Agulhas, and Africa\u2019s southernmost point.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Strandveld%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As the fire flickers, Suzan urges Conrad to tell us about his award-winning Rh\u00f4ne blend, the Strandveld Navigator. \u201cWe named this wine after Prince Henry the Navigator \u2013 the Patron of early Portuguese exploration. Like the handful of winemakers in the Strandveld, he was one of the first to explore the secrets around Africa\u2019s southernmost tip,\u201d he notes. Conrad is a born host and next he ushers us to a vertical tasting of Syrah. He has six glasses lined up for each person. We taste our way from 2006 to 2011. I gulp down heavenly tones of mocha, red berry and pepper.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the morning we wake up to Overberg bliss: a lawn ideal for cricket, chickens cackling, morning light on a cellar and dirt roads waiting to be explored. Conrad leads the run to Pofadder Bos, his Sauvignon Blanc vineyard. He shows us the unique red colour of the soil. Trailed by three adoring dogs, we carefully jog past a herd of dubious cows and make our way through fields of fynbos. We\u2019re amazed by the generous display of proteas. They all look like they\u2019ve been to the hairdresser for a perm. From the top of the koppie, stretches of farmlands, marshlands and coastline lie before us. On the way back, Conrad points out his, and Africa\u2019s, southernmost vineyard. \u201cRemember the four S\u2019s,\u201d he says in reference to his best-selling First Sighting Sauvignon Blanc, \u201cSingle-vineyard, Southern-most, Strandveld and Sauvignon Blanc.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The Black Oystercatcher&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Strandveld\u2019s food philosophy rivals culinary approaches in top foodie destinations like San Francisco and France. Every bite has a story attached to it: either the fish was caught on the same day in Struisbaai or the greens were grown on the land you\u2019re standing on. Dirk spotted the uniqueness of the Strandveld\u2019s culinary scene and decided to make it accessible to more people. In 2008 he opened the Black Oystercatcher, a family-run restaurant that celebrates homegrown food and local culture.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Strandveld%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We drive five minutes down the road to meet Dirk. Immediately it\u2019s apparent that he is the alpha-male of the Strandveld. If he\u2019s not making wine, he\u2019s introducing hippos to the area and building landing-strips for small airplanes. &nbsp;He also chairs the 25-farmer strong Nuwejaars Special Management Area project, aimed at conserving the Strandveld through social, agricultural and environmental initiatives. He loves the Strandveld and fondly recalls childhood memories of camping next to a close-by dam. Today, this very dam is where five hippos live that Dirk reintroduced to the area after 150 years. The Black Oystercatcher restaurant sits where the farm\u2019s stables used to be, but Dirk and his equally innovative wife, Sandra, managed to turn it into a space that radiates style and country luxury. Dirk presents us with a lineup of wines to taste. \u201cWinemaking is straightforward,\u201d he says. \u201cYou just have to follow a recipe.\u201d Dirk\u2019s \u201crecipes\u201d prove to be sensational. He recalls the weather conditions of every vintage, while we sip full-bodied Merlot, tropical Sauvignon Blanc and dry, crisp Ros\u00e9. For lunch, we snack on a platter of pastrami, local cheeses, figs and chicken liver, followed by black mussels and a homemade burger. I\u2019m ready to give up city living for the Strandveld.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Situated close to holiday hotspots like Hermanus, the Black Oystercatcher is the ideal spot for a casual lunch or a special occasion. During December, Dirk hosts a number of events like a Sauvignon Blanc Festival and an Oyster Festival. Their most popular event is the Traditional Food and Music Day hosted on the 29th of December. &nbsp;\u201cWe serve &lt;em&gt;boerekos&lt;\/em&gt; and Oom Manie and his band show up to entertain the crowd,\u201d Dirk explains. Oom Manie is apparently 82-years old and his choice of drink is vodka and water. Another favourite event in the area is the 1km braai that takes place on Dirk\u2019s landing strip every year on Heritage Day \u2013 the local farmers are hoping to turn it into a big event. Besides food and wine, the Strandveld is an outdoor enthusiast\u2019s paradise. It is home to an astonishing variety of birds and from the Black Oystercatcher, kilometres of hiking and biking trails start. Dirk tells us about the historic paraffin route that passes through his farm. During the 1800\u2019s, lighthouse keepers used to traverse this route with boxes of paraffin to keep lighthouse lamps burning.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Shipwreck Territory&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019m intrigued by the Strandveld and its lively history. That evening we huddle around a log fire crackling in our cottage and I start to read a Strandveld coffee-table book out loud. We\u2019re transported to the &lt;em&gt;Arniston&lt;\/em&gt;, a ship that was wrecked along the coast in 1815 while making its way to England. &nbsp;Due to outdated navigational tools, the captain was under the impression that they had passed Cape Point. As a result, they headed north prematurely and hit rocks 800 metres from the shore. Only 6 out of 378 people survived. I continue reading about hidden treasures, onboard slave revolts, murders fueled by jealousy, drunken sailors and missions gone wrong. As I fall asleep that night, I think about all the people who have perished along this coast known as the Graveyard of Ships.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Just before bidding Conrad farewell, I tell him that the Strandveld - with its wholesome foods, its shipwreck trails and its gorgeous wines - can really become a tourist hotspot. He knows it, but I get the sense that he wishes he could keep it as unspoiled as it is right now for a little while longer. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Eat and Sleep&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Strandveld Guest Cottages:&lt;\/strong&gt; +27 (0)28 482 1906;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"mailto:info@strandveld.co.za\"&gt;info@strandveld.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;, &lt;a class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;h2&gt;Come and meet your favourite Adventurers!&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The votes are in, the judges have spoken. Now it\u2019s time to have some fun\u2026 We would love to see you all at the Cape Union Mart Canal Walk Adventure Centre, a fitting venue for an evening filled with tales of daring shenanigans and intrepid expeditions.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/capeunionmart.formstack.com\/forms\/nightjaradventurer2015\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Click here to RSVP&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Date: 28 May 2015&lt;br&gt;Venue: Cape Union Mart Canal Walk Adventure Centre (Cape Town)&lt;br&gt;Time: 18:15 for 18:30&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After the announcement, some awesome prizes by &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.buffwear.com\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Buff&lt;\/a&gt;, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.seatosummit.com\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Sea To Summit&lt;\/a&gt;, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.cascadedesigns.com\/msr\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;MSR&lt;\/a&gt; and &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.powertraveller.com\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;PowerTraveller &lt;\/a&gt;will be presented, and both the Reader\u2019s Choice and the title winner of Nightjar Adventurer 2015 will give a short talk about their expedition. Afterwards, there will be plenty of opportunity to mingle with all the contenders over a glass of wine and finger foods.&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/A%202015%20logo%20s_0.jpg?itok=QMKoQFTc\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Adventurer 2015&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9759\" class=\"publisher-2376 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/subaru-xvs-go-wild-ones\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Subaru XVs On the Go - The Wild Ones&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Subaru XVs On the Go - The Wild Ones  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Subaru XVs On the Go - The Wild Ones\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/wheels-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%20Subaru.jpg?itok=8Y1W5scX\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/subaru-xvs-go-wild-ones\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/subaru-xvs-go-wild-ones\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/subaru-xvs-go-wild-ones&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%20Subaru.jpg&amp;description=Subaru XVs On the Go - The Wild Ones\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/subaru-xvs-go-wild-ones\" data-text=\"Subaru XVs On the Go - The Wild Ones\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/subaru-xvs-go-wild-ones\" data-title=\"Subaru XVs On the Go - The Wild Ones\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;May 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Danie Botha, pics Jannie Herbst&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;To some observers the Subaru XV may be just another pretend-pretend 4x4 that is really an accountant-type sheep in dingo\u2019s clothing. They\u2019d be wrong. There is much more to the XV 4x4 than meets the eye, and if you add some minor upgrades to the deal\u2026 well, then it turns into something a little bit wild.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;A little road trip to kick things off\u2026&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;It all started in June, 2014. There we were, driving on a deserted dirt road, snaking its way towards Sodwana Bay, KwaZulu-Natal. We were in a stock standard Subaru XV, and on a mission to drive from Sodwana on the country's east coast, using back roads where possible, all the way to Kleinzee on the West Coast. The total distance would be around 4500km.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But our adventure seemed doomed even before it had started. About 50km from Sodwana, the left rear tyre called it quits, the sidewall cut by a sharp rock. We changed the tyre in the dark, and thankfully the XV does come with a full-size spare wheel.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next morning the tyre was fixed with some strong &lt;em&gt;muti&lt;\/em&gt;, courtesy of a Sodwana-based repair shop. But with the standard low-profile tyres fitted to the beautiful 17-inch alloy rims, we were rather worried about picking up more punctures. On a 4500km trip, that seemed inevitable.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Meanwhile, we'd been impressed by the XV\u2019s comfort and the \u201csporty\u201d feel that is virtually a Subaru patent. It's not that the XV is fast. The two-litre Boxer engine does not breathe through a turbocharger, and it develops a mild 110 kW and 197 Nm of torque (at a high 4200r\/min). Power is permanently sent to all four wheels via Subaru\u2019s Lineartronic continuously variable transmission.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;CVT gearbox technology seems to be all the rage these days, and partnered with Subaru\u2019s turbodiesel engine it really is awesome in application. In the XV it is OK, but maybe not great, mostly because there is not so much low-end torque to work with.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Subaru%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As the days and kilometres on that trip flew past, we came to appreciate the Scooby\u2019s comfort, that sporty edge, its entertaining yet solid performance on most gravel roads and the frugal fuel consumption.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With the Lineartronic gearbox spinning the engine in its most efficient range for the conditions, the XV needed an average of 8,8 litres\/100km.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the final leg of our journey, on a dirt road nearing Kleinzee, another small issue became apparent: the low-profile tyres did not appreciate big corrugations. Instead of absorbing the continuous bumps, the jolts reverberated through the cabin, seemingly shaking everything to pieces.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the end &lt;em&gt;That&lt;\/em&gt; &lt;em&gt;4x4 Show&lt;\/em&gt; presenter Tumelo Maketekete and I completed the journey without any further problems or incidents. And amazingly, those 235\/55 R17 tyres, with their very commendable grip in corners but a less absorbing performance on a heavily corrugated dirt road, managed to avoid any more punctures.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Time for a nip &amp; tuck!&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The desert khaki Subaru XV was due to stay with us for a year, and with that 4500km trip behind us, we had some ideas on how to improve this nifty little 4x4.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But before we get to those upgrades, just some numbers and information to demonstrate that this car is actually a lot more capable in the rough than you might think.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Firstly, it has 220mm ground clearance, which is not just a thumb-suck number as is often the case with over-enthusiastic marketing department copy writers. And all the suspension components and other mechanical bits are neatly tucked away out of harm\u2019s way under the vehicle, so you can go places in the XV that you would not be able to tackle in other cross-breed hatches.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Secondly, there is Subaru\u2019s famous symmetrical AWD system \u2013 comprising a longitudinally mounted, horizontally opposed Boxer engine (flat four layout) and a symmetrically designed 4WD drivetrain.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Subaru%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Lineartronic model gets the Active Torque Split AWD system, which normally sends 60% of the horses to the front wheels, and 40% to the rear axle. Sensors constantly monitor all parameters, including vehicle speed and grip levels on all four wheels. An electronically controlled multi-plate transfer (MP-T) system then adjusts the torque split between the front and rear axles in real time to suit the grip levels and driving conditions, as well as transmission and driver inputs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With the CVT gearbox, you can switch to manual mode and use the paddle shifters on either side of the steering wheel for up or down shifts. So in off-road situations you can drive it \u201cmanual\u201d if you like -- just don\u2019t expect engine braking on a steep downhill.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Right, so with some of the XV\u2019s credentials explained, let\u2019s look at those upgrades, done in conjunction with Gary Swemmer of the 4WD Truckin\u2019 Company.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;All-terrain tyres were at the top of our shopping list, but it proved a challenge to find the ideal set of takkies. Hankook provided a set of 17-inch Dynapro ATM all-terrain tyres, and we fitted these to the original17-inch rims. But with the higher profile all-terrains, the wheels no longer fitted in the wheel arches. So that idea went out the window.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next step was to go one size smaller with the rims, and Subaru SA supplied four 16-inch steel rims from a Forester. On these more hardy rims we fitted Hankook Dynapro ATM all-terrains (235\/60 R16s).&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Not only are the chunky Hankooks more resistant to punctures and offer better grip in off-road conditions, but the higher profile allows you to deflate the tyres so they can absorb the impact of, for instance, major corrugations, resulting in a much more pliant, comfortable and composed ride.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The new tyre and rim combination is only marginally larger in circumference, so ground clearance is also slightly improved. Good news is that the vehicle\u2019s standard warranty is not affected.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Function without form is also no good, so to fit in with our black-and-desert khaki theme, the silver rims were sprayed in a coat of Plastidip \u2013 a vinyl spray-on wrap that not only protects the original surface but can be peeled off in a jiffy.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Subaru%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To add some extra space, Front Runner supplied an aluminium strap-on roof-rack. They also provided a 45-litre water tank with outlet, two 20-litre jerry cans and a spade that bolts onto the side of the rack. To add some packing space, a 4WD Truckin\u2019 Company Wolf Pack and transit bag were added, tied down with some good quality straps.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For increased safety when driving at night on those rutted dirt roads, we added a set of powerful Lightforce 170 Striker driving lights. And to round off the exterior package, some discreet decals were added.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The interior remains standard apart from an aftermarket Caska entertainment system that replaced the original head unit in the centre console. This new system, with its big LCD screen, includes a GPS navigation system with TomTom maps.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Although we were at first not greatly impressed by some of the features, the GPS and some other functions have proved invaluable over the past 20 000km.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;A little road trip to finish things off&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;So the beefed-up Subaru XV featured on the television programme, and for months it served as school taxi, camera crew vehicle that went where hatch-based crossovers should probably not venture, and general city runabout.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But there was only way to really judge whether the upgrades had been worth the trouble, and that was to compare the toughened up XV with a standard model \u2013 such as the Leisure Wheels XV.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;And so we put together a road trip to the Witwater Safari Lodge, near Mookgophong in the Limpopo province. Besides a 30km dirt road leading to the lodge, there are some rough mountain tracks to contend with, making it the ideal rough-roader test ground.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Subaru%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;So off we went, and on the smooth N1 highway there was a clear difference in the performance of the two Subarus. With all that gear on the roof, and the slightly taller tyres, the 4WD Truckin\u2019 Company XV required considerably more right-foot to maintain a steady 120km\/h. The roof load certainly compromised the XV\u2019s usual aerodynamic performance. It was like trying to launch a brick-shaped rocket into space. As you\u2019d expect, fuel consumption also suffered. (See the numbers elsewhere in this article.)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But once we hit the dirt road outside Mookgophong, any aerodynamic inefficiencies were quickly forgotten. In the standard XV, the driver had to be more circumspect about rocks and ditches, and although the driving experience was still quite excellent and sporty, it did get slightly bouncy -- with rattles -- in the rougher sections, because of the low-profile tyres.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thanks to the Hankook tyres, we hardly bothered about ruts and rocks as the all-terrain tyres absorbed the impacts more efficiently. The taller tyres did not compromise that inherent sporty feel, either \u2013 they actually enhanced it on the gravel.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Finally we reached some of Witwater\u2019s rougher tracks, normally reserved for the 4x4 game drive vehicles. From his lofty Landy Defender, ranger Jacob Maponyane looked at our XVs with a certain level of pessimism.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After the first rough section we crossed (in both XVs, without any hassles) Jacob was all smiles. In fact, he could hardly believe that the vehicles handled the conditions so easily, without leaving expensive plastic bits alongside the track.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But sometimes you have to quit when you're ahead, and we did this at one particularly rocky climb that would have given some pukka off-roaders with a transfer case a work-out. We parked the standard XV -- and had a go in the 4WD Truckin\u2019 Company version.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Amazingly, it managed to clamber about three-quarters of the way up the hill before we decided to retire, rather than carry some expensive Subaru body parts back home in the boot. With the Lineartronic gearbox in manual mode, and the AWD system and traction control doing their stuff, the XV got a lot farther than we'd thought it would.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Subaru%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Make no mistake, this is no hardcore 4x4 ready to tackle major off-road obstacles. But if you have to negotiate some rougher dirt roads or mud, rest assured that this Scooby can handle them.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Was this upgrade worth the effort? We reckon so, yes. When you use the XV around town you can always store the roof rack and its accessories, and refit them for those longer trips. Offering more packing space, fuel capacity (a total of 100 litres), water storage and a shovel, the accessories are practical, too.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The all-terrain tyres handled very well on tar roads, but they really came into their own off the beaten track. And with pot hole dodging becoming a national sport, the tougher all-terrain tyres are more resistant to punctures and damage, even in town.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The 16-inch steel rims also play their part here\u2026 in the middle of the bush, when a wheel is damaged, you can try to convince the buckled wheel to get better with a five-pound hammer. If an original aluminium alloy mag is damaged\u2026 well, that will be that.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The upgrades also demonstrate that you don\u2019t have to spend a small fortune to change an already very good package for the better. In fact, we\u2019d recommend the wheel and tyre upgrade all day long, while the roof accessories would be a question of personal preference and requirement.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This road trip again highlighted what a good all-round package the XV really is, even in stock trim. Five-star EURO NCAP safety rating meets fuel economy meets cool mom\u2019s taxi meets sporty driving experience meets comfort meets luxury meets extremely capable rough-roader.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is, in short, the rainbow wheels of the crossover segment.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The comparison&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Standard vehicle&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;* Great-looking 17-inch alloys with 225\/50 R17 low-profile tyres. Awesome grip on tar and in corners, but less happy on a corrugated dirt road.&lt;br&gt;* Fuel consumption on trip: 8,5 litres\/100km.&lt;br&gt;* Range @ consumption (standard 60 litre-tank) \u2013 about 700km.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;Manned-up vehicle&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;* Subaru Forester 16-inch steel rims (R1200 each) with Hankook Dynapro ATM 235\/60 R16 tyres (R2380 per tyre at Tiger Wheel &amp; Tyre outlets). Rims sprayed with Plastidip vinyl coating (R1200, includes application).&lt;br&gt;* Front Runner Slimline II aluminium roof-rack (1165mm x 1156mm) with four mechanisms to connect to standard roof-rails. Includes wind deflector. Retails for R4 971 (excludes fitment).&lt;br&gt;* Front Runner double jerry can holder (R695) plus two matte black jerry cans (20 litres each) at R325 each.&lt;br&gt;* Front Runner 45-litre water tank to fit on Slimline II rack (R1285) plus mounting system (R295).&lt;br&gt;* Lightforce 170 Striker 100W driving lights, one of the Aussie company\u2019s most popular models worldwide that weighs only 560g per light. Retails for R4500.&lt;br&gt;* Two Front Runner Wolf Pack storage containers (R204 each), in a 4WD Truckin\u2019 Company canvas transit bag (R880) and two tie-down straps (R300).&lt;br&gt;* Caska multimedia and entertainment system with (unexpectedly) capable TomTom mapping, Subaru approved product (R11 999).&lt;br&gt;* Fuel consumption on trip: 12,3 litres\/100km.&lt;br&gt;* Range @ consumption (includes extra 40-litres of fuel): About 812km.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Witwater - Waterberg paradise&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Set on the banks of the Phalala river, about 50km from Mookgophong in the Limpopo province, Witwater Safari Lodge and Spa offers a five-star experience in the beautiful Waterberg mountains.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Besides the amazing game viewing opportunities, Witwater\u2019s main lodge offers an unforgettable holiday experience, with friendly staff that treat guests like royalty. Accommodation ranges from suites, tented suites and lodge suites to self-catering options. Prices start from R625 per person for the self-catering house, which can be hired at R5000 a night for up to eight people. At the other end of the scale, the full board option in the most luxurious of suites costs up to R3000 per person per night (single).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The restaurant is a highlight, serving gourmet meals. The lodge also puts on outstanding braais in the lapa area.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another attraction is the luxurious spa, situated next to the main lodge. Here you can treat yourself to a long list of beauty and relaxation therapies.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;More information:&lt;\/strong&gt; &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.witwater.com;\"&gt;www.witwater.com;&lt;\/a&gt; e-mail &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@witwater.com\"&gt;info@witwater.com&lt;\/a&gt;; Tel. 011 675-2000.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Pocket-sized contact list&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;* &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.subaru.co.za\"&gt;www.subaru.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;* &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.4wdtruckin.co.za\"&gt;www.4wdtruckin.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;* &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.frontrunner.co.za\"&gt;www.frontrunner.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;* &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.hankook.co.za\"&gt;www.hankook.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;* &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.planetworld.co.za\"&gt;www.planetworld.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;* &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.plastidipsa.co.za\"&gt;www.plastidipsa.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;* &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.oppositelock.co.za\"&gt;www.oppositelock.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;* &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.witwater.co.za\"&gt;www.witwater.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Did you know?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are approximately 180 species of chameleon. They are primarily &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Insectivore\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;insectivores&lt;\/a&gt; that feed by &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Projectile_use_by_living_systems\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;ballistically projecting&lt;\/a&gt; their long &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Tongue\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;tongues&lt;\/a&gt; from their mouths to capture prey located some distance away. Their lifespan is about five years.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Did you know?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;In 2007 there were 16 266 white rhinos in &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/South_Africa\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;South Africa&lt;\/a&gt; \u2013 making them the most abundant rhino subspecies in the world. The white rhino can exceed 3 500 kg and has a shoulder height of up to 2 m. They live up to 35 to 40 years. In 2014, 1215 were killed for their horns.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Did you know?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The total number of blue wildebeest in Africa is estimated to be around 1 550 000. The average height of the species is 115\u2013145 cm. While males weigh up to 290kg females seldom exceed 260kg. The average life span is 20 years in the wild &nbsp;and 21 years in captivity.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Did you know?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;A giraffe eats around 34kg of foliage daily. When stressed, giraffes may chew the bark off branches. Although &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/en.wikipedia.org\/wiki\/Herbivorous\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;herbivorous&lt;\/a&gt;, the giraffe has been known to visit carcasses and lick dried meat off bones. Giraffes live up to 25 years in the wild. Fully grown giraffes stand 5\u20136 m tall, with males taller than females. The average weight is 1 192 kg for an adult male.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.mysubs.co.za\/magazine\/leisure-wheels\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Leisure Wheels&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/855\"&gt;&lt;br&gt;Sodwana&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3832\"&gt;Shipwreck 4x4 Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3833\"&gt;Strandveld 4x4 Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3937\"&gt;Ubumanzi Game Lodge 4x4 Trail&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n
