Bellamy and his magnificent Indian Ocean crossing\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cameron-bellamy-and-his-magnificent-indian-ocean-crossing\" data-text=\"Cameron Bellamy and his magnificent Indian Ocean crossing\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cameron-bellamy-and-his-magnificent-indian-ocean-crossing\" data-title=\"Cameron Bellamy and his magnificent Indian Ocean crossing\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;h2&gt;Cameron Bellamy \u2013 part of a team that set the Guinness World Record for the fastest crossing of the Indian Ocean in a rowboat&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;In a nutshell&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A 6720km unassisted row across the Indian Ocean from Geraldton, Australia to Mah\u00e9, Seychelles. The seven-person crew rowed in shifts of two hours on\/two hours off, day and night, for the entire duration of the two-month expedition, completing the crossing in a Guinness World Record-breaking time of 57 days. It was also longest distance rowed in the Indian Ocean by any team.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%201.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;They experienced mountainous ocean swells, reaching up to 60 feet during the tail end of a hurricane. They collided with a blue whale, made a daring escape from pirates off the coast of east Africa and were involved in a heart stopping mid-ocean rescue of an injured crewmate. Cameron raised R800,000 for two charities \u2013 assisting them in installing 5 mobile classrooms in rural Eastern Cape and constructing 2 classroom blocks in an overpopulated school in Northern Zimbabwe.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Category:&lt;\/strong&gt; Team, unsupported and unassisted.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Adventurer:&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;Cameron Bellamy, 32.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Residence:&lt;\/strong&gt; London and Cape Town.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Birthplace:&lt;\/strong&gt; Cape Town.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%203_0.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Profession:&lt;\/strong&gt; Analyst at Standard and Poors.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Previous big adventures&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Cycled solo and unassisted from Beijing, China to Kanyakumari, India, a 7000km journey through China, along the Silk Road, into Central Asia and then down to the southern India which took 4 month.&lt;br&gt;Cycled from Lands End to John 'o Groats (a 1500km ride from the southern-most tip of the UK to its northern-most tip) in 7 days.&lt;br&gt;Swam the English Channel solo - a distance of 35km in 16 hours 29 minutes&lt;br&gt;Cycled unassisted across Colombia, a 1000km ride over the Andes mountain range from Cartagena to Manizales&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Length of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 6720km&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Duration:&lt;\/strong&gt; 57 days&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Completion date:&lt;\/strong&gt; 11 August 2014&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Continuous or a series of adventures:&lt;\/strong&gt; Continuous&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Highlights&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;57 days at sea rowing in shifts of two hours on\/two hours off.&lt;br&gt;Rowing through a hurricane with waves 60 feet in height.&lt;br&gt;Amazing wildlife, including numerous pods of dolphins and whales.&nbsp; Sharks often came in and would follow the boat for extended periods of time.&lt;br&gt;Around the mid way point of the row, the boat collided with a blue whale which, we think, may have been trying to scratch the barnacles off its back.&lt;br&gt;One of the crewmates suffered first-degree burn wounds and was in dire need of evacuation. When a 250m-long tanker attempted to make the rescue it almost collided with the minuscule rowboat, forcing the crew to fend the gigantic tanker away with their oars. It was the closest near death experience any of the crew had experienced.&lt;br&gt;Close to the east coast of Africa, pirates curious about the boat\u2019s activities and purpose intercepted it. It took some quick thinking by skipper Leven Brown. He told them over the radio that the rowing boat was actually a navy 'Q-boat' awaiting refuelling by the Royal Navy in 20 minutes. Fortunately, on hearing this, the pirates scooted off in a hurry.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Why&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;In 2012 a few friends and I started the Ubunye Challenge, a charity platform whereby we look to complete extreme endurance events and expeditions in order to raise funds for educational projects in southern Africa. Our goal was to complete a Lands End to John o' Groats cycle, a solo English Channel swim and an ocean row. The ocean row was to be the pinnacle and the toughest of the three events (although the previous two were by no means easy). I chose that event as I was a passionate flat-water rower at high school and university and represented South Africa at the World U23 Rowing Championships and World Student Games (in 2003 and 2004 respectively). My father was a successful ocean yachtsman and a huge inspiration to me. The Indian Ocean row was a chance for me to marry my rowing past with my father's passion for the ocean. My father passed away, after a two-year battle with cancer,&nbsp;a short time after I completed the ocean row.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To date the Ubunye Challenge has raised R800,000 and assisted in installing five mobile classrooms in the Eastern Cape, and two classroom blocks in an overpopulated school in northern Zimbabwe.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Goals of Expedition\/Adventure&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our initial goal was to be the first crew to row across the Indian Ocean from mainland Australia to the African mainland, which had never been done. Our secondary goal was to break the speed record for the fastest crossing.&lt;br&gt;We were well on track to reach the African coast, but two vicious storms and a hurricane forced us further north than we intended. We were headed straight for the northern Kenyan\/Somalian coast, and after a terrifying encounter with pirates we decided to not risk the threat of piracy (and terrorism) any longer. We changed course and headed for the Seychelles, just off the coast of Africa.&lt;br&gt;We made the crossing in 57 days and 10 hours, breaking the Guinness World Record for the fastest Indian Ocean rowing crossing by over 10 days.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Originality&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There had been two previous attempts to cross the Indian Ocean from mainland to mainland.&nbsp; Both failed to reach the African coast. There have been 16 successful Indian Ocean rows to date, the most common end point being Mauritius.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%2012.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Planning&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I started planning this trip in late 2011. It took a very long time to come to fruition, mainly due to financial reasons. We were extremely lucky to have Leven Brown on board. He is an experienced skipper who has rowed numerous oceans before and provided most of the logistical support.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Risks&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are myriad risks involved in ocean rowing including:&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Capsizing, and potential drowning in big seas. The highest swells we experienced were 60 foot in height.&lt;br&gt;Being washed overboard while not harnessed into the boat, especially during the night. It is extremely hard to stop a fast moving rowing boat and turn it around.&lt;br&gt;Burn injuries during cooking. This happened to one of the crew, Shane Usher, who needed an emergency evacuation in the middle of the Indian Ocean.&lt;br&gt;Encounters with ocean dwelling predators and poisonous jelly fish while off the boat.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%204%20Ending%20in%20Seychelles.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Back-up plan&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are very few options available should an emergency occur in the middle of the Indian Ocean. Small islands are at least three weeks row away and air support can only occur within 200km of the mainland. Rescue by ship is the only feasible option available. When Shane Usher sustained first-degree burn injuries, a huge tanker, which happened to be in the near vicinity, was alerted to the situation. They diverted their course to intersect with us and take Shane on board. The evacuation nearly ended the expedition as our boat was almost destroyed when it collided with the tanker!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Self-funded. The crew paid their own way after a major sponsor pulled out only weeks before the expedition was set to leave. It demonstrated their tenacity and determination to keep going and successfully complete the expedition despite the severe and unexpected financial burden.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%2013.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Scariest moment&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There were numerous. We experienced huge storms and waves, a collision with a blue whale, and interaction with pirates. However my scariest moment was having to scrape the barnacles off the underside of the boat, knowing full well that there were sharks in the immediate vicinity. It was a Friday, about 35 days into the row and the hull was 90% covered in barnacles. Leven, the skipper, advised that I would be cleaning the boat the following Monday. We had had numerous visits by sharks leading up to this, but on the Saturday and early Sunday morning a lone tiger shark followed us. From then until Monday morning it disappeared from sight. I had been secretly praying that Leven had forgotten about the hull-cleaning job, but just after lunch he instructed us to stop rowing and told me to get ready to start cleaning.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019ll always remember that dreadful feeling of standing on the edge of the boat, barnacle scraper in hand, fearfully searching for any sign of the shark, while trying not to let my crew mates see my unease! I eventually decided to take the plunge. On entering the water I quickly skirted around looking for my hungry tormentor. Luckily there was no sign of him and I timidly started my cleaning duties, keeping a careful eye over my shoulder for the shark. Forty minutes later the hull was clean of barnacles and I was extremely happy to be back on deck!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%206%20Scraping%20off%20barnacles.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Most unexpected experience&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;On one of the two-hour breaks I slipped into my bunk and fell soundly asleep. Suddenly, the boat came to jolting halt and I was flung forward and off the bunk. I immediately thought we'd hit a reef and started to worry about damage to the boat. But we\u2019d hit a huge blue whale, bigger, by far, than our 15m rowing boat. It moved a distance away and then came back straight towards us. We thought it was going to hit us again, but it managed to divert at the last moment. It did this a few more times before disappearing into the depths.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Just seeing a blue whale was an amazing experience; it trying to use our boat as a back scratcher was truly unique.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Best piece of gear&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We had to row for 12 hours a day in all types of conditions on pretty uncomfortable seats. So my favourite gear was my merino wool Icebreaker underwear. All 15 pairs of them!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%207.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What did you eat on the trip&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Freeze-dried meals (a variety of different types from bobotie to ice cream), two-minute noodles, protein shakes, energy bars and various snacks.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On various occasions we landed a fish or squid. I caught two dorados, a barracuda and two large Humboldt squid. We ate the fish raw or boiled, but the tastiest treat was the calamari, which we fried, with some chicken stock, in the Jetboil.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What\u2019s next&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I am currently training for 3 solo swims this year:&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;- Spain to Morocco in mid April.&lt;br&gt;- 3 Anchor Bay to Robben Island and back in mid May.&lt;br&gt;- The Irish Channel (Ireland to Scotland) to late August. This is a very tough swim of 35km in extremely cold water and tough weather\/water conditions. The area is also known for its large swarms of the poisonous lion's mane jellyfish.&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/A%202015%20logo%20s_0.jpg?itok=QMKoQFTc\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Adventurer 2015&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9607\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/england-book\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;England by the Book&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    England by the Book  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"England by the Book\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/England%20MAIN.jpg?itok=5zc4v3fr\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/england-book\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/england-book\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/england-book&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/England%20MAIN.jpg&amp;description=England by the Book\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/england-book\" data-text=\"England by the Book\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/england-book\" data-title=\"England by the Book\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words and pics Nancy Richards, &lt;a href=\"mailto:nancyrichards@intekom.co.za\"&gt;nancyrichards@intekom.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; 083 431 9986&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I made a point of not taking a book. There\u2019s always so much to read in England. Not least the glut of weighty newspapers. But the literary thread that wormed its way through the excursion began with an in-flight glossy. An article called &lt;em&gt;Book Shelfies&lt;\/em&gt;, reflected the current titles on the bedsides of some leading Brits. Knowing I\u2019d be overnighting at a number of different homes, I decided to take a leaf out of the concept and sleuth my hosts\u2019 shelves to see what was feeding their souls \u2013 maybe borrow a title or two for some late night speed reading. Good idea, but I didn\u2019t get much sleep.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/England%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;WOMEN\u2019S LIB: The suffragette picture window at the entrance to LSE\u2019s Women\u2019s Library.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The theme was further underlined by a visit to the Women\u2019s Library at the London School of Economics where a giant black and white blow-up pic of the early 19th-century suffragettes\u2019 protest filled an entire window. I got to do a guided tour with special collections librarian, Indy Bhullar who rolled back shelves in temperature controlled vaults loaded with tomes dating from centuries past. With reverence he picks out a 1792 copy of &lt;em&gt;The Vindication of the Rights of Women&lt;\/em&gt; by Mary Wollstonecraft before moving on to the more contemporary archives containing e-zines and the jump suits worn at the Greenham Common Women\u2019s Peace Camp in the 80s.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/England%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;READING ROUTE: Persephone bookshop on Lamb\u2019s Conduit St.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As luck would have it, Persephone, a publishing house that focused mainly on the \u2018neglected\u2019 writings of women between the world wars, was in Lamb\u2019s Conduit Street, not a million miles away from the LSE. Not to miss an opportunity, my co-pilot on this particular venture brazenly approached a young woman deep in her Kindle for directions, \"I always feel you can ask the way from someone who reads\". Gut feel paid off and sure enough The Reader was able to oblige and minutes later we were in the serene, low-lit surrounds of the publisher\u2019s office-cum-shop where every treasured title is discreetly jacketed in dove grey with period piece textile designs gracing the end pages and matching book marks. Persephone pilgrims come from all over the world to shop here.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/England%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;READING ROOM: Inside Persephone bookshop on Lamb\u2019s Conduit St.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Luck or coincidence \u2013 but on at the National Portrait Gallery annexed to the National Gallery in Trafalgar Square was an exhibition on the Art, Life and Vision of iconic writer Virginia Woolf (1882-1941). Needless to say, more of a literary than visual portrait \u2013 but it exposed the inner working of her troubled, finely tuned mind. Woolf was one of the key members of intellectual, artistic set, The Bloomsbury Group, and it was she who famously wrote: \u201cA woman must have money and a room of her own if she is to write fiction\u201d. And write she did. But tragically, following several bouts of depression, she took her own life by throwing herself into the River Ouse with pockets full of stones to ensure she reached her goal. It\u2019s possible that many of the Persephone pilgrims also found their way to this exhibition.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/England%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;PRIDE OF PLACE: Jane Austen\u2019s house museum in Chawton.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Woolf exhibit was a bonus, but on the agenda from the outset had been a visit to Charleston, Sussex home of painters Duncan Grant and Vanessa Bell (Virginia Woolf\u2019s sister) who were also members of the rule-breaking Bloomsbury Group. A guided tour of Charleston and its blowsy garden is an experience of art as a way of life. Every hand painted wall and piece of furniture has a story and the inspired guide explained that it was here that this \u2018circle of friends who loved in triangles\u2019 would sit and share their alternative and visionary views into the night. Virginia herself lived not far away in Monk\u2019s House where she had a writing \u2018room of her own\u2019 in the garden. Though I didn\u2019t get there, this house too is open to the public.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/England%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;EMPIRE LINES: &nbsp;There\u2019s a lock of the writers hair amongst the exhibits at Jane Austen\u2019s house.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Clearly the goddesses of the pen were with me on this trip, because next, at a stop somewhere between Petersfield and Guildford in Hampshire, I asked in passing what there might be of interest along the way. \"I don\u2019t suppose you\u2019d be interested in Jane Austen, but her house is up the road.\" Minutes later, the car was headed for Chawton, home of the princess of the romantic novel. Well if the Persephone pilgrims had made it to the Woolf exhibition, their American cousins had all come to pay homage at Chawton. They revelled in the empire lines of her wardrobe, sighed at sight of the virgin calico-covered bed where she and her sister Cassandra shared their virgin nights and listened as a white haired lady tinkled ivories on a harpsichord in the drawing room. In the picture book rambling rose garden, watercolourists had set up their easels. Pride and not a little prejudice had prevailed for the companion on this trip who had whiled away a moment not at Cassandra\u2019s Cup the coffee shop across the road, but The Greyfriar pub next door. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/England%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;DOING THE CHARLESTON: Literary charm of an artist\u2019s house and garden.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Booking Out&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;For reasons of excess baggage, it was not my intention to actually buy any books \u2013 and regrettably, or perhaps luckily, I didn\u2019t get to the new home of the legendary Foyles. Having first opened in 1906 at no. 113-119 Charing Cross Road, in June last year, they moved their many hundreds of thousands of titles to no. 107 where they boast 4 miles (around 6.5km) of shelving to accommodate them. Chances are high that you\u2019d find a title you\u2019re looking for here. But where my resolve was seriously challenged was at The Fifteenth Century Bookshop in High Street Lewes. Owner Susan Mirabaud, peering from behind towering stacks, explained that she was a \u2018bit of a collector\u2019 until her late husband drew the line so she moved into this timbered old building which now bursts at the seams with around 10 000 books. Speciality areas? \"I specialise in children\u2019s books, but women writers are my passion \u2013 Virginia Woolf is favourite.\" Could have guessed.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Postscript&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I shouldn\u2019t have expected anything less, but it was a fitting final chapter on the return flight to find myself sitting next to an author and owner of a private library in Sea Point. Focused on Military and Political science, with the Balkan wars a speciality, it wasn\u2019t quite in keeping with the gender interests previously prevalent, but hey!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/England%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;DOING THE CHARLESTON: Literary charm of an artist\u2019s house and garden.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Readers' Research&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Women's Library&lt;\/strong&gt; at The London School of Economics, 10 Portugal St, London WC2. Viewing and research by appointment. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.lse.ac.uk\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.lse.ac.uk&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Persephone Books&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;Open weekdays 10 \u2013 6, Sat 12 \u2013 5. Mail order available. &nbsp;59 Lamb\u2019s Conduit Street, London WC1. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.persephonebooks.co.uk\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.persephonebooks.co.uk&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Charleston a bloomsbury home and garden&lt;\/strong&gt; near Lewes, Sussex, have tours, workshops and talks. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.charleston.org.uk\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.charleston.org.uk&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Virginia Woolf's Monk's House&lt;\/strong&gt; is a national trust property, tours available. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.nationaltrust.org.uk\/monks-house\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.nationaltrust.org.uk\/monks-house&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Jane Austen's House Museum&lt;\/strong&gt; has regular exhibitions and workshops and every year on her birthday, December 16, entrance is free with tea and mince pies. There are plans for special celebrations to mark the 200th anniversary of her death in 2017. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.jane-austens-house-museum.org.uk\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.jane-austens-house-museum.org.uk&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Foyles Bookshop&lt;\/strong&gt; Open 9.30 \u2013 9 Monday to Saturday. 107 Charing Cross Road, London WC2. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.foyles.co.uk\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.foyles.co.uk&nbsp;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The Fifteenth Century Bookshop&lt;\/strong&gt; High Street Lewes. Mail order available. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.oldenyoungbooks.co.uk\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.oldenyoungbooks.co.uk&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/England%20end.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"723\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;WRITE STUFF: &nbsp;Portrait of Virginia Woolf by her sister Vanessa Bell.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9653\" class=\"publisher-4123 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/riaan-manser-and-vasti-geldenhuys-morocco-new-york-rowing-expedition\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Riaan Manser and Vasti Geldenhuys&#039; Morocco to New York rowing expedition&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Riaan Manser and Vasti Geldenhuys&#039; Morocco to New York rowing expedition  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Riaan Manser and Vasti Geldenhuys&#039; Morocco to New York rowing expedition\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #09906f' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/A%202015%20logo%20s.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%20M.jpg?itok=D20zYX0V\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riaan-manser-and-vasti-geldenhuys-morocco-new-york-rowing-expedition\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riaan-manser-and-vasti-geldenhuys-morocco-new-york-rowing-expedition\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riaan-manser-and-vasti-geldenhuys-morocco-new-york-rowing-expedition&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%20M.jpg&amp;description=Riaan Manser and Vasti Geldenhuys' Morocco to New York rowing expedition\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riaan-manser-and-vasti-geldenhuys-morocco-new-york-rowing-expedition\" data-text=\"Riaan Manser and Vasti Geldenhuys' Morocco to New York rowing expedition\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/riaan-manser-and-vasti-geldenhuys-morocco-new-york-rowing-expedition\" data-title=\"Riaan Manser and Vasti Geldenhuys' Morocco to New York rowing expedition\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;h2&gt;Take me 2 New York \u2013 a non-stop ocean rowing expedition from Morocco to New York&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;In a nutshell:&lt;\/strong&gt; A world first rowing expedition from Morocco to New York which saw Riaan Manser and Vasti Geldenhuys become the first people to row from mainland Africa to mainland North America. Vasti is the first woman from Africa to have rowed across any ocean. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Category:&lt;\/strong&gt; Team: unassisted, continuous.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%202.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Adventurer:&nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Riaan Manser, 41.&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Residence: Betty\u2019s Bay.&lt;br&gt;Birthplace: Pretoria.&lt;br&gt;Profession: Author and explorer.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Adventurer:&nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Vasti Geldenhuys&lt;\/strong&gt;, 36.&lt;br&gt;Residence: Betty\u2019s Bay.&lt;br&gt;Birthplace: Randfontein.&lt;br&gt;Profession: Advocate.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%203.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Previous big adventures: Riaan Manser&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Circumnavigating Africa by bicycle (2003 \u2013 2005) - a self-supported expedition which took 2 years, 2 months and 15 days.&lt;br&gt;A yearlong circumnavigation of Madagascar by kayak (2008 \u2013 2009).&lt;br&gt;A six-month circumnavigation of Iceland by kayak with handicapped partner Dan Skinstad (2011).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Length:&lt;\/strong&gt; 10 765km.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Duration:&lt;\/strong&gt; 6 months, of which four and half months was spent on the water.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Completion date:&lt;\/strong&gt; 20 June 2014.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Highlights:&lt;\/strong&gt; Rowing into New York Harbour and ending our trip next to the Statue of Liberty: spending four and a half months at sea; not seeing land or other people for a continuous period of two and a half months; seeing the swimming pigs of Staniel Cay in the Bahamas.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Website:&lt;\/strong&gt; &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.riaanmanser.com\"&gt;www.riaanmanser.com&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Twitter:&lt;\/strong&gt; @riaanmanser &amp; @vastigee &amp; @TM2NY.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Facebook:&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;Take me 2 New York.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Why&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We were sitting on our coach in Betty\u2019s Bay last year when Vasti announced that she wanted to do something great in her life. I knew she always wanted to go to New York, so I said \u2018I\u2019ll take you, but we are going my way\u2019.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We wanted to do something exceptional, something that hasn\u2019t been done before. &nbsp;So we took ocean rowing to the next level. Nobody has ever rowed from mainland Africa to mainland North America; nor has anyone rowed up the east coast of North America. We realized that the Gulf Stream is an amazing phenomenon \u2013 one that not many people will get to experience in their lifetime.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Doing it together was what made the expedition special. But I have always chosen expeditions on which there\u2019s a real possibility of me losing my life. That aspect made this expedition very difficult for me as I didn\u2019t want anything to happen to Vasti. (RM)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Goal&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;To row, unassisted, from Morocco to New York.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Originality&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;This was a world first expedition. &nbsp;Nobody has ever rowed from mainland Africa to mainland North America. There have been many Atlantic Ocean rowing crossings, but most take the \u2018trade winds\u2019 route from the Canaries to one of the Caribbean Islands - a distance of approximately 5000km. Since we were heading for New York we had to take a very different route. After reaching the US mainland at Miami we spent another month at sea to reach New York, our final destination. The total distance of our row (10 765km) was more than double a \u2018conventional\u2019 Atlantic crossing.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Planning&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We dreamt up the idea in April 2014, left for Morocco on 3 December 2014 and started our expedition on 30 December 2014. &nbsp;So it took us about eight months of planning.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Risks&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Getting separated from the boat. &nbsp;The total surface of the Atlantic is one fifth of the earth's. &nbsp;If you get separated from your boat, there is no way you\u2019ll be spotted in that vast amount of water. And even if you are able to send any type of emergency signal, it is unlikely the rescue team wouldn\u2019t reach you in time.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;Capsizing in big waves during storms.&lt;br&gt;Being run over by ships, especially in the shipping lanes near land. (We were run over by a 250 metre-long Russian oil tanker at 2am in the morning, only 5 days from the end of the expidition.)&lt;br&gt;Shark attacks while swimming and cleaning underneath of the boat. &nbsp;We caught a lot of sharks and cut the line as close to the mouth as possible when releasing them. Sometimes this was at night and often the boat was rocking so one of us could easily have fallen in the water in the process.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Scariest moment&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;When Riaan got separated from the boat. Physically it would have been impossible for me to turn the boat around to pick him up. Fortunately he was able to grab hold of the fishing line that we trawled behind the boat, and I managed to reel him back in. Quite a catch!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Being capsized by an eight-metre wave 2000km from the closest land was also pretty hairy. (VG)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Back-up plan&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Initially we had a satellite phone, but it broke when a big wave hit us 19 days from leaving the Canary Islands. Our boat had an Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon (EPIRB) through which we could send an emergency signal. We also had Personal Locator Beacons, which work in the same manner: when activated it a signal goes out to the nearest boat in the vicinity. But there were almost no boats in our vicinity on the Atlantic crossing leg of our journey, and even if there were it would have taken at least 48 hours for a ship to reach us.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%2013.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Sponsors&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sun International, DSTV, Zurich Insurance, Columbia Clothing, Imtech, Dion Wired, Seaport and Outward Ventures, the distributors of Back Country Cuisine. &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Verification&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The expedition was tracked by a Yellowbrick GPS tracker, which sent out our GPS location at least every two hours. The whole route is visible by following the Yellowbrick link on riaanmanser.com.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Unexpected experiences&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Pushing our boat out of the swamps after it got stuck in the mangroves as we were rowing through Andros Island in the Bahamas.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Reaching Miami and almost being detained by the police who thought we were Cuban refugees. They let us go after we persuaded them that Cuban refugees don\u2019t usually have sponsors\u2019 logos displayed on their boats!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%2011.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funniest moment&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;One day, near the start of the crossing (ie when it was still cold) Riaan went outside to the toilet. &nbsp;Waves were crashing over the boat all the time and he got completely soaked. &nbsp;He was cold and miserable and just wanted to get back into the \u201cluxury\u201d of the cabin. &nbsp;He pleaded with me to open the cabin door before another wave hit him but I wouldn\u2019t in case he got his timing wrong and the cabin flooded. He was a sorry sight, but I had to laugh when yet another wave crashed over the boat. (VG)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Best piece of gear&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Yellowbrick tracker. It tracked our expedition, and when our satellite phone broke down as a result of water damage after the capsize, we used the Yellowbrick to send short text messages to the outside world.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%207.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What did you eat&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We ate Back Country freeze-dried food. You boil water and add it to the packet and within 10 minutes you have Roast Chicken, Moroccan Lamb, Chana Masala, etc. From about half way we caught a lot of fish - dorado, tuna, gator fish, bonito and various fish that we couldn\u2019t identify. We even made biltong from the fish that we really enjoyed. &nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What was the worst thing that bit you&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Flies in the mangroves of Andros Island. &nbsp;There were thousands of them and the bites burnt and itched for days.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What hurt most&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our backs, bums, knees, wrists \u2013 actually everything. When we got up in the mornings, we felt like old people. We contracted a condition called rower\u2019s claw. When we got up at night, after a rowing day, we couldn\u2019t close our hands. We had to spend five minutes working to loosen our fingers enough for them to grip.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Riaan%20%26%20Vasti%2014.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/A%202015%20logo%20s_0.jpg?itok=QMKoQFTc\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Adventurer 2015&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9604\" class=\"publisher-1813 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/ride-wolwespruit-mtb-erasmuskloof-pretoria\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Ride Wolwespruit MTB in Erasmuskloof (Pretoria)&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Ride Wolwespruit MTB in Erasmuskloof (Pretoria)  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Ride Wolwespruit MTB in Erasmuskloof (Pretoria)\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.ride.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #E31933' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/ride-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Wolwespruit%20MAIN.jpg?itok=Kje_Z5hh\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/ride-wolwespruit-mtb-erasmuskloof-pretoria\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/ride-wolwespruit-mtb-erasmuskloof-pretoria\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/ride-wolwespruit-mtb-erasmuskloof-pretoria&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Wolwespruit%20MAIN.jpg&amp;description=Ride Wolwespruit MTB in Erasmuskloof (Pretoria)\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/ride-wolwespruit-mtb-erasmuskloof-pretoria\" data-text=\"Ride Wolwespruit MTB in Erasmuskloof (Pretoria)\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/ride-wolwespruit-mtb-erasmuskloof-pretoria\" data-title=\"Ride Wolwespruit MTB in Erasmuskloof (Pretoria)\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words and pics Andrew Steer&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;When it comes to trails in inner city spaces, Pretoria has always been a little ahead of the pack. We tested out the capital\u2019s latest mountain-bike offering, Wolwespruit, in Erasmuskloof.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I headed to Wolwespruit on a pleasant Highveld Sunday afternoon to try out its heralded wares first hand. It was easy to find and access, even for a confused Joburger. I\u2019d read a few positive reviews online, and its website is neatly done (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.wolwespruit.co.za\"&gt;www.wolwespruit.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;), but you just never know what to expect until you\u2019ve actually been there and sampled it for yourself.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After a quick park and unpack, I headed to the registration, paid my 30 bucks, and sorted out my indemnity. I got a quick idea of the lay of the land from the manager on duty and headed out into the sunshine to burn off a little winter excess, and soak up some much-needed rays in the most enjoyable way.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The Riding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The main (blue) trail through the park is 15km long, with around 300m of climbing. It is what would generally be considered an intermediate-level trail, while still being challenging enough to test even the hardiest riders. There are various options to shorten the loop, should you get tired, and \u2018chicken runs\u2019(green) to skip some of the more technical sections, if they aren\u2019t your cup of tea, so it caters for just about all levels of mountain bikers. Work is under way on a new beginner route and a pump track, so by the time you read this, there should be an option for everyone in the family.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trail starts at the parking lot and you head into some singletrack that takes you alongside the highway, over several optional jumps and some north-shore-type bridges, and around a couple of sweet berms \u2013 all the while nipping in and out of small wooded sections. It\u2019s generally flat and fast until you hit a proper little leg-tester a couple of kilometres in, which quickly pops you atop a nice rocky koppie.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There you get a glorious view of the park to your left (and the intimidating-looking climb that looms later on in the lap), while just to your right you might notice the busiest freeway in Africa \u2013 how did that sneak in there? A quick downhill ensues, before more singletrack whips you around, taking you back in the direction of the start. There is a bail-out option here (ideal, probably, for kiddies), or just follow the signs that take you out on a separate singletrack loop. This leads you, via a wooden bridge, to the other side of the Wolwespruit, which neatly bisects the park.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolwespruit%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;On this side of the spruit, a challenge gets thrown into the mix \u2013 a mini-Alpe d\u2019Huez-style switchback climb that takes you off the linkage road, and up the formidable main slope. It is, however, at a reasonable gradient, so with a little determination it\u2019s possible to make it to the top in something resembling comfort. Once there, you can enjoy the panoramic views back over the park, the hospital and the motorway (which you sometimes need reminding is even there). The descent is challenging but great fun, and some tight turns mixed with fast, rocky sections will get the adrenalin going. There\u2019s something to be said for the experience of doing a white-knuckle descent with a hospital in full view\u2026&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Once back on the linkage road, you can either use this to head home, or tackle the last little challenge: a deceptively long jeep-track climb up along the park perimeter, which takes you back up to the main slope. You\u2019re rewarded, though, with a long and fast descent that has fast, rocky sections, some tight, bermed switchbacks and even a couple of (black diamond) drop-off options. They\u2019re not as hectic as you might think; taken at a sensible speed, most people will be able to ride them.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The long descent again takes you back to the main linkage road, which, if you follow the signs, will take you back to the start via a bridge over the spruit, and along the bottom of the hospital grounds. If you\u2019re up for more action, the main climbs could easily be tackled again off the main linkage road. Another full loop will make sure you\u2019ve earned that post-ride boerie roll.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Overall Experience&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trails on offer at Wolwespruit are great fun. The course is 95% singletrack and, although the length might be a bit short for fitter riders, the fun factor on offer means that doing two laps is a serious consideration. There are plans to add some distance to the route (there is 90ha of land to play with) and some easier options for less technically minded riders, and for children.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A huge amount of work and passion has gone into building the specific routes \u2013 Charl Fischer and his team from &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/tool-upcycles.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Tool-Up Cycles&lt;\/a&gt; have done a great job. Tons of singletrack have been cut, the whole area has been fenced and cleaned up, there are berms on many corners, bridges where needed, north-shore type obstacles, jumps \u2013 if you can\u2019t have fun here on your bike, then you are definitely doing something wrong!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolwespruit%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trails still need a bit of riding in, and they could do with some rain, but with summer approaching, the best of what the park has to offer is probably just around the corner. Apart from extra distance, technical challenges will also be added throughout, with specific jump lines and possibly even a full enduro line.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Wolwespruit\u2019s facilities are still basic, but long-term plans include a full restaurant and bike shop, and ultimately setting up the park as a full-time venue that can cater for more activities. Being fully fenced and patrolled, it also offers safety in riding. I\u2019d recommend the park to anyone: it\u2019s great fun, but challenging too. And it\u2019s just going to get better.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Cycling hours&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Saturday and Sunday from 7am to 6pm. There is a recently launched ticket to allows you to ride during the week. These can be bought from &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/tool-upcycles.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Tool-Up Cycles&lt;\/a&gt; or at the park on weekends. No ticket, no weekday riding.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Weather&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Pretoria is always pretty hot, but with only small sections of the trail heavily exposed, and riders never too far from the starting point, a bottle of water\/energy drink should keep you in decent shape.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Riding Rates&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;R30 for a single-rider entry; seasonal passes are not yet available.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Restaurant&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Someday Caf\u00e9 serves anything from condensed-milk coffee to a braaibroodjie or jaffle. There\u2019s no set menu, just the chef\u2019s daily whims on offer, but you\u2019ll go home fulfilled in more than one way. Email &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@somedaycafe.co.za\"&gt;info@somedaycafe.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Address&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;501 Jochemus Street cul de sac Erasmuskloof Pretoria (next to Kloof Medi-Clinic)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Directions&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;From Johannesburg&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;br&gt;Take the M1 north to Pretoria, staying with the M1 when it splits outside Centurion. Continue on the M1 until you take the Rigel Road off-ramp. Turn right onto Delmas Road, take the first left into Nossob Street, and first left into Jochemus Street. The park entrance is at the end of the cul de sac. (The Kloof Medi-Clinic is well signposted from the off-ramp.)&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;From Pretoria&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/em&gt;Take the Rigel Road off-ramp from the M1. Turn east onto Delmas Road, take the first left into Nossob Street, and first left into Jochemus Street. The park entrance is at the end of the cul de sac. (The Kloof Medi Clinic is well signposted from the off-ramp.)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Other Attractions&lt;\/strong&gt; Trail running, Walking (dogs strictly on leashes)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For more information, contact Wolwespruit MTB and Trail Park, &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@wolwespruit.co.za\"&gt;info@wolwespruit.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;, Tel: 061-085-8120, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.wolwespruit.co.za\"&gt;www.wolwespruit.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;, Twitter: @Wolwespruit_MTB, Facebook: Wolwespruit Mountain Bike &amp; Trail Park.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolwespruit%20end.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"770\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source:&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.ride.co.za\/training\/where-to-ride-rides\/wolwespruit\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ride Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9611\" class=\"publisher-4076 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/meet-r%C3%A9union-island\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Meet R\u00e9union Island&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Meet R\u00e9union Island  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Meet R\u00e9union Island\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.travelideas.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #f69220' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Travel%20Ideas%20s.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Reunion%20M.jpg?itok=LqIIWz4l\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/meet-r\u00e9union-island\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/meet-r\u00e9union-island\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/meet-r\u00e9union-island&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Reunion%20M.jpg&amp;description=Meet R\u00e9union Island\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/meet-r\u00e9union-island\" data-text=\"Meet R\u00e9union Island\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/meet-r\u00e9union-island\" data-title=\"Meet R\u00e9union Island\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Franki Black&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Victor Frankl equated the passing of time with the accumulation of memories. He believed that memories are like treasures owned by the bearer forever and therefore, the older you are, the richer you become. What a wonderful way of looking at life! On the way back from a recent trip to R\u00e9union Island, it occurred to me that I had just added a marvellous treasure to my memory bank.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This Indian Ocean Island - situated east of Madagascar and four hours by plane from Johannesburg - surprised me from all angles. As a French territory, R\u00e9union allows visitors to submerge themselves in easily accessible European culture. The island is 63 kilometres long and 45 kilometres wide, but despite being so small it boasts the highest GDP of all the Indian Ocean Islands. For decades it\u2019s been a favourite holiday (and studying) destination for French people hailing from the mainland and it offers the same medical, educational and infrastructural standards as France. Visitors can expect an island filled with remarkable natural wonders, fast-flowing rum and ridiculously good-looking people.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Reunion%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Nicolas Cyprien, our guide, has blue eyes, a tanned skin and a Master\u2019s degree in anthropology. He welcomes us in Saint Denis - R\u00e9union\u2019s administrative capital -and we file onto a bus, west-coast bound. \u201cThere are hundreds of micro-worlds in R\u00e9union,\u201d says Nicolas. &nbsp;\u201cIf you take a road trip through the island, you\u2019ll find a completely different landscape and experience every half an hour.\u201d &nbsp;As we drive, I am struck by how developed the island is and how far removed it seems from Africa. Nicolas shares a few facts: 850 000 people inhabit the island, French and Creole are the local languages spoken and 40% of R\u00e9union is a UNESCO World Heritage site. Saint Denis is bustling and half-perched on a mountainside. We drive past 19th Century Creole mansions, chic French boutiques, pastry shops and a promenade filled with active locals. Nicolas points to a pair of humpback whales breaching just off the coast. R\u00e9union is one of the best places in the world for humpback-whale watching and up to 130 new whales arrive off its coast every year. We check into the LUX Resort &amp; Hotel and get ready for action.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Reunion%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"722\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Hikes and Volcanoes&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;R\u00e9union can confidently claim first prize for being adventure capital of the Indian Ocean Islands. For starters, it is home to one of the world\u2019s most active volcanoes and to three gigantic calderas (amphitheatre-like valleys). Over 1000 kilometres of hiking paths crisscross the island, allowing hikers to take on multi-day treks with stay-overs at traditional mountain guesthouses. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our adventure starts with a 4-hour hike through the Mafate Caldera, a vast terrain that is only accessible by foot or by helicopter. The landscape looks like the set of Jurassic Park \u2013 green mountains tower around us, a river lined with black stones flows past us and indigenous plants seem better proportioned to dinosaurs than humans. The path leads us to higher and more isolated territory. 20% of R\u00e9union\u2019s people live in the mountains and according to Nicolas, the only way to deliver post and remove rubbish in these mountain villages is by helicopter. We stop at the first mountain village for a traditional Creole lunch of homegrown chicken and rice. Bob Marley\u2019s voice softly wails from a loudspeaker, while curious children observe our every move. For a few fleeting moments, the serene mountain life turns into an action flick as six helicopters arrive in perfect succession to scoop us back to the beach. Our female pilot points out a few isolated villages as she whizzes past cliff faces, ravines and summits.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Reunion%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In R\u00e9union you can lie on a tropical beach, shop in a European city and hike through a misty forest all on the same day. Our next expedition takes us from the beach into higher and cooler terrain and entails a walk along Piton de la Fournaise, one of the most active, safest and best-monitored volcanoes in the world. \u201cClose your eyes for 30 seconds,\u201d advises our taxi driver. We follow his instructions and when we open our eyes the land looks like mars. Stretched out before us, lies a flat, orange-dusted plain intersected by a lonely road leading to the volcano. Spontaneously, we jump and moonwalk. My friend smiles at me and says, \u201cR\u00e9union has a way of making people feel freer \u2013 you do things that you never thought you\u2019d do.\u201d We reach the lookout point and regard the volcano. There are traces of hardened, black lava and a few big craters around the main mound. Far in the distance, I spot two hikers making their way to the top of the volcano.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Waterfalls and Vanilla&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;R\u00e9union\u2019s west coast is known for sandy beaches and dive-friendly tropical waters, while its east coast forms the bulk of the island\u2019s World Heritage site.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Reunion%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The latter is lush, it offers spectacular routes for river rafting and hiking and it is home to litchi, sugarcane and vanilla plantations. We head east and arrive at a balmy jungle. Our guide - clad in a wetsuit and helmet - gives us two options, \u201cYou can choose the six or two- metre jump,\u201d he says. &nbsp;I timidly go for two metres and wallow in the water as my petrified friends succumb to the plunge of a lifetime. &nbsp;We form a 24-person train and float down a crystal-clear river, before separating for jumps over waterfalls and gullies. Fuelled with adrenaline, our aquatic hike ends the R\u00e9union way, with pineapple-and-banana-flavored rum. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Alongside Madagascar, R\u00e9union is one of the world\u2019s top producers of vanilla and no visit to the island is complete without a stopover at a vanilla plantation. Bertrand Come, the director of the regional vanilla cooperative, welcomes us at a French-style villa. He leads the way to his crops and tells us that patience is the name of the vanilla-growing game. Vanilla plants grow fast and need to be wrapped around poles on a regular basis. They are mostly pollinated by hand and once harvested; pods are washed, wrapped in blankets like babies and dried in various shapes and forms over several months. While drying, the pods are regularly checked for fungus. Bertrand says that all this effort pays off, as 80 kilograms of vanilla can fetch up to 40 000 Euro!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Reunion%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"578\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;A Blend of R\u00e9union&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;R\u00e9union is a melting pot of European, African and Asian cultures, and according to Nicolas, everyone lives in harmony. \u201cIf you like the French lifestyle, but dislike its politics, come to R\u00e9union,\u201d he jokes. A visit to the Saint-Paul market will give you a delicious taste of the island\u2019s diverse spices, exotic fruits, and local dishes like samosas, dumplings and cari. A drive through Saint Denis will give you a glimpse into R\u00e9union\u2019s funky street art scene and if music is your thing, Maloya \u2013 the island\u2019s traditional music and dance \u2013 can be heard and seen at local beach bars and restaurants.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;My island adventure ends with dinner at a family-owned creole eatery and a Maloya dance-off. First we watch as beautiful, amber-skinned women grace the stage in twirling floral skirts. Within a few minutes, I\u2019m feeling the sensual mood of Maloya and I\u2019m ready to slip on my skirt. The lead guitarist sets the tone for us and our hips casually start to roll. &nbsp;The beat speeds up and before long I\u2019m spinning around like a swirling dervish and laughing out loud.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In just a few days, R\u00e9union turned me into an exotic dancer, a conqueror of volcanoes, a canyon adventurer, a co-pilot and, on occasion, a rum-sipping beach bum. Life is good in R\u00e9union.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Reunion%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"722\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.travelideas.co.za\/subscribe.php\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Travel Ideas&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.travelideas.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;&lt;!--[if gte mso 9]&gt;&lt;xml&gt;\n &lt;o:DocumentProperties&gt;\n
