&lt;o:AllowPNG&gt;&lt;\/o:AllowPNG&gt;\n &lt;\/o:OfficeDocumentSettings&gt;\n&lt;\/xml&gt;&lt;![endif]--&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span lang=\"EN-GB\"&gt;The 'Unlimited' Twin Peaks Expedition, bagging peaks in the Arctic.&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span lang=\"EN-GB\"&gt;In a nutshell&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span lang=\"EN-GB\"&gt;Unlimited Twin Peaks Expedition \u2013 a first ascent of a 1860m high Antarctic peak, preceded by an ascent of Mount Vinson, the highest peak in Antarctica.&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span lang=\"EN-GB\"&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Category:&lt;\/strong&gt; Team, assisted.&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Twin%20Peaks%2012.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Adventurer:&nbsp;Iain Buchan, 65.&lt;br&gt;Residence: Nottingham Road.&lt;br&gt;Birthplace: Lusikisiki, Eastern Cape.&lt;br&gt;Profession: Entrepreneur.&lt;br&gt;Previous big adventures: The Unlimited Child South Pole Expedition.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Adventurer: Zack Buchan, 37.&lt;br&gt;Residence: Durban.&lt;br&gt;Birthplace: Durban.&lt;br&gt;Profession: Entrepreneur, Business Strategy Advisor.&lt;br&gt;Previous big adventures: The Unlimited Child South Pole Expedition, The Unlimited Kitesurfing Expedition.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Twin%20Peaks%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Adventurer: Barney Buchan, 35.&lt;br&gt;Residence: Durban.&lt;br&gt;Birthplace: Durban.&lt;br&gt;Profession: Head of a software development company.&lt;br&gt;Previous big adventures: The Unlimited Child South Pole Expedition.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Adventurer: Dr Peter Berning, 67.&lt;br&gt;Residence: Plettenberg Bay.&lt;br&gt;Birthplace: Cape Town.&lt;br&gt;Profession: Medical doctor.&lt;br&gt;Previous big adventures: Race to the North Pole; The Unlimited Child South Pole Expedition.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Twin%20Peaks%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Adventurer: Ken Watt, 32.&lt;br&gt;Residence: Durban.&lt;br&gt;Birthplace: Durban.&lt;br&gt;Profession: Lawyer.&lt;br&gt;Previous big adventures: None.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; Summiting Mount Vinson (4 892m) and the first ascent of Mount Peace (1 860m).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Duration of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 10 days, continuous.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Completion date of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 9 January 2015.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Sponsors:&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;The Unlimited.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Twin%20Peaks%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Highlights:&lt;\/strong&gt; The privilege of being the first people to ever stand on the top of a virgin peak in Antarctica. We were climbing in freezing conditions (-25 degrees Celcius) and the adventure aspect was mind blowing as there was no designated route. We had to discover each section, make decisions, back track where necessary, and thrash out a route from nothing. This included scaling a 950m ice wall with a 40-degree slope on fixed ropes and each carrying 22kg.&nbsp;It was an amazing experience to summit both peaks, but the opportunity to do it as a family (with close friends) made it unforgettable.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Why&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We made the decision to return to Antarctica during our first expedition on the frozen continent when we trekked the final 111km to the South Pole. Antarctica draws you back. For our second expedition, we decided to take on the challenge of climbing Mount Vinson \u2013 the highest peak on the continent and the coldest and most remote of the Seven Summits \u2013 arguably Antarctica\u2019s ultimate experience. (Iain Buchan)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Goals&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;To summit two peaks in Antarctica, Mount Vinson and an unclimbed peak in the Ellsworth Mountain range.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Twin%20Peaks%205.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Originality&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The unique part of The Unlimited Twin Peaks Expedition was the climb of the second peak. While the mountain range has been photographed, due to its remoteness there are still unclimbed peaks there. As the land lies under permanent ice it is impossible to read the terrain from aerial photographs. So we had to make the route ourselves, doubling back when necessary and taking precautions for travelling in areas that were crevassed and prone to avalanches \u2013 the two biggest dangers that face mountaineers in Antarctica.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Planning&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;It took two years to plan the trip partly because of the short summer weather window in Antarctica. We also wanted to ensure we had the necessary preparation under our belts \u2013 which included summiting two 4000m plus peaks in Europe.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Risks&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The greatest dangers were falling into crevasses and avalanches, so climbers were roped at all times.&nbsp;The cold was also a major challenge as the temperature seldom climbed above -20 degrees Celsius.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Twin%20Peaks%206.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Back-up plan&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The team was accompanied by two seasoned Antarctic guides at all times.&lt;br&gt;The team and the guides also had satellite phones with them so that in the case of an emergency they could make contact with the base camp at Union Glacier.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The expedition was privately funded with additional sponsorship received from the naming sponsor, The Unlimited.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Verification&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;As well as photographic proof, the two guides can independently verify that the team reached the summit of both peaks.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Twin%20Peaks%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Scariest moment&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Approximately 40m from the summit of the previously unclimbed peak that we we named Mount Peace, we had to walk out on to a large section of blue ice at a slope of 60 degrees. It was so steep that only one or two crampon spikes were holding our weight. The guides went out ahead and secured the ropes, but the last three climbers all slipped and fell. Thankfully it was okay because they were secured with taut ropes and the rest of the team were able to bring them back up to safety. (Iain Buchan)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What was the biggest lesson&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;That you have to be purposeful and meticulous. Antarctica has claimed lives, but if you don\u2019t take risks, it is (relatively) safe.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Any amazing person that you met on the trip&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We met the most remarkable people on our trip including a mother-daughter team who had climbed all Seven Summits and a man who went blind on Everest \u2013 along with the Sherpa who guided him down.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Twin%20Peaks%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;!--EndFragment--&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/A%202015%20logo%20s_0.jpg?itok=QMKoQFTc\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Adventurer 2015&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9347\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/makhonjwa-magic\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Makhonjwa Magic &lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Makhonjwa Magic   &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Makhonjwa Magic \" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%26L%20Makhonjwa.jpg?itok=gVhPkG5T\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/makhonjwa-magic\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/makhonjwa-magic\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/makhonjwa-magic&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%26L%20Makhonjwa.jpg&amp;description=Makhonjwa Magic \" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/makhonjwa-magic\" data-text=\"Makhonjwa Magic \" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/makhonjwa-magic\" data-title=\"Makhonjwa Magic \"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Bridget Hilton-Barber&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Just south of Barberton in Mpumalanga, lies a mountain range whose ancient green rocks preserve a unique scientific record of the pre-history of the earth. Bridget Hilton-Barber headed out of town to discover the ancient magic of Makhonjwa.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When my ancestors Fred, Henry and Graham Barber discovered gold in the De Kaap Valley in 1884, they broke a bottle of gin over the reef and named the place Barber\u2019s Camp. It later became Barberton; and while there are still those in our family who grumble about the terrible waste of gin, the celebratory note struck in Barberton\u2019s proclamation seems to strike every time I pass this way. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This time it struck hard and fast as we left town and headed for the Songimvelo Nature Reserve, a hundred kilometres away. We crossed over the increasingly urgent Komati River heading for Swaziland and then the ocean - and were soon were climbing up into the most amazing mountain scenery. Endless, soft and green - welcome to the Barberton Mountain Lands, greenstone rocks dating from the dawn of time.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Makhonjwa%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Centrepiece of Songimvelo is the Makhonjwa Mountain, some of the oldest rocks on earth, dating back 3.5 billion years. They were among the first rocks to solidify on the earth\u2019s crust, and contain remarkable evidence of the earliest life forms. Geologists, scientists and boffins from NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Agency) have been coming here for years in search of scientific clues to early earth - but it\u2019s only now that the Makhonjwa mountains are earmarked for UNESCO World Heritage Site status, that the rest of us are starting to sit up and take note. You can\u2019t really help it out here\u2026 not only are these mountains old and incredible, they are drop dead gorgeous. So drop dead gorgeous in fact that we pulled over and had a long, slow DIY G&amp;T and drank in the views. You can take the Barber out of Barberton \u2026&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Makhonjwa%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Songimvelo is part of the Songimvelo-Malalotja Transfrontier Conservation Area which also includes Malolotja in Swaziland, an equally wild mountain wilderness, characterised by mountains, valleys and floodplains. &nbsp;The accommodation is pretty rustic \u2013 either a campsite or self-catering wooden chalets (they sleep six) at Kromdraai in the eastern part of the reserve, with no electricity. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But that\u2019s the magic of Makhonjwa. It\u2019s wild. There\u2019s a reason they call this part of Mpumalanga the Wild Frontier. It\u2019s so wild in fact that at Songimvelo only five percent of the reserve has 4x4 access and most of the rangers here patrol on horseback. It\u2019s the preferred mode and you can take guided rides \u2013 and also guided drives \u2013 into the dramatic reaches of the mountains.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Makhonjwa%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are more than 300 bird species \u2013 and we saw zebra, wildebeest and frisky giraffe who love the open grassy plains here, and elephant, crashing their way through the shadier wooded areas. &nbsp;You can also go on a guided walk to see some of the circular walls and ruins of small houses and religious structures that date back to 400BC.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Gold has been mined at Makhonjwa for more than a 120 years and some of the oldest gold on the planet is still mined here. (There\u2019s an interesting jewellery project next to the Barberton Museum which promotes local design and craftsmanship.) &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Makhonjwa%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But the strongest Makhonjwa magic comes when you take time out to be still and breathe and admire: the forest, the bush, the caves and stream, the views, the last wild population of the delightfully unruly sounding Woolly Cycad. And of course the ancient rocks themselves. \u201cHere in Barberton is the Rosetta Stone for this period of time.\u201d wrote Professor Don Lowe of Stanford University in California. \u201cThese rock layers are like the pages of a book that we can read and translate in terms of early Earth\u2019s history\u201d. Eish.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;For more information check out Mpumalanga Parks and Tourism Agency\u2019s website &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.mpta.co.za;\"&gt;www.mpta.co.za;&lt;\/a&gt; call +27 (0)13 759 5300\/01; fax +27 (0)13 755 3928 or email &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@mtpa.co.za\"&gt;info@mtpa.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;Cost: From R450 a chalet a night, plus a one-off entry fee of R15 a person and R25 a vehicle. Self-driving in the reserve is R125 a vehicle and guided game drives are R125 a person.&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;It\u2019s also worth checking out Barberton and surrounds, click on &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.barberton.co.za\"&gt;www.barberton.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; or &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.barbertontourism.com\"&gt;www.barbertontourism.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Makhonjwa%205.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2525\"&gt;Songimvelo Game Reserve&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3940\"&gt;Eureka City 4x4 Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3310\"&gt;Queen Rose Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3541\"&gt;Barberton Museum&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/5723\"&gt;Pioneer Mine&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9650\" class=\"publisher-4123 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/bernie-theron\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Bernie Theron&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Bernie Theron  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Bernie Theron\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #09906f' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/A%202015%20logo%20s.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Bernie%20Theron%20M.jpg?itok=hU_LeE0c\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bernie-theron\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bernie-theron\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bernie-theron&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Bernie%20Theron%20M.jpg&amp;description=Bernie Theron\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bernie-theron\" data-text=\"Bernie Theron\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bernie-theron\" data-title=\"Bernie Theron\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;h2&gt;Solo walk across Iceland - Bernie Theron's extraordinary trek&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;In a nutshell:&lt;\/strong&gt; A self-sufficient trek from the most northerly to the most southerly point of Iceland. &nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Category:&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;Solo, unsupported and unassisted.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Adventurer:&lt;\/strong&gt; Bernie Theron, 20 years old.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Bernie%20Theron%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Residence:&lt;\/strong&gt; Pretoria.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Birthplace:&lt;\/strong&gt; Pretoria.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Profession:&lt;\/strong&gt; Student at the University of Pretoria.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Previous big adventures:&lt;\/strong&gt; A solo hike down the east coast of South Africa (2013).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Length of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; Approximately 600km.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Duration of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 27 Days.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Completion date of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 27 July 2014.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Continuous or a series of adventures:&lt;\/strong&gt; Continuous.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Bernie%20Theron%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Highlights:&lt;\/strong&gt; Deep isolation in a country with mindboggling landscapes. Fixing my MSR stove after three days of cold food!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Social Media:&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/RunoutsInAfricaPhotography\" target=\"_self\"&gt;facebook.com\/RunoutsInAfricaPhotography&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Why&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Iceland is a magical country with great volcanoes, glaciers, lava fields and snowcapped peaks. Hiking though its interior, where there are no towns, few roads, and even fewer people was not an easy undertaking. To experience this beautiful country in isolation I had to carry everything that I need to survive for a month on my back, around 45kg of gear.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The interior had a multitude of challenges. I knew I\u2019d have to endure icy cold glacial river crossings, jagged lava fields and extensive plains of mud sucking at my boots. But that was the reason I wanted to hike there.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Goal&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;To cross Iceland and prove that solo \u201cold-school\u201d adventures are still possible for any age group.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Bernie%20Theron%204.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Originality&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;A Swiss crew successfully completed this journey in 2013, and I\u2019m sure that there have been other attempts in the past. &nbsp;But, to the best of my knowledge no South Africans have done it.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Planning&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I started my planning and training about 5 months before the start.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Risks&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Being washed away during glacial river crossings, hypothermia, dehydration and the chance of falling in the odd crevasse.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Back-up plan&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;My back-up was that if I failed to notify my contacts in South Africa within 30 days then they would start looking for me on my designated route. As it turned out my route changed on a daily basis so it wasn\u2019t a great emergency plan! &nbsp;My emergency phone to the outside world was my old Blackberry phone, which was not ideal, but was all that I could afford at the time.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Bernie%20Theron%205.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Self-funded but with the help of the Mountain Club of South Africa\u2019s Supertramp Award \u2013 a dedicated award for young adventurers between the ages of 18 and 25.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Sponsorship&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;MCSA Supertramp Award.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Verification&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Photographs and hours of video footage. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Inspiration&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I was always looking for an adventure. One day I watched a video about Iceland and was smitten by the hiking opportunities there. Months later I decided to motivate a traverse of Iceland as my proposal for the Supertramp award.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What technical skills were needed&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Good navigational skills are essential on long cross-country treks. And it\u2019s important not to dwell too much on the fact that you are alone in the middle of nowhere, so you need a strong will.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Bernie%20Theron%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Scariest moment&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Getting lost late in the afternoon in blizzard conditions high up in the mountains - with a broken tent and in a bad mood.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Lowest point on the adventure&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;When I got sick of my daily allowance of cookies!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funniest moment&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Being attacked by two \u2018wild\u2019 and extremely dangerous sheep.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What was the biggest lesson&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Anything is possible if you have the right attitude.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What would you do\/have done differently&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I would not have followed the advice of the Icelandic mountain wardens, who advised against most of my plans and told me that various sections of my planned route were impassable. Fortunately for me, they weren\u2019t. And I would have taken better quality food and less clothing and gear such as ropes for river crossings, small gadgets and repair tools for my wagon (which broke early in the trek and was not repairable). All that unnecessary weight made my pack almost too much to bear.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Bernie%20Theron%207.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Best piece of gear&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;My La Sportiva Vajolet hiking boots and my Deuter backpack; solid gear.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Piece of gear you wish you\u2019d taken along&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;A better rain jacket that could have kept me dry through days of bad weather, as mine did not do its job at all.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Any amazing person that you met on the trip&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I met a Frenchman called Stephan while on my trek. He was a lightweight backpacker doing his own hike in Iceland. He had some amazing adventures under his belt and gave me great advice.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What did you eat on the trip&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;My daily food consisted of 8 cookies, 100g of couscous, 200g of pasta, 4 blocks of melted chocolate, 3 (50g) breakfast bars and 3 chocolate bars (also 50g each). I am still planning on selling this diet to a weight loss guru since I lost about 10kg on the trek!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What was the worst thing that bit you&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;An Arctic tern.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What hurt most&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;My shoulders from carrying so much gear.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Bernie%20Theron%208.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What\u2019s next&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I am planning to hike across Lesotho this winter. A 6-month kayaking trip in the Patagonia area of southern Chile is on my long-term horizon. Time to get some cash\u2026&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Tips for other adventurers&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Don\u2019t let age, gender, disabilities, fitness or lack of money stop you from going on your own adventure. Just commit to your idea and make it happen.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/A%202015%20logo%20s_0.jpg?itok=QMKoQFTc\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Adventurer 2015&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9615\" class=\"publisher-1785 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/island\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;The Island&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    The Island  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"The Island\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.zigzag.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/zigzag_0.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/The%20Island%20M.jpg?itok=7wkXrGBr\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/The%20Island%20M.jpg&amp;description=The Island\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island\" data-text=\"The Island\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/island\" data-title=\"The Island\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By Will Bendix, pics Alan Van Gysen&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The nasal groan of the cessna\u2019s twin propellers buzzes us onto the runway at Kuala Namu International Airport and soon we\u2019re floating over roads and rivers, dense coconut plantations and minarets that poke into the sky like ornate needles. Then there\u2019s only thick green jungle punctured by rusty volcanic peaks. Finally a sea of turquoise opens up below us and disappears into the horizon.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sean Holmes and his wife Jeannie have their heads pressed to the window upfront. We bank right and little blobs of land appear then disappear beneath the wing of the Cessna. It\u2019s rumoured that an old matriarch with ties to the mafia started this airline of twin prop workhorses. She was a lobster farmer who used to live on the island we find ourselves heading towards.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When business started booming, the boss-lady needed a more reliable way of getting her wares to market. So she enlisted a fleet of second hand Cessnas and effectively opened the island up to outsiders. Previously the only transport was an erratic ferry that could take up to two days, or wouldn\u2019t arrive at all. Nobody sees the boss anymore. It\u2019s said she just sits in her office in the capital all day, tattooed from head to toe, chain-smoking ciggies while counting all her money.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There\u2019s an audible shift in the drone of the engines as the plane starts to descend. Whitewash licks the reefs below and soon everyone\u2019s head is pressed to the window.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cYOU\u2019RE NOT GONNA BE DOING ANY BUNNY HOPS OUT THERE,\u201d Frankie says as he picks his way over the rocks. \u201cBut hell, it feels good to get some barrels.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;50 metres behind him a lump of swell hiccups over the ledge and detonates in a haze of spit. This is, after all, what we\u2019ve come for. The Indonesian dream. Barrels, warm water and swaying palms. Frankie can\u2019t really recall the first time he came to Indo. It\u2019s all smudged into one long, luminous memory when he used to trawl the archipelago with Tom Curren and an ensemble of legendary surfers, looking for virgin waves as part of The Search. But this is different. This island does not belong to the flat teardrops that make up the Mentawai chain or the Banyaks. It is a thousand miles away from the dry eastern expanse of Nusa Tenggara. The island is a land unto itself. Massive clouds swell from its mountainous centre, heated by the significant landmass that creates its own unique weather pattern. The winds shift on a whim, bringing with them a dark vortex of cloud or sunshine so intense it feels like your insides are broiling. The waves are different too. More Hawaii than the Mentawais. Thick chunks of reef broken by beachbreaks and rivermouths. A different kind of perfection.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s Koby\u2019s first trip abroad, their first trip together, and it\u2019s hard to tell who is more excited - father or son. \u201cIt\u2019s good for the lightie to feel some island power,\u201d Frankie says as he swigs his water. \u201cAnd for him to surf with someone like Holmesy. He\u2019s always been one of my favourite surfers.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A few minutes later Sean drops into a hopeless suck-out, his rail barely connecting as he hits the trough. It looks like the lip\u2019s going to square him in the head but he miraculously squeaks under it and the wave shuts down. Or so we think. A few seconds elapse and he shoots out onto the shoulder, relaxed, standing tall.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The slab is just one of a dozen waves littered across the island. Others, we\u2019re told, are still being discovered with each new season. A serviceable road runs around the perimeter of coastline, making discovery relatively easy. The trick is wetting your finger, weighing up all the variables and knowing where to go.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As we drive and explore, Frankie talks. He talks about surfing and fishing and trips gone by. He talks about how cayenne pepper is good for you - just half a teaspoon in the morning and you\u2019re hundreds. He loves to cook and carries a fiery bottle of red curry powder around with him wherever he goes. He catches fish for a living and shapes boards for a bit of extra coin. He talks about rocker dimensions and the best way to braai a couta (wrapped in foil and marinated in chutney, marmite and coke). He still lives in Warner Beach, where he was \u2018discovered\u2019 decades ago and thrust into the limelight as Curren\u2019s prot\u00e9g\u00e9. He loves South Africa but hates the crime. He\u2019s still married to his high school sweetheart Lisa. He has a daughter now too. His life revolves around his family and the sea. Frankie is 41 and many days have gone by since he first started searching. Many, and none at all.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;THE KAK-KAK-KAK OF THE OUTBOARD MOTOR IS DEAFENING and Koby has his hands clamped firmly around his ears to try block out the sound. The nose of our small fishing skiff is aimed at an islet in the distance, one of many that lie sprinkled just offshore. Towering plumes of cloud erupt along the horizon. The heat is building steadily but the soft sea breeze keeps us cool. There are no roads to the wave we\u2019re chasing. It\u2019s said to be the best - and heaviest \u2013 in the area. I had asked a travelling Australian if he knew why it was called Teabags before we left. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cY\u2019know mate,\u201d he said, pointing a finger offshore \u201cWhen you eat it out there, it\u2019s worse than someone dropping their balls on your head. You get properly fucken\u2019 teabagged!\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The swell is an awkward size when we arrive - not quite big enough to break in deeper water allowing for a roll in, but instead it focusses all the energy onto the inside. It\u2019s a cruel, perfect wave. A thin sheet of water covers the live reef. If you don\u2019t make the take-off, you find yourself washed up on a dry coral ledge that runs the length of the point. There\u2019s nowhere to hide as the sets detonate on top of you.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We\u2019re told how a famous Aussie pro scooped the cover of a big international magazine here on a recent visit. After getting the shot in the bag, he paddled further up the reef to where an even shallower, faster section beckons. Shortly thereafter he was taken to the airport in an ambulance and flown back home.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sean and Frankie give it a sniff, paddling up the point, but return empty handed. \u201cYou could try up there,\u201d says Sean. \u201cBut you\u2019re just asking for trouble.\u201d They settle for the main section, Sean waiting patiently for the sets, Frankie locked behind the curtain or carving big arcs in the powerful bowl.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Koby is tentative at first, but his courage builds wave by wave. Soon he is connecting double barrels as his fins barely clear the coral heads. Say what you want about nature versus nurture, but the similarity in style he shares with his father is uncanny. The same relaxed centre of gravity. The exact same dropped knee and compressed bottom turn. His calm under pressure belies his 13 years of age. Sean will later say that while subbing a wave Koby was taking off on, he was getting ready to turn around and \u201cgo pick pieces of the lightie off the reef\u201d. But Koby returns to the skiff in one piece, his eyes bulging with excitement, his world altered forever. The only person smiling more than him is his old man.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We pull anchor and motor to another small island in the distance. The leeward beach is flanked by a solitary outcrop of rock, sprouting jungle like a wild green afro. We jump off and swim to shore, rolling up the beach in the shorebreak.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cGilligan\u2019s Island!\u201d Frankie shouts, summing up the postcard we find ourselves washed up on.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sean disappears around the corner and quickly trots back. \u201cThere\u2019s a wave there,\u201d he says, and swims back to the skiff for his board. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It doesn\u2019t make sense. The swell is coming from the same direction as the landmass in the distance, yet there is a turquoise A-frame bouncing off the other side of the outcrop. It\u2019s like God\u2019s private wavepool. Sean and Koby frolic in the wedges, sliding in next to the rock, throwing down one big turn or pulling in before the wave runs dry. Frankie rolls around in the shorebreak, filming on his GoPro, hooting as his son takes off and he in turn gets smashed into the sand by the lip. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When everyone finally scrambles back onto the boat, hair caked with sand, eyes bloodshot, Frankie turns around and says, \u201cJa, we\u2019ll look back on this and won\u2019t believe we were here.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2011.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;THE RAIN DOESN\u2019T FALL ON THE ISLAND. It gushes from holes in the sky, like someone is emptying a giant, endless bucket. We sip coffee and watch the water as it cascades around us.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cOus think you go to the islands and it\u2019s offshore and perfect every day,\u201d Frankie chuckles. \u201cBut sometimes it\u2019s jut.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He launches into a story from years ago.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2012.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThe one time I was in Hawaii though, it was cooking for weeks on end! First day we\u2019re there getting barrelled, barrelled, and then I pull in and my board hits me in the groin. Tickets. 30 stitches. 20 on the outside, 10 on the inside, thanks for coming. I got back from the hospital and Jason Ribbink &nbsp;arrived. The next morning he goes for a surf and I\u2019m parking on the couch. You know with injuries like that, the pain only kicks in later and I\u2019m on the couch in pain cuzzie, goofed on painkillers, watching TV. The next thing the news comes on and the presenter, he tunes,\u201d at this Frankie switches effortlessly into a nasal American accent. \u201cHe tunes 'Jason Ribbink from South Africa almost died on the North Shore today when his board scalped him at Backdoor' Hawaii national news, bru! Jason had just walked out the door a couple of hours ago. I thought I was still asleep, dreaming. Same thing happened, his board hit the backwash in the barrel but it ended up taking half his head off. When Jason got out the water the Hawaiian guys reckoned this ou was going to fall in the sand and peg right there in front of them. Half his pineapple was hanging open. They stitched him back up but that was it for both of us, first day over, thanks for coming.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2013.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The stories continue to flow from Frankie as the rain falls. He talks about Europe and Oz and Indo, about the days of hustling on the \u2018QS when all the South Africans used to sleep on the beach or in the bushes - \u201cHotel Le Grasse\u201d, as they would tell the French customs officials. He talks about his first trip overseas with Mike Roscoe for a pro junior event in Sydney when they were 16 and how they were supposed to be gone for a few weeks and ended up staying for five months, working as \u201cgarbos\u201d, collecting trash to make enough money to get to Kirra. He remembers how they ended up sleeping in a shredded tent during a cyclone and had their boards stolen, but then their luck changed and they were taken in and ended up staying in an apartment above the point for weeks on end, fridge full, surfing the best waves of their life. He talks about Kirra \u2013 the old Kirra, the real Kirra, the best wave there ever was - and Burleigh and Supertubos and Supers, about Coxos and Macaronis and the South Coast. He talks about getting buzzed by sharks and contracting malaria and even typhoid - not from some tropical backwater, but from dodgy Makro boerewors. He talks about his friends and connections and the people who colour his memories, about the waves he\u2019s surfed and the waves he still wants to surf. A life made up of stories from the road and the sea.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2015.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;THE SWIRLING WIND CONTINUES TO PUSH US around the island each day. We drive, flanked by ocean on one side and houses on the other. Families live and work in the doorways, on rolled out mats and in concrete rooms visible from the road. Most of the houses are less than 10 years old, built after the Boxing Day tsunami that levelled villages across the island. Only one person died, however, in the aftermath. It\u2019s reported he suffered from a heart attack while heading for higher ground. Local folklore tells of a devastating tsunami in 1907 in which thousands of the islanders perished. They had rushed to the beach to collect fish after seeing the water recede, exposing the flapping bounty. They did not know the water would return. The story of the semong has since been passed down from generation to generation. Everyone on the island knows that if the ocean inhales, it will exhale again.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2016.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We find evidence of these seismic shifts in the waves we surf. At one particular beach the entire shelf has been thrust up from deep below the surface. Petrified coral heads bake in the sun and break off like crystal in your hand. Not long after the Boxing Day tsunami, an 8.7 magnitude quake struck directly off the southern end of the island. Geologists estimate that the island rose at least six feet on the western coast, while on the east coast the land was submerged, seawater flooding fields and settlements. The island had been tipped like a saucer. Some of the waves we surf are less than a decade old. There are vague stories of other waves before the quake. A surf camp was perched in front of the best one, but after the earthquake it was gone. The devastated owner packed up and left shortly afterwards. While we are there, a volcano erupts on the mainland and smolders for days. Villages are evacuated and tense hours pass as the earth rumbles and shifts deep below us.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2017.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;THERE\u2019S WAVES DAD, THERE\u2019S WAVES!\u201d Koby grabs his board and is bouncing around on the porch. The wind has dropped off as it does most afternoons and the peak out front is producing smooth lefts and rights. He jogs down to the channel, dodging the water buffalo on the beach. It\u2019s local custom that when one of the animals gives birth, the owner gets to keep the first calf, but the second belongs to the community. Large herds of these water buffalo roam the island, belonging to everyone and no one.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From the water the jungle is drenched in the warm glow of late afternoon light, making it look deceptively inviting. But deeper inside it\u2019s writhing with leeches and animals and insects bigger than a human hand that crawl into your hut at night. The jungles are revered but mostly left alone.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2018.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Frankie leans into a left and effortlessly glides off the bottom before cracking his board under the lip. The move is standard but his positioning is so unique, only a few surfers in the world could capably draw those lines.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Much later, thousands of kilometres away back home, I\u2019ll ask Frankie if he has any regrets. There are surfers with lesser talent but more marketing savvy who have capitalised on having style or being a personality. They\u2019ve built their careers off it. Made good money out of it. There are others who have used their sway to get big jobs inside the industry, or those who have just left surfing altogether to pursue more lucrative ventures.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2019.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Frankie thinks about it then smiles.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cNah, I\u2019ve had a good life,\u201d he says. \u201cI can\u2019t complain. The only thing I would\u2019ve liked to have done is a couple more contests, to give it a proper crack, but we didn\u2019t really have the backup then. We could\u2019ve made it with a little more help. But I\u2019ve had the best days of my life freesurfing, surfing good waves. My sponsors have always been good to me. And I\u2019ve learnt a lot from travelling, from guys like Curren. I have good memories. Now I want to see if I can break into surfboard designing. I love it, I love shaping. And Koby\u2019s going to do well. He\u2019s got a really good style and he tries hard. It\u2019s nice to see your lightie ripping. I think he\u2019s got a good future ahead of him, that\u2019s the main thing. I\u2019m really stoked about that.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2020.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Back on the island that night, after the sun has dipped below the horizon and the insects come out and fill the darkness, we get word that the volcano has erupted again. The last time it happened the sky was filled with ash and all flights were cancelled for a week. The earth is constantly changing, moving, but on the island, for now, time stands still. A silence falls over everyone before Koby Oberholzer asks his dad, hopefully, \u201cDoes this mean we don\u2019t have to go home yet?\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/The%20Island%2021.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.zigzag.co.za\/magazine\/subscribe\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Zigzag Surfing Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n about=\"\/magazine\/hein%E2%80%99s-sight\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;In Hein\u2019s Sight&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    In Hein\u2019s Sight  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"In Hein\u2019s Sight\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/The-Intrepid-Explorer-logo2.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Hein%201.jpg?itok=zpBZpYDr\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hein\u2019s-sight\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hein\u2019s-sight\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hein\u2019s-sight&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Hein%201.jpg&amp;description=In Hein\u2019s Sight\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hein\u2019s-sight\" data-text=\"In Hein\u2019s Sight\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hein\u2019s-sight\" data-title=\"In Hein\u2019s Sight\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By Jo Kromberg&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hein Wagner\u2019s favourite colour is black (he thinks). He was born blind and, dear reader, before you think me gormless enough to pose such a question to a blind person, he says so himself on his website.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cI believe fear is the one thing that stands between disaster and us.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Apart from being blind (and evidently having a slightly dark sense of humour about it all), Wagner is no ordinary person. He was born on 24 May 1972 with a condition known as Leber\u2019s congenital amaurosis, or LCA \u2013 an inherited retinal degenerative disease characterised by severe loss of vision at birth. There is no known cure at present.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Wagner had to learn to be resilient and tenacious from a very young age. \u201cAt the age of five, my parents sent me off to the Worcester School (now Institute) for the Blind. At the time, I could not believe they dropped me off at the school at such a young age, and for days I got totally lost on the school grounds and in the boarding house,\u201d he recalls. \u201cBut, in retrospect, that is the best thing they could ever have done for me. Struggling to find my way at such a young age taught me such valuable lessons.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cI\u2019m inspired by people who find their passion and live fulfilling lives and at the same time making a contribution to society. My parents, both mom and dad, played a huge role in helping me believe in myself and being kind and generous to others.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He started his career as a switchboard operator, but the development of technology inspired him to enter the information technology industry, which saw him working for companies such as MWEB and Thawte Consulting. Here he quickly worked his way up to international sales manager, managing a team of 15 sighted individuals.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Yet, Wagner still struggled with his disability psychologically, and decided to take up extreme sports events. Some of his adventures include sailing from Cape Town to Rio de Janeiro in the Cape to Rio Yacht Race, skydiving, participating in IRONMAN events and completing the Absa Cape Epic. In 2009 he set the World Blind Land Speed Record at 322.52 km\/h.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Hein%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He also completed the 15th Antarctica Marathon in March this year (colloquially described as the harshest marathon on the planet), the first time ever that a blind person participated. Nick Kruiskamp, well-respected athlete and race champion, was Wagner\u2019s guide.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cI always knew the Antarctica Marathon would be a test of endurance, mental strength and perseverance. However, I never thought that being on the seventh continent \u2013 surrounded by ice-capped mountains, glaciers, icebergs, snow, penguins, whales and other wildlife \u2013 would be so emotionally overwhelming,\u201d says Wagner.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The treacherous race covered the most rugged terrain comprising mud, ice and sludge. He describes his perilous start of the race: \u201cWithin a few minutes, we tracked through the first bit of snow, followed by loads of mud. This quickly turned into a series of small water streams and, although we tried to jump over them, they pulled me in to the very centre of their icy cold. My mind was racing ahead to frostbite and amputations, when I told myself to snap out of it \u2013 motivating myself by realising it was just the beginning, so I forced myself to focus.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Wagner continues: \u201cIn a brutally honest way, Antarctica reflects the ever dramatically changing world we live in, as no five minutes down there are the same. A beautiful, sunny morning at zero degrees Celsius can very quickly change into a snowy ice wind and rain, with a chill factor of minus 15 to minus 25 degrees. I\u2019ve never experienced anything colder than Antarctica. It had me shaking to my very core!\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He participated to promote the abilities of those living with disabilities, and to raise funds and create awareness of the Vision Trust \u2013 a non-profit organisation he founded in mid-2008, which strives to make the world as we know it a more accessible place for persons living with disabilities.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cSince I can remember, I\u2019ve had a fascination with the North and South Poles, and when Mike Bailey (his running partner) came up with the idea to try and get an entry for the Antarctica Marathon, I jumped at the chance!\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;So how does Wagner prepare for events such as the Antarctica Marathon? \u201cIt is tricky to simulate the conditions in sunny Cape Town. We spent some time in a cold room at minus 18 degrees to acclimatise. I decided not to do many off-road miles or trail runs, as being blind leaves me a lot more exposed to ankle injuries than the sighted.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cNothing I did back home could ever prepare me for what we went through in Antarctica. My approach on the day was one step at a time.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He does not consider himself an adrenalin junkie, however. \u201cI guess I\u2019m just hooked on great experiences and life has so many to offer.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Hein%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"428\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Wagner says that accepting his blindness unconditionally has certainly been his most challenging expedition and achievement to date. \u201cJust when you think you get it, you\u2019ve got it, you have it \u2013 the mountain is just a little higher. Accepting the one thing I cannot do \u2013 see \u2013 allowed me to open my mind to so many other opportunities. The Absa Cape Epic also came close as my second biggest challenge, though.\u201d &nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;His unique experiences and outlook on life have afforded him numerous invitations to share his story and, in 2004, he decided to take up motivational speaking as a full-time career.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another of his initiatives is a concept known as &lt;em&gt;Dinner in the Dark&lt;\/em&gt;, and his website describes it thus: \u201cDinner in the Dark is the perfect dinner event to open the eyes of those who are simply too lazy to see.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cI\u2019ve been working in the corporate entertainment industry for many years, but this event really moves people deeply. Many funny things happen in the dark, like highly educated guests arguing with me over the fact that I gave them white wine and they asked for red wine. When the lights come on, they avoid me like the plague!\u201d Wagner says with a laugh.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is not all fun and games, though, and he has been faced with a few life-threatening situations in the course of his adventures. So how does he cope with fear? \u201cI made fear my friend a long time ago. I believe fear is the one thing that stands between disaster and us. Make fear your friend, acknowledge it for what it is, take from it what it is trying to point out to you, and get on with it.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He says his team is the most important part of all his adventures. \u201cWithout my team\u2019s backup and support, I cannot do what I do. Somehow I manage to find amazing people on my journey who are willing to help, support and get involved, and I\u2019m most grateful to all of them.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;So what are Wagner\u2019s plans for the next couple of years? Any exciting quests?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cAt this time, I\u2019m training very, very hard to try and qualify for the South African para-cycling team to represent South Africa in the 2016 Paralympic Games in Rio. A long, hard road ahead \u2013 however, I\u2019m willing to give it all I have.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When I ask him what message he most wants to impart to people through his life\u2019s quests, this remarkable man says the following: \u201cAnything you believe is not possible is actually possible; you just have to change the way you look at things. If you do that, the things you look at will change.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.heinwagner.co.za\u00a0\"&gt;www.heinwagner.co.za\u00a0&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;The Intrepid Explorer&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Intrepid%20Cover%20Dec_0_0.jpg?itok=NeVmD1IL\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;The Intrepid explorer&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9616\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/sun-international%E2%80%99s-stunning-nkandla-deal\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Sun International\u2019s Stunning Nkandla Deal&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Sun International\u2019s Stunning Nkandla Deal  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Sun International\u2019s Stunning Nkandla Deal\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Nkandla%20LM.jpg?itok=5mVsg6xN\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sun-international\u2019s-stunning-nkandla-deal\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sun-international\u2019s-stunning-nkandla-deal\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sun-international\u2019s-stunning-nkandla-deal&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Nkandla%20LM.jpg&amp;description=Sun International\u2019s Stunning Nkandla Deal\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sun-international\u2019s-stunning-nkandla-deal\" data-text=\"Sun International\u2019s Stunning Nkandla Deal\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sun-international\u2019s-stunning-nkandla-deal\" data-title=\"Sun International\u2019s Stunning Nkandla Deal\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Apr 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Ken Quero&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sun International has been on the prowl, and in March of this year announced the acquisition of casino resort group Peermont for a staggering R9.4 billion. The jewel in the crown is the iconic Emperor\u2019s Palace, one of the largest casino hotels in Africa. According to Sun International\u2019s chief executive Graeme Stephens, this will significantly expand its South African portfolio.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But it seems that this is just the beginning. Sun International may be in the final throes of closing a second deal.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;According to a confidential dossier that was recently left behind on the Gautrain, senior officials in the Department of Treasury have become increasingly concerned with the controversy surrounding the development of the presidential compound at Nkandla. South Africa has faced a number of headwinds in recent years. Internationally, the International Monetary Fund recently called for extensive reforms in the country, and both Fitch and Moody\u2019s have downgraded South African sovereign rating in the last six months.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Nkandla%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the domestic front, opposition parties have been in a state of frenzy over the matter, and even COSATU, ANC veterans, and party stalwarts like Ben Turok have been critical of the state of affairs. According to DA Parliamentary Leader, Mmusi Maimane, the amount of taxpayers\u2019 money spent on non-security upgrades to the Zuma compound is in excess of R52 million, and just about the only thing the DA, the Freedom Front and the EFF can agree on is that this amount \u2013 at least \u2013 must be repaid.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We can only speculate that the presidency ultimately succumbed to this barrage of pressure, and have to admit that the solution is rather elegant. According to the dossier, which is now in the hands of the Train and Truck Drivers Union of South Africa (TT), final contracts are being drawn up for the sale of Nkandla to Sun International. Our source would not comment on the price, but hinted that it could be in the mid-9-figures, which would net a cool return of around 100%.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Nkandla%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sun International CEO Graeme Stephens would not comment on plans for Nkandla but did say that \u2018While the Peermont portfolio of assets will initially increase the proportion of the combined business that arises in Southern Africa, it also opens the possibility of further restructuring of local assets, with a medium term objective of creating a portfolio of fewer assets of a higher quality.\u2019 It is clear that a significant KwaZulu-Natal acquisition would round off the group\u2019s African portfolio quite nicely, as the province has long been the one gaping hole in their portfolio.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Separate to the above, but clearly inspired by this development, we have learnt that the Department of Environmental Affairs is using the deal as a catalyst to clean up an issue that has been a thorn in its side for a considerable time. Sources close the department confirmed that as of the end of 2015, any and all hunting of predators that were bred in captivity will be outlawed. This calls to an end the abysmal practice of \u2018canned hunting\u2019, that has horrified conservationists both locally and abroad.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Nkandla%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;According to an early draft of the white paper that will be presented to parliament at its next sitting, all such animals that exist in captivity at the time of January 2016 will be confiscated and released in the Emakhosini Ophate Heritage Park. This park, which lies exactly midway between Nkandla, and its more famous sibling, the Hluhluwe-iMfolozi Game Reserve, has been crying out for attention for years, and is finally getting the injection it so desperately needs.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Recognising the importance of ethical hunting as a key pillar of growing the tourism industry in South Africa, Emakhosini Ophate will apparently be set aside exclusively for hunting. Says a source close to the department: \u2018While we object to the abuse of animals in captivity, the hunting of free roaming animals is the purest of sport, and will form a key pillar in our attempts to attract more foreign tourists to our beautiful country\u2019. In an interesting twist, anonymous sources claim that the first five years\u2019 worth of hunting quota of five lions has been allocated to Sun International as well\u2026 and the stay, spray and pray package will be called \u201cThis Poker Face ain\u2019t Lion to You\u201d.&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n    &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9596\" class=\"publisher-1340 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/take-it-easy\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Take It Easy&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img     &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/wild.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" It Easy\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/take-it-easy\" data-text=\"Take It Easy\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/take-it-easy\" data-title=\"Take It Easy\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Bridgena Barnard&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Why go away if all you want to do is read a book? It\u2019s a question I\u2019ve often been asked, and the answer is obvious: I have a family to consider. So while I was looking for a relaxed weekend to recharge, my nearest and dearest, who had no interest in being transferred to a world of dragons, heroes and romance, had other priorities.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Comfortably seated in a deck chair on the balcony of our log cabin at Lang Elsies Kraal cottage, I paid no attention to my family\u2019s pleas of \u201cI am hungry\u201d or \u201cWhat are we going to braai tonight?\u201d. Accompanied by bird song and the rippling sound of the Breede River, I finally got to wolf down the pages of my book, a Christmas gift of last year.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;My imagination coloured the scenes from the book with the soft pinks of the Langeberg wrapped in loose blue clouds. The smell of the adjacent cottages\u2019 braai fires finally prompted me to put my book down and suggest our supper options.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The kitchen, fully equipped with a stove, oven, microwave and tableware for six enabled me to prep a salad and some toasties in no time, while handy hubby took care of the braai. After supper the kids started playing cards and, apart from competitive shouts, the night was dead quiet.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Bontebok%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As they fell asleep, tired from swimming and playing outdoors, I listened to a lonely nightjar in the tree outside the chalet and felt wonderfully content. Hubby had enjoyed the birding and his treasure for the weekend was the abundance of black harriers in the area. I had escaped to never-never land.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Trip Planner&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The rest camp at Bontebok is on the banks of the Breede River, with wooden decks and braai areas perfectly situated to make the most of sunset. In addition to 10 one-room chalets ideal for two people (R900 base rate a night), there are now four family units that cost R1 500 a night and can sleep four people. The family units can accommodate an extra two people, R200 an adult, R100 a child. The camping facilities are outstanding, from R180 a night for one to two people.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThe project cost around R3-million to complete and created work for 16 people and a contractor from the local communities.\u201d Roland January, Bontebok park manager.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\/blog.htm?action=view-post&amp;id=4662\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Wild Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/752\"&gt;&lt;br&gt;Bontebok National Park&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Karen Hauptfleisch and the mountains of the Sahara  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Karen Hauptfleisch and the mountains of the Sahara\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #09906f' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/A%202015%20logo%20s.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%20M.jpg?itok=419V2fHZ\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/karen-hauptfleisch-and-mountains-sahara\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div
