Hauptfleisch and the mountains of the Sahara\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/karen-hauptfleisch-and-mountains-sahara\" data-text=\"Karen Hauptfleisch and the mountains of the Sahara\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/karen-hauptfleisch-and-mountains-sahara\" data-title=\"Karen Hauptfleisch and the mountains of the Sahara\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;h2&gt;Sunrise on Africa\u2019s Peaks - Karen Hauptfleisch summits the highest peaks in the remote Saharan countries of Chad and Libya&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;In a nutshell:&lt;\/strong&gt; A six-week long expedition into the Sahara to climb the highest peaks in Chad (Emi Koussi) and Libya (Bikku Bitti); part of a lifelong ambition to summit the highest peak in each of the 54 African countries.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Team:&lt;\/strong&gt; Eamon Fullen (UK), aka \u2018Ginge\u2019, the first person to climb the highest peaks in Africa; Misha Somerville (UK), a professional photographer and film maker; and seven local Toubou tribesmen.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Adventurer:&lt;\/strong&gt; Karen Hauptfleisch, age 50.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Residence:&lt;\/strong&gt; Pretoria.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Birthplace:&lt;\/strong&gt; Senekal, Free State.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Previous big adventures:&lt;\/strong&gt; Climbing and cleaning on the highest mountain in 31 African countries.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Other achievements:&lt;\/strong&gt; Founding the environmental non-profit organisation SOAPkidz (Sunrise On Africa\u2019s Peaks kidz), which has introduced over 17 000 disadvantaged children to nature.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Duration of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 6 weeks (with 3 days to summit Emi Koussi and 5 days to summit Bikku Bitti).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Completion date:&lt;\/strong&gt; December 2014.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Highlights&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Seeing things what most people - particularly women - will never have the privilege to experience. The Toubou tribe do not allow women to mix with the men, and although I was allowed some interaction I wasn\u2019t allowed to eat with them.&lt;br&gt;Witnessing the locals praying in the desert with the sun setting behind them.&lt;br&gt;Waking up in the middle of the desert and watching the sunrise. The constant wind across the desert left a lasting impression and the millions of stars in the night sky made this a truly amazing place.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Sponsors&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;My family sponsored part of my trip, and they give me all the support I could ever wish for. My thanks also to Stuart Martin who kept everyone informed of my whereabouts and managed, through extremely difficult circumstances, to get money transferred to Chad.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;The Kempinski Hotel in Chad gave us two free nights\u2019 accommodation.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;To find out more&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/sunriseonafricaspeaks.blogspot.com\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;sunriseonafricaspeaks.blogspot.com&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.soapkidz.org\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.soapkidz.org&nbsp;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Inspiration:&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;Climbing these peaks was part of a lifetime ambition to climb all 54 of Africa\u2019s highest peaks - Sunrise on Africa\u2019s Peaks (SOAP). Various coincidences brought Ginge, Misha and me together, presenting a once in a lifetime opportunity to plan a trip into an area of the African continent which very few people have ever seen.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Goals&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;To climb the highest peaks in Chad (Emi Koussi) and Libya (Bikku Bitti) and to see the sunrise from the summit of each.&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;To raise awareness about pollution on many of our mountains.&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"322\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Originality&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The two mountains we visited are some of the most inaccessible mountains in Africa. Bikku Bitti has only been summitted once (by Ginge - after three attempts), so ours was the second expedition to summit Libya\u2019s highest peak. I was the first woman to climb the mountain. I am aware of commercial expeditions to Emi Koussi but according to our guides, I was the first African woman to summit \u2013 and as a result they nicknamed me Madame Africa.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Planning&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We started planning in March 2014. There is very little infrastructure in Chad and communication is extremely difficult. Tourism is almost nonexistent and getting the necessary permits to travel to the north was really tricky.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Risks&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;These desolate and unforgiving desert regions meant that even a small oversight or mishap carried a real risk. Dangers included t&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;he history of civil unrest and war in the region, s&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;everal mine fields encountered on our way to the mountains, and s&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;corpions and snakes.&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%2012.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;The extreme remoteness meant that any medical emergency beyond our general first aid knowledge would have resulted in a 2-week-long evacuation, and the&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;&nbsp;risk of mechanical breakdown could have left us stranded with limited rations of water and food.&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The highest mountain in Libya, Bikku Bitti, is in one of the most remote, least accessible and least known part of the Sahara desert - during the Viking Lander projects, NASA identified the region as that which that most closely resembles the conditions on Mars.&nbsp;The area is unfit for human habitation and there are periods of 20 to 30 years with no rainfall. &nbsp;There is no permanent human habitation, no roads or tracks, just a great open void.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Wars and conflicts have also played their part in keeping people away. &nbsp;Although Libya has recently started opening up, the southern part of the country is still off limits, as is the Tibesti in northern Chad, creating one of the biggest areas in Africa that foreigners are officially not allowed to visit.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Back-up&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;I carried a satellite phone.&nbsp;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;We used two vehicles - a primary and a backup \u2013 which were robust enough to cope with the extreme terrain. We carried basic spares and repair items, and had a mechanically skilled driver.&nbsp;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Because of the vast distances, we carried 600 litres of water with us, as well as extra food rations for at least two weeks.&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If something went wrong, however, it would have taken up to 2 weeks for help from N\u2019djamena to reach us. &nbsp;Because we were in a vast ocean of rocks and sand, finding us could be compared to finding a rowing boat in the Atlantic.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I personally funded the whole expedition by taking out a second bond to the value of R380 000 on my house. &nbsp;The sensitive situation in south Libya meant that I was not able to advertise the trip, so was unable to find sponsors or self-funded people to join the trip and share the costs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Verification&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Videos and photos - Misha Somerville is making a documentary on the expedition. I reported back after the Emi Koussi summit to the Chadian Minister of Tourism at the South African Embassy in Chad.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Necessary technical skills&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Being able to survive in the desert and understand the dangers associated with snakes, scorpions, mine fields, unexploded ordnance and the lack of water was paramount to the success of the trip. The local Toubou people knew the area and navigated us through the desert.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Scariest moments&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Security police at the airport in Chad detained me after they noticed that I was using a satellite phone \u2013 which is illegal in Chad. &nbsp;Eventually, the head of security, who could not speak a word of English, dropped me off at my hotel. &nbsp;While driving there, he swerved left and right while showing me pictures of himself with VIPs on his camera. &nbsp;I thought it would be really tragic dying in a car accident in Chad even before the dangerous bit of the adventure started!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Mahadi, one of my porters, has a heart condition but was very stubborn and insisted on going to the top of Emi Koussi with me. I was petrified that he would have a heart attack.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Breaking down 150km from the nearest water and worrying that our driver, who went back to get vehicle parts, might have an accident or get lost and never make it back.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Lowest point&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;A huge personality clash within the team after climbing Emi Koussi in Chad, which nearly resulted in the trip to Libya being cancelled.&nbsp;I begged and begged, and eventually persuade the team to climb Bikku Bitti but it cost me another R60 000.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%209.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funniest moment&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;After some serious vehicle trouble, we were stuck waiting for our backup vehicle to return with the required parts. &nbsp;We were all sitting in the shade when Mahadi jumped up, assembled a gold detector and just walked off in the sunset, detector in his hand!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Most unexpected experience&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Driving 26 km along the Dohone Spur of the Tibesti Mountains in Southern Libya on the way to Bikku Bitti. The spur was like something out of the Avatar movie: absolutely breathtaking. No picture can ever capture the beauty of it.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Biggest lesson&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I learnt what Ubuntu is really about: I will always cherish is the way the locals looked after me and came to enjoy meeting the locals just as much as I enjoy the mountains. One incident stands out. I was in Ethiopia, travelling on the top of a beer truck, when a lady took my hand, looked me in the eyes and said something. &nbsp;When I asked the guy next to me what she said he replied \u201cshe said we are all one\u201d. &nbsp;Then an elderly lady who was lying with her back to me squeezed my hand. &nbsp;It was the most profound moment in my life. &nbsp;When the truck stopped, I was invited to her home - at 22:00 \u2013 and she cooked a chicken for me.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What would you have done differently&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Contact the South African embassy in the countries before my visit.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;Carried huge wads of cash. Despite what I was told by a bank in South Africa, my credit cards were not accepted in Chad.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Best piece of gear&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;My Columbia clothing.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Most amazing people you met on the trip&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Mahadi, my porter\/guide and the other Toubou people I met were gentle souls with a great sense of humour. They really knew the area and the environment well, so I always felt safe even when they were leading us into \u2018the unknown\u2019.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%2013.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What did you eat&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019m vegetarian so normally take my own mixture of soya and couscous, which only requires a cup of boiled water to prepare. &nbsp;The staple diet in Chad, however, is goat and very sweet pasta. &nbsp;The porters were quite shocked when I wanted salt on my pasta and I wouldn\u2019t eat goat meat.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What was the worst thing that bit you&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I was not bitten by anything major \u2013 but I got into serious trouble when I objected to a scorpion being killed. Apparently, in Chad, more people die from scorpion stings than malaria. &nbsp;With SOAPkidz, we teach the children and volunteers not to kill snakes\/spiders\/bats etc. But then we are close to medical help and our lives are not threatened.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What\u2019s next&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Probably the four Southern African islands (Madagascar, Seychelles, Mauritius and the Comoros).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Tips for other adventurers&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Follow your heart \u2013 even if your adventure does not make sense to anyone else.&nbsp;If you want to live your dream, you have to learn to let go of your own ego. I had to learn to contain my emotions and frustrations. People do things differently. &nbsp;Some people are very competitive and want to do everything on their own.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Karen%20Hauptfleisch%20replacement.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/A%202015%20logo%20s_0.jpg?itok=QMKoQFTc\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Adventurer 2015&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9595\" class=\"publisher-2376 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/reader%E2%80%99s-adventure-solo-wilderness\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Reader\u2019s Adventure - Solo, into the Wilderness&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Reader\u2019s Adventure - Solo, into the Wilderness  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Reader\u2019s Adventure - Solo, into the Wilderness\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/wheels-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Canyon%20MAIN_0.jpg?itok=DUyGTVjj\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/reader\u2019s-adventure-solo-wilderness\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/reader\u2019s-adventure-solo-wilderness\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/reader\u2019s-adventure-solo-wilderness&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Canyon%20MAIN_0.jpg&amp;description=Reader\u2019s Adventure - Solo, into the Wilderness\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/reader\u2019s-adventure-solo-wilderness\" data-text=\"Reader\u2019s Adventure - Solo, into the Wilderness\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/reader\u2019s-adventure-solo-wilderness\" data-title=\"Reader\u2019s Adventure - Solo, into the Wilderness\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics J\u00fcrgen H\u00f6ntsch&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Revisiting some of southern Africa's most remote wilderness areas was long overdue for J\u00fcrgen H\u00f6ntsch, so he planned a solo journey to Namibia's \u201cCanyon Land\u201d, via the Richtersveld.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Starting my trip into the wilderness at The Growcery was an excellent idea. The camp is beautifully situated on the banks of the Orange (Gariep) River, about 22km west of Vioolsdrif. It offers, besides the wet and wild river tours, great 4x4 trails.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The camp has 10 sites on grass, close to the water with a great view of the river. There are also chic shacks and en suite double rooms for the \u201csofter\u201d folk.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I had acquired a brand new Malamoo \u201cinstant\u201d tent for better connection with Mother Nature and slept very well on my air mattress.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After a hearty breakfast, breaking camp and deflating the Jeep\u2019s tyres, I was ready to tackle the western part (or second leg) of the Namaqua 4x4 Trail.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This was new territory for me. Driving along in a harsh and hot mountain desert wilderness really sharpens the senses. No cell phone signal, no barking dogs and no radio, TV and politics for at least a week. Priceless! Admiring the landscape, reading the trail, listening to the sound of the engine and watching over the GPS and tyre pressure monitor were the tasks at hand.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Richtersveld is hauntingly beautiful. Seared by blistering sun, it is \u2013 to me -- the uncontested champion of SA\u2019s wilderness areas. It now forms part of the greater Ai Ais\/Richtersveld Transfrontier Park, which is divided by a vein of life, the Gariep River, in an almost surreal contrast to its surroundings.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Canyon%202.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Summer temperatures can reach the mid-50s and rain is as scarce as diamonds. Life sustaining moisture comes in the form of early morning fog that rolls in from the cold Atlantic. It is called malmokkies by the locals and sustains a remarkable range of small reptiles, birds, mammals and plant life, some species found nowhere else. Dramatic and beautiful, this is not a pampered paradise but rather an arid wilderness retreat for the nature lover. My love for it goes back to my first visit in 1965.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Along the Akkedis Pass, gnarled quiver trees, tall aloes and quaint &lt;em&gt;halfmens&lt;\/em&gt; keep vigil over this inscrutable landscape. I stopped more than once to absorb the beauty and solitude, and take pictures.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The best camping spots at De Hoop were taken. It looked overcrowded, so I decided to continue south, towards Richtersberg, through thick river sand and with the temperature at 36\u00b0C. Louisa, the De Hoop receptionist, had warned me to avoid this section, but there was always deep sand in that area and what was wrong with a bit of sand driving? The tracks, however, differed from those I remembered and for some peace of mind I engaged the front airlockers whenever it seemed necessary. The trusty Jeep had no problems and my new set of A\/Ts performed really well in the sand.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the Richtersberg camp, I was rewarded by being the only camper and the visit turned out to be the highlight of my trip. I pitched my tent on a section of grass overlooking the river and the rugged mountains on the Namibian side. After a not-so-cold shower, I settled in my camping chair with a cold one. A few vervet monkeys played in the riverine thicket and two goliath herons watched from an island nearby.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When the sun vanished behind the mountains, I enjoyed a tasty rump steak with a chilled bottle of Durbanville\u2019s finest sauvignon blanc. In the fading daylight, the night spectacle started with hundreds of fireflies, in streaks of green light, dancing up and down and along the river.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Canyon%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;During my numerous travels (on four continents), I have met many remarkable people, and this trip turned out to be no exception. At the Kokerboomkloof camp, I met Braam from Nelspruit and his charming wife. They were there for six days in a 76 series Cruiser.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Kokerboomkloof was said to boast a number of spectacular rock formations. When I asked Braam about them, he smiled and said that fellow travellers, as well as park officials, weren\u2019t exactly forthcoming on the matter, and it had taken him three days to find them. He showed me the places and I took great pictures of these marvels, including a pair of little klipspringer nearby. Thanks again, Braam!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Roaming through the park, I compared today\u2019s situation with 10 years ago. It seemed to me that the ablution facilities provided at the various camps had had a positive effect on the environment. This was particularly noticeable at De Hoop, where visitors previously ignored the \u201cbush code\u201d, resulting in a disgusting situation and a health hazard, with plenty of flies.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A concern, however, was the making of new tracks, sometimes four running side by side, at places where road maintenance was neglected and corrugations had become a great nuisance.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I also observed that quiver trees were dying at an alarming rate, and couldn\u2019t help wondering whether the &lt;em&gt;halfmens&lt;\/em&gt; was disappearing\u2026 just like the rhino.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another disturbing thing was the great number of goats foraging in the park, particularly in the Richtersberg area, as well as dogs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The pontoon at Sendelingsdrift took us over the Gariep and into Namibia. Border crossing formalities were swiftly settled and soon I was heading north, on tar.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;An old wish was due to become reality. I was going to see the Fish River Canyon from \u201cthe other side\u201d, as I planned to drive around the canyon.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Canyon%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After refuelling at Rosh Pinah, I called in at Daisy Truck &amp; Auto to tighten my \u201ccosmetic\u201d Maxe runner boards. The corrugations had taken their toll and to diminish the rattles, I had squeezed empty plastic water bottles between the rails and the chassis. Johan would not accept payment and with a big smile handed back the plastic bottles. Well, he tried!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I headed east to the Namuskluft 4x4 base camp, at the end of a scenic valley in the harsh mountain desert, bordering the transfrontier park. It is well laid out with stands on a bit of lawn under shady trees. There are braai facilities, clean ablutions, Wendy houses, a pool and conference facilities. The camp offers self-drive and guided 4x4 trails, as well as hiking trails.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After setting up camp, I headed along the Bushman\u2019s Grave 4x4 trail into the mountains. The trail was not a great challenge. Game in the region includes gemsbok, kudu and mountain zebra, as well as smaller buck such as klipspringer and steenbok, but they remained invisible in the afternoon heat. Not finding the Bushman\u2019s Grave either, I returned to camp.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The following day, at the cattle post Witputs, 46km north of Rosh Pinah, I left the tar again and turned east onto the D463. The gravel road is in good condition and the geology is fascinating, but watch your travelling speed and look out for hidden obstacles. There was water in the Konkiep River and the vegetation attracts wildlife.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After about two-and-a-half hours of driving on gravel, with many photo stops and farm gate negotiations, I turned right into the Canyon National Park, and 30 minutes later I arrived at the Fish River Lodge. This is the only place on the \u201cother side\u201d from which you can see the canyon. It was a dream come true.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Canyon%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The lodge, perched on the western rim of the canyon, is an up-market retreat in the middle of nowhere, with a view like no other. It lies within a privately owned reserve of 450km2 and offers plenty of game viewing and bird spotting, and photo opportunities to match. From here you can explore the canyon and its surrounds. It is a special place in a dramatic location. Although I was not a lodge resident, I was handed a welcome cocktail and shown around by the friendly staff anyway! &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Located along the rim, less than 10m from the canyon\u2019s edge, are 20 chalets, each with its own terrace and outdoor shower, as well as roof-top windows for viewing the stars.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The restaurant, with 10 chalets on each side, has a pool and there are indoor and outdoor bars and dining facilities from where the spectacular sunsets can be enjoyed. I would have loved to experience the sun setting and painting the canyon, but that had to wait for another time.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Back on the D463, the Jeep rolled on north, eating up the kilometres in the dusty desert wilderness. The Drielingkop, or Inachakuppe, a landmark in that area, is visible from a great distance. Soon after it, I turned right against the GPS lady\u2019s order, and after some re-calculating, she finally agreed that I had made the correct decision.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After a mere 28km on tar, I crossed the Fish River near Seeheim and then turned south and hit the gravel once again. The C12 was in much better condition than on my last trip in 2011.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Canyon%206.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After a long day, I finally arrived at the Canyon Roadhouse, where the self-catering accommodation was fully booked. A room at 1145 Namibian dollars a night was beyond my budget so I decided to carry on camping. I set up camp at site No 11, right at the end, which turned out to be a good choice. Besides the missing grass, there was power, an enormous shade tree, braai facilities and a well-designed ablution block with clean toilets and a hot shower -- all to myself. And, as I found out later, there was plenty of wildlife in the neighbourhood.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The restaurant and bar have acquired a sort of cult status among visitors. The good old days of the automobile are celebrated in their theme \u2013 brilliant!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When I planned the trip, one of my ambitions was to drive down into the canyon. I knew it could be done, and Canyon Adventures said on their website they could arrange it, but I received no reply to my e-mails. Unfortunately, I found that they were doing only mule trips at the time, but would soon be back in business with the 4x4 trail. My bad luck!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Fish River Canyon is one of Namibia\u2019s most impressive natural wonders. I recently read that, contrary to popular belief, it wasn\u2019t \u201ccarved out by the power of the water over 1500 million years\u201d but rather was formed by plate movement and cracks in the earth's crust related to the break-up of Gondwanaland about 550 million years ago. It became the natural route of the river cutting its way along the floor. This also accounts for the sulphurous springs.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The canyon radiates a captivating solitude and silence and exerts a magnetic force drawing you back again and again. It has relatively modest colours and contours. It seems flat and soft at noon, when the sun is directly overhead. The colours deepen and intensify at other times of the day. The shapes within the canyon, viewed at different times, seem to be moving. At midday they appear to withdraw to the sides, flattening themselves against the multi-layered walls as though they fear the sun.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Canyon%207.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is an awesome place and should be approached with caution. I\u2019ve visited the canyon many times and have hiked down to the river in summer and in winter. We have pitched our tent next to the abyss and admired the sunset, stars and sunrise, back in the days when that was still allowed. But things have changed in the new Namibia, and the days of quiet and solitude at the canyon are long gone.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On my arrival at the famous Hell\u2019s Bend, the main lookout point where an information centre has been built, busloads of tourists spoiled the ambience. After a few quick pictures, I took the road south, along the canyon\u2019s edge.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After Sulphur Spring is the start of the hiking trail - the only place where you are still allowed to walk down in \u201corganised groups\u201d. Silence returned and I enjoyed the rest of the 20km trip along the rim.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The road deteriorated into a 4x4 trail leading down two terraces, where I engaged low range. After many photo stops I reached the end of the road, and here I opened a cold one to celebrate my reunion with the canyon.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;My thoughts went way back to my first visit when the only attraction of Ai-Ais was a little pond, accommodating the thermal spring, surrounded by palm trees and thorny bush. A few visits later, over the Easter weekend in 1970, we were the first visitors to the new camp. It wasn't officially open yet, but they allowed us to stay in one of the new chalets, sleeping on brand new mattresses that were still wrapped in plastic, and they didn't charge us a cent. A few years later that holiday camp was washed away by a devastating flood \u2013 and not for the last time!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On my way back I was signalled to stop by the driver of a blue Pajero with a GP registration number. \u201cWhere does the road go?\u201d he asked. \u201cYou know, my navigator isn\u2019t so good,\u201d referring to his wife sitting next to him.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I laughed and answered: \u201cThis road goes nowhere \u2013 &lt;em&gt;pad loop dood&lt;\/em&gt; \u2013 and don\u2019t worry my navigator is hopeless!\u201d So we had a good laugh and a chat, and then he made a U-turn and followed me.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On my final leg, I stayed for two nights at the Norotshama River Resort, on the northern banks of the Gariep. Situated in the Aussenkehr Nature Park, it offers a variety of leisure activities.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The shaded camping sites are on grass and there is electricity, clean ablutions and a good restaurant, overlooking the river. Here I met up again with Hennie and his crew from The Growcery camp, on their return from a trip far down the river.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;My first excursion was into the rugged and sweltering Gamkab River Canyon at a blistering 39\u00b0C (October). The trail follows the riverbed for about 10km and forms part of the old Ai-Ais 4x4 trail. Along a trickle of water, the riverbed is painted white by the crystallisation of soluble salts. Gigantic rock faces tower on the western side of the canyon. They are carved out at the bottom, and one can easily park a car underneath them.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The scenic Gamkab Canyon is another place of great silence, rarely frequented and deprived of life in that harsh desert wilderness, but it\u2019s a rewarding drive. The C13 gravel road through the transfrontier park is very scenic. I made an excursion up a mountain on a steep track from which there is a great view over the river, the Aussenkehr winelands and the Richtersveld.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Then it was time for my last trail, the canyon route in the Aussenkehr Nature Park. It is called the Canyon 4x4 Trail, but apart from two rocky obstacles it is relatively easy to drive. You have to pay 145 Namibian dollars to get a key that unlocks a gate.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trail follows a dry riverbed through the canyon with dramatic dolerite rock formations, 100m high. This would make a great location for a Wild West movie.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After crossing the Springbokvlakte and negotiating the rocky obstacles, the trail passes a kloof of quiver trees, followed by a plain, sparsely grown with silvery Aristida grass waving in the wind. Here I spotted a number of wild horses and, among them, a mountain zebra with an identity crisis.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It had been a journey into the past, but I also conquered new frontiers and experienced again that overwhelming feeling of relaxation in the solitude and tranquility of wild places \u2013 particularly the desolate and hauntingly beautiful \u201cCanyon Land\u201d.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;More information&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Driver&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;J\u00fcrgen H\u00f6ntsch, 73, learned about off-roading and sand driving in the old South West Africa, particularly during a Kalahari crossing in 1970 with a friend in his Toyota Corona 1200 bakkie.&nbsp;Geology played a role in his professional life, so it still interests him in his retirement.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Vehicle:&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Customised\/converted Jeep KJ Cherokee 2002 Ltd, 2.5l CRD with OME raised suspension, Rancho dampers, ARB bumper\/winch bar, ARB air-lockers front and rear, Centreforce competition clutch, large tyres, SAC chip and a number of other modifications. No mechanical problems were experienced.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;J\u00fcrgen's first 4x4:&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Brand new Toyota FJ40 Series Land Cruiser in 1975.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Tyres:&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;New set of Kumho Road Venture A\/Ts. Jurgen was impressed by their performance in sand. No punctures.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The trip:&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Total distance: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 2450km&lt;br&gt;On gravel and trails: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 1210km&lt;br&gt;Average fuel consumption: &nbsp;10.3l\/100km&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Fridge:&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Engel 40-litre, powered at night by a jump start\/power supply.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.mysubs.co.za\/magazine\/leisure-wheels\"&gt;Leisure Wheels&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/1504_LW.jpg?itok=XvB0Frmw\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Leisure wheels&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9605\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/rhino-conservation-ambassadors-imfolozi-wilderness-trail\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Rhino Conservation Ambassadors on the iMfolozi Wilderness Trail&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Rhino Conservation Ambassadors on the iMfolozi Wilderness Trail  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Rhino Conservation Ambassadors on the iMfolozi Wilderness Trail\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Rhino%20M.jpg?itok=BLTOyMtk\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rhino-conservation-ambassadors-imfolozi-wilderness-trail\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rhino-conservation-ambassadors-imfolozi-wilderness-trail\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rhino-conservation-ambassadors-imfolozi-wilderness-trail&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Rhino%20M.jpg&amp;description=Rhino Conservation Ambassadors on the iMfolozi Wilderness Trail\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rhino-conservation-ambassadors-imfolozi-wilderness-trail\" data-text=\"Rhino Conservation Ambassadors on the iMfolozi Wilderness Trail\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rhino-conservation-ambassadors-imfolozi-wilderness-trail\" data-title=\"Rhino Conservation Ambassadors on the iMfolozi Wilderness Trail\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Pics Penny Parker&nbsp;and Micah van Schalkwyk&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Leaves for loo paper, voracious sand fleas, toe-nibbling river shrimp, 20kg backpacks to carry supplies for five days, taking turns on night watch to guard the camp, heat, dirt and walking among wildlife \u2013 these were some of the challenges faced by seven women who recently completed an iMfolozi Wilderness Trail in memory of the late Dr Ian Player.&nbsp;Teenagers Gwendolyn Isaacs from Ballito, KZN (18), Jacom\u00e9 Pretorius (16) from George, Western Cape, and Kelly Dramos (16) from Maputo, Mozambique, said it was one of the best experiences of their lives.&nbsp;All of them participated in last year\u2019s World Youth Rhino Summit and were chosen to join the \u2018Women in the Wilderness\u2019 trail because of their ongoing youth ambassador efforts to raise awareness of the continuing rhino poaching crisis in South Africa. They were joined by Sheelagh Antrobus (Project Rhino KZN), Micah van Schalkwyk (World Youth Rhino Summit coordinator), Bronwyn Laing (Rhino Art \u2018Let our Voices Be Heard\u2019 campaign leader) and Penny Parker (Cape Union Mart). &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rhino%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Player\u2019s lifelong work to conserve the southern white rhino and the iMfolozi Wilderness area, which forms part of the greater Hluhluwe-iMfolozi Park, was the inspiration for the group to give up their home comforts and leave school and rhino conservation work for a few days to personally experience life in the wild, surrounded by the Big 5. The 30 000ha area is home to a large population of endangered black and white rhino and is under constant threat from armed poaching syndicates. It is also threatened by Ibutho Coal\u2019s pending application to develop an open-cast mine close to the Wilderness boundary fence, which conservation groups are fighting to prevent, saying the continual noise, light and dust emanating from the mine will destroy the sensitive ecology of the Wilderness area, as well as intensify poaching threats.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rhino%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With no communications or contact with the outside world, the group - led by Denis Zondi and Sipho Buthelezi, field guides from the Wilderness Leadership School - traversed the hills and valleys flanking the Black iMfolozi River, sleeping in the open and cooking evening meals using only two pots, one kettle and a large spoon. Tasty pasta dinners, oats porridge for breakfast, cheese and tuna sandwiches for lunch and dried fruit to snack on kept them fed. Water drawn from the river and purified provided their drinking water. The girls became quite fond of \u2018Mr Dug\u2019 \u2013 the yellow and green hand trowel, so necessary for digging that important little hole after early morning coffee.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rhino%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cWe weren\u2019t allowed toilet paper!\u201d exclaimed Bronwyn Laing. \u201cSo we became very good at identifying non-poisonous leaves and grass to use instead!\u201d Lion, rhino, hyena, elephant and buffalo were always in close proximity and on night three, two elephants visited their campsite, causing the group to beat a hasty retreat in the darkness. \u201cWe weren\u2019t in any real danger,\u201d said Micah van Schalkwyk from Pietermaritzburg, who spotted the looming pachyderms during her night watch. \u201cMoving away from them was more about showing respect: we were, after all, in their world.\u201d Experiencing the interconnectedness of wildlife, wilderness and humanity was a constant theme of the five-day trail and each woman took away a different experience. \u201cWilderness represents that quiet place we all have to go sometimes when we need to look at life through a wider lens. Wilderness teaches patience, rhythm and process, and gave me time to reflect,\u201d said Micah. \u201cBeing in the wilderness is not easy but it is simple. By un-complicating life, you leave room to learn about yourself and find peace.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rhino%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Penny Parker agreed: \u201cFor me, the most important and memorable moments of the trail where those times in which nothing was said. \u2018Solo time\u2019 spent reflecting on how profoundly the wilderness impacted us, the Night Watch and the great sense of responsibility towards your fellow trailists. The sounds of the night, the distant roar of a lion, incessant chirping of cicadas, the lullaby of a fiery-necked nightjar and the eerie whoop of a hyena all combine to create a magical moment in which you literally feel more at home than ever. \u201cAnd of course, the camp life: collecting and purifying water, making the fire, preparing dinner, washing pots and ensuring no sign of our presence was left behind. \u2018Leave no trace\u2019 meant absolute respect for the land that supported us.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rhino%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cIt was the personal heartache of being lead to a grassy slope on which the two-year old bones of a poached rhino still lie - a bleached, silent appeal to please do more,\u201d said Sheelagh Antrobus. \u201cOn the opposite bank of the river, a breeding herd of elephant wandered past and buffalo wallowed in the shallows. I fingered the long rib bones and perfectly pitted vertebrae of what was once a magnificent rhino in her prime as Zondi related the tale of how she was shot by poachers and her horns forcibly removed. I felt personally responsible: it happened during my watch. \u2018I\u2019m so, so sorry\u2026\u2019 was all I could whisper to the bones through which the wind blew a deeply sad memorial, and make a promise to do more to protect KZN\u2019s rhinos.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rhino%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trail ended at the memorial iSivivane (stone cairn) at the iMfolozi Centenary Centre, built by the World Youth Rhino Summit participants last year, where each trial member laid a pebble from the Wilderness in memory of Dr Ian Player.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To show your support and contribute to the Save the iMfolozi Wilderness campaign, please visit: &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.indiegogo.com\/projects\/women-in-the-wilderness\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.indiegogo.com\/projects\/women-in-the-wilderness&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/831\"&gt;&lt;br&gt;iMfolozi Game Reserve&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/830\"&gt;Hluhluwe Game Reserve&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9564\" class=\"publisher-1333 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" Game Reserve: two small KZN parks well worth visiting&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Inanda Dam and Weenen Game Reserve: two small KZN parks well worth visiting  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Inanda Dam and Weenen Game Reserve: two small KZN parks well worth visiting\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta           &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/inanda-dam-and-weenen-game-reserve-two-small-kzn-parks-well-worth-visiting\" data-text=\"Inanda Dam and Weenen Game Reserve: two small KZN parks well worth visiting\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/inanda-dam-and-weenen-game-reserve-two-small-kzn-parks-well-worth-visiting\" data-title=\"Inanda Dam and Weenen Game Reserve: two small KZN parks well worth visiting\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\/author\/teagan-cunniffe\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Teagan Cunniffe&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Grand names dominate the KwaZulu-Natal nature scene. Hluhluwe, iSimangaliso, Ithala, Phinda \u2013 these parks take priority on most bush-lovers\u2019 lists. And for good reason: when it comes to big game in the garden province, they\u2019re unmatched. But that doesn\u2019t mean they\u2019re all that\u2019s out there.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;With the morning sun rising over Durban\u2019s golden shores, Justin Fox hit the N3 heading inland in search of the smaller, two-wheel-drive-friendly nature escapes that slip through most itineraries.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;\/blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sound familiar? That\u2019s the opening text for &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\/author\/justin-fox\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Justin Fox\u2019s&lt;\/a&gt; &lt;em&gt;KwaZulu-Natal\u2019s Smaller Parks&lt;\/em&gt; feature in the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\/magazine-issues\/december-2014\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;December 2014 issue of Getaway Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I followed his dust trail to &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/msinsi.co.za\/inanda\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Inanda Dam,&lt;\/a&gt; a place I have visited many a time with friends and family, and &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.kznwildlife.com\/index.php\/weenen.html\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Weenen Game Reserve &lt;\/a&gt;(where?!). It was at the latter that I discovered first-hand the difficulty of single-handedly setting up a tent in gale force wind. Turned out I wasn\u2019t so successful \u2013 after the tent ripped I ended up sleeping in the car.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Here are a few of my images from the two days I spent on the road.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Smaller%20parks%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Amongst the bird life, the most common sighting you\u2019ll have at Inanda are the zebra. As with all wildlife photography (and wildlife interactions in general!), let them do their thing around you and don\u2019t go too close.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Smaller%20parks%201%20%28M%29.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"385\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;The green banks at Inanda Dam make for great picnic and camping areas, just on the shores of this beautiful expanse of water.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Smaller%20parks%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;At first I didn\u2019t see this giraffe, silhouetted by the sunset at Weenen Game Reserve. When I did I did a sudden, skidding stop and reversed back up the hill until I was in the right place. Go Getz go!&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Smaller%20parks%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Smaller%20parks%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Smaller%20parks%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;I saw so much at Weenen Game reserve, eland, red hartebeest, kudu and more in one evening. This was such a worthwhile game reserve to visit!&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Read Just Fox\u2019s full feature on KZN\u2019s smallest parks in the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\/magazine-issues\/december-2014\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;December 2014 issue of Getaway Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\/photography\/kwazulu-natals-smaller-parks\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Getaway Blog&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2463\"&gt;eNanda Adventures Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3863\"&gt;Mzinyathi Falls Crags Rock Climbing&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/864\"&gt;Weenen Game Reserve&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" style=\"text-decoration: underline;\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/1529\"&gt;Tugela River Rafting&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Getaway-march2015-cover.jpg?itok=3p44k_VR\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Getaway&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;Featured blog provided by Getaway Magazine&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9346\" class=\"publisher-1335 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/hail-high-and-mighty\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Hail the High and Mighty&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Hail the High and Mighty  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Hail the High and Mighty\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #222222' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/cl.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%26L%20High%20%26%20Mighty.jpg?itok=LxK6q3ij\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hail-high-and-mighty\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hail-high-and-mighty\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hail-high-and-mighty&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%26L%20High%20%26%20Mighty.jpg&amp;description=Hail the High and Mighty\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hail-high-and-mighty\" data-text=\"Hail the High and Mighty\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hail-high-and-mighty\" data-title=\"Hail the High and Mighty\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Keri Harvey, pics &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.keri-harvey.com\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Keri Harvey&lt;\/a&gt; and supplied &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Kruger\u2019s Magnificent Seven elephants were so named for their giant tusks. Since the last of them died 30 years ago, 15 new princes to the throne have been chosen. They are the Emerging Tuskers.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We are up early, ready to leave when the gate opens at Letaba Rest Camp in northern Kruger. The first light of day offers excellent game viewing and sightings of interesting animal behaviour, and we\u2019re not missing the action for anything. In the picnic basket, a flask of hot coffee and a week\u2019s supply of rusks is backup, should we encounter something extraordinary and stay out longer than usual.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We spot the usual suspects \u2013 impala, baboons sunning themselves, and a large herd of buffalo in the distance, as we head in the direction of the Giriyondo Border Gate, which connects Kruger with Limpopo National Park in Mozambique. This effectively creates the Great Limpopo Transfrontier Park that also includes Zimbabwe\u2019s Gonarezhou. The day is warm and still, hardly a leaf moves. Then a tree next to the road shakes and we stop and wait. The Mopani tree continues to shiver.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A grey trunk appears, so close we can see the scars in its wrinkled skin. And then the tusks, the huge tusks. One drapes long and low to the ground, the other curves upwards. There\u2019s no mistaking that they belong to a giant elephant, and we know this is our lucky sighting for the day.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Slowly the massive bull emerges. He looks back at us but shows no aggression. Still, his size is intimidating as we sit transfixed in what feels like a Lilliputian double cab. We watch and he watches and for a moment I wonder who is really watching whom, since we are the intruders today.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The bull forces his way out of the Mopani thicket and we get to photograph him from all angles, and notice his perfectly shaped ears as he slowly eases out onto the roadside, before he ambles off ahead of us.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/High%20%26%20Mighty%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"385\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Emerging tusker Mculu has noticeable curved tusks and was first spotted by Kirsty Redman in 2009. He lives around Letaba.&lt;\/em&gt; &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Back at camp, we head for the the Elephant Hall museum, where the Magnificent Seven \u2013 the seven biggest tuskers in Kruger \u2013 are honoured, and enquire about the identity of our big tusker that morning. A photo ID display of current big tuskers there makes this easy, and Kirsty Redman, interpretive officer for the Nxanatseni Region of Kruger, is around to confirm our excitement.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We had in fact seen Masthulele, currently the biggest known and named elephant in Kruger. He\u2019s one of the current crop called the Emerging Tuskers and is named after Dr Ian Whyte, Kruger\u2019s retired large-mammal scientist, who formalised an Emerging Tuskers project in about 2001.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Kirsty explains that Masthulele means \u2018the quiet one\u2019, which was Dr Whyte\u2019s local name, one he earned from his colleagues for his quiet temperament on research trips, a temperament he shares with Masthulele.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Back in the early 1980s, when elephant poaching in Kruger was a big problem, Dr Uys deVillers Pienaar (known as U de V), chief warden at the time, had the idea of calling the seven elephants with the biggest tusks in Kruger the Magnificent Seven, to raise awareness of the poaching problem as well as honour any conservation success.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Each of these elephants was named for where it lived or what it looked like \u2013 Dzombo, Kambaku, Jo\u00e3o, Mafunyane, Ndlulamithi, Shawu and Shingwedzi. Public response was overwhelming, awareness went global, and the Magnificent Seven \u2013 which were regularly spotted \u2013 became arguably the most renowned elephants on Earth.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/High%20%26%20Mighty%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Ngonyama (on the right) means \u2018lion\u2019 in Tsonga and honours renowned Sanparks conservationist Dr U de V (Tol) Pienaar, who survived being bitten by a lioness in the mid 1950s. Ngonyama is docile and doesn\u2019t mind being photographed.&lt;\/em&gt;&nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But by the mid-eighties, all The Magnificents were dead \u2013 two at the hands of poachers. Their glory days were short \u2013 only around five years \u2013 but most of their lives were long, many living into their fifties. Dzombo died in a hail of AK47 bullets fired by poachers from Mozambique, and Kambaku had to be euthanised after a bullet wound turned septic. The rest of the Magnificents died of natural causes.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThese elephants were the biggest of that era,\u201d Kirsty tells us. \u201cAnd they roamed throughout the park. So the chances of the public seeing these big tuskers was high. Even now, decades after the last of The Magnificents died, people remain fascinated by them. It may be their sheer size \u2013 each had tusks weighingin at a combined minimum of 100kg \u2013 or maybe simply because they are elephants and embody grace and intelligence.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Now, with the new generation of big tuskers in Kruger, the legend continues. Elephants are constantly being monitored as contenders for the title Emerging Tusker \u2013 their tusks need to protrude at least a metre from the lip line \u2013 and at the moment there are 15. All the present tuskers are named in honour of rangers or SANParks staff members, both living and deceased, who made a notable contribution to conservation. The 15 are Bidzane, Machachule, Masasana, Masthulele, Madolo, Mavalanga, Mbazo, Mculu, Ngunyupezi, Ngonyama, Ntombazana, Nwashinangana, Thandamamba, Timaka and Tsotsi.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Kruger currently has about 17 000 elephants and a limited elephant-poaching concern, having lost just two to poachers in 2014. So for now the 15 Emerging Tuskers are safe in their various territories across the park. Masthulele \u2018The Quiet One\u2019 heads the list and continues to fascinate all who see him. He symbolises this new generation of greats, and has claimed his place as a living legend among elephants so impressive they simply have to be seen.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za\/subscribe\/\"&gt;Country Life&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3285\"&gt;Kruger National Park (North and Far North)&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\"
