class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;h2&gt;JEAN CRAVEN, the first person to complete all six inter-continental swims&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;In a nutshell:&lt;\/strong&gt; Completing the six inter-continental swims and in the process raising in excess of US$300 000 for 11 children\u2019s and orphanage charities in South Africa and Russia.&nbsp;The swims were:&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Asia to North America 5.5km (Bering Strait) 2014&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;North to South America 21.3km (Isthmus of Panama) 2013&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Asia to Africa 21km (Red Sea) 2012&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Asia to Oceana \/Australasia 23.3km (Papua New Guinea to Indonesia) 2011&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Asia to Europe 12km (Bosphorus) 2010&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Europe to Africa 17km (Strait of Gibraltar) 2009&nbsp;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Category:&lt;\/strong&gt; Individual; assisted&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Adventurer:&lt;\/strong&gt; Jean Craven, 43 years&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Jean%20Craven%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Birthplace:&lt;\/strong&gt; Que Que, Rhodesia (now Kwe Kwe, Zimbabwe)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Residence:&lt;\/strong&gt; Johannesburg&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Profession:&lt;\/strong&gt; &nbsp;Entrepreneur&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Previous big adventures:&lt;\/strong&gt; Swimming 38km across Lake Tanganyika.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Duration of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 6 days, over 6 years&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Completion date of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 29 July 2014&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Highlights:&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;Becoming the first person to have completed all inter-continental swims; the extremely remote locations and attendant logistical issues; sighting various water animals including orcas, sharks, crocodiles, and walruses&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Jean%20Craven%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Sponsors&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;ETG (Papua New Guinea, Panama, Bering)&nbsp;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Barak Fund Management (Panama, Bering)&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Riparian Commodities (Panama, Bering)&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;NMB Insurance Brokers (Bering)&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;RFIB Insurance Brokers (Bering)&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"&gt;Eurofin Asia (Bering)&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;To find out more&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.madswimmer.com\"&gt;www.madswimmer.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/pages\/Madswimmercom\/109754595726429\"&gt;www.facebook.com\/pages\/Madswimmercom\/109754595726429&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.madswimmer.com\/our-cause\/\"&gt;http:\/\/www.madswimmer.com\/our-cause\/&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Jean%20Craven%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Goal&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;To complete all the intercontinental swims and, through Madswimmer, raise money for children\u2019s charities.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Originality&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;To the best of my knowledge three other swimmers have completed 4 or 5 inter-continental swims but no one has done all 6.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Planning&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Each trip took on average 9 months planning and administration. Getting permission to swim across international boundaries was especially time-consuming: getting permission for the Red Sea swim took 18 months!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Risks&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Besides drowning and, on the Bering Strait swim, hypothermia, there was also the chance of being attacked by hostile sea animals.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Jean%20Craven%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Back-up&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We always had support boats though these were not always up to much. On the PNG crossing for example I was the only swimmer. A good friend of mine (I struggled to convince anyone to join me for the swim because of the remote location), together with a local boat driver supported me from a \u2018banana boat\u2019, a small wooden boat with a 40cc outboard so I kept close to the shore where I could.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On some trips we had spotters for crocodiles (Papua New Guinea and Panama), sharks (Papua New Guinea, Red Sea) and walruses (Bering Strait). On the Bering swim, we had lifeguards and hypothermia doctors on the boat.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Corporate sponsors helped cover our costs on the day of the swim but I paid my own accommodation and flights. What cash was left from the corporate sponsors went to charity. Donations from the public entirely went to our charities.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Verification&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Photographs, video footage and the word of our fellow swimmers.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Jean%20Craven%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Inspiration&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The first leg, swimming the Strait of Gibraltar, was the result of a bet between friends \u2013 with the winnings donated to charity. Then came the familiar \u201cwhat next\u201d question: so, I decided to attempt to become the first person to complete the inter-continental swim challenge to raise funds for children\u2019s charities.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Necessary technical skills&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Obviously being able to swim long distances in open water, but as with most extreme adventures the key thing is to have a strong, determined mind \u2013 particularly when organizing and training for the event.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Scariest moment&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Seeing the meter reading a current of 7km\/hour and 3.2 degrees C water temperature in the Bering Strait&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Lowest point&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The arrival of a general from the Papua New Guinea army at our shack at 10pm the evening before our planned swim telling us we wouldn\u2019t be permitted to do so.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Jean%20Craven%209.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funniest moment&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;After a few celebratory drinks at a bar following our final swim, the entire population of Nome, Alaska joined us for a tour of a luxury cruise liner that was only intended for the swimmers. Luckily the Captain was a South African.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Biggest lesson&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Perseverance will grant you success.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What would you have done differently&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Started earlier in my life with this swimming adventure.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Best piece of gear&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Vaseline&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Anything you wish you\u2019d taken along&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;More swimmers.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Jean%20Craven%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Most amazing person you met on the trip&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There were two. Amos Oxereuk, an ex Wall Street capitalist who\u2019d returned home to Wales, Alaska to join his fellow Inupiaq and assisted us in our Bering Strait swim. Steve Tekwei, PNG surf champ and head of the Sunset Surf Club &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.journeyman.tv\/?lid=57146&amp;tmpl=transcript\"&gt;http:\/\/www.journeyman.tv\/?lid=57146&amp;tmpl=transcript&lt;\/a&gt; who helped us in Papua New Guinea. I sent him a BlackBerry from South Africa when I got back so that we could message and keep contact.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What did you eat&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Carbs before swims, beer after.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Worst thing that bit you&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The bug to do the next adventure.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What hurt most&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The chafing on my neck \u2013 the result of wearing a wetsuit for so long in salt water.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Jean%20Craven%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What\u2019s next&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Swimming in the lake below the Ojos del Salado peak \u2013 the world\u2019s highest ever swim at 6400m. We have already registered this with the Guinness Book of Records.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Tip for other adventurers&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;NIKE (Just do it)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Disclaimer&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The contenders for the Nightjar Adventurer 2015 competition were all interviewed by Nightjar. The content included therein is, to our knowledge, accurate and true.&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/A%202015%20logo%20s_0.jpg?itok=QMKoQFTc\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Adventurer 2015&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9563\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/bonkers-boesmanland\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Bonkers in Boesmanland&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Bonkers in Boesmanland  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Bonkers in Boesmanland\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Boesmanland%201%20%28M%29.jpg?itok=wodK9otV\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bonkers-boesmanland\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bonkers-boesmanland\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bonkers-boesmanland&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Boesmanland%201%20%28M%29.jpg&amp;description=Bonkers in Boesmanland\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bonkers-boesmanland\" data-text=\"Bonkers in Boesmanland\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bonkers-boesmanland\" data-title=\"Bonkers in Boesmanland\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words and pics Andrew Brukman&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As I start to lose control I feel an internal explosion of cold panic as if mercury is shooting up every nerve ending in my body and spilling out of my pores, freezing as it makes contact with the air. A moment ago my wandering thoughts were of beautiful landscapes and worriless futures. Now thought is suspended for two seconds. Then I look up, sight as blurry as sound, with nothing but a desiccated windscreen on the bonnet, the glass still in one piece but with cracks all over it, like a dried out salt pan in the Kalahari. The severity of the situation quickly hits us; we have just rolled our car on a dirt road in remote southern Tanzania somewhere near the border of Mozambique. In a region known for man-eating lions.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A few weeks earlier I\u2019d taken a call from Paul, a friend of mine from school, \u201cEeerrrr\u2026 howzit Andy, I\u2019m going on a eight-month road trip with Zanne to Chad in two weeks, do you want to come?\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Not the most informative or formal of propositions, but he had hooked me with \u201croad trip\u201d and \u201cChad\u201d.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cWhere on route are we going? What must I bring?\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cJust bring matches, we must NEVER run out of matches,\u201d he shouted over the phone, \u201cI\u2019ve got a spare &lt;em&gt;gat&lt;\/em&gt; (revolver) for you!\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Boesmanland%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;The well-known Kokerboom, or Quiver Tree, is prolific in Boesmanland in the Northern Cape.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After rambling through some vague coordinates to the north, south, east or west of a general area near a somewhat plausible village name, it became very obvious that this wasn\u2019t going to be a standard Lonely Planet page-turner. We were to go to the last wildernesses of Africa; remote areas with no reserve boundaries and no inhabitants \u2013 untouched, uncontrolled and brutally wild.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trip would take three intrepid South Africans; Zanne Labuschagne, a recent conservation biology masters graduate, Paul Benecke, graduate in civil engineering, myself, Andrew Brukman, a professional photographer and producer, and a 1998 Land Rover 300TDI through the bushman lands of Northern Cape in South Africa into Namibia; across to Botswana to track wild elephants on unexplored islands in the Okavango Delta; to Zambia to see an ancient dance ritual of the Chechewa tribe; on to Malawi for a surf on the lake, into man-eating lion territory in remote southern Tanzania; then through Kenya, Democratic Republic of Congo, Central African Republic, Cameroon and eventually Zakouma National Park in south-eastern Chad.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Boesmanland%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;A view looking over a farm in the heart of the Karoo. The Karoo Koppies in the far distance lead onto dwarf shrub and rocky plains.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;According to Paul, 90km\/hr is apparently the most fuel-efficient speed to travel in a Land Rover. He is like an old mechanic with early onset Alzheimer\u2019s \u2013 seemingly experienced after years in the field but with massive gaps of knowledge. Still, you don\u2019t argue with him so we decided to call our trip \u201c90km\/hr\u201d. It started off as an essential money saving scheme for our lowly budget but ended up as the perfect metaphor for our trip.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trip wasn\u2019t about racing to the finish. We wanted to find the most obscure dirt roads, far-out camping sites and fascinating people in the hope that we would discover places where no travel blog or guide had featured. Most importantly though we sought the feeling you get in places unspoiled by footprints and the interaction you have with strangers untainted by tourism.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Boesmanland%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;In these hot and sunny areas of Karoo shade is a currency provided by sparsely positioned trees for cattle to rest under.&nbsp;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trip began with a bang and a thud \u2013 the thud of our tent falling off our roof rack and into the tangle of vineyards somewhere between Robertson and Montagu. We were driving from a successful opening night at the Wacky Wine Festival, a popular event held just outside Cape Town in the well-known wine region of Kannaland.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It all started making sense when we sped, at 90km\/h, past Ronnie\u2019s Sex Shop, made a quick U-turn and joined some folk for a Windhoek. Ronnie\u2019s Sex Shop, a bush bar somewhere on the road to Barrydale at the start of the Klein Karoo region, is a famous landmark on the R62 landscape. The story goes that a bunch of mates decided to put \u201cSex\u201d in-between Ronnie\u2019s Shop, which at the time was just that. Well\u2026 Business started booming and Ronnie decided to open a bar, passing more beers over the counter than a German Brauhaus, and his establishment, decorated with bras, coasters and dildos, turned into a mish mash watering hole of local farmers and Israeli tourists.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Boesmanland%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Etton \"Da Mal Moer\" Wiggins, raconteur extraordinaire, in full swing on another hilarious story.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Backtracking slightly, we took a dirt road through farmlands that led, eventually, to Riversdale. After a stopover in Still Bay we went guns blazing up the Outeniqua Pass near George towards Britstown. It\u2019s not the most direct or common route but has its hidden rewards. Forest passes and fertile farmlands level out into open Karoo veld, or grasslands. &nbsp;The landscape is epic, morphing into dwarf shrub and rocky plains balanced with Karoo Koppies \u2013 prehistoric flat-topped mountains of compacted lava \u2013 and slowly thinning out into the Kalahari Desert, a large semi-arid sandy savannah that takes you into Namibia.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s safe to camp anywhere so long as you\u2019re not too close to a town. But where ever you are do yourself a favour and stop on the side of the road, jump on the roof or grab a chair and open a beer as the sun is setting. Look at the dark mauve sky meeting the long golden shadows of the veld and listen to the vastness. &nbsp;In the distance you\u2019ll hear the victorious cry of the jackal echo through open country while the farmer wakes up in bed plotting his next move to get rid of the vermin.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Boesmanland%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Paul bumped into a friend when we stopped at the Kenhardt Hotel. What are the chances!&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After waking up the in the morning (covered with dew and with slight hangovers) next to a farm boundary called Donkerhoek (\u201cdark corner\u201d in Afrikaans) near Britstown we started off towards Warmbad in Namibia. Through a series of bumpy dirt roads, we twisted and slid our way into what was supposed to be a hot tourist attraction of natural warm springs and a spa. It was all relative we realized very quickly.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Arriving, we were greeted by one 200m strip of tar road and a scattering of dilapidated houses with a half-hearted \u201cTourism Office\u201d sign hanging on to its perch for dear life. No one was on site so we took a self-drive safari around the area eventually landing up at what would\u2019ve been quite a pleasant stone clad indoor hot spring had it not for the fact that it was now more like a vandalised shack with an algae-filled pool, floating plastic Coke bottles and smashed windows. It reeked of the all-too-familiar South African municipal mismanagement and coffer plundering. Despite this, it did have another outdoor lukewarm green pool, which we used as a bath to wash underarms and blurry travel eyes.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Boesmanland%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Our picnic spot on the Orange River in Kakamas.&nbsp;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This part of South Africa is not well known for its tourism but this was the reason we chose that route. The economy of the area is dominated by farming, mainly Dorper sheep, and hunting. The dorpie (small town) of Kenhardt is the centre for all this activity; essential to this is the Kenhardt Hotel. This by-gone era establishment sits at the junction of the main road like a rusty car relic, but despite this it is the hub of social activity.&nbsp;Sit at the bar and you are sure to strike up a conversation with the owner Etton \u201cDa Mal Moer\u201d Wiggins \u2013 a local raconteur par excellence. All our conversation was conducted in Afrikaans as he claimed he could only say two words in English, \u2018hello\u2019 and \u2018goodbye\u2019, and those were reserved for self-defence. We sat in the thatched, bush-themed bar with a Castle beer in hand listening to stories of bikers and two-week beer binges. Two ales down, and getting comfortable, we realised how these stories all started so decided to cut our midday drinks stop short.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Boesmanland%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Just outside Nous, on the way to Onseepkans near the Namibian border, we pitched camp on the side of the road, read books and slept next to a cosy fire under crazy constellations of stars.&lt;\/em&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bushmanland, or Boesmanland, was a bantustan in South-West Africa (present-day Namibia), intended by the apartheid government to be a self-governing homeland for the San people (the Bushmen). Despite this, a government was never established in the region. Our destination for the day was Kakamas, a big table grape farming town on the banks of the Orange River. It originated as a place where the Orange River could be relatively easily crossed, hence its former moniker Bassonsdrif. In 1898 a proper settlement was established and under the auspices of the Dutch Reformed Church the area was developed as an agricultural centre.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Boesmanland%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;We were convinced that the green algae infested pool held some unknown spa treatment qualities.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is a pleasant town to stop off for a night and there are some great walks along the Orange River. With the help of some local knowledge from a friend who we were staying with we found the perfect sundowner spot on a rocky hill overlooking the whole town and adjacent mountains. Vantage points like these are always great, giving you a wide perspective on the landscape. We could see clearly the contrast between the small, fertile, irrigated band along the river and the rocky outcrops of dry land beyond.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From Kakamas we headed for Namibia. We took, as per our mission, the most obscure route past a spooky settlement called Nous to an obscure border post called Onseepkans. All of this took two days; with a breakdown and a spectacular camp spot on an open plain near Nous! We were now on our way to trace the Orange River, the border between South Africa and Namibia, and over into Big Sky Country - the next stage of our journey.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Boesmanland%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Paul grooming himself at the Warmbad lukewarm spa pool.&nbsp;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Watch this space for Part 2 of Andrew\u2019s journey.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2032\"&gt;Ronnie\u2019s Sex Shop&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/4115\"&gt;Augrabies Falls National Park Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3303\"&gt;Dassie Trail Augrabies&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3307\"&gt;Klipspringer Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2143\"&gt;Riemvasmaak MTB Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/1534\"&gt;Khamkirri Horse Riding&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/1525\"&gt;Khamkirri Rafting&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n   &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img of Board Grace the Kogelberg\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/kings-board-grace-kogelberg\" data-text=\"Kings of Board Grace the Kogelberg\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/kings-board-grace-kogelberg\" data-title=\"Kings of Board Grace the Kogelberg\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Dale Barrow, pics Lauren Barrow&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What do you get if you combine a smooth tar road on the slopes of the Kogelberg Biosphere with speed fanatics on skateboards? The answer is Hot Heels Africa.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Started in 2003, Hot Heels Africa, a World Cup Downhill Skateboarding race, is the longest continuously-running event in the International Gravity Sports Association (IGSA) World Cup Series and attracts challengers from near and far. This, along with the fact that it is the final leg of the domestic competition, means that local and international gravity racers are lured to battle it out for final points on the international league, as well as the South African Champion title.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Organised by the South African Gravity Racing Association (SAGRA), in association with 78a Production and Management, this year's event kicked off on Thursday, 11 December and saw local and international challengers competing in the knockout tournament, which culminated in the finals on Sunday, 14 December.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Riders and supporters alike descended on the coastal towns of Pringle Bay and Rooi Els in the fair Cape to play their part in this high-speed, action-packed experience.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The tranquil and pristine Kogelberg Biosphere Reserve, considered the heart of the Cape floral Kingdom, was given a slightly different focus as gravity riders sped down the track at break-neck speeds in search of the coveted title. With young and old gathered to watch the spectacle, the event also managed to attract the attention of several baboons that ventured down to investigate what the humans were up to, much to the annoyance of the organisers who needed to keep the track clear.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kings%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At first, I was not unlike the baboons in my ignorance of skateboarding, but after the first race I had newfound respect for these athletes; and athletes they are! One does not need to be a skateboarder to appreciate what these competitors achieve as they hurtle down the tar track at speeds of between 75 and 80 km\/hour, with no protection save for a helmet and leather suit. What is more, falling is even somewhat expected, and several contestants found themselves sliding along the tar and slamming into hay bales in their endeavours to earn a podium finish. Miraculously, most riders were ok and able to pick themselves up and continue competing. How they do it, I have no idea!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The racing categories included Downhill Skateboarding, Street Luge and Classic Luge, and as the track warmed up under the afternoon sun the speeds increased, as riders pushed the limits for a podium finish.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There were about 85 contestants taking part, of which a quarter were international competitors. Our hopes were firmly on our local boys and girls, and they left nothing on the line as they tried to hold off the international challengers. In a sport of such small margins there was very little to separate the competition, but the South African contingent did themselves proud.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the Downhill Skateboarding final, the premier event of the day, Kyle Wester of the USA took top honours in the Open category, while Marie Bougourd of France took first place in the Ladies race.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For more details, see &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.sagra.co.za\/index.php\/hot-heels-home\"&gt;www.sagra.co.za\/index.php\/hot-heels-home&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kings%20end.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"723\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/content\/kings-board-grace-kogelberg\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;DO IT NOW&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/769\"&gt;Kogelberg Nature Reserve&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" &lt;div class='bio'&gt;Article provided from Do it Now - Adventure, Sport and Lifestyle Magazine.&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9562\" class=\"publisher-1813 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/cycling-cape-town-vic-falls-%E2%80%93-big-trip-save-tiny-bird\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Cycling from Cape Town to Vic Falls \u2013 a Big Trip to Save a Tiny Bird&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Cycling from Cape Town to Vic Falls \u2013 a Big Trip to Save a Tiny Bird  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Cycling from Cape Town to Vic Falls \u2013 a Big Trip to Save a Tiny Bird\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.ride.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #E31933' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/ride-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Cape%20Town%20to%20Vic%20Falls%201%20%28M%29.jpg?itok=8CjDpia8\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycling-cape-town-vic-falls-\u2013-big-trip-save-tiny-bird\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycling-cape-town-vic-falls-\u2013-big-trip-save-tiny-bird\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycling-cape-town-vic-falls-\u2013-big-trip-save-tiny-bird&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Cape%20Town%20to%20Vic%20Falls%201%20%28M%29.jpg&amp;description=Cycling from Cape Town to Vic Falls \u2013 a Big Trip to Save a Tiny Bird\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycling-cape-town-vic-falls-\u2013-big-trip-save-tiny-bird\" data-text=\"Cycling from Cape Town to Vic Falls \u2013 a Big Trip to Save a Tiny Bird\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cycling-cape-town-vic-falls-\u2013-big-trip-save-tiny-bird\" data-title=\"Cycling from Cape Town to Vic Falls \u2013 a Big Trip to Save a Tiny Bird\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Eelco Meyjes will be setting off on a big journey, 3000km big, to help a little bird. &nbsp;As part of a fund raising initiative to launch the new Orange-breasted Waxbill conservation project, Meyjes who is a member of both BirdLife South Africa and a founder member and director of the Rare Finch Conservation Group, will attempt to do a solo cycle from Cape Town to Victoria Falls. The ride in aid of Africa\u2019s smallest finch will kick off from Cape Town on 15 March 2015.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In 2013 Eelco cycled from Joburg to Cape Town \u2018for fun\u2019. He hopes to complete the ride from Cape Town to Victoria Falls within 40 days. We caught up with him and asked a few questions, before he heads off on this next adventure.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cape%20Town%20to%20Vic%20Falls%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Of all the endangered and threatened species on Earth, why did you choose to raise funds for this little bird that you refer to as an avian jewel?&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.rarefinch.org\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Rare Finch Conservation Group&lt;\/a&gt; is made up of a group of finch enthusiasts, from South Africa and Australia, wishing to make some kind of meaningful contribution to finch conservation work in the wild. For nine years we worked up in Uganda at the Bwindi Impenetrable Forest, home to half of the world\u2019s remaining threatened Mountain Gorillas, trying to find one of Africa\u2019s rarest finches: the threatened and elusive Shelley\u2019s crimsonwing. To date there are still only two known photographs of the bird in the world. Sadly in 2014 , due to lack of funds and various logistical reasons we were forced to defer our work in Uganda. We then made the strategic decision to offer our services and enthusiasm to BirdLife South Africa.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.birdlife.org.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;BirdLife South Africa&lt;\/a&gt; informed us that the beautiful little Orange-breasted Waxbill, which is not yet listed as threatened, has unfortunately experienced unexpected significant declines in various parts of its natural habitat. This development has resulted in the urgent need for the species to be researched. So what we are doing now is launching the public awareness and fund raising campaign for Africa\u2019s smallest finch that now needs conservation help.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;You clearly enjoy riding your bike, as you cycled from Joburg to Cape Town for fun, in 2013. &nbsp;Where did your love of cycling begin?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As 12-year-old kids we loved cycling and we often cycled to wherever we went. Some of us even learnt how to ride a bicycle backwards while sitting on the handlebars. Not a thing I can recommend.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cape%20Town%20to%20Vic%20Falls%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;This trip will be more than double the distance of the Joburg to Cape Town trip and cross into two other countries. Do you have any concerns about this trip?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sure. This is a massive ride and it requires a huge amount of planning and preparation. The number one priority with endurance cycling is safety and health, and not speed.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Other than accomplishing your goal of getting to Vic Falls and raising as much money as possible to help save the Orange-breasted Waxbill, what are you looking forward to most on the trip?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Each day will have its own specific targets, challenges and highlights. I have had to add an extra 200km to the distance between Cape Town and Johannesburg in order to make the total distance to Vic Falls 3000km. Arriving in Johannesburg will be a big achievement for me. Not only will I then be well over the half way mark, but I will also be one of the very few people to have cycled both down as well as up, between these two major cities. The second next big target will be to cross the border into Botswana and reach Palapye which will be the first major town in that country. From there I cycle to Francistown and then up to Nata, where there is a beautiful bird sanctuary. From Nata up to Kusene is another major challenge. The distances in the northern part of Botswana are massive so managing my water supplies, potential heatstroke and keeping a good look out for the wild game will all be part of the adventure. Reaching Kasane on the Chobe river will certainly be another highlight for me. From there I prepare to do the final 90km by crossing the border into Zimbabwe and heading to Vic Falls.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cape%20Town%20to%20Vic%20Falls%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What does your bicycle weigh once it\u2019s all packed for a trip and ready to roll?&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The bike weighs 16kg, my kit excluding water weighs 30kg. At the start in Cape Town my weight will be approximately 90kg, but I expect to have lost approximately 12 kg by the time I reach Vic Falls.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What would your three top tips be for other cyclists that would want to do a solo cross country or cross border cycling trip?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;1. Upfront planning is key. Research the entire route thoroughly and if possible try and drive the route at least once before riding it. Knowing where each water and safety point is, what the road conditions are, exact distance splits, B&amp;B\u2019s, emergency assistance, bicycle shops etc. all helps to reduce the guess work and improve safety.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;2. Don\u2019t think you will ride yourself fit. You need to train for it and close to the start date you need to do full kit training so that you are comfortable with the additional weight.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;3. Always try and have a plan A ,B, C and even possibly D for every situation. Strange as it may seem sometimes plan C actually works out better than plan A.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cape%20Town%20to%20Vic%20Falls%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Get involved by&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Making a donation, no matter how big or small to:&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;br&gt;Rare Finch Conservation Group&lt;br&gt;Nedbank&lt;br&gt;Account number: 1933 198885 SWIFTJJ,&lt;br&gt;Sandown branch code: 193305&lt;br&gt;South Africa&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Participate in the &lt;em&gt;All or Bust&lt;\/em&gt; pledge.&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;A minimum pledge amount of R500 will be required to be part of the fun. If Eelco Meyjes makes it all the way to Vic Falls you\u2019ll need to pay the pledged amount and you receive a souvenir coffee mug to thank you for your support. If he doesn\u2019t make it to Vic Falls you won\u2019t owe him a cent.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;To pledge&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sms the amount (R500 or more), plus your full name and contact details to 082 457 4936&nbsp;or email &lt;a href=\"mailto:editor@avitalk.co.za\"&gt;editor@avitalk.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Nevarest has sponsored Eelco\u2019s satellite tracking device, you can follow his journey at &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.nevarestchallenge.com\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.nevarestchallenge.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source:&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.ride.co.za\/people\/cycling-cape-town-vic-falls-big-trip-save-tiny-bird\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Ride Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9448\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/tankwa-camino\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;The Tankwa Camino &lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    The Tankwa Camino   &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"The Tankwa Camino \" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Tankwa.jpg?itok=y_qPL-1H\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tankwa-camino\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tankwa-camino\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tankwa-camino&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Tankwa.jpg&amp;description=The Tankwa Camino \" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tankwa-camino\" data-text=\"The Tankwa Camino \" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tankwa-camino\" data-title=\"The Tankwa Camino \"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Pics by Marlize Stander&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The first Tankwa Camino was held in August 2013, and the second in September last year. For 2015, three events are planned, and one is already fully booked. 3 - 12 April, and 24 September - 3 October still have availability. So, how has this 250 km \/ 10 day hike through this desolate part of the country come about, and why is it becoming so popular?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tankwa%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Danie Pieterse has always cherished a dream of walking from his grandfather Jan Pieterse\u2019 s grave in the Tankwa-Karoo to his other grandfather's grave in Rawsonville. He once shared this idea with one of his friends, Charl van der Merwe, and soon the planning for the first Tankwa Camino started. The main idea behind the Camino would be to introduce people to this beautiful part of the country.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tankwa%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Charl and his wife (Mariete) started training for the hike straight away, with Danie and his wife (Rhina) delegated to coordinate the hike and the support team. All this planning and preparation bore fruit when a motley crew of 45 hikers and 10 support staff gathered in front of the big red postbox in Calvinia on Friday 9 August 2013 for the start of the 'great trek'.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tankwa%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tankwa%205.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hunter Thompson's 1971 odyssey &lt;em&gt;Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas&lt;\/em&gt; opens with the words: \"We were somewhere around Barstow on the edge of the desert when the drugs began to take effect\". The Tankwa desert will became your drug for ten days, as you walk through one of the most extraordinary landscapes in Africa, a landscape that beggars belief, that makes you&nbsp;realise&nbsp;God is indeed in the details. This is a place where time and distance is stretched,&nbsp;where horizons dance and disappear, and where every corner brings a new startling vista.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Tankwa%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"462\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Tankwa Camino costs R3 500 per person. Dinner, and coffee and fruit at other times of the day, is included in this fare, as is portage of your tent, sleeping bag and other surplus belongings. You also get 5 litres of hot water to wash in the evenings! Breakfast and lunch is your responsibility.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next Tankwa Camino will be from 3 - 12 April 2015. For more details, visit their&nbsp;website&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.tankwacamino.com\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.tankwacamino.com&lt;\/a&gt; or mail them at &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@tankwacamino.com\"&gt;info@tankwacamino.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9561\" class=\"publisher-3008 node Capes\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/5-capes\" data-title=\"5 Capes\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By Dawid Mocke&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Join Dawid and Jasper Mocke as they take you on a journey of adventure and exploration during this paddling expedition along the amazing southern coast of Africa. You cannot ask for two better coaches, mentors and tour leaders; the Mocke brothers love their paddling and cherish their country. During this trip you will have an awesome paddling adventure and improve your paddling as you are coached by the best. All levels of paddler are tailored for; an intrepid spirit is the only requirement.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Days 1 -2 | 23 \u2013 24 Mar&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Your sojourn starts on the 23rd March in the Eastern Cape, well known for its down to earth and friendly locals. You will begin in the \u201cFriendly City\u201d Port Elizabeth, where the adventure starts by paddling around the Cape Recife, culminating in riding the longest surfski wave in the world, with rides sometimes in excess of 2 minutes!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/5%20Capes%20cape-recife_web.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;The haunting Cape Recife \u2013 home to the longest surfski wave in the world.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From P.E. it is a short drive to the small coastal town of Cape St Francis. This is one of South Africa\u2019s favourite ocean playgrounds and home to the highest mason structure in Southern Africa, the St Francis Lighthouse. St Francis is also near the world famous surfing break Jeffrey\u2019s Bay. After working on your wave skills at the friendly surf break of St Francis and some technique coaching on the nearby canals, you will paddle around the Cape St Francis.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/5%20Capes%201%20Cape-St-Francis.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;The Cape of St Francis \u2013 home to Southern Africa\u2019s largest mason structure.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Days 3 \u2013 4 | 25 \u2013 26 Mar&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the 26 March you will then continue your journey down the coast. Your destination is the beautiful town of Knysna. After a training session on the Knysna Lagoon, home to the world\u2019s only estuarine seahorses, you will paddle through the Knysna Heads, an unforgettable experience since it is as if passing through a massive natural ocean gateway.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/5%20Capes%202%20Knysna-Heads-The-Waves-Were-Large.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Knysna Heads \u2013 The Heads was passable through the westerly channel.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From the base in Knysna you will paddle around Cape Seal \u2013 the Robberg Peninsula - one of South Africa\u2019s most precious marine protected areas, and the headland leading to Bahia Formosa, Plettenberg Bay.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/5%20Capes%203%20Robberg.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"323\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;You can see why the Portuguese named it Bahia Formosa (Beautiful Bay).&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Days 5 \u2013 6 | Mar 27 \u2013 28&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After paddling around Cape Seal you will head further south. Your next destination? The tip of Africa! The small coastal town of Agulhas will be your base for 2 days as you explore the Overberg region, famous for its immense bio-diversity. During your stay you will visit the L\u2019Agulhas Lighthouse, which houses South Africa\u2019s lighthouse museum and enjoy a meal at a restaurant at the bottom of Africa. But before lunch you will do a landmark paddle. You will paddle around the southernmost tip of Africa \u2013 Cape Agulhas \u2013 and lay claim to having officially paddled from one ocean to another \u2013 the Atlantic to the Indian.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/5%20Capes%204%20cape-agulhas-01.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;The bottom of Africa.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/5-Capes%206%20Agulhas-Visiting-the-Lighthouse.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Agulhas \u2013 Visiting the Lighthouse.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Days 8 \u2013 10 | Mar 29 \u2013 31&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is then time to head for the most majestic cape of them all. You\u2019ll arrive in Cape Town, one the most beautiful cities in the world. You will spend 3 days paddling and exploring the area with Dawid and Jasper as they take you on the famous Millers Run and paddle their favourite training routes. You will climb Table Mountain, one of the 7 natural wonders of the world. Most importantly, you will be paddling around the spectacular and iconic Cape of Good Hope.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/5-Capes%207%20Tablemountain.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Table Mountain, a lifetime landmark to see and visit.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You can expect this trip to be filled with much more than just paddling. This part of the country offers not only amazing trails and spectacular mountains and gorges just begging to be explored, but is rich in history and cultural diversity. The short distances between the capes will allow ample time for exploration.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;All Levels are catered for; an intrepid spirit is the only requirement.&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Whether you are an experienced ocean paddler, or have just started your paddling career, the 5 Capes adventure will satisfy every intrepid bone in your body. Dawid and Jasper are some of the most experienced ocean guides you could ask for; you can trust that they will use their experience to get you around each Cape.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;All equipment is provided across a range of ability, from racing surfskis to the most stable \u2013 you may use whichever you feel comfortable depending on the day. Dawid and Jasper will also bring double skis that are a great way to learn skills and also paddle if conditions get tricky.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Leaving the shores of South Africa you will have had an adventure and an experience that very few can lay claim to \u2013 paddling the 5 Capes with Dawid and Jasper Mocke.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/5-Capes%209%20paddling%20round%20CapePoint.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Paddling around the Cape of Good Hope is unforgettable.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;TRIP ITINERARY&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Arrive in Port Elizabeth (P.E.) 22 March&lt;br&gt;23\/24 March \u2013 P.E. &amp; St Francis | Cape Recife &amp; Cape St Francis&lt;br&gt;25\/26 March \u2013 Knysna | Cape Seal Robberg Peninsula&lt;br&gt;27\/28 March \u2013 L\u2019Agulhas | Cape Agulhas&lt;br&gt;29 \u2013 31 March \u2013 Fish Hoek | Cape Point | Millers Runs&lt;br&gt;Depart Cape Town 1 April&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Transfers, transport, accommodation, surfskis, coaching and meals included. Flights to Cape Town, and connecting flights, not included.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bring your paddles, PFD, Leash, Cellphone Dry Bag &amp; Booties\u2026and 3 sets of paddling kit (or purchase from Mocke Paddling and collect when you arrive).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Price per paddler: R37 000. &nbsp;Space is limited to 6 persons per trip.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For more information and to \u201cBook your Spot\u201d send and email to: &nbsp;&lt;a href=\"mailto:dawid@mockepaddling.com\"&gt;dawid@mockepaddling.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/5-Capes%2010%20Cape-Point-Conquering-the-Cape-of-Good-Hope1.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;Conquering the Cape of Good Hope.&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Your hosts &amp; the team:&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Dawid Mocke:&lt;\/strong&gt; &nbsp;Dawid is a 4 x World Surfski Series champion (2009-2012) and is the founder of the Surfskischool and the Mocke paddling brand. In 2002 Dawid was a team member of the 1000mile Challenge that paddled from Cape Town to Durban including the 5 Capes coast. Always optimistic, his careful, cautious and calculated approach makes Dawid the voice of reason on tour and our tour leader.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Jasper Mocke:&lt;\/strong&gt; &nbsp;Jasper is the 2014 (and currentl9 World Surfski Series Champion. &nbsp;A qualified physiotherapist now professional paddler, he has multiple international titles and podium finishes across a variety of paddling disciplines from surfski, to flatwater and river marathon. The former National Lifesaving team member and captain, has spent the last 4 years exploring the coastline between Knysna and Port Elizabeth. His sense of adventurous fun and games will ensure never a dull moment while on tour.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Aden Kleeve:&lt;\/strong&gt; &nbsp;Aden will be taking care of mission critical tasks during the trip. A long-time employee of the Surfskischool and Paddling Centre, Aden is our trusted steed ready and willing to take on the challenges that make any tour a success. Aden is a semi-professional body boarder who has spent many hours along the 5 Capes coast and knows its nuances down to a tee. His input on tour will be most valuable.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Nikki &amp; Micaela Mocke: &nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;Nikki, married to Dawid, is a former Olympian who is well versed in the specific needs of a travelling paddler. Micaela, married to Jasper, is a designer and brand specialist in the fashion industry. She is also well versed in the world of travel. Nikki and Micaela will be taking care of logistics from \u201cHome Base\u201d in Fish Hoek and make sure that various travel arrangements are operating smoothly. They will be taking care of accommodation arrangement and bookings as well as other activities planned.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source:&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/mockepaddling.com\/paddle-5-capes\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Mocke Paddling&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2229\"&gt;Cape Recife Lighthouse&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/8133\"&gt;Cape St Francis Resort&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3745\"&gt;Sailing on the Knysna Lagoon&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/773\"&gt;Robberg Nature Reserve&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/170\"&gt;Agulhas National Park&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3214\"&gt;Cape Agulhas Lighthouse Trail&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n Francisco&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Delightful Madness in San Francisco  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Delightful Madness in San Francisco\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.travelideas.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #f69220' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Travel%20Ideas%20s.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/San%20Fran%20List.jpg?itok=1s6nkm6y\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/delightful-madness-san-francisco\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" Madness in San Francisco\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/delightful-madness-san-francisco\" data-text=\"Delightful Madness in San Francisco\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/delightful-madness-san-francisco\" data-title=\"Delightful Madness in San Francisco\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Franki Black&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;No place embodies America\u2019s creative drive and entrepreneurial spirit quite as well as San Francisco does. This northern Californian city was born thanks to the discovery of gold in 1848. Young men from around the world descended upon San Francisco (and surrounds) with high hopes of realizing the American dream. &nbsp;It quickly became a melting pot of cultures, food and attitudes and as you wander through its streets, it becomes clear that not much has changed in this regard. \u201cIf you\u2019re worried about not fitting in, move to San Francisco,\u201d says my friend as we walk down another street filled with eccentric characters. The San Francisco experience is a bit like unintended street theatre: musicians busk, graffiti artists paint, foodies embrace farmer\u2019s markets and gay men flaunt hot-pants. &nbsp;This is a city that bristles with delightful madness. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Food Heaven&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Kori Goff, our Trafalgar Travel Director warns us, \u201cDon\u2019t eat a big breakfast tomorrow; we have a full day of food ahead.\u201d After an irresistibly big breakfast, we walk to the Old Ferry Building for a Trafalgar Local Speciality. Constructed in 1898, the Ferry Building was once the focal point of San Francisco\u2019s transportation. Today it houses a lively farmer\u2019s market filled with artisans selling cheeses, breads, desserts, olives and more. We join our guide, Joshua Clever from Edible Excursions, for a tasting tour of the market\u2019s best. As a trained chef, it\u2019s obvious that Joshua loves to share local cuisine with visitors. &nbsp;He tells us about the six years he spent working in France and to him the ferry building market rivals top French food markets. We move through a crowd of trendy visitors and start with dessert at Farmer Al\u2019s Pastry Shop. Apple tartlets, certifiably-humane beef chili, salted caramel, triple-cream brie, sourdough bread and coconut macaroons are some of the delicacies we nibble on. To end, we nurse a steaming cup of Blue Bottle coffee, allegedly the best brew in the city, and my friend buys a T-shirt that says, &lt;em&gt;Praise the Lard&lt;\/em&gt;.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/San%20Fran%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Neighbourhood Explorations&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;San Francisco\u2019s neighbourhoods can be categorized by nationality (or sexual orientation). Among others, The Mission is the city\u2019s Spanish neighbourhood; North Beach is its Italian neighbourhood and Castro is its rainbow neighbourhood known for being the &lt;em&gt;gayest place on earth&lt;\/em&gt;. Perhaps above all, Chinatown is most notable, as it is the oldest and largest Chinese community located outside of Asia.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For starters, Kori leads the way to the Mission to show us her personal favourite sight. This eclectic neighbourhood has been home to Latino residents for decades, but in recent years the so-called &lt;em&gt;dot-com&lt;\/em&gt; professionals have moved in. Today its quirky streets are filled with &lt;em&gt;taquerias&lt;\/em&gt;, Mexican cafes, hipsters and antique shops. What makes The Mission particularly special is its street art. &nbsp;Kori\u2019s hidden treasure turns out to be one of the most beautiful alleyways in the neighbourhood, Balmy Alley. From top to bottom, Balmy Alley is filled with painted depictions of Spanish guitar players, mamas carrying baskets and protestors from the sixties. Besides the odd stray dog, we have the alley all to ourselves.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/San%20Fran%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next neighbourhood we visit is a densely-populated and lively one, Chinatown. Kori points out an old pub en-route and shares her insider knowledge. &nbsp;\u201cHave you ever heard the phrase: 'you\u2019ve been shanghaied?'\u201d she asks. Responding to our blank stares, she continues. \u201cWell, it all started at this bar - Shanghai Kelly\u2019s - in the 1800s. New Chinese immigrants were pleased to be in America and the last thing on their minds was returning to China. The boat captains however, needed crew for their ships, but with a lack of sailors signing up for the arduous voyage, they were in a pickle. Captains quickly discovered that Shanghai Kelly\u2019s was a favoured watering hole for Chinese immigrants, so they struck a deal with the compliant bar owner. He spiked select drinks with opium in exchange for bribes, and the unsuspecting patriots would wake up on a ship Shanghai-bound!\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We enter through the Chinatown Gate. This grand entrance is flanked by two stone lions believed to bring wealth and prosperity to the district. We are instantly transported to Beijing. Red lanterns dangle across streets, pagoda roofs cover the skyline and dragon lamp-posts light the way. Kori explains that almost everything in San Francisco is somehow related to the 1906 earthquake. It wreaked havoc across the city and subsequent fires were even more devastating. An estimated 3000 people died and over 80% of San Francisco was destroyed. &nbsp;According to Kori, Chinatown had to be completely rebuilt.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/San%20Fran%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We duck into a narrow avenue (Rose Alley) and sniff out the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory for another Trafalgar Local Speciality. Inside, an old Chinese man puffs a cigar, while his workmate curls the edges of fresh cookies delivered from a machine. Carefully he fills each cookie with strips of fortunes, soon to be delivered to thousands of hopeful people around the world. Instead of tempting fate, we make our way to the Empress of China, Chinatown\u2019s most sought-after restaurant, to feast on platters of walnut prawns, sweet and sour pork and curry chicken Chow Mein.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our next stop is Haight Ashbury, a quirky neighbourhood dotted with Victorian houses, buskers and wafts of marijuana. \u201cThe Haight\u201d was the hub of the 1960\u2019s hippie movement and few songs depict its 1967 Summer of Love better than Scott McKenzie\u2019s &lt;em&gt;San Francisco&lt;\/em&gt;. &nbsp;We make our way to the Haight, and McKenzie\u2019s lyrics, &lt;em&gt;be sure to wear flowers in your hair&lt;\/em&gt;, play from the loudspeaker. One of Trafalgar\u2019s most appealing offerings is its Insider Experiences where local people share local activities with travellers. Kori is beaming, \u201cYou\u2019re gonna love her,\u201d she says as we step off the coach to meet Izu, our guide. She and her leashed sausage dog, Bennie, form a striking pair. Izu, about 70-years old, wears a tie-dyed coat, Converse shoes, a cross around her neck and John Lennon sunglasses. She arrived in Haight Ashbury during the summer of 1967 as an impressionable teenager and the flower power movement became such an important part of her life that she decided to relive it every day as a guide.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/San%20Fran%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In a raspy New York accent, she describes the scene, \u201c70 000 backpackers from around the world descended upon Haight Ashbury. We lived in compounds, there was no homelessness, strangers invited you to stay, music filled the streets and weed was the drug of choice,\u201d she explains. &nbsp;\u201cPeople came here to be accepted.\u201d We follow Izu and Bennie to houses that once belonged to Janis Joplin, the Grateful Dead and the Hell\u2019s Angels. As we bid Izu and Haight Ashbury farewell, I hear Izu praise Bennie, \u201cYou did good, boy, you did good.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Around the Bay&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Much like Cape Town, San Francisco centres on the ocean. Runners frequent its promenade, tourists flock to Fisherman\u2019s Wharf to shop and everyone finds delight in the screeches of seals gathered on Pier 39. The best view of the city is arguably from the deck of the Sausalito-bound ferry that transports tourists across the bay on a daily basis. Kori rounds us up in time for departure. On the one side is a view of Alcatraz - San Francisco\u2019s version of Robben Island - and on the other side, lies the city\u2019s most spectacular landmark, the Golden Gate Bridge.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/San%20Fran%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We approach Sausalito - the town that inspired Otis Redding\u2019s &lt;em&gt;Dock of the Bay&lt;\/em&gt; - and I\u2019m surprised to see that it resembles a high-end Italian island. Sail boats bob in marinas, mansions rise from the hillside and boutique shops abound. For lunch we go to Scoma\u2019s, a maritime-themed restaurant perched over water. I order my favourite American dish \u2013 Clam Chowder. According to Kori, there\u2019s a lot of old money in Sausalito and property prices are exceptionally high.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We conclude our time in San Francisco with the most epic of crossings, a walk over the Golden Gate Bridge starting on the Sausalito end. Our coach driver drops us at the starting point. It\u2019s windy, but the bridge is the most spectacular manmade structure I\u2019ve ever seen. &nbsp;227 metres of orange steel tower into the sky, a wild Pacific Ocean lies far beneath my feet and cars whizz past at dizzying speeds. The views of sea and city are spectacular. Built between 1933 and 1937, the Golden Gate Bridge ticks all the boxes: engineering genius, foresight in design, an extraordinary construction feat and aesthetic consideration. On the other side of the bridge, we gather for a Trafalgar group photo and climb back onto the coach for a journey along California\u2019s coastline. I bid farewell to San Francisco, city of delightful madness, and it occurs to me that the world seems a little bit too ordinary beyond San Francisco. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/San%20Fran%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Make it Happen&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;San Francisco &amp; Wine Country Delights&lt;\/strong&gt;: Priced from R30 225 per person twin share, enjoy 8 days on this At Leisure Trafalgar guided holiday. This includes fantastic hotel accommodation with a full breakfast daily, a picnic lunch with drinks at a winery, three evening meals including a special Be My Guest dinner at a Sonoma Valley winery, private cooking class, wonderful sightseeing including an expert guided tour of Haight Ashbury and the Ferry Plaza Farmer\u2019s Market and so much more. &nbsp;Guests will also enjoy the opportunity to create and sample their own wine at a private blending and learn how to make fortune cookies. Flights are extra. Departures from September 2014 through to October 2015. Travellers who wish to depart on any itinerary after 31 October 2014 into 2015 can enjoy a 10% early payment discount if they book and pay in full before 27 November 2014.For more information contact your ASATA travel agent or Trafalgar on (011) 280 8400. Visit &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.trafalgar.com\"&gt;www.trafalgar.com&lt;\/a&gt; and follow #TrafalagarInsider to learn more.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;About Trafalgar&lt;\/strong&gt;: Trafalgar is the world\u2019s leading guided holiday company offering exceptional quality and value itineraries to a range of exciting destinations. With over 67 years of experience and unrivalled local expertise, Trafalgar provides an authentic insider\u2019s view to create truly unique travel experiences in Europe, Britain and Eastern Mediterranean, Australia and New Zealand, China, Mexico, Central and South America, USA and Canada.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;About The TreadRight Foundation&lt;\/strong&gt;: Trafalgar is a part of a joint initiative with The TreadRight Foundation, a not-for-profit foundation established by The Travel Corporation to encourage sustainable tourism within their own family of brands and in the places they visit. To date, TreadRight has donated more than US$2 million to sustainable tourism projects around the world. To find out more about Trafalgar's work with TreadRight visit: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.treadright.org\"&gt;www.treadright.org&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Get Going!&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Fly South African Airways&lt;\/strong&gt;: SAA operates two daily flights from South Africa to the United States as well as operating the only direct flight from Johannesburg to New York City on the Airbus A340-300. In addition to direct flights to New York, you can get daily SAA flights direct to Washington's Dulles Airport from Johannesburg on the Airbus A340-600. This long haul flight has a brief stop in Dakar, Senegal. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.flysaa.com\/za\/en\/\" href=\"http:\/\/www.united.com\/web\/en-US\/default.aspx?root=1\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.united.com&nbsp;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Kai Fitchen Kape to Atacama&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Kai Fitchen Kape to Atacama  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Kai Fitchen Kape to Atacama\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #09906f' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/A%202015%20logo%20s.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Kai%201.jpg?itok=OUTSjsql\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/kai-fitchen-kape-atacama\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/kai-fitchen-kape-atacama\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a
