Fitchen Kape to Atacama\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/kai-fitchen-kape-atacama\" data-text=\"Kai Fitchen Kape to Atacama\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/kai-fitchen-kape-atacama\" data-title=\"Kai Fitchen Kape to Atacama\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;h2&gt;Kai Fitchen Kape to Atacama&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;In a nutshell:&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;A peak-bagging expedition to the Bolivian and Peruvian Andes with an environmental spin which included sailing the Atlantic Ocean and then trekking, hitch-hiking and catching rusty buses to the start of the climbs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Category: &lt;\/strong&gt;Individual, assisted&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Adventurer:&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;Kai Fitchen, 20 years old, from Cape Town&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Previous big adventures:&lt;\/strong&gt; KAPE 2 KENYA Environmental Expedition 2012, high points of which included summiting Batian (5199m), the highest point on Mt. Kenya; sharing the K2K eco-programmes with over 600 students along the way and completing the journey on foot and by basic public transport. This expedition saw Kai voted as Nightjar Adventurer Readers Choice winner 2013). Member of the Mike Horn Pangaea Expedition to the Himalayas 2010, on which the team made the first ascent of Pangaea Peak (6170m) in Northern Pakistan, carried out research for the MAYO clinic and observed how climate change is affecting the Baltoro Glacier.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Length of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 21,000km&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Duration of expedition:&lt;\/strong&gt; 6 months&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Completion date:&lt;\/strong&gt; 7 August 2014&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Continuous or a series of adventures:&lt;\/strong&gt; Continuous&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Highlights:&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;30 days at sea travelling by the power of the wind and viewing dolphin pods and extraordinary sunsets; wading through the swamplands of Pantanal; making it to the mountains in a sustainable and eco-friendly way; ascents of three 6000m peaks in Peru and Bolivia, Tocllaraju, Peru (6035m) being the most significant as he summited despite suffering from an intestinal parasite and being ditched by his partner at 5400m with no tent or fuel.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;To find out more:&lt;\/strong&gt; &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.mykape.com\"&gt;www.mykape.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Why?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The first MY KAPE expedition KAPE 2 KENYA 2012 laid the foundations for a far more ambitious adventure. South America is home to some of the wildest peaks on the planet and I wanted to climb there. As with my previous adventure I wanted to get myself to the mountains with minimal environmental impact. Sailing, cycling, hitching and walking were my only means of transport.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Goals of the expedition&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=\"color: #575757; font-size: 12px; line-height: 20px; text-align: justify;\"&gt;To bag as many 6000m peaks as possible&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"color: #575757; font-size: 12px; line-height: 20px; text-align: justify;\"&gt;To visit Peru\u2019s Cordillera Blanca&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"color: #575757; font-size: 12px; line-height: 20px; text-align: justify;\"&gt;To cross the Atlantic Ocean by boat&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"color: #575757; font-size: 12px; line-height: 20px; text-align: justify;\"&gt;To travel each and every kilometre by sustainable means&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span style=\"color: #575757; font-size: 12px; line-height: 20px; text-align: justify;\"&gt;To raise awareness about environmental issues and epilepsy&nbsp;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Originality&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;MY KAPE 2 ATACAMA expedition was one of a kind. The big chilly climbs, the low impact means of travel and the causes I championed made for a unique combination.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Planning&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ha ha. The planning was more difficult than the expedition! I began planning a year and a half before I set sail. Initially, everything went swimmingly. I had a team partner, we\u2019d found a boat for the Cape to Rio yacht race and there was a title sponsor. Then 3 months before we were supposed to head off, I lost the title sponsor, my partner pulled out and everything came crashing down. I even blew my knee out during this turn of unfortunate events. It was crazy!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The adventure that unfolded began in a dinghy, with me buzzing around different marinas in search of a ride to Latin America. I was lucky enough to come across a crew just 6 days before they pushed off to Brazil!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;All my plans and preparation of the previous year and a half went out the window when I jumped on that boat.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Back-up plan&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;No real back-up at all but there were other climbers on the peaks and the guides\/rescue facilities in the Cordillera Blanca are pretty good so if we had had a serious accident the chances of alerting rescue were reasonable.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Funding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;It all came out of my own pocket. I got some cash from friends and through a small crowd funding campaign, but I was travelling on the bones of my arse the whole way. I managed to get a job in Southern Peru for a few weeks during the trip, which topped up my funds a bit.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Verification&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Photos and the friends I made on the journey and on the climbs. Oh yes, and I\u2019ve got some hospital bills that I picked up along the way!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Scariest moment&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Coming down Illimani, Bolivia. The snow was far too soft, deep and unstable. We couldn\u2019t place any protection and everything became quite intense. An avalanche went off in the icefall below us. It was just luck that it didn\u2019t set off an avalanche on the slope we were on. Fortunately we managed to traverse to a safer area, which had harder snow. That got my heart going.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Most unexpected experience&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The ascent of Tocllaraju. When I arrived in Huaraz (a Peruvian town at the base of the Cordillera Blanca) I started looking for climbing partners and within a few hours I\u2019d met a Brazilian named Cissar who was keen to take on Tocllaraju (6009m). It would be one of the most difficult peaks I\u2019d attempted and on the eve of departure I fell violently ill. I was meant to be leaving a few days before Cissar to acclimatise with Dani, a groovy bloke from Spain. However, I could barely get out of my sleeping bag and an 8-hour trek into base camp was out of the question.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The following day I left alone thinking that it was just a bit of food poisoning. (As it turned out, I had a nasty parasite). I would have bailed but Cissar was out of contact and I couldn\u2019t leave her stranded.In my nauseous state I moved slowly to base camp despite logic telling me to turn back. By the time I found Dani the next day I was feeling better, yet I hadn\u2019t properly eaten for 3 days.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Tocllaraju glared at us as we pushed up to high camp where both Dani and I waited for partners. Dani\u2019s arrived and Cissar didn\u2019t. Yes, I got stood up at 5000m. She was also meant to bring the tent and fuel! I couldn\u2019t believe it and neither could any of the other climbers at our camp. I was about to turn around and undertake the rather dangerous descent back to base camp but charity smiled at me. In 30 minutes I had two climbing partners and a tent to sleep in. &nbsp;The summit push that followed turned out to be one of the most trying and life-changing ascents I\u2019ve ever experienced.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What was the biggest lesson?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Climbing out of season isn\u2019t the best idea.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Best piece of gear&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;My Osprey backpacks. They were crammed full of everything I depended on; rope, climbing gear, high-altitude apparel, smelly foods from the smelliest Bolivian markets and sailing gear which was too expensive to dump. They dealt with salty sea spray, were dragged up mountains and down canyons and were thrown on and off dodgy buses more times than I can count.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Any amazing person that you met on the trip?&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;So many cool folks! The backpackers and climbers I met kept me psyched particularly since I was travelling alone for so long and was generally the youngest at any spot. Towards the end of the trip an amazing family in Chile looked after me. And I spent 3 weeks with a group of interesting Argentineans on the Peruvian coast\u2026they were musicians, artists, and some very talented cooks. Even though I barely understood a word they were saying, I felt very relieved and privileged to be in such a positive environment.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What did you eat on the trip?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Mainly rice and boiled eggs\u2026 yum! But, my favorite meal was ceviche, a fish dish where the fish is \u2018cooked\u2019 (ie pickled) in lemon juice. Simple, tasty and cheap. We ate a lot of it on the boat, because fresh fish was all we had. After we touched land in Brazil, I craved it. Luckily ceviche is a national dish in Peru.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%2011.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It did, however, give me a damn stomach parasite, which put me in a dodgy Peruvian hospital for a few days. But it was worth it.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What was the worst thing that bit you?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The mozzies of Patanal, Brazil. These beautiful wetlands are home to toucans, capybaras, alligators, and some of most extraordinary creatures that Mother Nature has to offer, however I\u2019ve never been attacked by so many flippin\u2019 mosquitoes in my life. Our hikes involved being chased by swarming dark clouds of the blood suckers. Never again! &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What\u2019s next?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Cycling the Silk Road - with some big climbs along the way! Now, it\u2019s time to start scrounging around for some cash!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Kai%2012.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Disclaimer&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The contenders for the Nightjar Adventurer 2015 competition were all interviewed by Nightjar. The content included therein is, to our knowledge, accurate and true.&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/veteran\u2019s-air-travel-survival-guide\" data-title=\"A Veteran\u2019s Air Travel Survival Guide\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Julia Domanski, pics Desktop Wallpapers 4 Me and Shawn Kathleen (creator of Passenger Shaming on Facebook)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019ve heard it said that as a mother gazes down at her newborn child, she forgets all about the hours of agony she endured to get her bundle of joy. The 11 hours of excruciating labour is forgotten and two years later, she may very well be eager to go through it all again. And then, she will likely be surprised at just how very painful and uncomfortable the whole ordeal is. &lt;em&gt;I\u2019d forgotten how absolutely horrific this is!&lt;\/em&gt; She thinks.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Air travel is very much like childbirth in this way. No matter how many times (your knees aching and your feet swollen, your eyes dry and puffy from lack of sleep) you swear &lt;em&gt;never again&lt;\/em&gt;, the lure of that tropical beach or snow-covered mountain is too strong. And so you find yourself standing in that queue once again - boarding pass clutched in your hand, waiting to board the plane.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;I am excited&lt;\/em&gt;, I chant to myself. &lt;em&gt;No, really&lt;\/em&gt;. Even as the man behind me turns and thwacks me in the ribs with his carry-on bag. Even as my boarding pass refuses to scan and the stern lady at the desk narrows her eyes at me suspiciously. Even as I step into the plane and that musty, stale air-smell envelops me like an old blanket left in a dark cupboard for far too long.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I am excited. I am going to Rome - my home away from home - and the fact that I just happen to have remembered that I loathe air travel is completely insignificant.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I shuffle along towards my seat (27F). As a lowly economy class traveler, a swell of deep resentment crashes over me as I walk down through the business class section and watch as people settle into their cloud-like seats. They\u2019re offered champagne and chilled raspberries. I, too, am a fan of chilled raspberries. But I guess I\u2019ll settle for the stale, too-salty peanuts us mere mortals are graciously given. I resist the urge to throttle the VIPs with their oxygen mask straps.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Air%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It comes as no surprise to me that I am seated next to a large, already-sweating elderly gentleman. Behind me is a small, smirking child and his irritated mother. It is always me that gets the obnoxious child who kicks the back of my seat like a malfunctioning, cheap massage chair. This child will also always have an overprotective, dragonesque parent (generally the mother; the father is too busy checking out the air hostesses) who, if you dare to cast an evil-eye back at the little monster, will stab said eye with her lip liner stick. I settle for sticking my tongue out at the tiny terror while his mother\u2019s nose is buried in her massive snakeskin handbag.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After what seems like an eternity, and after several calls for a Mr Wyatt-Jones who is holding up the entire flight, we\u2019re about to take off. The air hostesses are doing their usual robotic \u2018your exits are here, here and here\u2019 routine and, as usual, no one is paying them any mind whatsoever. The sweating man next to me boisterously shoves my elbow off of the armrest and simultaneously manages to waft a pungent breeze of armpit-sweat in my direction. I gag, and then I begin to plot. Gazing at his bulging beer belly a flash of inspiration hits me. I discover that if you offer the grumpy, sweating man next to you, say, 3\/4 of your bag of ridiculously scrumptious chocolate-covered toffees, it will come back to you in a good way. In the form of, if you're in luck, an offer of the much-desired armrest. Julia- 1, Air Travel- 0.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With a few bumps and a couple of nervous squeals from my surrounding passengers, we\u2019re in the air at last. Skinny airhostesses wearing too much lipstick and well-spoken air stewards with hair slicked back with too much gel hand out the dreaded peanuts. Next come the earphones for our in-flight entertainment. Through extensive research, I have discovered that airplane headphones are capable of inducing chronic migraines due to their astonishing ability to jab into 32 different areas of your scull at the same time. Avoid them at all costs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Shortly after take-off, just as I am settling in to watch Harry Potter, the pilot crackles over the announcement system to inform us that we are entering into a 'brief' period of turbulence. Heed my warning, future travellers! &lt;em&gt;Never&lt;\/em&gt; assume that you are a skilled enough connoisseur of &lt;em&gt;anything&lt;\/em&gt; (drinking, nail painting, standing) to attempt it just after the pilot announces a period of turbulence. My moist neighbor discovered this the hard way when he decided that he needed to fetch down his hand luggage just as the plane began to bounce and swoop. Sadly, it was I and not he who actually suffered from his idiocy. As he stood, the plane dipped, and he sprawled, armpit first, directly into my horrified face.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It was the beginning of the end.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Air%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I was onto my second Harry Potter movie when the announcement was made that dinner was about to be served. I dove into my handbag and managed to extract my eye mask. Then, caring not at all about the strange looks I was getting, I fastened the mask around and over my nose and mouth. I was prepared. Regardless of how nice airplane food may TASTE, it will never, not ever, SMELL nice. It will always remind you of dog vomit, old age homes and the antiseptic spray used in hospitals. Also, if it could be bottled in an aerosol can, no one would ever need pepper spray again.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As I had predicted, my neighbour scoffed his entire meal with relish, and then he had the audacity to ask if, seeing as I wasn\u2019t eating mine, he could have it? The only other person in the vicinity who seemed to despise the stale bread and too-yellow custard as much as I did was the boy sitting behind me. He wailed and screamed and kicked until his mother pulled a packet of chips out of her bag for him. The enticing scent of salt and vinegar and oil made my mouth water.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;How many hours to go? Oh, ten. Just ten? Piece of cake.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Once the dinner trays have been cleared and I have managed to find momentary relief in the lemony-freshness of a wet wipe upon my dry, anxious face, the lights are dimmed in the cabin. If you ignore and forget everything else I have said in this article - remember this one tip and it may very well save your life (and keep your sanity intact):&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Don't try to evade the '&lt;strong&gt;seat-reclining cycle of suffering and pain&lt;\/strong&gt;'. Don't even waste your much-needed energy on getting riled up about it. It goes something like this:&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;- The person in front of you reclines their seat slightly (it's usually the obnoxious child). You are watching a movie which you don't really like, but feel is vital to watch anyway considering you have 12 more hours of flight time left. The reclining of the seat sets your screen at an angle. You're not really bothered - you can simply tilt the screen up and continue watching.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;- The seat in front of you reclines further. Now, your movie looks like an experimental art nouveau film about polar bears and aliens. You die a little inside, and tilt the screen as far up as possible. You pray to whatever God you believe in that the cycle ends here. But your prayers are unanswered.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;- The lights in the cabin dim. People settle down to attempt to sleep, a feeling of dread builds up in your stomach. As if in horrific slow motion, the seat in front of you reclines at full-throttle, until the small screen is pressed against your face. Your angry puffs of breath cloud it up, and suddenly you're not watching a movie, but bacteria writhing around under an intensely focused microscope.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;- You are forced to recline your seat. And you've started the cycle for the person behind you.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Game. Over.&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Air%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I have found that sleeping pills become more appealing than heroin to an addict on a 15-hour flight. Invest in some before you leave or steal a few from your insomniac relative (we all have one). Having brought my own and taken two with a swig of red wine, I am well on my way to a few blissful hours of rest when it happens. It pierces my eardrums and tears my fragile soul apart. It is 2am. Everyone else is asleep. And then there is Satan; that one person onboard who laughs like a demented, drunk hyena when everyone else is trying to sleep. Most of the time, that person will be you, or your embarrassing relative. This time, it is the mother of the brat behind me. A tear leaks out of the corner of my eye. All hope is lost.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019ve finished three Harry Potter movies. My portly neighbor is snoring softly beside me (his name is Bert, I\u2019ve discovered). The cackling mother and her cub are fast asleep. I\u2019ve never been more awake. I turn my attention to the little screen pressed up against my nose. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Know nothing about the layout of the continents or where different countries are situated? Watch the 'track your journey' map for a few hours. You will be a geographic pro in no time. By the time the sun starts to leak under the partially closed shutters- I could give a guided tour of the entire continent of Asia.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hours pass. I begin to wonder if this is all a bizarre nightmare and that I\u2019ll wake up in my cozy bed at home- snug and safe and alone. It\u2019s a comforting thought. The nauseating smell of breakfast approaching on the trolley awakens Bert from his peaceful slumber.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018Air travel puts me right to sleep!\u2019 He says cheerfully, \u2018In fact, I sleep better on planes than I do in my own bed at home.\u2019 I bite my tongue and smile weakly.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hazel, our air hostess, glows down at me as she hands me my orange juice. It occurs to me that air hostesses only look so pretty because after traveling for however many hours in a cramped, sweaty, stuffy environment, they appear as goddesses of elegance, freshness and space. I drink three cups of coffee (black with six sugars; the airhostess watches each granule disappear into my cup with great disdain) and prepare for the final stretch- the last three hours.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Air%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I flick through the glossy pages of the in-flight magazine to kill some time. It may be the sleeping pills, coffee and red wine affecting my brain but things that you DO NOT need or even vaguely like, such as gold-plated teaspoon sets engraved with baby meerkats, suddenly appear to be VERY appealing when they are on the colourful pages of the duty free shopping section.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I must have dozed off (thank the Lord!) because the next thing I know I am being jolted awake by a particularly nasty kick from the spawn of Satan behind me. The in-flight magazine lies open in my lap and Bert\u2019s head lolls on my aching shoulder. I can\u2019t bring myself to wake him so that I can go to the loo. The announcement system pings and the pilot, sounding tired and bored, says that we are about to begin our descent. Yes!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Twenty minutes later, the hours of torture are over. The plane has landed and as usual, a few annoying individuals have applauded the qualified pilot's flying skills. I remind myself: DO NOT STAND UP STRAIGHT AWAY. In other words, do not be a sheep. I know that I will simply stand and cast awkward glances at those around me as I wait for a long period of time before I can leave the aircraft. Instead, I sit down comfortably, and plan how I\u2019m going to push in front of the impatient businessman hovering next to my seat.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As the plane empties, I manage (by some miracle) to hoist my hand luggage down from the overhead baggage compartment without bashing someone on the head with it. I shuffle off of the aircraft and breathe in the fresh air of my much-anticipated holiday destination. Roma. Home.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Now all I have to do is collect my baggage from the \u2018&lt;strong&gt;carousel of false hope&lt;\/strong&gt;\u2019.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I am strong. I can do this. And so can you. Good luck.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Air%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9131\" class=\"publisher-1944 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/rowing-wind\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Rowing with the Wind&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Rowing with the Wind  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Rowing with the Wind\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/The-Intrepid-Explorer-logo2.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Cameron%20Bellamy%201.jpg?itok=bjsl2y6f\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rowing-wind\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rowing-wind\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rowing-wind&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Cameron%20Bellamy%201.jpg&amp;description=Rowing with the Wind\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rowing-wind\" data-text=\"Rowing with the Wind\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rowing-wind\" data-title=\"Rowing with the Wind\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Mar 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By Roy Watts&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On 11 August, a team of six rowers reached the Seychelles after setting out from the port of Geraldton in Australia on 11 June \u2013 57 days earlier. In doing so, they set two world records: At 6 720 kilometres, it was the greatest distance covered by any team in the Indian Ocean and it was also the fastest crossing in a rowing boat. One of the crew members was Cameron Bellamy \u2013 a Capetonian and Bishops Old Boy. This is his story.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;What does it take to row two hours on and two hours off for 57 days? Interviewing Cameron Bellamy was a fascinating experience, which brought home the kind of determination necessary in an epic adventure such as this.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;His story starts in his final year at Diocesan College (Bishops) when he won the Rower of the Year award. At Rhodes University, he was chosen for the South African under-23 team, and a year later rowed for South African Universities at the world championships. After achieving a BCom honours degree, he furthered his academic career with a master\u2019s degree from The University of Queensland in Brisbane. He rowed for this institution as well.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bellamy\u2019s adventurous wanderlust took root at the end of a three-year period of working in Beijing. He decided to embark on a 7 200km bike ride from there to Kanyakumari on the southern tip of India. He set out on a specially equipped bicycle fitted with a rack and side panniers housing sleeping bags, a tent, cooking equipment, blankets, pillow and a mattress.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He was conversationally fluent in the Chinese language and describes himself as a gregarious loner. This sociability meant that he only spent half of his time sleeping and cooking in forests or open fields. For the rest, he was offered a bed and meals by well-wishers along the way.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;During his long ride, he started thinking about a concept where a group of like-minded adventurers may channel their energies into fund-raising exploits for charity. Four months later, he pedalled into Kanyakumari \u2013 having spent his budget, which was the equivalent of R50 per day.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The bicycle ride from Beijing to India was Bellamy\u2019s Chinese swan song, and his next job was in Britain where he set up the Ubunye Challenge in 2011. Three separate ventures were planned. The first was to cycle 1 349km from Land\u2019s End to John O\u2019Groats in northernmost Scotland. This was to be followed by a solo swim across the English Channel, and finally an Atlantic crossing from the Canary Islands to Barbados in a six-man rowing boat.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The beneficiaries were to be the Ubunye Foundation (formerly the Angus Gillis Foundation), a project that would instal containers fully kitted out as classrooms in the Eastern Cape; and Vimba, an outfit dedicated to fostering the development and education of underprivileged children in Zimbabwe.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Preparing for the Land\u2019s End\/John O\u2019Groats ride was easy enough, as it consisted of cycling in a nearby gym at lunch times. The really tough one was training for the Channel swim, scheduled for the end of June \u2013 two months after the bike ride. This involved early-morning lengths in the gym pool and two open-air swims a week in Hyde Park\u2019s Serpentine Lake at 8 degrees Celsius in mid-winter. From April onward, Bellamy attended weekend training courses run by the English Channel Swimming and Piloting Federation (CS and PF) at the Port of Dover, with occasional sessions at Bournemouth.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Land\u2019s End charity ride was split into two groups of five using country roads and was a lot of fun. The same could not be said of the Channel swim, however. Bellamy was the only one of the \u2018Challengers\u2019 to make it. Accompanied by supporters in a boat provided by the CS and PF, he got to the English shore in 16 hours 30 minutes. He was not one of the recognised competitive swimmers at school, so this says a lot about his determination and staying power.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The final Atlantic challenge ran into trouble when he failed to find sponsors for the Atlantic rowing event. He then approached Scotsman Leven Brown, who had a 45-foot (13.5-metre) eight-man rowing boat and had already completed four successful Atlantic crossings. Long story short: he decided to join Brown\u2019s team in a rowing venture from Australia\u2019s west coast to Durban. This, then, was how he found himself \u2013 the only Ubunye Challenger \u2013 in the Ozzie port of Geraldton, setting out with a crew of six men and one woman for the ambitious crossing to Africa.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The going was tough in the first two weeks. There was much seasickness caused by the extremely rough conditions created by three low-pressure systems \u2013 the last of which was on the tail end of a hurricane. Adjusting to sleep deprivation was another difficulty as they embarked on the two hours on\/two hours off rowing routine. With the on\/off sleeping sessions seldom lasting for more than 90 minutes, there was a continual degree of tiredness for the duration of the trip. Conditions did improve, however, once they reached the tropics.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Twenty-four days out, they experienced their first major mishap when the autopilot packed up. It became evident that it could not be fixed out at sea and thus the crew now had to steer manually for the duration of the trip.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For meals, the crew depended mainly of freeze-dried food that was prepared by pouring boiling water into the sachet containers. This led to the next setback, when two huge waves hit the boat four days later: Shane Usher was preparing a meal and boiling water splashed onto his leg, creating serious blisters. Despite ointment and bandaging, the wounds continued to deteriorate \u2013 and after four days, it became necessary to embark on a casualty evacuation. Global Rescue was contacted and a tanker was diverted to arrive a scant five hours later.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The first attempt to winch him on board in a basket nearly ended in disaster, as their limited steering capacity proved to be too erratic when the tanker was nearly blown onto their boat. An oar was broken in fending it off. In the end, a lifeboat was lowered to complete the transfer. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The loss of Shane meant that for the remaining 25 days, they could only have two oarsmen at a time \u2013 with one person steering!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cameron%20Bellamy%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While fairly far out, it was decided to switch the destination to the Seychelles. Storms and unseasonal winds had blown them too far north to make Durban safely and, due to current unrest in Kenya and Somalia, this was the only viable option.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Seychelles also has a pirate problem, and as they neared their destination, a 12m wooden skiff approached and radioed the demand that they stop. It was manned by a group of swarthy looking individuals claiming they were fishermen \u2013 but there was nary a rod in sight. Brown decided to brazen it out and they carried on rowing. When asked what they were up to, he replied that they were on a Royal Navy exercise, waiting to be refuelled. That did the trick and the suspicious boat scooted off.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The interlude with the suspected pirates was the final drama in their marathon journey and they continued on to a welcome at the harbour in Victoria \u2013 the capital city of Mahe.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When Cameron Bellamy set out from Geraldton, he weighed 105 kilogrammes. On arriving back in Cape Town in high spirits after his arduous crossing, he weighed 87kg, his hands were calloused \u2013 and the Ubunye Foundation was R798 660 better off.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;The Intrepid Explorer&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Intrepid%20Cover%20Dec_1.jpg?itok=ZP8OSTOh\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;The Intrepid explorer&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9289\" class=\"publisher-4090 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/fly-tying-tips-and-tricks-better-tying-part-1\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Fly Tying - Tips and tricks for better tying  - Part 1 &lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Fly Tying - Tips and tricks for better tying  - Part 1   &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Fly Tying - Tips and tricks for better tying  - Part 1 \" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.vagabondfly.com\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #000000' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Vagabond.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Tips%201.jpg?itok=BcephqGw\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fly-tying-tips-and-tricks-better-tying-part-1\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fly-tying-tips-and-tricks-better-tying-part-1\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fly-tying-tips-and-tricks-better-tying-part-1&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Tips%201.jpg&amp;description=Fly Tying - Tips and tricks for better tying  - Part 1 \" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fly-tying-tips-and-tricks-better-tying-part-1\" data-text=\"Fly Tying - Tips and tricks for better tying  - Part 1 \" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fly-tying-tips-and-tricks-better-tying-part-1\" data-title=\"Fly Tying - Tips and tricks for better tying  - Part 1 \"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By Gordon van der Spuy&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I have been very fortunate to have taught over 300 tyers locally in the last two years. I think I have learnt more from my pupils than they have from me, but don\u2019t go telling them that. It has been interesting to note how most tyers seem to battle with the same elements. These observations were in fact the impetus for me writing this. This article is basically just a summation of the trends I\u2019ve seen, a fly tying state of the nation address if you will. Hopefully it will be of help.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Know your mayflies from your midges&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The first thing I have students do at a workshop is draw a selection of aquatic insects that I randomly name. Most guys can\u2019t draw 20% of the bugs I name; they simply don\u2019t know what they are, and \u2018therein lies the rub\u2019 as old William would\u2019ve said.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;How can you effectively imitate or suggest a creature if you have no insight regarding it in the first place.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;\/blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;How can you effectively imitate or suggest a creature if you have no insight regarding it in the first place. This might seems obvious but statistics don\u2019t lie. Most guys approach their tying like they would baking a cake. They are recipe orientated and tie by numbers as it were. This is very one dimensional, the tyer never really understands what he or she is doing and thus remains in the proverbial dark. Sure, you\u2019ll catch fish being a recipe tyer but you will definitely be more successful once the proverbial light goes on for you. One needs to tie beyond the book or the pattern and you can only do this once you know something about the creatures you wish to imitate.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;One needs to tie beyond the book or the pattern and you can only do this once you know something about the creatures you wish to imitate.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;\/blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;To tie an effective imitation you need to incorporate the important features of that natural in your fly. Take a bit of time looking for insects when next you find yourself on the water. Put the little guys in a tank and observe them, see what they do, sure, you might need to chase them around a bit to get them moving, some won\u2019t move that much, they simply don\u2019t have the ability to cover vast distances. These observations will not only stand you in good stead when you\u2019re at the vice but also when you\u2019re actually fishing the fly. That is a guarantee.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.vagabondfly.com\/fly-tying-tips-and-tricks-for-better-tying-part-gordon-van-der-spuy\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Vagabond Fly Mag&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.vagabondfly.com\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Vagabond%20cover.jpg?itok=sQPODvfS\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Vagabond Fly Mag&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9130\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/place-heaven-swazi-style\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;The Place of Heaven, Swazi Style&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    The Place of Heaven, Swazi Style  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"The Place of Heaven, Swazi Style\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Swazi%201.jpg?itok=dlb21C-Z\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/place-heaven-swazi-style\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/place-heaven-swazi-style\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/place-heaven-swazi-style&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Swazi%201.jpg&amp;description=The Place of Heaven, Swazi Style\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/place-heaven-swazi-style\" data-text=\"The Place of Heaven, Swazi Style\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/place-heaven-swazi-style\" data-title=\"The Place of Heaven, Swazi Style\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Bridget Hilton Barber&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Swaziland has cool places to stay, great mountain scenery, friendly people, amazing arts and craft, and soulful spots \u2013 and much of it is centred round Ezulwini Valley.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The tiny mountain kingdom with the big heart. That\u2019s what they call Swaziland. It is a small country indeed \u2013 you can drive through it in a day \u2013 but you could stay for a week and not get bored. There\u2019s plenty to do and see - Swaziland has cool places to stay, great mountain scenery, friendly people, amazing arts and craft, and soulful spots \u2013 and much of it is centred round Ezulwini Valley.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Swazi%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From Mbabane the capital city, the King\u2019s Highway goes down a long steep pass called Malagwane Hill and at the bottom is the exit to Ezulwini Valley, which means place of heaven, and is the main tourism hub. Believe me, the place of heaven is where you want to be. It\u2019s a lush subtropical area with plenty of funky overnight spots, colourful local markets and craft centres, gorgeous nature reserves, and interesting restaurants and galleries. Ezulwini is also home to official stuff like the Swazi Royal palace, the houses of parliament, the national museum and archives and the national stadium.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Swazi%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The main road through is called Swazi Spa Valley and along here you\u2019ll find the long-time touristy hotels like the Royal Swazi Spa, the Lugogo Sun and the Ezulwini Sun - as well as the upmarket Royal Villas. Ezulwini is also home to the infamous Happy Valley Casino, which was the favoured haunt of white South African men in the apartheid days, who came gambling and looking for black flesh. Now it\u2019s far more salubrious and kinda blingy, and draws an assortment of people in search of Lady Luck. The Gables Shopping Centre is also a welcome addition to Ezulwini Valley \u2013 for last minute shopping and dining out or having a quick drink. Actually it\u2019s more likely to be a slow drink since Ezulwini is not really a very fast moving area.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Swazi%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;One of the distinctive peaks in the Ezulwini Valley is a mountain peak called Execution Rock, which is part of the legendary Mlilwane Wildlife Reserve, which has a &lt;em&gt;lekker&lt;\/em&gt; hotel and a backpackers. The name comes from a century back when criminals were made to walk to the summit and plunge to their death. Swazi warriors provided assistance with their spears of course; a quick prod to facilitate the downward journey. These days, thankfully things are much more laid back.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Swazi%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Round up the gang and head for the place of heaven. Here are some suggestions for what to do and where to stay in Ezulwini.&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;See the funky House on Fire venue which is an amazing Gaudi-style place that hosts music events, art exhibitions, plays, theatres groups, dancing and other cultural stuff &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.house-on-fire.com\"&gt;www.house-on-fire.com&lt;\/a&gt;. It is home to the annual Bushfire festival of the arts (check out &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.bushfire.com\"&gt;www.bushfire.com&lt;\/a&gt;) which is a wonderful reflection of contemporary Swazi and SADC culture, held each year in May. Next to House on Fire is Malandela\u2019s, another inspiring and creative venue with a wonderful restaurant. It\u2019s a cool sundowner spot because of its soft and sweeping views of the mountains. And next to Malandela\u2019s is the iconic Swazi shop called Gone Rural which has hand woven home accessories like mats, placemats, lamp stands, baskets and more. This is where traditional skill meets high end design with amazing results. You have been warned. Easy on that credit card.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Swazi%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;Check out Mantenga Craft Centre and Nature Reserve, another long-time favourite spots for picnickers and ramblers, strollers and those in search of peace and quiet. One of the hikes here takes you up the mountain and rewards you with amazing views of Sheba\u2019s Breasts, twin mountain peaks named after the beautiful and mysterious Queen Sheba of Ethiopia. Take a picnic and a couple of Sibebe Beers, the local brew.&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;Go for a chilled lunch and a bit of rural retail therapy at the Guava Gallery, a bistro and gallery with more beautiful views.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Swazi%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;Visit the Swazi Candles centre, which is a short drive from the place of heaven, along a scenic road with markets and more pretty views. Swazi Candles is one of the oldest organizations in Swaziland and their place has a huge display room full of unusual candles and soaps. The centre also has Kwazi Swazi, a bookshop with music, t-shirts &amp; souvenirs; the Baobab Batik shop, and a charming mercado selling mainly Mozambican arts &amp; crafts. The Sambane Caf\u00e9 is good for a light lunch or strong espresso.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Swazi%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;Take a drive to Mbabane, the capital city, which is positively tiny if you\u2019re used to Jozi, Durbs or Cape Town. There are two main malls, The Mall and the Swazi Plaza which are worth a quick visit; and then check out the famous old Mbabane market which sells fresh produce and has a good and cheap range of arts &amp; crafts, fabric and pots. And then round it off with a drink at Mountain Inn, a much loved old hotel on the outskirts of Mbabane which has wide and wonderful views of Ezulwini Valley. &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.mountaininn.sz\"&gt;www.mountaininn.sz&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Swazi%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Places to stay:&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;For a self-catering stay in a gorgeous setting, go straight to the lovely Buhleni Farm Cottages which are just off the main road, and make you feel like you\u2019ve landed in an ancient garden in another world. Their chalets are simple and well kitted out, you can also go for walks and picnics on the farm. &nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.buhlenifarm.co.sz\"&gt;www.buhlenifarm.co.sz&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;Lidwala Backpackers Lodge is a stylish spot with a swimming pool and Jacuzzi, a bar and a laid back restaurant serving traditional Swazi food &amp; good vibes. Email &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@lidwala.co.sz\"&gt;info@lidwala.co.sz&lt;\/a&gt;.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;For more info on travelling in Swaziland check out &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.welcometoswaziland.com\"&gt;www.welcometoswaziland.com&lt;\/a&gt; and &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.swazitravel.com\"&gt;www.swazitravel.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Swazi%2011.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9344\" class=\"publisher-2745 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/belle-rodrigues\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Belle Rodrigues&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Belle Rodrigues  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Belle Rodrigues\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.aa.co.za\/shop\/aa-traveller' target='_blank' style='background-color: #000000' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/AA-traveller1.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/M%26L%20Rodriques.jpg?itok=dxyRF8BW\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/belle-rodrigues\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/belle-rodrigues\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/belle-rodrigues&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/M%26L%20Rodriques.jpg&amp;description=Belle Rodrigues\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/belle-rodrigues\" data-text=\"Belle Rodrigues\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/belle-rodrigues\" data-title=\"Belle Rodrigues\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By Richard Holmes&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018That little piggy really, really does not want to go to market,\u2019 I think to myself as the panicked squeals echo down the bustling street. Ignoring its protests, three men push and pull the reluctant creature as shoppers wander past with barely a glance.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s Saturday morning on the island of Rodrigues, and the weekly market in the capital Port Mathurin is in full swing. The air is soft and humid, teetering undecided on the edge between warm and bloody hot. A steady thwack-thwack-thwack sounds as young coconuts are shaped into takeaway drinks, while handwoven straw hats are sold for a song and the butcher is doing a roaring trade. Fresh pork will be on the menu a little later, no doubt.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s a colourful, character-filled market, where the locals greet customers with a broad smile and a chat about the weather and, oh-so-gently, what\u2019s for sale. It\u2019s a perfect mirror of the island as a whole: a place where tourists are something woven into the fabric of life, not the reason for it. Here, life carries on with or without visitors, although the welcome in Creole-tinged French is always warm.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;So, don\u2019t be surprised if you\u2019ve not yet heard of Rodrigues. Lying around 600 km north-east of Mauritius, it has a degree of autonomy but is officially a constituency of its more famous neighbour. Unlike Mauritius, though, there\u2019s a dearth of sprawling resorts and manicured golf courses here... That lack is precisely why I fell in love with the island, but I discovered many reasons to stay enamoured.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rodriques%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;First of all, it\u2019s a gorgeous place. With the landmass just 18 km long and 8 km wide, it is the surrounding lagoon \u2013 300 km\u00b2 dotted with coral reefs \u2013 that takes your breath away as the Air Mauritius flight comes in to land at the small airport in the west of the island. There are no extinct volcanic cirques here, but also no acres of mono-cropped sugarcane. Rather, from the vantage point of Mont Limon, it\u2019s a patchwork of small-scale farms and valleys of indigenous forest that cover the hillsides tumbling down to the lagoon and its palette of blues.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ah yes, that lagoon. It is, to be honest, the reason many people come here. It\u2019s light and translucent over the sandy shallows, where kite-surfers play in the steady trade winds that waft in from the south-east. There are few better places in the Indian Ocean for the sport \u2013 the riot of colourful kites that weave and bob here in the summer are testament to this tiny island\u2019s status as a world-class destination without the world-class crowds.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Slashing through the shallows are a handful of passes, where the water drops from waist-deep to 40m in a matter of steps. The scuba-diving is superb here, with game fish patrolling the depths and the pristine coral a welcome change from the dynamite- and sun-damaged reefs of other Indian Ocean islands.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Beyond the passes and the shallows, the waters give way to the fringing coral reef. There\u2019s great snorkelling to be found, while on calm days local fishermen circle shoals of carangue \u2013 a tasty fish not unlike yellowtail \u2013 with their hand-drawn seine nets. Further out, local women scour the reef for octopuses \u2013 a local speciality traditionally hung out to dry on racks, like cephalopod washing waving in the tropical breeze.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rodriques%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Seafood looms large on Rodriguan tables, I discover at of Marie-Louise Roussety\u2019s comfortable auberge, Villa Mon Tr\u00e9sor. There\u2019s no shortage of cosy restaurants on the island, but \u2013 for a true taste of local cuisine \u2013 it\u2019s best to book a table at one of the many home-based table d\u2019h\u00f4te eateries. Usually attached to a guest house, this \u2018host\u2019s table\u2019 allows visitors to join the family and other guests for the meal of the day (whatever the proprietor happens to be preparing). \u2018Every Rodriguan will ask for their fish at dinnertime,\u2019 laughs Marie-Louise. \u2018Maybe a little roast pork too on special occasions, but every day there must be fish on the plate!\u2019&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With hundred of kilometres of ocean dividing it from its western neighbour and a few thousand to Australia in the east, local ingredients dominate on the island. Fragrant curries of seafood, chicken or pork feature strongly; alongside rice, maize, kidney beans and tangy salads of green papaya, onion, chives and tomato. A taste of the island\u2019s culinary culture is a further highlight of any visit.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another is, without a doubt, a trip to the idyllic Ile aux Cocos to the west. It\u2019s one of a number of tiny protected islands surrounding Rodrigues that provide a refuge for thousands of migrating seabirds. As our boat hisses up on to the sand, the casuarina trees that line the beach are filled with elegant lesser noddies and snowy-hued white terns, while their darker sooty tern cousins fill the sky. In the distant blue, riding the thermals, are the remarkable frigate birds.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rodriques%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This slender sliver of sand is cast away in the distant Indian Ocean, yet it provides a much-needed refuge for these wandering birds; allowing them to rest and recharge, readying for the journey home. As I settle down at the table laid by my guide in the shade of the trees \u2013 an octopus salad and bottle of local rum readying us for a languid afternoon \u2013 it strikes me that the same could be said for us human travellers. Rodrigues may be a little off the beaten track, but, for idyllic beaches, stunning scenery and a warm welcome, it is hard to beat.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;An unlikely settler&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;When he set foot on Rodrigues on 1 May 1691, the French Huguenot Fran\u00e7ois Leguat (fleeing persecution in France) became the island\u2019s first settler. The problem was, he had been told he would be deposited on R\u00e9union. The captain of the Dutch ship, wishing to avoid conflict with a squadron of French ships, would hear none of it though, and so Leguat and seven others were left to fend for themselves on Rodrigues. They lasted two years \u2013 living off the plentiful giant tortoises, abundant fish and the fruits of the lush valleys \u2013 before fleeing by raft to Mauritius. Leguat finally made it back to Europe, via Jakarta, in 1698.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Back to the future&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Fran\u00e7ois Leguat Giant Tortoise &amp; Cave Reserve in the south-west of the island is an attempt to recreate what the ecosystem was like when the first settlers arrived. Indigenous trees are being replanted to create a sanctuary for the endemic Rodrigues fruit bat and giant tortoises from Mauritius are being bred to slowly repopulate this corner of the island.&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.tortoisescavereserve-rodrigues.com\/en\"&gt;www.tortoisescavereserve-rodrigues.com\/en&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Rodriques%204.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Good to know&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Getting there&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Air Mauritius flies from Joburg, Cape Town and Durban to Rodrigues, via Mauritius. Depending on schedules you may need to overnight in Mauritius en route to Rodrigues, a 90-minute flight away.&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.airmauritius.com\"&gt;www.airmauritius.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Where to stay&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are no large Mauritian-style resorts here; rather, an array of family-run guest houses, small hotels and boutique resorts. Cotton Bay Hotel, Mourouk Ebony Hotel and Tekoma Boutik Hotel are some of the best options.&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.cottonbayhotel.biz\"&gt;www.cottonbayhotel.biz&lt;\/a&gt;, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.mouroukebonyhotel.com\"&gt;www.mouroukebonyhotel.com&lt;\/a&gt;, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.tekoma-hotel.com\"&gt;www.tekoma-hotel.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Visas&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;South African visitors do not need a visa to visit Mauritius (including Rodrigues).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;More info&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To really get a feel for the island, plan to spend around a week exploring. Visit the Rodrigues Tourism Office website for more information.&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.tourism-rodrigues.mu\"&gt;www.tourism-rodrigues.mu&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br class=\"Apple-interchange-newline\"&gt;Source:&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.aa.co.za\/shop\/aa-traveller\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;AA Traveller&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Autumn%202014~3_1.jpg?itok=elYsHKhq\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;AA clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/join-cheetah-watch\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Join the Cheetah Watch&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Join the Cheetah Watch  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Join the Cheetah Watch\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\/wild_magazine.htm' target='_blank' style='background-color: #b7cb35' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/wild.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Cheetahs%201.jpg?itok=BhSWSsvT\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/join-cheetah-watch\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/join-cheetah-watch\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/join-cheetah-watch&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Cheetahs%201.jpg&amp;description=Join the Cheetah Watch\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/join-cheetah-watch\" data-text=\"Join the Cheetah Watch\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/join-cheetah-watch\" data-title=\"Join the Cheetah Watch\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words and pics Matthew Schurch&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Next time you\u2019re in Kgalagadi, use the new #Cheetah Identification Guide for the Kgalagadi Transfrontier Park# to identify individuals, then submit your sightings to help the monitoring of the park\u2019s cheetahs.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Kgalagadi is known as one of the best places in the world to view cheetahs hunting in their natural environment. Over the past eight years, many of the park\u2019s cheetahs have become well known to visitors through the field research of Gus and Margie Mills. Particular favourites have been cheetah sisters Elena and Lisette, happily showing off and enthralling many guests with their litters of cubs in the Auob River, wearing radio collars for many years.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Mills\u2019 study highlighted that cheetahs are perfectly adapted to their hunting style and their environment. The greatest contribution to their daily energy expenditure is not from the high speed hunt as you might assume, but from the many hours they spend walking and searching for prey.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cheetahs%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"384\"&gt;&lt;em&gt;The two sightings of Smith occurred in December 2011 and 2013 respectively. Using the inside spots on the front left leg it is relatively easy to make a positive match. (Unfortunately Smith has since died. - Ed.)&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Cheetahs all over Africa suffer from kleptoparasitism, theft of their prey by other carnivores. In the Kgalagadi around 9,3 per cent of cheetah kills are stolen in this manner. Only when kleptoparasitism levels reach 50 per cent do the cheetahs\u2019 method of hunting become unsustainable. Other factors that cause the cheetahs to change their behaviour and move greater distances, such as human interference, could push their daily energy requirements to critical levels.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To continue the long-term monitoring of the Kgalagadi\u2019s cheetahs after the conclusion of the field work, an identification guide has been created for the cheetahs, a companion guide to the Leopard ID Project. Over the past two years as many reports of the park\u2019s cheetahs as could be found were studied, individuals identified and the Cheetah Identification Guide for the Kgalagadi Transfrontier Park compiled.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Visitors can use the guide to identify individual cheetahs, then submit their sightings to contribute to the monitoring of these felines.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cheetahs%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"384\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;How you can help&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Submit your pictures of the park\u2019s cheetahs so that their movements and breeding success can be monitored. Use the ID guide to identify your sighting. Here are some steps that will make your task easier.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;1. Decide on the appropriate section of the guide to use, this is typically sex or group composition.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;2. Make a note of where you had the sighting and use this information to reduce your initial comparison sample.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;3. Start with the inside leg spots when making a comparison. There tend to be fewer spots and they are much easier to orientate to look for a match. See the photos of Smith (first two images above) as examples of Smith. If you cannot see these spots then use what you have.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Email your sightings to Matthew Schurch of the Kgalagadi Leopard Project at &lt;a href=\"mailto:ktp.leopards@gmail.com\"&gt;ktp.leopards@gmail.com&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To read more about Kgalagadi Cheetah identification, go to &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\"&gt;www.wildcard.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; and type \u201cCheetah ID\u201d in the Search box.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cheetahs%204.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source:&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\/blog.htm?action=view-post&amp;id=4662\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Wild Magazine&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/798\"&gt;Kgalagadi Transfrontier Park&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a Lambert\u2019s Bay Bird Island&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Rare Red-footed Booby spotted on Lambert\u2019s Bay Bird Island  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Rare Red-footed Booby spotted on Lambert\u2019s Bay Bird Island\" class=\"rdf-meta class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rare-red-footed-booby-spotted-lambert\u2019s-bay-bird-island\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rare-red-footed-booby-spotted-lambert\u2019s-bay-bird-island\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\"
