title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rare-red-footed-booby-spotted-lambert\u2019s-bay-bird-island\" data-text=\"Rare Red-footed Booby spotted on Lambert\u2019s Bay Bird Island\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/rare-red-footed-booby-spotted-lambert\u2019s-bay-bird-island\" data-title=\"Rare Red-footed Booby spotted on Lambert\u2019s Bay Bird Island\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Pics CapeNature&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Lambert\u2019s Bay Bird Island welcomed a rare visitor to its shores late last year when a Red-footed Booby was spotted on the island, largely inhabited by up to 17,000 Cape gannets.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Red-footed Booby is usually restricted to the open ocean with a Pantropical distribution, meaning it occurs in a band between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn right around the earth.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;CapeNature Ornithologist, Kevin Shaw, observed: \u201cThis is a very rare sighting in the Western Cape. It is possibly only the second recorded individual of this species ever recorded in the province.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cIt is an immature bird. The young birds tend to forage further afield than adult birds, but Lambert\u2019s Bay is still some way out of its normal distribution range.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Red-footed Booby belongs to the same family as the Cape gannets which inhabit the island. It is the most abundant species and also the smallest species within the &lt;em&gt;Sulidae&lt;\/em&gt; family. Unlike other members of this family it has several different colour morphs. At least five different colour variants are known.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Booby.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The bird has now flown, but a visit to Lambert\u2019s Bay Bird Island is a great day out. The island lies about 100m off the shore of Lambert\u2019s Bay on the Cape\u2019s West Coast. It offers visitors a rare opportunity to see the blue-eyed Cape gannet up close. Bird Island is one of only six sites world-wide where Cape gannets breed, and it is the only breeding site easily accessible to the public.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The island, which is almost 3 hectares in size, is connected to the mainland via a breakwater. It is an important breeding and roosting site for seabirds, particularly Cape gannets and cormorants. Cape fur seals can be seen sunning themselves on the island\u2019s rocks.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the island\u2019s well-situated gannet lookout, visitors can get close to the birds and witness their unique mating dances. The bird hide is signposted with interesting information about these seabirds and their habits.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.capenature.co.za\/reserves\/bird-island-nature-reserve\"&gt;www.capenature.co.za\/reserves\/bird-island-nature-reserve&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;Office hours: 07h00 to 19h00; for more information phone 027 432 1672 or 082 336 5936&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/751\"&gt;&lt;br&gt;Bird Island Nature Reserve&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9191\" class=\"publisher-1338 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/hobbit-trail-run-king-trails\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Hobbit Trail Run - King of Trails&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Hobbit Trail Run - King of Trails  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Hobbit Trail Run - King of Trails\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #d22127' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/din.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Hobbit%201.jpg?itok=Q5xeU33_\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hobbit-trail-run-king-trails\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hobbit-trail-run-king-trails\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hobbit-trail-run-king-trails&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Hobbit%201.jpg&amp;description=Hobbit Trail Run - King of Trails\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hobbit-trail-run-king-trails\" data-text=\"Hobbit Trail Run - King of Trails\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/hobbit-trail-run-king-trails\" data-title=\"Hobbit Trail Run - King of Trails\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics: Mark Sampson, Thribe Media&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Just the name \u2018Hobbit Trail Run\u2019 conjures up ideas of mystical creatures in a faraway place covered in mist-covered mountains and lush forests. When you then hear that it's in Hogsback, in the Eastern Cape, well, then the ideas just get an additional stoke of the coals.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Towering mountains covered in forests, both indigenous and pine, rivers and streams, waterfalls and mushrooms, birds frolicking and unique inquisitive monkeys observing you as you make your way along the single track, and so the list continues. Run this event and you will find it hard to find another to compare it to; not necessarily because it's the best, longest, or hardest, but because of the combination of core ingredients that make for a genuine, pure trail run.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Make no mistake though, it's as tough as they come, with numerous runners throwing the towel in along the 100 km adventure, which took place over 28 and 29 November 2014. Starting at Maiden Dam, just outside of King Williams town, the route follows the beautiful six-day Amatola hiking trail. Due to logistics, the race is limited to only 45 runners, who each have their own story to tell as to how they arrived at the starting line. From an American biologist to a lab technician from Tembisa, it was a field with variety and spice and a huge amount of heart.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Each day the runners covered approximately 50 km and needed to be self-sufficient, as only one water table was available over the two days.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Water in the mountains is plentiful due to all the streams, however with that comes technical terrain, something many runners underestimated and this resulted in longer-than-expected times out on the route.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Hobbit%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Day 1&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On day 1, Jacque Mouton (Team Merrell) managed to squeeze into the halfway hut in first place, although he took a 30-minute detour due to losing his way. He was not the only one, with Suzette von Broembse, who was leading at the time, also getting lost en route and ending up in the local township. Although the locals kindly pointed her in the direction of the waterfalls she needed to reach, Race Director Graham Bird called her back to make sure she was on the correct path. Ultimately, she came in two hours after the leading lady.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At the back of the field, organisers made sure any backmarkers were redirected onto a shorter route because of the fast-approaching inclement weather. Once all were safe and sound in the hut, the organisers put out an array of food for the weary field. From hot dogs to vegetarian pasta, marshmallows and Quality Street chocolates, and for those still feeling up to it, an ice-cold beer was also on offer.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Day 2&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Day 2 dawned with near-perfect but slightly cool conditions, which changed to warm weather later in the day. Runners were sent off for an early morning ascent prior to making their way through more indigenous forest and pine until they reached the famed Hog, or to be specific, Hog One, as there are three Hogs. With just over 30 km on the legs, runners emerged from the forest to face a 700 metre zigzagging, scrambling ascent prior to summiting. Once at the top, their efforts were well rewarded with amazing views.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The final stretches of the run saw runners mainly on forest roads that meandered through pines all the way to the famous Kettle Sprout Waterfall. Once here, many of the competitors stopped briefly to refill their water bottles with the crystal-clear liquid that would get them to the finish line, and where cold Aquelle water awaited them.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Hobbit%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The encore came in the form of pure single track, with a gentle decline to the district road and home. The men\u2019s race saw a relatively unknown Izak van der Merwe emerge as the overall winner in a time of 14:50, ahead of Nick Mulder, who once again had a good showing with a time of 15:21. In the ladies, Suzzette von Broembse made up for her first day's mishap by coming in strong on day two. However, the overall title went to four-time finisher Shelley Hufner in a time of 19:23, with Harriot Cullinan in second place in a time of 19:49.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The organisers of the Hobbit Trail Run cater for all levels of runner, with distances of 38 km, 16 km and 5 km for the beginners. In the 38 km discipline, Samel Luqongo had a good showing with a time of 5:22:52, while Jane Barnado took the ladies race in 6:10:48. In the 16 km race, Graeme van der Nest won in a time of 1:40:00 and Mariella Dierks showed the rest of the ladies up in a time of 1:52:20. The 5 km sprint race was a hotly contested affair, with the eventual winner De Waal van der Heever coming home in a cracking time of 0:29:51. The first female, and junior, was Neve Hayman in 0:31:55.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Prize-giving took place at the host hotel, The Arminal, and the sponsors spoilt all the finishers with hampers packed with Nikwax and Isostar product, plus some Merrell vouchers for good measure.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To all the starters, regardless of the time you crossed the finish line, congratulations!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While racers return home and the forest becomes still once more, the organisation of next year's Merrell Hobbit Trail Run is already underway, with some exciting changes to be announced. Until then, get outdoors and stay active!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For more information about the Merrell Hobbit Trail Run, visit &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/mountainrunner.co.za\/events\/hobbit-trail-run\"&gt;http:\/\/mountainrunner.co.za\/events\/hobbit-trail-run&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Hobbit%20end.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/content\/hobbit-trail-run-king-trails%20\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;DO IT NOW&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3708\"&gt;Hogsback Circular Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2123\"&gt;Hogsback MTB Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3992\"&gt;Hogsback Rock Climbing&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/8274\"&gt;Hogsback target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/cover39_1.jpg?itok=EUJX7eFP\" \/&gt;\n &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9128\" class=\"publisher-1335 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/cut-above\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;A Cut Above&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    A Cut Above  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"A Cut Above\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #222222' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/cl.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Cut%20Above%201.jpg?itok=RUCxhR10\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cut-above\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cut-above\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cut-above&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Cut%20Above%201.jpg&amp;description=A Cut Above\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cut-above\" data-text=\"A Cut Above\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/cut-above\" data-title=\"A Cut Above\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Marianne Heron, pics David Morgan and supplied&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Constantia Valley&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The roots of flower farming run deep along the Spaanschemat River in Constantia Valley, none deeper than those of Moses Jaftha\u2019s family. Their story stretches back to the 1800s to Moses\u2019 great-grandmother Susan Williams, a member of the Christian community who grew flowers and strawberries in the area for generations, a vanished tradition remembered in the name Strawberry Lane.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In those days Susan and her eldest sons would rise before dawn to walk to Adderley Street, Cape Town to sell strawberries and violets. But under the Group Areas Act, the families in the valley were forcibly removed from their leased land in the late 1960s, and relocated to Parkwood Estate near Grassy Park. Luckily, 28 years ago now, Moses was offered land on lease in this valley when childhood mate Andr\u00e9 Badenhorst gave up his strawberry growing business in the area, and Moses was able to establish his flowers there.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Today a simple road sign that announces \u2018fresh cut flowers\u2019 entices customers from across the southern Peninsula, from Newlands to Simon\u2019s Town, to buy bunches from Moses and his sons Malcolm and Charles at the Brounger Road Flower Stall. \u201cCustomers like to see the flowers growing because they know they are fresh,\u201d says Moses.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But perhaps there is more to the attraction than that, for the Jaftha\u2019s flower farm is a patch of rural paradise surrounded by affluent suburbs and upmarket wine farms, protected by its wetland status. Cocks, hens and ducks root about under the fig and plums trees Moses grew from cuttings. Throughout the year, the12ha garden is magnificent, with rows of sweet peas, strelitzia, sweet William, watsonia, agapanthus, feverfew and poppies on either side of the Spaanschemat River, where tiny fish dart about in the clear water.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;All the cultivation is done by hand, with nesting sparrowhawks, plus caracal and porcupine among the visiting wildlife. Malcolm now manages the farm while Charles looks after sales, takes flowers to market in Cape Town and buys some varieties from suppliers for the stall.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Listening to Malcolm talk about his flowers \u2013 which plants self-sow, how to get sweet peas to grow straight and tall or how to store dahlia tubers (dahlias are their biggest sellers), is like taking a crash course in gardening. \u201cI learnt it all from my father,\u201d says Malcolm, who gave up his job as manager at Chapman\u2019s Peak Hotel four years ago in preparation for carrying on the business with Charles when his father retires. Ask him which job he prefers and he doesn\u2019t hesitate. \u201cThis one any day,\u201d he says. \u201cBut it isn\u2019t low maintenance.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Farming has been handed down from generation to generation in the Jaftha family. Moses learned from his mother Susan, a flower seller. \u201cWe used to cut grass for hens, feed the pigs, and we had to carry water in two pails on a stick,\u201d recalls Moses. \u201cIt was very hard after school.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Moses has nine grandchildren and already three of the older boys, Seth, Samuel and James, arrive at the farm on Fridays to help. Will the family tradition continue? \u201dWe will have to see,\u201d says Malcolm, his eyes twinkling.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Elgin Valley&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=\"float-left\" src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Cut%20Above%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"216\" height=\"270\"&gt;If you\u2019ve ever wondered where your bouquet of chrysanthemums \u2013 long-lasting queens of the vase \u2013 comes from, the chances are, if you live in the Cape, it\u2019s Oak Valley Estate in Elgin, the biggest flower grower in the province.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The flower farm in a valley beneath the Groenlandberg mountains is surrounded by Oak Valley\u2019s apple and pear orchards, vineyards for cool-climate wines and pastures where grass-fed cattle and acorn-fed pigs are raised. Flowers are either grown in shade houses or in climate-controlled greenhouses on five hectares, using methods developed by the Dutch \u2013 long-established masters of the flower trade.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The flower farm was founded in 1978 by a Dutch horticulturist named Arend Doorduin, who worked closely with the current fourth-generation owner Anthony Rawbone-Viljoen. After a flirtation with tomato growing on the estate, Arend started with chrysanthemums for the cut-flower trade and launched what was to become the largest flower-production unit in the Western Cape. Today, the flower division employs 160 workers that produce more than 40 varieties of chrysanthemums alone, plus alstroemeria, lisianthus , three different types of lilies (Asiatic, Oriental and St Joseph\u2019s), gladiolus in summer, iris and freesia in winter and seasonal flowers like Queen Anne\u2019s lace, tulips, sweet William and snapdragon.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Growing large volumes of flowers to order requires expertise: harnessing technology combined with knowledge, not only of the requirements of each flower type but the lifecycle of pests like western flower thrips, where the female is capable of laying 150 eggs every day for 15 days. Those chrysanthemums, for example, are grown in a computer-controlled environment that manipulates the amount of light and heat to replicate autumn conditions, so that the plants are persuaded to flower year round.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cFor instance, if we want chrysanthemums to flower on 19 December for the Christmas period, we have to plant them in spring,\u201d explains production manager Carel Malherbe. \u201cAnd as soon as we harvest them we have to replant in order to get four cycles&nbsp;a year.\u201d Each section of plants has a chart, a bit like a hospital patient does, detailing progress. Timing is everything when it comes to picking the blooms too. \u201cThere is a half-day window of opportunity, otherwise we are in trouble,\u201d says Carel. The farm sells around 800 000 bunches of chrysanthemums a year, each bunch sold by weight, with five to eight stems per bunch. Peak times in the flower trade are the festive season and Valentine\u2019s and Mother\u2019s days.&nbsp;\u201cI just don\u2019t have Christmas and I can never take holidays until after Mother\u2019s Day in May,\u201d says Carel with a laugh.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In Holland, many cut flowers are now farmed using robots, (forget those jolly images of ladies in national costume gathering tulips). But at Oak Valley there are specialised teams for planting, cultivation, picking and packaging, while good old-fashioned methods like composting and a fertiliser made from vermicasts are used. And The Man Above still ultimately takes a hand in decisions like which nights will be cold and which days warm, and what affects things like the colour of blooms. Computers don\u2019t always have the last word. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Knysna&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Flowers are literally a way of life for Hannes Stander and his partner DP (Daniel) Ferreira. They are the foundation on which their business Ecozest is built. The flower garden that supplies their business surrounds Woodcutters Forest Cottages \u2013 their home and their guest cottages on the edge of the forest above Knysna, on the Garden Route. And Hannes and DP spend time in the workshop creating bouquets with flowers and natural material from their surroundings.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the heart of their four-acre smallholding near Jubilee Creek is a cutting garden where they harvest flowers both for arrangements and for the flower workshops they hold at their home, an original woodcutter\u2019s cottage dating back to 1827. The garden, filled with dozens of species of flowering plants and shrubs, from strelitzias to pelargoniums, roses to viburnum, is gradually being expanded. And the indigenous forest and vlei that border the garden provide decorative material and a playground for Hannes and DP\u2019s five dogs, two Dutch decoy spaniels, a peke and two lurchers.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hannes and DP\u2019s former florist shop on Thesen Island, Kynsna has evolved into Ecozest, a home-based business where their imaginative creations range from pyramids of proteas plus a display of different protea species for a wedding, to branches hung with plants and lights for a golf tournament.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s a way of life that keeps them in touch with nature and brings an appreciation of the changing seasons. \u201cIt\u2019s such a harmonious thing to do and so many people have lost that connection with nature,\u201d says DP. The self-catering guest cottages, with cosy fires for winter, are in the vernacular style, and anyone who joins the workshops can stay there, where a welcome bouquet of freshly picked flowers is guaranteed.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za\/subscribe-win-painted-wolf-wines\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Country Life&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt; &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/CL%20Cover_0.jpg?itok=5E7YRxuO\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Country Life&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9129\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/company-wolves\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;The Company of Wolves&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    The Company of Wolves  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"The Company of Wolves\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Wolves%201.jpg?itok=6oEQenwQ\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/company-wolves\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/company-wolves\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/company-wolves&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Wolves%201.jpg&amp;description=The Company of Wolves\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/company-wolves\" data-text=\"The Company of Wolves\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/company-wolves\" data-title=\"The Company of Wolves\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Matthew Holt, pics Matthew Holt and Fiona McIntosh&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In 1897, the Irish novelist Bram Stoker wrote about \u2018one of the wildest and least known portions of Europe\u2019, for which no maps existed, where every meal contained paprika, the superstitious locals repeatedly crossed themselves and an elderly count inhabited a spooky castle, venturing out after sunset disguised as a wolf. Of course, nowadays you can purchase reliable maps of Transylvania from Stanfords in London. But as for the rest of it, who knows what\u2019s true?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Driving north from Bucharest, the drab factories and housing blocks gave way to grain fields and fruit orchards, and the Mercedes cars and trucks to bicycles and horse-drawn carts. After several hours we reached Transylvania, \u2018the land beyond the forest\u2019, famous for its bears, wolves, plum brandy and vampires. Fiona and I had come here to traverse the Fagaras Mountains, which run across Romania from east to west. We were accompanied by Razvan Radu, who divides his time between being a mountain guide and a major in the Romanian army.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolves%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We stopped to buy provisions in Brasov, admiring its medieval walls, cobbled streets, Gothic church and haunted town hall. Having lunched on trout soup and grilled trout, it was late afternoon when we finally started hiking from Sambata, first negotiating a picket line of gypsies selling berries and lucky charms. As we wound through the pine forest, past signs warning of bears, a strange grunt from behind made me jump with alarm, though it was only Razvan practising some curious form of pressure breathing he\u2019d picked up in Nepal.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It took a couple of hours to reach the Sambetei Hut, where we spent our first night. As we approached, a giant hound came bounding up, tongue out and slavering. \u2018Beware the dog, it will bite,\u2019 shouted Razvan, arming himself with sharp stones. Dodging the barrage of missiles, the hairy beast charged right up to us and then rolled playfully onto its back. While Razvan eyed it distrustfully, Fiona tickled its tummy.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolves%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Leaving the hut early the next morning, we hiked up to the ridge at 2200m. From here, we would follow the range for some 30km, taking in Romania\u2019s three highest peaks along the way. We were allowing five days for our journey which, while hardly a trailblazing pace, was still a reasonable challenge given the rollercoaster terrain and volatile weather, with thunderstorms most afternoons.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;That afternoon we reached Moldoveanu, the country\u2019s high point at 2544m. A thin ar\u00eate led to the summit, with steel cables providing some comfort over an exposed notch. With the clouds thickening around us, we didn\u2019t stay long on top. Descending towards the Podragu Hut, we paused to watch purple-black storm clouds churn along the ridge, like computer-generated special effects in a disaster movie. Then it dawned on us that the clouds would envelop us before we reached the hut. Exchanging gormless glances, we started running pell-mell down the steep trail, skidding on scree and tripping over boulders. Lightning illuminated the sky like phosphorus bombs, thunder boomed like heavy artillery and even Razvan, who was an ordnance expert for the military, jumped with shock when a lightning fork fizzed past. Though it only took 10 minutes to reach the hut, we were drenched to the bone.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolves%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Set in a valley at 2100m, the Podragu Hut had the cosy charm of a medieval castle. But it served pork stew and beer, and was far more comfortable than camping outside. In order to lighten our packs, we hadn\u2019t bothered with a tent, but instead were relying on the huts and refuges that irregularly dotted our route. There was a marked difference between them. The refuges had the advantage of being up on the ridge, but were typically just dank, tin A-frame shelters. Conversely, the huts had guardians, mattresses and cooked meals, but were located down in the valleys, requiring us to descend off the ridge to reach them and then hike back up the following morning, invariably burdened with hangovers.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trail was well marked and even when we couldn\u2019t spot the red and white painted signs, plaques and crosses invariably signalled the way, with virtually every notch and gully hosting a memorial to some hapless climber. To be fair, there were some awkward sections, with the high level option sticking doggedly to the ridge, with metal cables and staples for protection in places.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolves%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The most challenging stretch was between Negoui and Serbota, which we came to on our fifth day. We\u2019d spent the preceding night in the Caltun Refuge, crammed in like sardines, with seven of us sleeping there, plus seven campers sheltering from the storm. Leaving the refuge at dawn, we scrambled up chain ladders to the summit of Negoiu, the country\u2019s second highest peak at 2535m. From here, an airy traverse led across to Serbota Peak, a couple of kilometres away. As we clambered along metal staples, we tried to ignore pitiful howling coming from the cliffs above. An hour later we came upon a sheepdog that had somehow fallen off the cliff into a cleft, where it was now firmly stuck.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolves%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As we made to climb past, the dog looked at us with such doleful eyes that Razvan was moved to suggest we put it out of its misery. Instead, Fiona volunteered me to climb down and rescue it, on the grounds I\u2019d recently been inoculated for rabies. The dog was uninjured but in a complete state of shock, able only to wag its tail and slobber, so we had to carry it along the ridge, passing it between us on the trickier sections. It was only when we reached flat ground that it recovered its confidence and legs, and went ungratefully bounding off. In fact, for all Transylvania\u2019s reputation for abundant bears and wolves, the only wildlife we encountered in the mountains was a herd of chamois, several flocks of sheep and some sheepdogs.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From Serbota, we followed the trail up and down and over a couple more peaks, till we reached the summit of Vistea Scara. Although the Fagaras Mountains continued west for another 15km, the main peaks were behind us now. More importantly, we\u2019d arranged to be picked up from the road head at Poina Neamtului, some 10km to the north.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolves%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Dropping off the ridge, we descended through alpine heather and bushes thick with blueberries, which we plucked till our hands were stained crimson as if we\u2019d killed someone. We spent our last night in the mountains at Barcaciu Hut, a charmingly rustic, ramshackle place, like Doctor Doolittle\u2019s, with a large dog that slept in the doorway and wouldn\u2019t budge, cockerels and hens that clucked underfoot, and a donkey that tried to steal our dinner off the table, contenting itself with Fiona\u2019s notebook instead.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next morning, we hiked down through the forest to the road. The taxi ride to Sambata, where we\u2019d left our car, took barely an hour, partly because we hadn\u2019t covered much ground as the crow flies, but largely because Romanians drive so recklessly fast.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolves%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We headed back south on the Transfagarasan Highway, climbing over the mountains on tight hairpin bends. On the way down, we stopped off to visit the ruins of Poenari Castle, perched precariously on a rock outcrop. Panting up 1400 steep stone steps, we were greeted by a pair of morose-looking dummies impaled on wooden stakes. The castle belonged to a 15th century warlord, Vlad Tepes III, whose precise achievements are obscured by time, but possibly had as many as 100,000 victims impaled to death, with 20,000 Turkish prisoners skewered on one day. Portraits show a thin-faced man with crimson lips, shoulder-length jet black hair and a moustache like a piece of sailing rope. Also known as \u2018Sir Impaler\u2019 and \u2018Vlad Dracula (Dragon)\u2019, he\u2019s generally credited as being the inspiration for Bram Stoker\u2019s bloodsucking count.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;That evening we stayed in Curtea de Arges, a historic rural town with haystacks, donkey carts and a medieval church. Celebrating our traverse with beer, wine and, rashly, plum brandy, we staggered back to our hotel under a full moon. But we felt safe now, for we were no longer within Transylvania.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wolves%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\/author\/melanievanzyl\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Melanie van Zyl&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;1. Go grill with a tire mounted braai&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Taking up little packing space this ingenious &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.frontrunner.co.za\/camping-gear\/camp-kitchen\/front-runner-spare-tire-mount-braai-bbq-grate.html\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Front Runner Spare Tyre Mount Braai Grid stores&lt;\/a&gt; (as the name suggests) over the spare tyre hanging off the back of your 4\u00d74. Made from stainless steel the grid is sturdy and features two different grill options plus versatile legs, which easily adjust to your tyre size (fits sizes 29 to 35-inches).&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Buy the tire mounted braai:&lt;\/strong&gt; R925, from &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.frontrunner.co.za\/camping-gear\/camp-kitchen\/front-runner-spare-tire-mount-braai-bbq-grate.html\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Front Runner&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;2. Pack this Collapsible Stew Pot&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;h2&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Camp%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"433\"&gt;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Compact and made from soft silicone this &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.smacs.co.za\/products\/collapsible-stew-pot-red\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Collapsible Stew Pot&lt;\/a&gt; packs down to a flat disk making a change from bulky potjie pots. The stainless steel base can be used on gas or sit on a grid over hot coals, but keep away from open flames to prevent it blackening. It will not dent or wear out and it\u2019s easy to carry and store.&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Buy the Collapsible Stew Pot:&lt;\/strong&gt; R390 including delivery, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.smacs.co.za\/products\/collapsible-stew-pot-red\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;from www.smacs.co.za.&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;3. Cool down with this 11-litre Snomaster Console Fridge&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Camp%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"369\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It looks small but the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/snomaster.co.za\/snomaster-products.php?categories_id=304e2853bd7858c824115118f5a6b7e2&amp;products_id=3a48a0d12614a0491907499057fb419c\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;11-litre Snomaster Console Fridge &lt;\/a&gt;packs a punch. It fits snugly on the floor between the front and back seat, and the lengthy cord easily plugs into the cigarette lighter. It\u2019s a great weekend companion to keep basic dairy or meat supplies fresh and fits two upright two-litre bottles. Use as either a fridge or freezer.&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Buy the 11-litre Snomaster Console Fridge:&lt;\/strong&gt; R5 000, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/snomaster.co.za\/snomaster-products.php?categories_id=304e2853bd7858c824115118f5a6b7e2&amp;products_id=3a48a0d12614a0491907499057fb419c\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;from Snomaster&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;4. Rinse off with a High-Volume Camp Shower&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Camp%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"355\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Powered by a 12-volt battery the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.outdoorwarehouse.co.za\/natural-instinct-high-volume-camp-shower.html\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Natural Instinct High-Volume Camp Shower&lt;\/a&gt; is for remote and dusty camping trips. Fill up a bucket or a jerry can and fit one end of the hose into the water and power up the showerhead. The pressure is impressive for its small size and there are three water flow settings to choose from. Unfortunately, it won\u2019t work with boiling water, but a lukewarm shower is still welcome when there are no ablutions nearby.&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Buy the the Natural Instinct High-Volume Camp Shower:&lt;\/strong&gt; R570, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.outdoorwarehouse.co.za\/natural-instinct-high-volume-camp-shower.html\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;from Outdoor Warehouse&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;5. Power up with the Lumeno Battery Buddy&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Camp%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"370\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Compact, nifty and easy to operate the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.outdoorwarehouse.co.za\/lumeno-battery-buddy-12-and-220v-charger.html\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Lumeno Battery Buddy&lt;\/a&gt; works beautifully with all kinds of camping gear and devices that need 12-volt battery power like the shower and fridge featured above. It fits over a small 7ah or 9ah battery (which cost about R350) and can be charged up at home using electricity or via the cigarette lighter in your car. The extension cable reaches five meters and my only gripe is there\u2019s no indicator to tell you it\u2019s charging.&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Buy the Lumeno Battery Buddy:&lt;\/strong&gt; R270, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.outdoorwarehouse.co.za\/lumeno-battery-buddy-12-and-220v-charger.html\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;from Outdoor Warehouse&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;6. Scrub it with a Scrubba Washbag&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Camp%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"367\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Travel light with the &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/outdoorelements.co.za\/Scrubba.shtml\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Scrubba Washbag&lt;\/a&gt; \u2013 a portable, compact laundry bag with a flexible washboard built into it. Fill it with about three litres of water, add some soap, shampoo or washing liquid and put in the equivalent of around three large t-shirts then agitate for 40 seconds. When finished pour out the water, rinse and dry your clothes.&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Buy the Scrubba Washbag:&lt;\/strong&gt; R799, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/outdoorelements.co.za\/Scrubba.shtml\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;from Outdoor Elements&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;7. Sleep on an Inertia Klymit Xl&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Camp%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"385\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.capeunionmart.co.za\/klymit-intertia-x-frame-inflat\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Inertia Klymit Xl&lt;\/a&gt; is not your average mattress. It\u2019s a hi-tech sleeping mat that uses special mapping to support the heaviest points of your body when you lie down, but doesn\u2019t sacrificing insulation or comfort. A small air pump is included and it takes a while to inflate, but it\u2019s not difficult.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Camp%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"385\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;No bigger or heavier than a full sports water bottle (480-grams) it sounds too good to be true, but after sleeping on one for five days in the desert I confidently recommend this great piece of camping gear.&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Buy the Inertia Klymit Xl:&lt;\/strong&gt; R1 299, &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.capeunionmart.co.za\/klymit-intertia-x-frame-inflat\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;from Cape Union Mart&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;8. Stay charged with the RED-E Powerbank&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Camp%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"372\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Charge your phone or GoPro with the portable &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.actiongear.co.za\/the-red-e-powerbank-premium-edition\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;RED-E Powerbank&lt;\/a&gt;. Available in three battery capacities, the Premium Edition 6 000mAh pack is best. The LED indicator lets you know how much charge is left and comes with four adaptors for different devices in a sleek package no bigger than your iPhone.&lt;br&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Buy the RED-E Powerbank:&lt;\/strong&gt; R699, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.actiongear.co.za\/the-red-e-powerbank-premium-edition\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;from Action Gear&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\/gear-reviews\/8-convenient-camping-gear-updates\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Getaway Blog&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.getaway.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt; &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Getaway&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;Featured blog provided by Getaway Magazine&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9144\" class=\"publisher-4076 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/home-artisan\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Home of the Artisan&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Home of the Artisan  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Home of the Artisan\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span target='_blank' style='background-color: #f69220' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Travel%20Ideas%20s.jpg\" \/&gt;\n of the Artisan\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/home-artisan\" data-text=\"Home of the Artisan\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/home-artisan\" data-title=\"Home of the Artisan\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; Pics Franki Black&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A friend asked how my trip to Wellington was. I responded with one word: Fantastic! I left Cape Town in the morning and 45 minutes later I was in Wellington, a town that embodies artistic flair, Victorian and Cape Dutch architecture and country allure.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Talk about Wellington&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;My first stop is Twist Some More, a quirky farm eatery situated a few minutes from Wellington\u2019s centre. Chef and owner, Johan Van Schalkwyk, welcomes us like long-lost friends and dives right into telling us about his love for Wellington. He believes that Wellington sets itself apart from nearby tourist hotspots like Franschhoek and Stellenbosch by preserving old-world charm. \u201cIn Wellington, winemakers and estate owners still shake your hand and welcome you in person,\u201d he explains.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wellington%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Johan\u2019s greatest passion is his restaurant. Eight years ago, he stumbled upon a barnyard covered in cobwebs and since then, he\u2019s transformed it into a space filled with chalkboard menus, handcrafted wooden tables and aromas of delectable food drifting from the kitchen. \u201cTwist Some More is like an extension of me,\u201d he says. All his food is prepared from locally-sourced ingredients. According to Johan, his Wild Boar Burger is a local favourite and thanks must go to the Europeans of yesteryear. In the 1920\u2019s a number of wild boars were sent from Europe to Wellington. They were brought in to control agricultural pests, but over the decades they\u2019ve multiplied, mixed with farm pigs and become something of a pest themselves. Johan is reaping the benefits and occasionally sends hunting parties into the surrounding mountains to source these prized beasts for their meat.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I feast on a \u201ctwisted\u201d poached egg and salmon Florentine and the conversation turns to town design. We conclude that Franschhoek\u2019s popularity can be traced to its central main road lined with shops and cafes, while Wellington\u2019s charm lies in the very fact that its attractions are more spread out. This has kept tourist numbers relatively low and as a result, those in the know have the town\u2019s artistic sanctuaries, world-class restaurants, wineries and breath-taking scenery all to themselves. It is here where travellers can find a tranquil country experience, coupled with welcoming locals and children who walk to school barefoot.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wellington%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Wine Time&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;After breakfast, we head down the road to Lelienfontein, an 8th generation wine farm that was applauded by Helen Zille for being a model of how land redistribution should be implemented in South Africa. Marketing Manager, Neil Buchner welcomes us at a 250-year-old cellar. We taste a creamy1952 Chenin Blanc (the fourth oldest in South Africa) and a hearty Adama red blend, while Neil tells us about the resident Bosman family. The Bosmans prove to be an exemplary clan - they\u2019re involved in everything from growing vines across South Africa to running holistic development programmes to hand-grafting vines. And, according to Neil, Lelienfontein\u2019s vine-growing nursery is the biggest of its kind in Africa.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We follow Neil to the grafting workshop. Like a well-oiled machine, dozens of dedicated employees sort, cut and graft various parts of the vine. It\u2019s an impressive system fuelled by drive and dedication. I\u2019m intrigued to see that a number of the more experienced workers have adopted a head-bopping dance to accompany their labour. Worker morale is stimulated by Lelienfontein\u2019s extensive social upliftment programmes that include: a day-care centre ; a karate club; a music school; a women\u2019s club; an old-age home; a sports club; a library; bursaries and agricultural training \u2013 all aimed at farm workers and their families.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wellington%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;A Wellington Bazaar&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Perhaps above all, what stands out for me about Wellington is its artisanal character. During the 1800\u2019s, the Wellington and Paarl areas were world-renowned as a wagon-manufacturing centres, and acclaimed for robust, well-constructed vehicles. South Africa\u2019s first and only piano manufacturer (Dietmann Piano Company), &nbsp;was based in Wellington up until 1989 &nbsp;and besides a robust wine route (and brandy route), Wellington is home to the country\u2019s first indigenous grain whisky.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Next on our itinerary is one of Wellington\u2019s artisanal treasures, the Redemption Leather factory and shop. En route, my travel companions point to a \u201cW\u201d etched out of rock at the top of the Hawequas Mountains \u2013 it\u2019s said to stand for Wellington. We pull into a lovely farmstead surrounded by guava orchards and fynbos and on it lies Redemption Leathers. Owner and artisan, Arnold Slabber, has been crafting the finest quality handmade products from his factory since the 1970\u2019s. He learnt the tricks of leather-making at age 11 from Oom Japie, a 70-odd-year-old man who hailed from the Karoo. Having grown up on a wagon during the depression, Oom Japie made leather goods for a living and eventually became something of a leather master. He luckily lived to pass on his talents to Arnold who, in turn, is passing them onto his own son.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wellington%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Pockets of lavender lead the way to the leather shop that is situated in a beautiful Cape Dutch house decorated with coppers and kilims. I get lost in a world of leather. &nbsp;Rich colours cover the walls and the smell of top quality leather drift through the air. &nbsp;Sandals, wallets, bags, belts and leather fly-swats fill every corner of the room - it resembles a Granada bazaar. A local in the shop urges me to try on their legendary sandals. I step into a pair of red sandals and immediately put in an order - the perfect excuse to return.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The Hub of Creativity&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our next stop \u2013 the Breytenbach Centre - seems to be the heart of modern-day Wellington\u2019s diverse creative spirit. The centre is the former family home of acclaimed South African poet, Breyten Breytenbach, and today it serves as a hub for community-orientated training in visual arts, music and writing. We walk through a ceramics studio, a theatre, a poetry garden, a drama room, a book-and-coffee shop and a gallery filled with local and international art. The house exudes classic style - wooden floors lead to wrap-around porches and mosaic sculptures rise from lush gardens filled with surprise poems etched on glass stands. In the theatre, I glance at posters of musicians like David Kramer who have performed here in recent years and from the coffee shop drifts the smell of cinnamon. &nbsp;It\u2019s almost too good to leave, but our next stop promises wine that tastes like chocolate\u2026&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wellington%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Chocolate Wine&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Diemersfontein Wine and Country Estate is perhaps best known for its Pinotage on Tap Festival. Hosted in Johannesburg, Durban and Cape Town, it has been dubbed the best wine event in the world by the Drinks International Wine Tourism Awards. The Cape Town festival alone attracts 2500 people who flock to the estate for free-flowing pinotage, local meals and live music. Diemersfontein Event Manager, Rene Reece, welcomes us to the estate. We\u2019re all eager to get stuck into the famed chocolate-flavoured &nbsp;pinotage, but first Rene presents us with Carpe Diem Chenin Blanc and a full-flavoured Cabernet Sauvignon. We sip and nibble on traditional Cape chicken curry and hearty beef burgers sent out from Seasons, the estate\u2019s restaurant. \u201cOur Diemersfontein Pinotage has a cult following,\u201d says Rene as she fills our glasses with the chocolate-inspired liquid. Heavenly flavours of dark chocolate, mint and plum tantalize my senses.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wellington%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Ceramics Matters&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;We end our Wellington adventure at Ceramics Matters, a multi-award winning ceramics business owned and run by artists, Gerhard Swart and Anthony Harris. As former winners of the VISI Design Awards, this creative pair undertakes commissions from highflying clients based in places like New York and Hong Kong. They live in a house dating back 300 years and all of their delightful creations are born right here in the backyard. &nbsp;As we drive along their driveway, I see Gerhard flanked by a patterned Great Dane and Anthony standing with a parrot perched on his shoulder. Gerhard is the chattier of the two and leads the way through the studio. Ceramic skulls, limbs and hearts, vases, bowls and plates fill every corner of their sunlit workroom. From the studio, we walk to their home, through rooms filled with objects like ceramic chickens and stuffed owls. An elephant\u2019s skull rests on a wooden table and an avant-garde picture of the crucifix is displayed above a fireplace. &nbsp;It\u2019s the most unusual place I\u2019ve ever seen. Gerhard and Anthony renovated and restored the house to make it what it is today and like many an artist, Gerhard declares that their home is a work in progress, and once they\u2019ve completed it, they\u2019ll probably move on.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As we leave, I tell Gerhard it\u2019s a blessing that important buildings like his home land in the hands of people with insight and style. They\u2019ve turned it into something utterly gemlike. &nbsp;Style, innovation and rejuvenation seem to be a trend among the handful of passionate locals I met during my trip. Keep your eyes on exciting Wellington: it might just be turning into a town that will give Franschhoek a run for its money.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Wellington%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Itinerary Add-On&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Ouma Granny\u2019s House Museum: Take a journey through history in this old, Victorian cottage that was built in 1876. Situated in Fountain Street, the Ouma Granny House museum exhibits historic furniture, artifacts and fascinating articles from the area. Contact: 083 231 7027, &lt;a href=\"mailto:d.j.s@mweb.co.za\"&gt;d.j.s@mweb.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Wellington Wine Walks: Calling all hiking enthusiasts! Wellington\u2019s wine walks are the ideal way to walk through fynbos and the winelands. Sample wine along the way and enjoy delicious picnic lunches. Itineraries range from 3 to 4 days and accommodation is prearranged. Contact Judy at 083 313 8383, &lt;a href=\"mailto:judy@winescapetours.co.za\"&gt;judy@winescapetours.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; , &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@winewalk.co.za\"&gt;info@winewalk.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Fynbos Horse Trails: Experience the foothills of Wellington\u2019s Hawekwa Mountains on horseback. Trails range from short scenic outrides to three-day trails \u2013 accommodation ranges from self-catering to luxury. Contact: Diemersfontein Country House \u2013 &lt;a href=\"mailto:steytlers@mweb.co.za\"&gt;steytlers@mweb.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;, 082 335 8132&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Books, Berries and Fine Mountain Fare\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/books-berries-and-fine-mountain-fare\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/books-berries-and-fine-mountain-fare\" data-text=\"Books, Berries and Fine Mountain Fare\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/books-berries-and-fine-mountain-fare\" data-title=\"Books, Berries and Fine Mountain Fare\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Bridget Hilton-Barber&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Haenertsburg village is no longer the isolated backwater hamlet it was a few years ago. These days you can do neighbourhood food markets, second hand bookshops, coffee and art, berry and kiwi festivals and more.&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Bridget Hilton-Barber discovers some of the new delights in and around this village in Limpopo\u2019s Magoebaskloof mountains.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Caution pig crossing&lt;\/em&gt; says the sign outside the Pennefather outpost in Haenertsburg. The sign was put up to warn motorists of the presence of Matilda the pig, darling of Pennefather\u2019s owner, Linda Thom Changuion. She is a very well-read pig \u2013 with a penchant for historical non-fiction - and a symbol of the kind of weekend you can enjoy at the Pennefather, pigging out on books, food and beautiful mountain scenery.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Magoebaskloof%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The building of the Pennefather complex a few years ago - a collection of cottages, a bistro, a bookshop and a collectibles shop - started a shift in the soul of Haenertsburg, by giving locals and visitors a new place to meet, greet, gather and chatter.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Built in the gold-rush style of early Haenertsburg, with wood and corrugated iron, the Pennefather has a bistro out front and a lounge inside the bookshop, with a fireplace and a basket for Matilde and the dogs. The shop has a good solid second hand collection, an excellent Africana and local history section, with books by local authors. &nbsp;There\u2019s a small Anglo Boer War Museum and all sorts of interesting memorabilia in the d\u00e9cor \u2013 from coco-pans to old stoves, typewriters, biscuit tins and Toby jugs.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Magoebaskloof%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The whole of the main street in Haenertsburg village has gotten trendier of late. There are nice gift shops and coffee shops, a decent grocery store \u2013 even the old age home seems livelier. For the best coffee in town head for Minky\u2019s Art &amp; Coffee Shop, which is a sexy new spot that does a mean line in pastries and breakfasts and also sells art supplies. Further down, the Iron Crown Pub, named after the highest peak in the district, has also changed from a rather dreary Alpine style bar to a contemporary restaurant serving local trout, Mozambican prawns and other fine fare. &nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The best foodie addition to Haenertsburg however, is Mina\u2019s Neighbourhood Food Market which happens at a farm called Zwakala, about 20 minutes out of the village. To the brassy sounds of a jazz band, Mina\u2019s gets rocking on regular Sundays and showcases local fare like trout, blueberries, kiwis, organic cheeses, sweet chillies, avocadoes, pomegranates, as well as pastas, tapas, curries, sushi and gourmet burgers.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Magoebaskloof%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Mina\u2019s is an old farmhouse with massive wooden tables and benches, funky d\u00e9cor and a wraparound stoep looking onto greenery. There is seating outside under the oak and lovely rustic Medieval-style wooden tables - or inside alongside the fire on chilly days \u2013 and Mina\u2019s attracts hundreds of people from the area. Families, hippies, yuppies, oldies, the whole country mix who gather together to eat soul food, dance to the music, hang out and gaze at the beautiful mountain views.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Further up the road is the Wegraakbosch Organic Farm, a Swiss-inspired organic farm dairy offering daily cheese tours, tastings and lunches. They are completely organic using no machinery, fertilisers or herbicides in their process from cow to curd to cheese. You can take a tour, wander about the farm saying hello to the happy chickens, ducks and pigs \u2013 and a cat that really did get the cream - and finish it off with a bottle of wine and a Ploughman\u2019s Platter of assorted Wegraakbosch cheeses and cold meat overlooking gorgeous blue green mountains. Blessed are the cheesemakers.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Magoebaskloof%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Blessed are the berry makers. Given any excuse, the people of Magoebaskloof will celebrate, and the Berry Festival has become an annual village highlight. The raspberry and blueberry farms in the area open their orchards for berry picking, berry tours, berry tasting and just about berry anything. The whole of the village does a harvest table and there are great bales of hay put out for seating under the oak trees. Try the signature local cocktail called Dark &amp; Stormy, made from mountain berries; and also some of the locally brewed ales and drafts.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You can visit farms \u2013 like the lovely Kuhestan an organic raspberry and avocado farm set high up in the mountains, with amazing gardens and fabulous views. Kuhestan does a range of delicious Persian cordials, preserves and pickles \u2013 produced on the farm, and they also sell kilims.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Magoebaskloof%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;And in autumn, there\u2019s the Kiwi Festival, another great foodie weekend, where visiting chefs cook up a storm using anything to do with kiwi fruit and fine wine and everyone eats, drinks and gets on down and merry.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;For more information about &lt;strong&gt;Haenertsburg&lt;\/strong&gt; and the &lt;strong&gt;Magoebaskloof&lt;\/strong&gt; area check out &lt;a 8433&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Wegraakbosch Farm&lt;\/strong&gt; \u2013 &nbsp;&lt;a href=\"mailto:cheese@haenertsburg.co.za\"&gt;cheese@haenertsburg.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; ; call 015 276 1811; or 082 853 8754;&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Pennefather and Memory Hold the Door bookshop&lt;\/strong&gt; &lt;a href=\"mailto:pennefather@telkomsa.net\"&gt;pennefather@telkomsa.net&lt;\/a&gt; ; Call 015-276 4885 or 079 525 7849;&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;For info about the &lt;strong&gt;Berry Festival&lt;\/strong&gt; \u2013 &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.berrryfestival.co.za\"&gt;www.berrryfestival.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Kuhestan Organic Farm&lt;\/strong&gt; \u2013 &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.kuhestan.co.za;\"&gt;www.kuhestan.co.za;&lt;\/a&gt; Call 082 &nbsp;903 7593&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Magoebaskloof%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"723\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3666\"&gt;&lt;br&gt;Magoebaskloof Adventures Kloofing&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3667\"&gt;Magoebaskloof Adventures Quad Biking&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a
