Changuion Trail&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9232\" class=\"publisher-4090 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/fishing-alone-0\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Fishing Alone&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Fishing Alone  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Fishing Alone\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.vagabondfly.com\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #000000' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Vagabond.jpg\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Alone%201.jpg?itok=zitfavXU\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fishing-alone-0\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fishing-alone-0\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fishing-alone-0&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Alone%201.jpg&amp;description=Fishing Alone\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fishing-alone-0\" data-text=\"Fishing Alone\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/fishing-alone-0\" data-title=\"Fishing Alone\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By Andrew Fowler&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To fish alone, is to inoculate oneself against one\u2019s own ostentatiousness. Provided you don\u2019t boast about it afterwards, it is to score one for humility. To head out there alone with a fly rod in hand is to put ones vanity in the back of the cupboard and close the door.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;To head out there alone with a fly rod in hand is to put ones vanity in the back of the cupboard and close the door.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;\/blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is also an opportunity. An opportunity to re-set the compass in your life, to think deeply on things, and to decide afresh who you will be in this world. You will not return with pictures of yourself with large Trout. None of your friends from the pub will share the story about the fish you lost. Neither will that day become the subject of banter, admiration, or friendly competition. You will have ventured forth to find fish for yourself, and the venture will have done nothing to promote you, or make known your prowess. You will be alone under the sky of that day, and the memories of it will not be saved in the vault of human knowledge. If we assume that you returned all fish you caught, and may I suggest that you do so, the day will be without evidence. If you took photos, they will be timeless landscapes, not linked to you.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A day with fishing friends is a rich and priceless thing. So is a day alone, but it is less inclined to advertise itself. It is the unmarked envelope in the Church collection. It is the artwork without a signature. It is also the invisible beacon of a person. A pointless thing of immeasurable value. It is in hours alone in the countryside that you are made.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Alone%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Un-surrounded, and unmatched, a fly-fisherman must sustain his determination to hike further, and stalk more fish, even though no one will ever know.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;\/blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Un-surrounded, and unmatched, a fly-fisherman must sustain his determination to hike further, and stalk more fish, even though no one will ever know. He will reach into his inner self to determine if he will lie in the grass beside the pickup and watch clouds before driving home or if he will hike up the valley and stalk a small Trout with a tiny dry fly in the face of an approaching rainstorm.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You are alone on a mountain stream. The weather looks doubtful. You have caught some fish already. The section ahead looks tricky to wade. No fish are rising. There is hot coffee to drink back at the pickup, or cold water swirling about your legs. If, around the next corner you lose a lunker, have a close call with a puff adder, or see a rare bird, it will be something to bank in your memory. It will not make you a hero. Think back on the days when you ventured on; and think back on the ones when you retreated.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Will you explore an unknown stream, which may be devoid of fish, or will you seek the cover of a glossy magazine.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;\/blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;In these days of freeways, airports, power lines and telephones, the world will value the photo of you with a big fish. Will you choose the time alone up that valley with your fly rod? Will you explore an unknown stream, which may be devoid of fish, or will you seek the cover of a glossy magazine.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Who AM I?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This calls for a day on the stream. &nbsp;Alone.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Alone%20end.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"722\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.vagabondfly.com\/fishing-alone-by-andrew-fowler\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Vagabond Fly Mag&nbsp;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.vagabondfly.com\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Vagabond%20cover.jpg?itok=sQPODvfS\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Vagabond Fly Mag&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9127\" class=\"publisher-2809 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/bay-plenty-0\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Bay of Plenty&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Bay of Plenty  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Bay of Plenty\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.hsm.co.za\/magazines\/details\/cape-etc' target='_blank' style='background-color: #ffffff' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/capeetclogo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/L%20Grootbos.jpg?itok=FIwsuPxN\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bay-plenty-0\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bay-plenty-0\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bay-plenty-0&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/L%20Grootbos.jpg&amp;description=Bay of Plenty\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bay-plenty-0\" data-text=\"Bay of Plenty\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/bay-plenty-0\" data-title=\"Bay of Plenty\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Feb 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Jade Cooke&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Whales just off shore, endemic fynbos as far as the eye can see and a pick-and-mix itinerary of adventure activities make a visit to Grootbos Private Nature Reserve in Walker Bay, frankly, mandatory.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He (or she \u2013 it\u2019s not exactly easy to tell) surfaces not five metres from the boat, water streaming down the smooth skin of his (or, again, her) exposed back. Even the mild seasickness I\u2019m inexplicably experiencing for the first time in my life can\u2019t mar this astonishing moment: an adult southern right whale just popping over to say hi on a Saturday morning.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019m clutching the metal railing of &lt;em&gt;Whale Whisperer&lt;\/em&gt;\u2019s upper viewing deck, the rolling swell of Walker Bay making this higher vantage point an exercise in holding on and staying upright. We launched from Gansbaai harbour not 20 minutes ago and already we\u2019re face to ... well ... back, with one of nature\u2019s most wonderful creatures \u2013 all 11 or so metres of him making tight circles around our boat as if to magnanimously give everyone the best possible view.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Grootbos%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"385\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;One of the top 10 land-based whale-watching sites in the world, the sheltered cove of Walker Bay is something of a nursery and speed-dating hub for the southern rights who return here annually between June and December to calve and to mate. Us fragile humans may need a wetsuit to dive its waters, but compared to their icy Antarctic feeding grounds, this is a tropical paradise for the whales, with perfect conditions for rearing their young before heading back to the freezer.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you\u2019re going to set up base camp in Walker Bay for a spell of whale watching, there is no better place to do so than Grootbos Private Nature Reserve. Touted as a \u2018five-star eco paradise\u2019, this is one location that lives up to its marketing, and its name \u2013 \u2018groot bos\u2019 translates to \u2018big forest\u2019 in Afrikaans.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Forest Lodge (our decadent home for the weekend and one of three accommodation options on the reserve) is situated in an ancient milkwood forest, the gnarled, mossy trunks and yearning, intertwined branches of these trees lending a kind of magic to the shaded walk between the main building and our freestanding suite. And then there you are, standing on your private balcony with a forest at your back, a sea of fynbos in front of you and Walker Bay gilded by the setting sun in the distance. Paradise indeed.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Grootbos%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you can tear yourself away from that view, Grootbos has a large selection of activities that can be tailor-made into your perfect itinerary, whether you\u2019re enjoying a family vacation, honeymoon or adventure-focused getaway. Many form part of the all-inclusive package, a select few (such as boat-based whale-watching and scenic flights over Walker Bay) are at an additional cost, but all can be arranged at a moment\u2019s notice via the front desk.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Or after a spontaneous decision at dinner the night before, which is how we\u2019ve ended up on &lt;em&gt;Whale Whisperer&lt;\/em&gt; this morning. It\u2019s more than worth the 6 am wake-up call. The expedition (exclusive to Grootbos guests at this time) is led by a marine biologist and whale-crazy team of guides, including a spotter who explains to us what he calls the \u2018footprint\u2019; a smoothening of the water that helps him pick out a whale close to the surface from a distance. The boat keeps a minimum distance of 50m from these leviathans at all times, but their naturally curious nature means they\u2019ll often swim up to it to investigate. And it doesn\u2019t get any better than that \u2013 unless you spot dolphins and great whites on the same trip of course, a trifecta some guests have been lucky enough to experience.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Grootbos%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Funnily enough considering all there is to do on the reserve, our next excursion also takes us out of its beautiful limits on a social responsibility tour to Masakhane. A neighbouring Gansbaai township, Masakhane was first built in the 1960s for men working in the fishing industry.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While marine creatures, relaxation and attentive service are all part of the Grootbos experience, its core focus is on conservation and social development. This it achieves through the non-profit Grootbos Foundation, which was established in 2003 to protect the biodiversity of the area and develop sustainable nature-based livelihoods for its people.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Seventy percent of the reserve\u2019s staff complement of around 120 is from Masakhane, including our guide, Bongani Mjokweni. He paints a vivid picture of the area\u2019s past and present, pointing out local landmarks and some personal ones as well, like the sand bowl of a soccer field where he first played the beautiful game as a child. It\u2019s in stark contrast with the green, floodlit fields Masakhane\u2019s kids now have access to, thanks to a R15 million fund injection raised by Grootbos owner Michael Lutzeyer in collaboration with Fifa and Barclays.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Grootbos%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Next, Bongani takes us back on to the reserve to Green Futures, a horticultural school. Its aim is to help Masakhane\u2019s youth find employment, which 90% of its graduates do. In addition to horticulture, students are taught computer skills, given lunch and breakfast daily and paid a stipend, and each year the three top students are given the opportunity to visit the Eden Project in Cornwall to further their studies.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After a tour that includes a somewhat surprise meeting with the resident baby boomslang, we purchase a gorgeous pincushion protea from the nursery attached to the school, happy in the knowledge that all proceeds are funnelled back into Grootbos Foundation projects.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next time we see a pincushion, it\u2019s from the back of an open Land Rover, the sort usually reserved for viewing the big five. This time we\u2019re focusing our attention at grass-roots level \u2013 literally. Our flower safari guide, Jo de Villiers, is laying some serious knowledge on us about the 2 600ha paradise, the most alien-free reserve in the country. She stops the Landie every now and again to school us on the interesting flora, from the list of indicator species that classify something as a fynbos area (proteas, Ericas, restios and various bulbs, in case you were wondering) to the astounding endemism of the Cape Floral Kingdom (for example, of all the species of &lt;em&gt;Erica irregularis&lt;\/em&gt; worldwide, 98% are endemic to Grootbos). She\u2019s threatened a test before we drive back to the lodge, too.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Grootbos%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A short while later, the seven of us from the Landie are balancing on a rocky outcrop at Klipgat Cave, pretending to be a baobab in silhouette while Jo snaps away. We\u2019ve gone from seeing the bush to this historical sea cave inhabited by bushmen 2 000 years ago. It\u2019s the site of the earliest pottery unearthed in South Africa to date, and a goldmine of archeological discovery. But Jo\u2019s informative talk of shell middens and the Ice Age nonetheless plays second fiddle to the beauty of this massive rocky shelter, the crashing waves just a stone\u2019s throw away and, beyond that, presumably more whales.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our presumptions are right, because half an hour later, as we\u2019re sipping sparkling wine on the deck of Whale House, a Grootbos-owned property on the cliffs of De Kelders, the bay below us is full of flukes and flippers, waving lazily at the sky. Every now and again, there\u2019s a burst of deep, throbbing whale song, and it occurs to me that the southern rights may be on to something...&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If I had the opportunity to return to this paradise year on year, I\u2019d be singing too.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Grootbos%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;HOW TO GET THERE&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Grootbos is a scenic two-hour drive from Cape Town. Take the N2 over Sir Lowry\u2019s Pass, heading through Hermanus and Stanford. Note, the turn-off to Grootbos is marked four kilometres prior, with no signage at the turn. Take the coastal road through Gordon\u2019s Bay on your way home for a change of scenery.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;RESERVATIONS 028 384 8008, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.grootbos.com\"&gt;www.grootbos.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;CHOOSE YOUR ACCOMMODATION&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022 Garden Lodge\u2019s stone and thatch freestanding suites are warm and welcoming, with a modern African aesthetic. Perfect for families, the lodge has a children\u2019s entertainment room and outdoor play area with rabbits to pet, and is in close proximity to the well-kept stables so little ones can visit the ponies.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;\u2022 The high ceilings and large windows of Forest Lodge offer unrivalled views of Walker Bay and the surrounding fynbos, with cosy fireplaces and an infinity pool in which to cool off come summer. Suites are embedded in the ancient milkwood forest, and you can\u2019t beat the private pool on the deck of the honeymoon cabin.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;\u2022 Grootbos\u2019s private villa sleeps up to 12 adults, with a private guide, chef and butler allocated to you during your stay. It\u2019s 1 000m2 of ultimate luxury complete with a wine cellar, gym, pool and media room.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Grootbos%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;LINGER LONGER&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;When you\u2019ve ticked boat-based whale watching off your list, sign up for one of these adventurous activities, all offered by Grootbos&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. GO SHARK-CAGE DIVING&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;There are few thrills as intense as coming face to face with a great white shark in its natural habitat. Grootbos, in partnership with Marine Dynamics, will take you on a luxury boat tour of Shark Alley, the hunting ground of these fearsome marine predators. View them from the observation deck or get into the cage for a close encounter. All equipment (plus lunch!) is provided and a marine biologist accompanies the trips.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. RIDE THE RESERVE&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;A horse-riding trail through the fynbos is a wonderful way to get back in touch with nature, and the views over Walker Bay are hard to beat. The Grootbos stable caters to everyone from absolute beginners and children, to experienced riders who prefer a canter up the mountainside. A three-hour beach ride in the Walker Bay Nature Reserve is offered to proficient riders \u2013 a blissful opportunity to spot whales in the bay.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. TAKE TO THE SKIES&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;For a bird\u2019s-eye view of this beautiful area, book one of the scenic flights that leave from the reserve\u2019s private airstrip. Options include a flip over Grootbos and Walker Bay, a whale-watching flight, trips around Cape Point, Table Mountain and the Winelands, or a visit to Cape Agulhas, the southernmost tip of Africa.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. HOP ON A QUAD&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;Go full throttle with a quad-biking adventure through forest, valleys and mountains. This fun, two-hour ride through designated trails in the fynbos includes lookout points over the bay and Dyer Island, famous for its seals and circling great whites. No previous quad-biking experience necessary.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. RAISE A GLASS&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;If you need to steady your nerves after all that adventuring, a turn at a few Overberg tasting rooms should do the trick. The Standford, Elim and Hermanus wine routes are all within an easy drive of the reserve and can be explored on a Grootbos guided wine tour, so you can sample many of the bottles from your wine list the night before.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/apphau5.com\/e-editions\/e-reader\/954\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Cape Etc&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.hsm.co.za\/magazines\/details\/cape-etc\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/CET3_Oct_2014_web_317_379_0.jpg?itok=WezKV1bG\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Cape Etc&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9126\" class=\"publisher-2376 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/softroader-getaway-adventure-crater\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Softroader Getaway Adventure in a Crater&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Softroader Getaway Adventure in a Crater  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Softroader Getaway Adventure in a Crater\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/wheels-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/L%20Peogeot.jpg?itok=BO5E_2wG\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/softroader-getaway-adventure-crater\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/softroader-getaway-adventure-crater\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/softroader-getaway-adventure-crater&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/L%20Peogeot.jpg&amp;description=Softroader Getaway Adventure in a Crater\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/softroader-getaway-adventure-crater\" data-text=\"Softroader Getaway Adventure in a Crater\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/softroader-getaway-adventure-crater\" data-title=\"Softroader Getaway Adventure in a Crater\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Gerhard Horn, pics GG van Rooyen&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The Peugeot 3008 doesn\u2019t look like your average SUV or crossover, but that doesn\u2019t mean it can\u2019t handle a drive through one of the world\u2019s largest asteroid craters.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Take a long hard look at the Peugeot 3008. It\u2019s not really an SUV or crossover, is it?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s much closer to an MPV\/station wagon than a sports utility vehicle, but who are we to argue with the French manufacturer? If it says its car is a crossover, we believe them.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It all comes down to where you want to cross over to. If you want to cross over a river, you\u2019d be better off in something with low-range and locking differentials. Some people simply don\u2019t want to cross over that far, so why bother with unwanted mechanicals that just push up the price?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;That\u2019s basically the thought process behind the 3008. It has the looks and high driving position associated with SUVs, but that\u2019s about it. Does that make it a bad car? Not in the least, in our opinion.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When you buy a vehicle like this, you are basically making a statement. A car like the 3008 lets your neighbours know that you\u2019re adventurous and that you like spending time outdoors. You don\u2019t want to venture too far into the wild, but just far enough to remove yourself from the hustle and bustle of city life.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Some of you might frown at this concept, but it\u2019s a market that is set to grow in the coming years. From 2015 and onwards, we\u2019ll be seeing a lot more of these compact crossovers with limited off-road ability, and it\u2019s not just the automotive world that\u2019s getting in on this new fad.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Adventure farms are sprouting up all over SA. These places aren\u2019t hard to reach and they offer a host of activities that were previously available only to a brave few who dared to venture far off the beaten path. The Peugeot 3008 was thus the perfect vehicle to take to one of these farms, if only to see how much adventure one can have with a French front-wheel drive crossover.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Peogeot%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;In the dome&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are a few adventure farms in Gauteng, but we wanted to get some proper time behind the wheel of the 3008. We settled on Parys in the Free State and pointed the new nose of the recently face-lifted French vehicle towards the N1.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A few kilometres before the Grasmere Plaza, the road splits in two. You can take either the N1 and arrive in Parys within the hour, or the more scenic N12. As we are adventurous types, we chose the N12. This turned out to be a big mistake as the road is currently undergoing massive reconstruction. At one point we were down to 10km\/h.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In desperation, we made another detour, opting to drive to Parys via Carletonville and Potchefstroom. At the end of the day, this supposed 45-minute drive took us about three hours, but at least we were exposed to the best qualities of the 3008.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This is definitely a car that\u2019s suited to long distances on tar. The unplanned changes to our route would normally have caused considerable irritation, but we were untroubled. The car did a fine job of keeping us cool and comfortable, even though the thermometer was climbing steadily towards 40\u00baC.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We were also surprised at how easy it was to get to grips with the infotainment system. The Bluetooth connection was set up within minutes and we had a huge playlist of Empire podcasts at our disposal. We were only too happy to enjoy the scenery while listening to film critics discussing the difficulties of making a movie based on an obscure novel.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The time slipped by and we soon found ourselves on a gravel road heading towards our final &nbsp;destination, Thabela Thabeng. This is an adventure farm nestled in the Vredefort Dome \u2013 our main reason for visiting the region. We had recently read a book on the subject, and decided to check out the impact site of the asteroid for ourselves.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Imagine our disappointment when we were told that we had been driving around in the crater for the last hour or so! The impact zone is so large that it can\u2019t be identified at ground level. To get a full appreciation of the crater, you must view it from the air.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At least the asteroid had a massive impact on the landscape, so we could at least enjoy the diverse plant, animal and rock formations that formed as a result of a 10km-wide rock colliding with planet Earth.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Before we get to the modern-day adventure activities, some history on the Vredefort Dome. The asteroid is thought to have been one of the largest to hit the planet. The resulting crater would originally have been about 300km wide, but since it has eroded away over time, there\u2019s no way of knowing how large it actually was.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The dome, as it exists today, is a half-ring of hills created by the force of the impact. The visible part is more or less 70km in diameter, but the effects of the impact can be seen much farther away. It is believed that the impact played a part in elevating the gold found in region closer to the surface. The asteroid may have destroyed everything in its path when it smashed into the earth around 2023 million years ago, but at least it provided easier access for man to that most precious of metals.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Peogeot%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Not on target&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thabela Thabeng manager Albie de Villiers was kind enough to take a full day out of his busy schedule to show us around, and organise a few activities, including archery. This was something different for us, but how difficult could it be to hit a target a mere 20m away? As it turned out \u2013 very difficult!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Albie gave us a quick lesson, which resulted in us shooting more or less near the target, but the experience left us thankful that we live in a modern world where meat is readily available on supermarket shelves. If we had lived hundreds of years ago, our families definitely would have been vegetarians, and not by choice. We feel duty bound to advise the burly men out there not to attempt archery as a means of impressing your partner. Albie said the fairer sex had a natural aptitude for archery, and many men left the range with an undamaged target and a severely dented ego.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thabela Thabeng is a perfect location for rock climbing and abseiling. There are various tours on offer, but since we were rock-climbing novices, we decided instead to scale a man-made object Albie and his crew have erected on the grounds. It\u2019s a mere 10m high, but objects seem much taller once you\u2019re on them. From up there, the ground felt more like 100m away.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At least you\u2019re in control of your own ascent up the structure\u2026 Abseiling down is another matter altogether. You stand on the edge while another person slowly lowers you into the traditional abseiling position. Leaving your fate in the hands of someone you don\u2019t know is not easy, but once you get the hang of abseiling, it's fun. We took some comfort from the knowledge that Albie and his crew are fully qualified and take every precaution to safeguard those who want to climb to the top of their tower.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After that scary experience, Albie took us on a leisurely drive on the property, which includes self-catering accommodation and a beautiful section of land where pecan nuts are farmed.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Peogeot%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Farther than expected&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There was just one slight hitch. We visited Thabela Thabeng\u2019s website a few days earlier in preparation for the trip and on the home page it mentioned that the gravel road on the property was best suited to vehicles with a reasonably high ground clearance. The Peugeot\u2019s ground clearance of 160mm is hardly impressive, but we weren\u2019t willing to accept defeat that easily. Driving on those roads was a nerve-racking experience, but only because of the seating position. We crept down the narrow road in anticipation of the low nose grinding onto something, but that awful noise never came. It turned out the 3008 was far better at soft-roading than we'd expected.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;During our venture into the Dome wilderness, we met up with Albie\u2019s children and their horses. Our red 3008 grabbed the attention of the horses and they followed us for a short distance. It would have been only too easy to outrun them, having 170 horsepower (120kW) from our 2,0-litre turbocharged diesel engine, but it seemed slightly unfair to the teenagers, who had only one bhp each. So we parked the car and enjoyed the scenery. The horses were friendly and curious, and it took some effort to keep one of them from nibbling on the side mirror.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Albie chose this moment to share one of his favourite quotes: \u201cThere is something about the outside of a horse that is good for the inside of a man.\u201d We\u2019re fairly certain that most horse owners will know who said that, but for those who don't it was Winston Churchill.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We ended the day with a leisurely row on the Vaal River. There are a few places that can offer visitors an action packed adventure in the rapids, but our abseiling had stirred more than enough adrenaline for one day.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Once again we'd driven the 3008 into the kind of place it was never intended to go. To get that perfect photograph, it was necessary to park the car on a slippery slope next to the river. It was easy enough to get the car into the spot, but we had some nagging doubts about getting it out. If we couldn't spin it out of there, we could call on Albie\u2019s 4x4 double-cab to tow us out. We decided not to worry about it for a while and drifted serenely on the river.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The shot worked perfectly, and soon we could no longer ignore the fact that we had to negotiate a front-wheel drive car over a wet and slippery incline. The worst-case scenario was too awful to contemplate \u2013 the 3008 at the bottom of the Vaal River! Since insurance forms don\u2019t allow much space to explain an accident of this nature, we were hoping it wouldn't happen.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;So we drove the 3008 out of there at the very first try. It struggled to find grip for a few seconds, but then flew out with no problem whatsoever. Who said we were worried?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Peogeot%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Summary&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Peugeot 3008 turned out to be a surprising companion. We have driven it before and it left us impressed with its levels of comfort, space and sophistication. It has a lovely diesel engine, which averaged around 7,0 l\/km on this trip, and it is lavishly equipped with standard features that tend to be optional extras in its competitors. The recent facelift has also done its part in turning the 3008 into a rather handsome vehicle.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We\u2019re not suggesting you attempt crossing the Kalahari in the 3008, but it\u2019s nice to know that it can cope on the odd occasion when you want to venture a little way off road.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Like the adventure farms, the 3008 offers entry into an adventurous lifestyle without you having to go the whole nine yards.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Want to do the same?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;How do I get there and when should I go?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The easiest way to get to Parys is via the N1. On the N1 the journey takes around 45 minutes to an hour from Johannesburg, but the N12 via Potchefstroom is more scenic. It takes two hours, but it\u2019s worth the trip. Potchefstroom is also worth a visit as there are some interesting places to see, including the historic Snowflake building and the North West University campus.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;An all-wheel drive vehicle is not necessary and a compact crossover should do just fine on the gravel roads surrounding Parys.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;During the winter it\u2019s extremely cold out there, with temperatures regularly dipping below zero. The best time to go is right now, during the summer months. The yellow hue of the hills has been replaced with a lush green, but take care not to spend too much time in the sun.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Where can I stay?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are a few places to stay between Parys and Potchefstroom. You can also choose to stay in either one of the towns, where accommodation ranges from basic to ultra luxurious.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thabela Thabeng has 12 three-star self-catering chalets built on the edge of a cliff. These units are popular, so it\u2019s best to book. (tel 056-818-1116 or e-mail to &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@thabelathabeng.co.za\"&gt;info@thabelathabeng.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What can I do while I\u2019m there?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are more than enough activities to keep the family busy over a weekend. At Thabela Thabeng you can hike or ride your mountain bike through the Dome. Those who prefer something more relaxing can go fishing in the Vaal River, or do some bird watching. There are more than 400 bird species in the Vredefort Dome, so it\u2019s a bird watcher\u2019s paradise.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are several adventure companies in the immediate vicinity that offer activities such as hot air ballooning, white river rafting and guided 4x4 trips through the Dome.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.mysubs.co.za\/magazine\/leisure-wheels\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Leisure Wheels&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/LW%20Jan_0.jpg?itok=QuEWZK-v\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Leisure wheels&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9135\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/tracking-turtles-place-miracles\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Tracking Turtles in the Place of Miracles&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Tracking Turtles in the Place of Miracles  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Tracking Turtles in the Place of Miracles\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Turtles%20M.jpg?itok=0RX4gj67\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tracking-turtles-place-miracles\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tracking-turtles-place-miracles\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tracking-turtles-place-miracles&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Turtles%20M.jpg&amp;description=Tracking Turtles in the Place of Miracles\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tracking-turtles-place-miracles\" data-text=\"Tracking Turtles in the Place of Miracles\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/tracking-turtles-place-miracles\" data-title=\"Tracking Turtles in the Place of Miracles\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Debbie Cooper, pics iSimangaliso Wetland Park Authority&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The silent beach is shrouded by a fine sea mist, the gloaming punctuated only by hundreds of ghost crabs scuttling out of the way of our vehicle\u2019s headlights. Moonlight glints on the curling waves and the gentle womb-like swish of the sea is a balm to the soul.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Turtles%201.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We are on the hunt for one of nature\u2019s greatest and increasingly rare spectacles \u2013 a turtle laying her eggs on the pristine shores north of Cape Vidal in iSimangaliso Wetland Park. The sign we seek is tracks leading from the water\u2019s edge to the base of the dunes. Two turtle species nest here - the loggerhead and the far larger and less common leatherback. The tracks of the latter are truly impressive \u2013 as wide as a tractor tyre, made by an animal weighing up to 800kg.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Turtles%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After endless miles, our guide, Jacques Breedt from Shoreline Turtle Tours (one of iSimangaliso\u2019s two St Lucia-based concessionaires) exclaims in excitement that he\u2019s spotted the telltale prints of a loggerhead. Immediately he turns off the lights and requests us to be silent and keep our distance while he checks on her. Time passes as we wait in anticipation \u2013 after an age, he returns to call us to gather around as she is finally in her trance-like stage where laying can begin.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Turtles%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With lights kept dim and avoiding flashlight in her eyes, we watch in awe this ancient ritual of life. The spectators are visibly moved, transfixed by the privilege of witnessing this most intimate act. Our turtle\u2019s eyes are weeping \u2013 is it sadness? Joy? Or just sheer exertion? Her body shudders and heaves with each expulsion of the white ping pong ball-sized eggs. She lays around 100 eggs each time, more or less every 15 days for several weeks. But this doesn\u2019t mean there will be many future turtles. Those eggs that evade discovery by honey badgers and other beach scavengers will hatch in approximately 60-70 days. That\u2019s when the real danger begins. Hatchlings must run the gauntlet of ghost crabs, birds and sea creatures in their mad scramble to reach the deeper sea. Only one in each thousand may make it to adulthood, and even those are unsafe from the perils of fishing nets and ingested plastic.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Turtles%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"368\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A leatherback turtle is rarer than a black rhino. The odds are not at all in their favour \u2013 but if they are going to make it anywhere, then the vigorously protected iSimangaliso Wetland Park world heritage site is the safest bet they have.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;You want to see a turtle too?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;iSimangaliso Wetland Park includes the marine protected area and marine sanctuary, where five of the world\u2019s seven species of turtles are to be found. The Park\u2019s 220km of untouched shoreline provides nesting grounds for two of these species, the loggerhead and leatherback, which return to lay eggs at the same beach where they themselves hatched. Monitoring and protection has taken place for over 60 years by conservation agencies. Tours are offered under concession license to operators in the St Lucia \/ Cape Vidal areas, Sodwana Bay, Coastal Forest and Kosi Bay sections. There are still a few weeks left to experience this highly moving and rare event, which occurs from November to February each year. To book, contact one of the operators below.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Turtles%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9125\" class=\"publisher-1944 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/7-swims-7-seas-1-reason\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;7 Swims in the 7 Seas for 1 Reason&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    7 Swims in the 7 Seas for 1 Reason  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"7 Swims in the 7 Seas for 1 Reason\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/The-Intrepid-Explorer-logo2.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Lewis%20Pugh%201.jpg?itok=eJyx_GPx\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/7-swims-7-seas-1-reason\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/7-swims-7-seas-1-reason\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/7-swims-7-seas-1-reason&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Lewis%20Pugh%201.jpg&amp;description=7 Swims in the 7 Seas for 1 Reason\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/7-swims-7-seas-1-reason\" data-text=\"7 Swims in the 7 Seas for 1 Reason\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/7-swims-7-seas-1-reason\" data-title=\"7 Swims in the 7 Seas for 1 Reason\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Overfishing, oil and plastic pollution, rising water temperatures due to climate change, extinction: the world\u2019s oceans are under siege. South African endurance swimmer and the United Nations Environment Programme\u2019s Patron of the Oceans, Lewis Pugh, is determined to help ward off an irreversible crisis \u2013 not for our children, but for the current generation.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cI spent the better part of the past four weeks with my head in the sea \u2026 and I am able to say that our oceans and coastlines are on the line. The biggest fish I came across during my swims was 30 centimetres long. I didn\u2019t see any sharks, nor dolphins or whales,\u201d says Pugh, barely a week after returning from his latest expedition. The campaign, during which he swam the seven seas of the ancient world, took place between 7 and 29 August 2014 and stretched some 200 kilometres.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cI knew these seas had been overfished, but never did I anticipate them to be this empty. I never, ever thought it was this bad,\u201d he says.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Lewis%20Pugh%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;What the swimmer did see was an insurmountable pollution crisis that exceeded his imagination. \u201cEspecially in the Aegean and Red Seas we saw huge amounts of pollution in the form of litter on the seabed,\u201d Pugh recalls. \u201cWe saw heaps of stuff you wouldn\u2019t expect on the ocean floor: tyres, shopping trolleys, bottles, cans and loads of plastic \u2013 from chips packets to carrier bags.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;He adds that his Seven Swims in the Seven Seas campaign strengthened his worries with regard to the health of the world\u2019s maritime resources, with oceans in particular. \u201cThe destruction has happened in my lifetime. I am 44 years old, and I am halfway through the average lifespan of a male of my socio-economic status,\u201d Pugh says. \u201cIf we carry on doing what we are doing to the oceans in the second half of my lifetime, then we will have an irreversible crisis on our hands. &nbsp;We are using oceans as our dumping ground, and we do so at our own peril.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cMy message to world leaders and policy makers is therefore that our oceans should be protected \u2013 not for our children and their children, but for us. Protecting the oceans is not about them. It should be about our generation,\u201d he says. \u201cWe need to protect the oceans for us because this crisis is unfolding now, in our lifetime.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Lewis%20Pugh%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The expedition wasn\u2019t all doom and gloom, Pugh says. The Red Sea leg stands out on that regard. \u201cThe swim started in Aqaba, Jordan and took me along the coast and into the Aqaba Marine Reserve. Once we entered this reserve, things changed below me. There were all sorts of corals \u2013 red, orange, yellow and even some beautiful dark blue varieties,\u201d Pugh recalls. \u201cMulticoloured fish darted in and out of the coral as we came past. It was truly magnificent.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cIt was great to see what a marine protected area can look like,\u201d he says. \u201cHowever, just two kilometres away, outside the marine protected area, the tyres, bottles, cans and plastic returned. It was startling to see the contrast.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In a way, this contrast was a highlight, says Pugh: \u201cIt was proof that marine protected areas do work and that we need more of them.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another memorable aspect of his Seven Seas campaign was the support he received from people from all walks of life. \u201cFarmers, fishermen, shipowners, housewives and school children came out to support us, as well as royalty,\u201d he says. \u201cFor our Red Sea swim, the King of Jordan decided to lend us his boat and a naval escort. During this swim, people from local villages \u2013 school kids included \u2013 came down to swim with me. The fact that so many different people supported what we did, from kings to ordinary folk, was wonderful.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Lewis%20Pugh%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The toughest stretch was by far the North Sea swim, which measured 100km and guided Pugh via the River Thames from South End to Parliament in London. \u201cThere was a very strong tide moving into one direction, with winds blowing the other way,\u201d he says. \u201cThe water was very choppy and I was swimming at night. The water temperature was 14 degrees Celsius. It was very tough physically.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The North Sea swim was completely different from his Red Sea leg the week before, Pugh says: \u201cIn the Red Sea, the air temperature was 44 degrees while seawater temperatures hovered around 30 degrees.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThe thing is that you can\u2019t really prepare your body for such extremes,\u201d he continues, adding that every swim was different. \u201cThere was no time to prepare for things like that. We would arrive in a country, travel to harbour, find somebody who was willing and able to escort us, and then do the swim. We would also do photo shoots, interviews with the media, and one or two speeches. Finally, we would get on a bus back to the airport, en route to our next destination.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Lewis%20Pugh%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Pugh says that his latest expedition has been different from previous campaigns and, in a way, more exhausting: \u201cThe world of campaigning has changed over the past years when I started what I do now. The overall package of 21st century campaigning is tough. Today, apart from the above activities, everyone expects you to be on Twitter and Facebook, and to communicate every few hours about what is going on. Media were phoning me all the time. Between 7 and 29 August, our team got an average four hours of sleep per night. The only way you can pull through is when you have a deep sense of purpose.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While he was still recovering from his Seven Seas expedition at the time of this interview, Pugh was already thinking about his next trip. On the agenda: the pristine and remote Ross Sea, situated on the New Zealand side of Antarctica.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cThis is an extraordinary region, with whales, seals, orcas and other species,\u201d Pugh says, adding that he wants to swim there to raise awareness around the necessity of preserving the Ross Sea as a marine protected reserve. \u201cThis region is truly the Garden of Eden. We need to protect it at all cost.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/Lewis%20Pugh%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"416\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Seven Seas of the Ancient World&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The term \u2018Seven Seas\u2019 has been making the rounds in various cultures for millennia, and therefore its definition varies from region to region. In Greek literature, the Seven Seas comprise:&lt;br&gt;* The Mediterranean Sea (stretching from the Atlantic Ocean, separating Europe from Africa)&lt;br&gt;* The Aegean Sea (an arm of the Mediterranean Sea, located between the Greek Peninsula and Turkey)&lt;br&gt;* The Adriatic Sea (part of the Mediterranean Sea, situated between Italy\u2019s eastern coastline and the shoreline of the Balkan Peninsula, which comprises Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro and Albania)&lt;br&gt;* The Black Sea (situated in eastern Europe, surrounded by Bulgaria, Romania, Ukraine, Russia, Georgia and Turkey)&lt;br&gt;* The Red Sea (an extension of the Indian Ocean, located between Africa and the Arabian Peninsula, with the entrance being the Gulf of Aden)&lt;br&gt;* The Caspian Sea (landlocked between Asia and European Russia \u2013 this sea is the world\u2019s largest inland body of water, with a surface area of 371 000 km\u00b2)&lt;br&gt;* The Persian Gulf (situated between Iran and the Arabian Peninsula)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Past expeditions&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Lewis Pugh has undertaken over a dozen swimming expeditions, of which quite a few served as tools to raise environmental awareness:&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;* 2007 \u2013 Pugh was the first person to swim along the Maldives (140km in 10 days) to draw attention to the impact of rising water levels on low-lying islands. The Maldives archipelago is so low that it is directly threatened if seawater levels start to rise.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;* 2007 \u2013 He swam 1km across an open patch of sea at the North Pole to draw attention to the melting of the Arctic sea ice.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;* 2008 \u2013 Pugh paddled 140km in a surf ski from the island of Spitsbergen in Norway into the Arctic ice packs. The objective was to show the world that this trip was only possible as a result of melting Arctic sea ice, which is a direct consequence of climate change.&lt;br&gt;* 2010 \u2013 Dressed in a Speedo costume and a swimming cap, he embarked on a one-kilometre swim across Lake Pumori, situated at 5 300m on Mount Everest. He wanted to draw attention to the fact that glaciers are a water lifeline for more than 2 billion people living in the Himalaya region. If the Himalayas continue to melt away, Pugh said, they are to become the Earth\u2019s next big battleground.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;The Intrepid Explorer&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Intrepid%20Cover%20Dec_0.jpg?itok=OLUHNndW\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;The Intrepid explorer&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9025\" class=\"publisher-1813 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/heia-you-doing\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Heia you doing&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Heia you doing  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Heia you doing\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.ride.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #E31933' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/ride-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Heia%201.jpg?itok=7_0cKe42\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/heia-you-doing\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/heia-you-doing\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/heia-you-doing&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Heia%201.jpg&amp;description=Heia you doing\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/heia-you-doing\" data-text=\"Heia you doing\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/heia-you-doing\" data-title=\"Heia you doing\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words and pics Andrew Steer&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;blockquote&gt;It\u2019s simply a fantastic mountain-biking and trail-running facility, and we had a great time testing it out&lt;\/blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Heia has the best lake in Johannesburg for open-water swimming (Lake Heritage), and I even accompanied some friends on an unsuccessful fishing expedition there once upon a time. There is some fairly tame wildlife roaming around \u2013 not petting-zoo tame, please, you will get kicked \u2013 but tame enough to linger around and not head for the hills at the first sign of human life. You will encounter giraffe, impala, zebra, wildebeest, blesbok and springbok on almost every visit to the park, and you may even be lucky enough to spot one of its three black springboks. The whole place has a nice African game reserve feel to it, from the rondawels and curio shop to the friendly zebras that frequent the poolside of the ranch\u2019s restaurant.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The latest addition to Heia is the Hero Adventure Park, which was built up in the last year and a half and opened officially in March this year. It\u2019s simply a fantastic mountain-biking and trail-running facility, and we had a great time testing it out.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Heia%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The riding&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are four routes available at Heia: three routes (12,5km, 15km and 18,5 km) for adults and the 3km Little Heroes route. Between these routes, riders of pretty much every level are covered, from those riding the 3km to those riding the pretty tough 49km (if riders choose to tackle all the routes of offer).&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Blue route (easy\u2013intermediate)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The 12,5km Blue route is an absolute blast and the ideal ride for anyone looking to have some fun on their bikes. There are some slightly more challenging sections, but in general there isn\u2019t too much in the way of serious grunt work required. Most importantly, the fun factor is set to the max most of the time: there are plenty of fun bermed descents, switchbacks on most corners, great flowing singletrack and, optional jumps and even a floating bridge (momentum is your friend, just stick to the middle).&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Yellow (intermediate)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The 18,5km yellow route is accessed via the Blue route through an access swing gate on the left end of the lake, taking you to the south-western side of the farm. You hit plenty of fun, tight, forestry sections (eight in total), with lots of quick, sharp rises and steepish drops to navigate. It\u2019s hugely entertaining fun but also pretty tiring work at the same time \u2013 your quads will feel it after a while. After those initial forest sections, you head out towards more open terrain, with some long drags up rocky exposed outcrops that offer some nice, wide views of the surrounding area. The descents from there are fast and furious, taking you back to more switchback forest sections and, ultimately, to the Blue route and home base.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Red (intermediate\u2013advanced)&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The 15km Red route is the toughest on the property and is accessed off the Blue route, this time via a wooden bridge just before the dam wall towards the end of the Blue route. This takes you to the northern side of the farm (the other side of the dam). After an initial quick XC-type assault that really gets the heart racing, the route becomes a lot more forgiving: 90% of it will be rideable for a cyclist with decent fitness and a basic MTB skill set. You climb along the banks on the northern side of the lake before eventually popping over the ridge onto some concrete tracks and returning a bit later for a last few challenges and a gnarly final descent back down to the dam wall. There is plenty of great singletrack (some of it even runs through abandoned houses), many switchback sections and great views of the lake\/dam wall as well as a lookout point\/lunch-stop bench \u2013 well worth the sweat you\u2019ll spill.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Overall experience&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Clearly, a lot of time and effort has gone into all the trails on the route: probably 90% of it is purpose-cut singletrack, and the number of bermed corners is already really impressive; yet it still seems to be expanding every time I return. The variety of terrain and challenges is fantastic \u2013 forest singletrack, bermed corners, long climbs, switchbacks for Africa, rocky koppies, a floating bridge, great lake views and free- roaming wildlife \u2013all this within just 30 minutes\u2019 drive of Johannesburg and Pretoria. It\u2019s an experience that\u2019s hard to topple. And yes, what better way to cap any ride than with a great meal.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Several more riding and running routes are in the pipeline, as are two more floating bridges that will have been opened by the time you read this. It\u2019s pretty clear to see why Heia is rapidly becoming one of the most popular event venues in Gauteng. There is just so much for everyone to enjoy.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Cycling hours&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Cycling hours are from &nbsp;sunrise to sunset. Night rides are offered only on specific event evenings.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Weather&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For most of the riding, you are pretty exposed to the elements \u2013 sunblock is a must for riders pretty much all year round. It can get very hot on the far ends of the Yellow and Red routes, so always make sure you have enough water before heading out there.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Riding rates&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It costs R30 to ride and there is a R20 deposit for your number board. Pay at reception, where you can also pick up a map of all the trails. There are no year permits, but the option is likely to be introduced soon.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Restaurant&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The restaurant is open daily for breakfast, lunch and dinner.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Heia%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Directions&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;From the East Rand:&lt;\/strong&gt; when coming from the OR Tambo\/ Eastgate direction, take the N1 Pretoria off-ramp at the Gillooly\u2019s interchange. You are now on the N3, which later becomes the N1. Follow the signs to Roodepoort. Take the Beyers Naud\u00e9 off-ramp, turn right over the Concrete Highway and keep straight for approximately 23km until you see Heia Safari Ranch sign on your left-hand side. Follow the dirt road for 150m and you will see the entrance on your right.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;From Johannesburg:&lt;\/strong&gt; from the Beyers Naud\u00e9 off-ramp on the N1, travel approximately 23km (away from Northcliff) until you see the Heia Safari Ranch sign on your left-hand side. Follow the dirt road for 150m and you will see the entrance on your right.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;From Pretoria:&lt;\/strong&gt; proceed along the N14 towards Krugersdorp, take the Randburg\/Swartkops off-ramp (the M5\/Beyers Naude) and turn right at the yield sign. Keep straight along Beyers Naud\u00e9 Drive for approximately 5,5km, until you see the Heia Safari Ranch sign on your left-hand side. Follow the dirt road for 150m and you will see the entrance on your right.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Sights and attractions:&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;trail running&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;open-water swimming&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;canoeing&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;catch-and-release fishing&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;game- and birdwatching&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;hand-made Franz Richter dam wall&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;Lake Heritage&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;CrossFit Adventure&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;restaurant&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;secure kiddies\u2019 play area&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;accommodation&lt;br&gt;\u2022&nbsp;conference facilities.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Contact information&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Heia Safari
