node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/adidas-rockstars-2014\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Adidas ROCKSTARS 2014&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Adidas ROCKSTARS 2014  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Adidas ROCKSTARS 2014\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Rockstars%201_1.jpg?itok=XtdHKmF2\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/adidas-rockstars-2014\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/adidas-rockstars-2014\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/adidas-rockstars-2014&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Rockstars%201_1.jpg&amp;description=Adidas ROCKSTARS 2014\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/adidas-rockstars-2014\" data-text=\"Adidas ROCKSTARS 2014\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/adidas-rockstars-2014\" data-title=\"Adidas ROCKSTARS 2014\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Pics Elias Holzknecht, Christian Waldegger and Bert Willer \u2013 adidas-rockstars.com&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s a Saturday evening in September. Some 3,500 spectators in the packed Porsche-Arena are going wild, because the superfinal of the fourth adidas ROCKSTARS bouldering invitational they have just witnessed was exactly what the name indicates: super. Super thrilling, super tight and super spectacular. Canada\u2019s 27-year old Sean McColl wins the duel on the final boulder and beats 18-year old Jongwon Chon from Korea by a nose. The two athletes almost climb synchronously, jump simultaneously, and swing parallel. At the rim to the topout they are abreast. Sean McColl slips and lunges at the buzzer while falling down. Not knowing whether he hit the button properly, he stays on his back. Jongwon Chon, who also stumbled to the top, is confident of victory and jubilantly throws his arms in the air.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Rockstars%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For a photo finish like this, the adidas ROCKSTARS organisers have set up two buzzers on the super boulder, to clearly determine a winner. A yellow light goes on at the buzzer that was hit first. The other buzzer is blocked automatically. And today the yellow light shines for Sean McColl. The two-time World Champion Overall (L\/S\/B), who is known for his climbing speed, claims his second adidas ROCKSTAR title after 2012. Jongwon Chon is happy, too. The young Korean has won the local adidas ROCKSTARS Korea competition in Seoul for the second time this year and was invited to Stuttgart. It is his first podium ever at a top-class international competition. Reaching the final of the top 6 and beating world cup stars like Dmitrii Sharafutdinov (RUS), Sachi Amma (JPN) or Jakob Schubert (AUT) in the semis has already been a huge success for Chon. Last year he placed 22nd.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Rockstars%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Chon is also the first who can top a boulder in the tough final. While all problems of the route setters were solved in the qualification and the semi-final rounds, the top 6 men and women literally wear themselves out on the first final boulder. After two exertive days, their fingers are trashed and they are hurting. One can feel the pressure. First the finalist don\u2019t want to disappoint the 3,500 spectators who have come to the Porsche-Arena to cheer them on; second they have to make the cut-off as after the first two boulders three athletes are eliminated. None of the finalists can solve the first problem.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Rockstars%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;However, Jongwon Chon and the defending champion Jernej Kruder (SLO) grab the bonus hold. It all comes down to the second boulder. Rustam Gelmanov (RUS) and Mathilde Becerra (FRA), who placed 6th in the semis, start first. Mathilde reaches the bonus in her fifth attempt. Next Jongwon Chon and M&#233;lissa Le Nev&#233; (FRA) take to the 44m wide stage. The two-time French Bouldering Champion and first woman who repeated Wolfgang G&#252;llich\u2019s legendary Wallstreet (8c) in May this year, reaches the bonus hold in her second try. On the opposite side the audience sees a very flexible Chon fighting. He\u2019s got one minute left. In his fourth and last attempt he finally makes it to the top. A wave of excitement spreads through the arena. Chon revels in the attention. The Korean has broken the spell.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Rockstars%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After him, Petra Klingler (SUI), Mina Marcovi&#269; (SLO) and Akiyo Noguchi (JPN) successfully complete the second boulder. Marcovi&#269;, silver medallist at the 2014 Lead World Championship in Gij&#243;n, even manages a flash. The adidas ROCKSTAR 2013, Jernej Kruder, reaches the bonus hold in his first try. Rei Sugimoto (JPN) secures a bonus point in his third attempt. As Sean \"The Machine\u201c McColl is about to top the second boulder in his fourth try, the spectators hold their breath, because the Canadian suddenly stops at the rim to the topout, clenches his fist and is about to jump down, believing that he completed the problem.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Rockstars%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the nick of time he hears the referee shouting that he must carry on. On top of the boulder the adidas ROCKSTARS 2012 realises that he almost squandered his chance for victory. After a brief moment of shock, Sean has to laugh at himself and flirts like a born entertainer with the crowd.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;After two boulders, the result is clear. Jongwon Chon, Sean McColl and Jernej Kruder advance to the next round; so do Mina Marcovi&#269;, Petra Klingler and Akiyo Noguchi. With only one bonus under her belt, last year\u2019s runner-up Shauna Coxsey (GBR) is out. But the British boulder badass is happy to have competed at all after spraining her ankle on Thursday. When the event\u2019s sport physicians gave her the green light, she made her way to the final with an aching, heavily strapped-up foot.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Rockstars%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the third boulder, the athletes start in reverse order to the intermediate standings. Akiyo needed three attempts for her top and has to go first. A bit short of breath the graceful Japanese lets the first 40 seconds pass, before she tackles the third dynamic problem of the route setters. She reaches the bonus hold without difficulty, but is wrestling with the mantle on the top. Akiyo sticks to her guns, she wants this flash that would be her ticket to the superfinal. And she nails it. The crowd goes wild. Swiss powerhouse Petra Klinger cannot top this boulder. Mina Marcovi&#269; however, successfully completes it in her fifth try. Hence the superfinal pairing of women is set: Japan vs. Slovenia, Overall Bouldering World Cup Champion against Overall Lead World Cup Champion.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Rockstars%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Jongwon Chon and Sean McColl have scored one top in four tries, respectively. Jernej Kruder hasn't reached a top yet, but he has a better bonus balance. Last year's winner is getting the crowd behind him. If he can complete the third boulder in his fourth attempt, he will enter the superfinal. But he doesn\u2019t succeed. Today the silver medallist of the 2014 Bouldering World Championship has to settle for third place.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;10:12 pm. The superfinal is set. Stuttgart\u2019s punkrock band Badasstics performs the adidas ROCKSTARS song \u201cNo Borders\u201d live. Akiyo Noguchi climbs on the left side of the super boulder, Mina Marcovi&#269; is on the right. They can\u2019t see each other. They can only imagine what\u2019s happening on the other side based on the reactions of the crowd. The Japanese takes the lead. 3,500 spectators in the arena go mad. Akiyo Noguchi wins the duel. After a second place in 2012 and a third place in 2013, she finally claims the title.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Rockstars%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Porsche-Arena is on fire. Can this atmosphere be topped? It can. While the route setters change the boulder for the superfinal of the men, European Beatbox Champion Robeat pumps up the crowd. The 25-year-old vocal acrobat is stepping on it: funny sound effects, hard techno beats, fast drum-and-base rhythms. The spectators are thrilled by his performance. Finally, Sean McColl and Jongwon Chon line up for the final duel of the evening. The rest is history.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;36 hours later the Porsche-Arena is empty. Apart from a few golden confetti shavings, there is no allusion that a few hours ago the world\u2019s best bouldering athletes have fought for victory on a giant 30m wide wall. The mobile climbing wall that has been specifically developed for adidas ROCKSTARS has been dismantled. Eight tractor trucks have transported many tons of material to the warehouse where it is stored \u2013 until next year.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;adidas-rockstars.com&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Rockstars%2012.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9016\" class=\"publisher-2376 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/how-dusty-can-you-get-duster\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;How Dusty Can You Get a Duster?&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    How Dusty Can You Get a Duster?  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"How Dusty Can You Get a Duster?\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/wheels-logo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Duster%201.jpg?itok=IvK3KB0U\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/how-dusty-can-you-get-duster\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/how-dusty-can-you-get-duster\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/how-dusty-can-you-get-duster&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Duster%201.jpg&amp;description=How Dusty Can You Get a Duster?\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/how-dusty-can-you-get-duster\" data-text=\"How Dusty Can You Get a Duster?\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/how-dusty-can-you-get-duster\" data-title=\"How Dusty Can You Get a Duster?\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Gerhard Horn pics Rob Till&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The Renault Duster is regarded as a soft-roader, which means it\u2019s quite good in a shopping mall's parking lot but not much use when the going gets tough. So what happens when you drive it through some really harsh terrain?&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The term \u201csoft-roader\u201d is widely recognised as the description of a car that has bigger tyres than usual, added ground clearance and some suspension tweaks, but not to the point that it\u2019s as capable off-road as a proper 4x4.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The question is, how far removed from a real off-roader is the average soft-roader? Is the gap between the two really that big, or would a soft-roader get you to some of the places seen as the preserve of the hardcore 4x4s?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We had the opportunity to find out a few months ago, on an epic adventure in Namibia. Renault invited us to drive a Duster through some remote parts of this beautiful country \u2013 to a secret location where a film crew was busy shooting a new season of Ultimate Braai Master.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We had previously driven the Duster on our own soft-roader adventure, but on that occasion it had faced little more than a badly corrugated dirt road in the Komatiland Forest. A bad road in Mpumalanga and five days through Namibia\u2019s most hostile terrain are two completely different things, and to be honest, we thought the Namibia trip could do some serious damage to the Duster's reputation.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On our arrival in Windhoek, the Renault dealership wasn\u2019t exactly reassuring. We were told over a cup of coffee that the Dusters we\u2019d be driving were brand new and that the modifications made for the trip had been completed that very morning. So not only were we heading out in vehicles with delivery mileage on them, but we were using untested equipment. The odometer had barely reached double digits, and we faced a five-day drive covering 3000km. At least we could look forward to a 600km section of tar on the final day!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The first leg of our trip was a gravel route from Windhoek to Sossusvlei Desert Camp. These roads are notorious for shredding tyres, so we were surprised to see that the modifications made to our cars did not include a new set of shard rock resistant rubber. In fact, the modifications were limited to a sturdy roof rack and a set of jerry cans in case we couldn\u2019t find 50ppm diesel.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Namibian version of the Duster includes a stainless steel bull bar as standard, but other than that it was the same Duster we know in SA.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Duster%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The first 300km turned out to be mostly uneventful. The Duster has a rather rudimentary all-wheel drive system that kicks in automatically when it detects a loss in grip. This made the Duster fairly entertaining on the first leg of the journey, simply because it lets you get the tiniest bit sideways before it intervenes and saves the day. It was loads of fun, but too much of a good thing can lead to a brand new Duster landing on its roof in the middle of nowhere, so we turned off the road to check the tyre pressures. In our hurry to get going, we had forgotten to check this vital element. The car was still set up for city driving and as anyone in the know will tell you, an overinflated tyre and a gravel road really don\u2019t mix. After we had let out some of the air the Duster fell back in line again.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We were missing the sideways action, but had some time to reflect on the Duster\u2019s 1,5-litre turbocharged diesel engine. We have praised this engine before, and it is certainly one of the best currently in production. For its size it delivers a powerful punch, and this allowed us to cruise kilometre after kilometre, without ever having to gear down from fifth.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The hours flew by uneventfully and eventually we pulled up at the Tropic of Capricorn to watch the sun setting over the magnificent Namibian horizon. Our tour guide started getting uncomfortable with our constant picture-taking and loitering, but we regarded this as a wonderful moment that needed to be savoured.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The reason for the guide's scurrying became apparent an hour or so later when we still had 100km or so to drive, without sunlight illuminating the way. The Duster\u2019s headlamps were in working condition, but a moon-free evening in the middle of nowhere is just about as dark as it gets. Couple that with wildlife running around freely and you have a recipe for disaster.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We suppose it was inevitable that one of us would hit something, and we just happened to be in the car when Lady Luck decided to go home for the night. We were in a hurry to get to Sossusvlei and, while driving at 100km\/h or so, crossed paths with a frightened young buck. It had simply stared at the first car in convoy, but decided to run across the road a split second before we arrived. There was no time to brake or swerve. The buck died instantly, as did our stupid determination to get to our destination quicker rather than safer.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Duster%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Surprisingly, the Duster suffered little damage, mostly thanks to the standard Namibian bull bar. The fog light was broken and the bumper was a bit scuffed, but other than that the car was fine.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We eventually arrived at Sossusvlei late at night, thankful for the harsh lesson in mortality. Let\u2019s just say that, in our experience, it\u2019s best not to drive in Namibia after dark.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next morning we headed for Death Valley. We had seen our itinerary a few weeks earlier and knew that this would be the true test of the Duster\u2019s off-road prowess. You can drive yourself into the desert up to a certain point, but then there\u2019s a large sign stating that only real 4x4s may enter here.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We were in a car with four driven wheels and we weren\u2019t about to give up just because some sign advised us to. It seemed that the previous night\u2019s lesson had been quickly forgotten.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We drove past the sign and got stuck about 300m later! It wasn\u2019t the car\u2019s fault, but rather our own for thinking that we could drive a soft-roader over soft sand in its default auto mode. In sand, momentum is king and the traction control was making anything resembling momentum nigh impossible.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We switched it off immediately, locked the car in all-wheel drive with power distributed 50\/50 to the front and rear axles, and set off again. This time we not only kept up our momentum but found ourselves choosing the most difficult path through the soft sand, time and time again.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We made it through, much to the amusement of a large crowd gathered in the 4x4-only parking lot. We explored the area and came back to an entirely new crowd that had gathered around our little 4x4. As it was decorated in \u201cUltimate Braai Master\u201d livery, most people thought it was a publicity stunt. They wouldn\u2019t believe we had got the car there under its own steam. One guy suggested that Renault had used a helicopter to drop it there. Another wondered aloud whether he had made a mistake in renting an expensive Hilux overlander at the airport. After all, there was a perfectly good Ford Kuga standing at home, but he'd thought a soft-roader wouldn't make it.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Duster%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;By the end of the second day we had proved that you could push a soft-roader much further than you\u2019d expect, but that deduction may be limited to the Duster. After we had driven it for the first time, we expected as much because it is a relatively straightforward, lightweight all-wheel drive crossover.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the days that followed we kept on driving the Duster into places it really shouldn\u2019t have been. We went to the edge of the Fish River Canyon, through dried riverbanks and over the occasional rocky stretch. On the last day, we even did a 50km off-road track in the hopes of seeing some wild horses.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Duster got us to the set of &lt;em&gt;Ultimate Braai Master&lt;\/em&gt;, where we enjoyed plenty of meat and &lt;em&gt;melktert&lt;\/em&gt; and revelled in the atmosphere of a reality TV show set. (In case you were wondering, the cooking time and elimination process really is as intense as it seems on the screen.)&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The trip left us with renewed respect for Renault\u2019s humble little Duster. It started with almost zero kilometres on the clock and by the end we had added 3000 more.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Along the way we lost a fog light and one tyre. That\u2019s the grand total of the damage Namibia could inflict on our French car. It did not develop a rattle, squeak or niggle. The dust did work its way into our luggage in the boot, but this was a small annoyance and something that would probably happen to a hardened 4x4.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Namibia is basically a torture chamber for cars. We often heard stories of how people had rolled their cars, or ruined tyres and been left stranded for days.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the fourth day, we saw an example of what can happen. We came across a Prado claimed by the desert. It had rolled and burned out \u2013 just beyond one of those sneaky corners after a rise in the road.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Namibia is as harsh as it is beautiful, but it turned out to be no match for the Duster.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/www.mysubs.co.za\/magazine\/leisure-wheels\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Leisure Wheels&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/LW%20Jan.jpg?itok=RftV_hUR\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Leisure wheels&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-8702\" class=\"publisher-1335 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/opting-out-salt-rock\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Opting out in Salt Rock&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Opting out in Salt Rock  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Opting out in Salt Rock\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #222222' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/cl.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Salt%20Rock%201.jpg?itok=Lt2ESyQY\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opting-out-salt-rock\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opting-out-salt-rock\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opting-out-salt-rock&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Salt%20Rock%201.jpg&amp;description=Opting out in Salt Rock\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opting-out-salt-rock\" data-text=\"Opting out in Salt Rock\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/opting-out-salt-rock\" data-title=\"Opting out in Salt Rock\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Andrea Abbott, Pics Andrea Abbott &amp; supplied&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I grew up in the Salt Rock area of the Natal North Coast when it was far from everywhere, especially school. Getting to and from school consumed so much time that the only thing to do was bunk. Often. Spending idle hours on the beach eyeing the talent, I never really got the hang of things like maths and science. But what the heck \u2013 as the song goes, we had joy, we had fun, we had seasons in the sun.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Times have changed. Development along the North Coast has brought Salt Rock closer to everywhere, including schools. No valid excuse now to bunk. But although the population has boomed, as is evident from the housing estates occupying former sugar-cane fields, Salt Rock has retained its small-town character. The village centre is much as it\u2019s been for decades. No high-rise buildings block the view or shade the beach, and amenities are few but sufficient. They include the Country Club, an unassuming cluster of shops, a couple of restaurants, and the famous Salt Rock Hotel that Basil Hulett built in the late 1930s and which has been passed down to his grandchildren, Craig Hulett and Linda Labidi. Except for the multi-storey wing tacked on in the 1960s, the hotel is still imbued with old-world tropical charm.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Lunch on the rustic patio or drinks on the sundeck perched high above the tidal pool, which Basil also built, is about as good as things get. Metres from the pool, the caravan park is probably closer to the sea than any other accommodation in the area.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A caravanning retiree from Cape Town told us he escapes the Cape winter every year, spending three months on the eastern side of the country, a month of that at Salt Rock. With the North Coast\u2019s climate balmy practically all year round, \u2018Retired from Cape Town\u2019 enjoys an almost endless summer. As another song goes \u2013 summertime and the living is easy.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It\u2019s easy indeed to enjoy all the area offers. Stroll along pristine beaches, brave the exhilarating surf or cool off in the tidal pools at Salt Rock, Shaka\u2019s Rock and Thompson\u2019s Bay that, like the legions of rock pools exposed at low tide, teem with marine life.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Salt%20Rock%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cWhen I first saw the creatures in Shaka\u2019s Pool, I knew I had to share that beauty,\u201d surfer and qualified nature guide, Michelle (Michy) Morris says. A year ago, Michy started Tidal Tao Snorkel Safaris. \u201cNot everyone wants to go scuba diving. Snorkelling is much the same but in miniature.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018Tao\u2019, Michy explains, is Chinese for \u2018telling a story\u2019. And what stories she tells as she guides snorkellers on unforgettable expeditions \u2013 some at night \u2013 in the tidal pools and hidden gulleys. Stories, for examples of the nudibranch. \u201cThe what?\u201d \u201cA sea slug,\u201d says Michy. \u201cThe name means naked gills. There are more than 3 000 species, all of them fabulously coloured.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another story is of the coral in Shaka\u2019s Pool. \u201cThe most southerly occurrence in the world of shallow-water coral,\u201d she says. In telling the ocean\u2019s stories, Michy\u2019s primary goal is to conserve marine life.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cI want to stop the cruelty along the coast.\u201d It\u2019s not mere talk. Twenty percent of her income goes to marine conservation projects.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another who cares deeply for animals, in this case domestic animals, is Genevieve Chisholm. \u201cIn ten years we\u2019ve rescued 10 000 animals,\u201d she says. Gen and her parents, Odile and Julian Foster-Greenwood, own Flag Animal Farm, situated a few kilometres inland from Salt Rock. \u201cIt was badly run down when we bought it,\u201d Gen says. \u201cToday it\u2019s rated as top of its kind.\u201d It\u2019s also one of the busiest destinations on the North Coast. Families stream in and schoolchildren arrive by the busload to picnic, party, play in the Jabula Playground and learn to love animals.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But Flag Farm is no zoo. It\u2019s a facility genuinely devoted to giving a loving home to abused or abandoned domestic animals. \u201cMany get dumped here,\u201dshe adds, hugging a kid goat whose mother escaped slaughter by jumping a fence and running away. \u201cIf we don\u2019t have space for an animal, we\u2019ll find it another home. But every one we accept lives its full life here and receives proper care.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Further inland is a venue devoted to wild animals. Rain Farm wildlife sanctuary and lodge is the only place of its kind on the North Coast, until the Hluhluwe-iMfolozi Park. \u201cThe owner, Douglas Nidd, is passionate about wildlife and conservation,\u201d marketing manager Tasmyn-Jain van Niekerk tells me as we sit on the restaurant deck watching zebras graze on coastal grasslands across the valley. \u201cHe dreamed of his own game reserve where his children could lead an outdoor lifestyle.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Eighteen years ago Douglas began a remarkable labour of love \u2013 the re-wilding of 300 hectares of sugar-cane fields. As Rain Farm evolved, the Nidd family decided to share it, and opened it to the public five years ago. It has become a sought-after destination that offers a range of facilities including accommodation, a wedding venue, day-visitor amenities, game drives and various adventure activities.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Salt%20Rock%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Back toward the coast, two other enterprises provide muscle-straining, bum-bruising adventure \u2013 more specifically \u2018the new golf\u2019, as some refer to mountain bike trail riding. \u201cIt\u2019s one of the fastest-growing sports,\u201d Nic Jordan tells us. A farmer and accomplished mountain-bike rider who has, among other challenges, ridden halfway around Rwanda, Nic started Holla Trails (named after \u2018holler\u2019 \u2013 what riders do when they\u2019re hurtling along a thrilling route) five years ago.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cOur 340km trail network is possibly the most extensive organised trail venue in the country,\u201d says Nic, adding that Holla\u2019s furthest point is high on an escarpment, a 70-minute drive from the clubhouse. That surely translates into a many-hour ride. (I\u2019ll take the drive, thanks).&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Next door, Sugar Rush Park offers mountain-bike trails ranging from a 5km course to a demanding 40km route. More than that, the park is a unique agritourism hub. \u201cOur initial plan was for a cut flower growing and distribution centre,\u201d says Rose Juby, one of four partners who developed the park. \u201cWe only needed two hectares, but ten is the required minimum for agricultural zoning.\u201d To make use of the surplus, Rose and her partners brought on board the Ballito Dolphins Rugby Club, which needed a home of its own, and iLembe Winery, a co-op with vineyards in the KZN hinterland. They also opened a caf\u00e9, decor shop and the Sugar Rush Adventure Centre, which incorporates the trails and a children\u2019s play park. And so, from its beginnings as a flower-packing facility, Sugar Rush has blossomed into a place where you can ride or shop until you drop.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Back at Salt Rock, shopaholics can feed their habit at two fine markets. On the north side of the N2, Burnedale Farmers Market concentrates on local fresh produce and home-made products. The Saturday morning market is part of the Burnedale Centre, which houses a caf\u00e9 and a range of small shops including a pottery gallery where you can buy hand-painted crockery, or do your own painting.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Across the N2, the Litchi Orchard \u2013 set, as one would expect, on a working litchi farm \u2013 also promotes local and sustainable food production. A day market is held on the second Saturday of each month, and the night market that includes live music is on the last Friday of the month. Facilities open daily include the dinky Coffee Roastery, a caf\u00e9, garden centre and pub.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Thinking back to my (misspent) childhood on the North Coast, I recall people commenting to my parents, \u201cWhy do you want to live all the way out there?\u201d Nowadays though, the Salt Rock area has so much going for it that anyone not living \u2018all the way out there\u2019 might be sorely tempted to bunk work or school and escape to this vibrant coastal paradise&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za\/subscribe-win-painted-wolf-wines\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Country Life&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3185\"&gt;Holla MTB Trails&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2456\"&gt;Ballito to Salt Rock Trail&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.countrylife.co.za\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/CL%20Jan%2015.jpg?itok=47gQ6iK9\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Country Life&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9024\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/soul-food-downtown-jozi\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Soul Food in Downtown Jozi&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Soul Food in Downtown Jozi  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Soul Food in Downtown Jozi\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Jozi%20Food%201%20beauty%20of%20urban%20renewal.jpg?itok=ti4W530o\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/soul-food-downtown-jozi\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/soul-food-downtown-jozi\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/soul-food-downtown-jozi&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Jozi%20Food%201%20beauty%20of%20urban%20renewal.jpg&amp;description=Soul Food in Downtown Jozi\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/soul-food-downtown-jozi\" data-text=\"Soul Food in Downtown Jozi\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/soul-food-downtown-jozi\" data-title=\"Soul Food in Downtown Jozi\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words and pics Bridget Hilton-Barber&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Sundays are food market days in downtown Jozi. You can either go east to Maboneng, a funky urban renewal district centred around Arts on Main - or you can go west, and discover the latest food market called The Sheds@1Fox, set in one of Jozi\u2019s oldest industrial warehouses.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From Africa to Asia and the Middle East - there\u2019s a whole of soul food going down at Market on Main in the Maboneng Precinct on Sundays. This weekly food and design market draws hipsters and foodies from all across town with its Afro New York charm and easy urban vibe.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Jozi%20Food%202%20prettiest%20woman%20on%20sunday.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Set inside a funky warehouse on the eastern edge of the CBD, the food market features a hundred or so traders \u2013 and you can do Mexican mama hot bowls, soul souvlakis, Indian paneers, Durban bunnychow, Mediterranean flatbreads, pap &amp; wors and fresh delicate pastries. The setting is designer industrial and the stall names have a fabulously South African flavour - the Jozi Smokehouse, Sharp Braais, Durban Deli, Cherrybomb Funky Foods. The design component of the market has retail and vintage \u2013 music, furniture, clothing, accessories and craft.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Jozi%20Food%203%20freshly%20baked%20ciabatta.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From rollerblading teens to people sitting quietly reading the Sunday papers, the whole of Maboneng comes alive on a Sunday. There are families, young crowds, couples and cool people hanging out, brunching, lunching and drinking. \u201cSundays is when Jozi is at peace with itself\u201d, a food seller told me and it certainly feels that way.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are interesting urban spaces within Maboneng \u2013 from coffee shops in container and enormous murals that adorn entire buildings to rooftop gardens and green courtyards. The name Maboneng means place of light and it\u2019s a privately developed urban neighbourhood with shops, galleries, restaurants (over 20) loft apartments, factory spaces, contemporary connected office spaces, a hip hotel. &nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Jozi%20Food%204%20sunday%20papers%20maboneng.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;And on the other side of town \u2013 head straight down Commissioner Street \u2013 on the western edge as it\u2019s become known, you\u2019ll find the hippest new addition to the urban-renewal-meets-food scene \u2013 the Sheds@1 Fox. It\u2019s in Ferreirastown where Joburg\u2019s first miners pitched their tents during the gold rush and neighbours historic Marshalltown, whose landmarks are the Stock Exchange and Diagonal Street.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Sheds@1Fox is a seriously sexy place. The food market is set in a vast warehouse whose main shed is one of the oldest industrial spaces in Jozi city. And from a culinary point of view, this market takes it up a level \u2013 offering things like sushi, champagne and oysters, organic vegetables, designer waffles, fair trade coffee, Mexcian street food and American style pork belly BBQ .&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Jozi%20Food%205%20soul%20souvlaki.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There is a fresh flower market as you walk in \u2013 yay! - and plenty of space and seating, although no electricity on the day I visited \u2013 prompting someone to joke that it should be called the Loadshed@1Fox. But the vibe is great and it\u2019s inspiring to see hip urban renewal. The Good Luck Bar inside the food market is named after one of the city\u2019s original bars which got its license all the way back in 1895.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Sheds@1Fox is in on the western edge of town - on the edge of First China Town, Fordsburg and Newtown, and home to historic buildings, like the old Chinese Club and the city\u2019s first Indian cinema. The district has many historic buildings and warehouses dating mainly back to 1920s and 1940s \u2013 and the good news is that there are plans to develop some of the surrounding spaces here.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Jozi%20Food%206%20urban%20jungle.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;For more information about the Arts on Main Food &amp; Design Sundays check out &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.marketonmain.co.za\"&gt;www.marketonmain.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;. The market happens at Arts on Main every Sunday from 10am - 3pm. The night market takes place once a month, on the first Thursday of every month. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;For more information about hip happenings in the Maboneng Precinct, check out &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.mabonengprecinct.com\"&gt;www.mabonengprecinct.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022&nbsp;For more information and about the food market The Sheds@1Fox, check out &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.1fox.co.za\"&gt;www.1fox.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;. The market is just off the Selby off-ramp into town, and a short distance south of the Nelson Mandela Bridge. &nbsp;It\u2019s open from Thursdays to Sundays during the day.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Jozi%20Food%2010%20canteen.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/1235\"&gt;&lt;br&gt;Arts on Main&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-8703\" class=\"publisher-1338 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/coffee-tour-keeps-you-pedalling-more\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;A Coffee Tour That Keeps You Pedalling for More&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    A Coffee Tour That Keeps You Pedalling for More  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"A Coffee Tour That Keeps You Pedalling for More\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #d22127' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/din.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Coffee%201.jpg?itok=31D5y94H\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/coffee-tour-keeps-you-pedalling-more\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/coffee-tour-keeps-you-pedalling-more\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/coffee-tour-keeps-you-pedalling-more&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Coffee%201.jpg&amp;description=A Coffee Tour That Keeps You Pedalling for More\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/coffee-tour-keeps-you-pedalling-more\" data-text=\"A Coffee Tour That Keeps You Pedalling for More\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/coffee-tour-keeps-you-pedalling-more\" data-title=\"A Coffee Tour That Keeps You Pedalling for More\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Sean Jansen&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you look beyond the history and controversy of Colombia, you will find a country that has not only moved on considerably from their past, when Pablo Escobar was running things, but one that has something for everyone. It has the tropical climes of the Amazon, Caribbean and Pacific coasts, as well as the breathtaking Andes Mountains and super cities. However, if you were to delve deeper into the areas surrounding the Andes, you would find Zona Cafeteria. A region famous for its coffee.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I visited Colombia for the first time many years ago, arriving via a five-day sailboat crossing from Panama. While on this boat trip, the Colombian couple whom were in charge introduced me to their local coffee. Now, I have had Panamanian, Indonesian, Bolivian, and Brazilian coffee, to name only a few, but it is the Colombian coffee that sweeps them all off their feet. It is rich with a thick coffee flavour, but also smooth enough so that you don't need to add cream or sugar to enjoy it. The region I visited on that first trip is close to the sleepy village of Salento, a paradise suspended in time and place I have since returned to for a third time.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While Salento is quite stunning in its own beautiful and own right, most who venture to this small town are here to visit the justifiably famous Valle de Cocora. This nature reserve is home to Colombia's national tree, the beautiful wax palm (&lt;em&gt;palma de cera&lt;\/em&gt;), which just happens to be the tallest palm in the world, at heights of up to 60 metres, and looks like it should have featured in the film Jurassic Park.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;What many tourists don\u2019t know about Salento is that it is a coffee hot spot and one of the country\u2019s top export regions. Not only is the coffee that\u2019s produced here excellent, there are some really cool tours to go on and getting to the plantations and surrounding areas is half the fun.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Coffee%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Salento is about 15 miles from Armenia, a bigger city, but it takes 45 minutes to get there. With that being said, the only way to get to Salento's coffee plantations are via dirt roads. Some of which are impossible to drive on. Therefore, you can walk, ride a horse or grab a couple mountain bikes - the later being the travel mode we chose, and what turned out to be a fantastic way to explore the plantations.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Jumping on our rented bikes, we cruised along the dirt roads, roller coasting up and down the terrain of the Andes, all the while taking in the scenery that had a prehistoric look to it. In fact, we wouldn't have batted an eye if a dinosaur had come sauntering out of the vegetation and crossed the road. While trying to breath at 6,000 feet, we momentarily forgot what the purpose of our trip was because we were so completely mesmerized by the sheer bizarreness yet beauty of this place. A place God clearly intended to remain lost forever. Yet, this was one of the country's top export regions, it was all quite mind blowing.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Continuing along the bumpy dirt road, we passed beautiful farms and plantations that you wouldn\u2019t mind calling your own. After about 45 minutes of the most jaw-dropping and breathtaking scenery, we arrived at the plantation and were immediately taken to the &lt;em&gt;finca&lt;\/em&gt;, where we were shown and educated about coffee. Educated on how it comes from a plant and is then transformed into an aromatic liquid that people from the world over have come to love.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;All about coffee&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;While on the tour, we learnt a lot of interesting facts and information about coffee, such as that it is grown between altitudes of 1,800 and 6,000 feet on the side of a mountain. It's planted with plantain and banana trees because they help each other grow and are thus beneficial to each other. We also learnt that Colombia is a special place to grow coffee. It turns out that other coffee-growing regions around the world only have one real growing and harvesting season due to their location. Since Colombia sits almost on the equator, it is not affected by the seasonal changes that other the other countries have to go through. Therefore, it has two growing seasons and not just one and coffee is produced all year round.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The guide explained to us how to pick the coffee beans and how the colour determines if it is ready or not to be picked, as well as what taste you would get from a particular colour. He then demonstrated how to peel the bean from the casing it is grown in. Keen to try this ourselves, we picked a coffee bean from the plant and tried our best to peel back the skin to get to the bean, which was no easy task, quite finicky and time consuming. A task, the guide told us, we would have been paid about 10 cents an hour. Once we finally got to the bean it was a light brownish color, ready to go into the cauldron for cooking.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Coffee%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;The process&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;The coffee we drink and beans we buy at the store are black because they are first cooked so that they are ready to be ground and brewed to our desire. But they don\u2019t look like that when they are first picked from the plant. To make a single cup of coffee, a picker has to pick around 40 to 100 beans. If I was a picker, it would have taken me about an hour to pick and peel the beans; a lot of effort for a cuppa. The beans are then put out in the sun to dry, to help speed up the cooking process. The drying can take up to a couple days, depending on the weather. Once dried, the beans are then placed in what is known as a popper.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A popper is a device that not only heats up to an incredible temperature but also stirs the beans every two to three seconds until they turn a dark brownish, black colour. At this point, they are taken out of the popper and cooled for approximately 12 hours. Then after the many hours it has taken to pick, peel, dry and cook them, you are finally ready to have your first cup of coffee. Oh, and after grinding them, of course.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Countryside cruising&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;After a delicious cup of coffee, we got back on our bikes feeling energized and happily continued to cruise around the Andes Mountains and this amazing region, the Zona Cafeteria.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Now, two of my most favorite things in the world are coffee and cycling. To be able to enjoy both of them in a setting as spectacular as anything you may have seen in &lt;em&gt;Avatar&lt;\/em&gt;, I\u2019m not sure my afternoon cycle could have been any better.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Coffee%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;TRAVEL TIPS&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;When to go&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Like I said above, the weather and climate in Colombia don\u2019t change too much, if at all. It sits not far from the equator and really only has two seasons; the wet season and dry season. The wet season is roughly from April to November, with a weird dry month in July. And the dry season is from December to March. I was there in September and did get rained on, but it wasn\u2019t anything to keep me from going outside and enjoying nature. But given your own limitations and what you want to do, you can choose when you would like to go.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Getting there&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Fly from Bogota, the capital of Colombia, to Armenia, and then go by road to the magic village of Salento. If you travel by road from Bogota, it is 278 kilometres to Armenia (about 7 hours), also using the Coffee Highway, which connects Quindio and Risaralda to Manizales. The remaining 25km to Salento takes about 45 minutes. There are also buses that run from 5:30am to 8pm and come about every 20 to 30 minutes from &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/wikitravel.org\/en\/Armenia_(Colombia)\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Armenia&lt;\/a&gt; and one every hour to Pereira.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Best way to get around&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are many ways of transport in and around the city. The best way I found was to simply walk. The town is not flat by any means and renting a bike and going around the city could be exhausting. But we obviously rented bikes one day and it turned out to be wonderful. Many people go by horseback with a guide and they take you around the city and surrounding areas. And finally there are also Willy\u2019s (a type of Jeep) and Land Rovers with the roofs chopped off and people cruise around in those for a fare of about 3,500 Pesos. But Ultimately, the preferred methods for me were to ride a bike or simply enjoy a stroll walking around.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Salento cuisine&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Salento has many different restaurants from local eateries to western accommodations. But if there was one dish that everyone has to try, it is the &lt;em&gt;trucha con platanos&lt;\/em&gt;. It is a dish of trout (the local fish in the rivers of the region) with deep fried plantain chips and rice or beans. Absolutely fabulous. But as I said, if you wish, you could always find a place that has pizza or other western delicacies.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What to do&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Visit one of the many organic coffee &lt;em&gt;fincas&lt;\/em&gt; in the area.&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Check out the Mirador, the lookout point, as it is supposed to offer one of the best views in Colombia.&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Hire a mountain bike and go for a full day or an hour's ride. There are a whole range of trails around the area that provide something for everyone, from relative beginners to those who want something a bit more technical. Some of the trails afford some spectacular views across the area and coffee plantations.&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Take a trip to Kasaguadua Natural Reserve, consisting of 12 hectares of lush tropical rain forest and a mountainous landscape that protects a natural creek. There is a network of well-maintained looping trails (4km), achievable in 1.5 hours up to 6 hours. Its altitude makes it quite different from Cocora Valley's and allows you to find another kind of vegetation and climate.&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Hire a guide, saddle up a horse and cruise around the city in style while also going through some areas outside of town.&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;Ask around town, and depending on the season, you may be able to go fishing for the elusive trucha and make your own trout dish.&lt;br&gt;\u2022 &nbsp;And sometimes the best thing to do is just sit back in a hammock and enjoy the view of the valley from whichever hostel or living arrangement you decide on, while sipping some coffee.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.doitnow.co.za\/content\/coffee-tour-keeps-you-pedalling-more?utm_source=TotalSend&amp;utm_medium=Email&amp;utm_content=Subscriber%2323367&amp;utm_campaign=DO%20IT%20NOW%20Weekly%207%20Nov%202014\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;DO IT NOW&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Summertime and the Livin\u2019 is Easy\u2026&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Summertime and the Livin\u2019 is Easy\u2026  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Summertime and the Livin\u2019 is Easy\u2026\" class=\"rdf-meta
