href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/PE%20Main.jpg?itok=gzYl8-21\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/summertime-and-livin\u2019-easy\u2026\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/summertime-and-livin\u2019-easy\u2026\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/summertime-and-livin\u2019-easy\u2026&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/PE%20Main.jpg&amp;description=Summertime and the Livin\u2019 is Easy\u2026\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/summertime-and-livin\u2019-easy\u2026\" data-text=\"Summertime and the Livin\u2019 is Easy\u2026\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/summertime-and-livin\u2019-easy\u2026\" data-title=\"Summertime and the Livin\u2019 is Easy\u2026\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Pics Shaen Adey, Lloyd Edwards, Michelle van Aardt, Sakkie du Preez, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.mype.co.za\"&gt;www.mype.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Despite its glorious beaches and magnificent mountain backdrop Port Elizabeth is often overlooked as an adventure holiday destination. But the Friendly City at the eastern end of the Garden Route has much to offer lovers of the outdoors. If you\u2019re heading there for a summer holiday add some of these adventures to your bucket list.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/PE%20PE%20beachfront.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Summertime or wintertime I think I\u2019d find livin\u2019 easy in the heart of Nelson Mandela Bay. Located on one of the most beautiful stretches of the South African coastline, backed by stunning mountains and gorges and with plenty of green lungs to hike, bike and run in, Port Elizabeth is the perfect playground for water babes and landlubbers alike.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Often billed as the Watersport Capital of Africa, the city is Mecca for sailors, windsurfers and kiteboarders and has a full calendar of local and international events.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/PE%20PE%20boat%20cruise.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Algoa Bay Yacht Club has hosted numerous continental and international sailing events including the J22 Worlds, Hobie 16 Worlds, Optimist Africans and Mirror Worlds. The 2007 Mirror Worlds were unique in that the same team won the Pre-Worlds regatta AND the World Championships; and it was an all-women team - Brits Anna Mackenzie and Holly Scott in Simply Gorgeous - to boot. (In sailing, men and women compete on an equal footing in most races.)&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The 60th 505 World Championships which will be held at Algoa Bay Yacht Club in March and South Africa's oldest offshore sailing race - the Vasco Da Gama - will finish off of the Shark Rock Pier at Hobie Beach (a great spot to watch the colourful sails year round) for the next three years.&nbsp;The 2015 race will start in Durban on 25 April and yachts to are expected to finish in Algoa Bay between 27 and 30 April.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/PE%20Andrew_Fourie_Chad_Bilsbury.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hobie Beach also plays host to various sailing and beach volleyball events as well as the annual Splash Festival and the swimming leg of the Standard Bank Ironman \u2013 both held in April.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A beachfront promenade makes access to the beaches easy. One of the most popular is the Blue Flag King's Beach, a fabulous stretch of golden sand that extends from the harbour wall to Humewood. Since it offers safe swimming it\u2019s popular with swimmers and bodysurfers while \u2018The Pipe\u2019 at Pollock Beach is a magnet for surfers. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/PE%20PE%20Promenade.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A catamaran cruise out with Raggy Charters is an absolute must-do to appreciate PE\u2019s magnificent coastal location and marine life. Three types of dolphin (bottlenose, common and humpback), Cape fur seals, Cape gannets, sharks, Bryde\u2019s and minke whales are seen year round, while during the whale watching season between early June and early January migratory humpback and southern right whales are found in the bay, often with calves. Trips out to see the African penguins on St Croix Island - the largest breeding colony of these endangered birds in the world \u2013 pelagic bird trips and cruises to Bird Island are among the cruise options.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/PE%20Diving%20PE%20HAERLEM%20Sakkie%20du%20Preez.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A little publicised fact is that Port Elizabeth offer some of the best, and most reliable scuba diving in the country thanks to a top-notch dive school, Pro-Dive and two very different dive destinations - the more sheltered Algoa Bay and the aptly named Wildside to the west of Cape Recife. Nutrient-rich cold water coming up from the Cape meets the warm waters brought down the east coast by the Agulhas Current in the making for a diverse marine life. There\u2019s plenty for both novice and advanced divers including pretty coral and sponge-encrusted reefs, deep pinnacles, shipwrecks, shark encounters and wonderful little critters. A bonus of diving the Wildside is that the boat ride out offers spectacular views of the bay and a good chance of spotting dolphins and whales.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/PE%20Diving%20Thunderbolt-%20Michelle%20v%20Aardt.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hikers and trail runners are spoilt for choice. With its dramatic surrounding mountains, magnificent coastline and green urban spaces PE has a wealth of hiking trails from easy strolls along the promenade to stiff walks in the nearby nature reserves; and most of them are free!&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Top trails include the magnificent Sacramento trail through the Schoenmakerskop-Sardinia Bay Nature Reserve. A large cannon salvaged from the wreck of the Sacramento, a Portuguese galleon that ran onto the rocks in 1647, marks the trailhead, then the easy 8km trail follows the coast to the lovely sandy beach of Cannon Bay and on to Sardinia Bay - another great swimming spot so pack your bathers. From there the path climbs to the ridgeline and completes the circle through dune vegetation and fynbos back to the start. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/PE%20PE%20Hiking%202%20copy.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another stunner, the easy 9km Roseate Tern Hiking Trail, winds its way through the beautiful Cape Recife Nature Reserve on the southern tip of Algoa Bay. With its attractive black and white lighthouse, diverse birdlife, pristine fynbos, rock pools and unspoilt beaches the circular hike is a fantastic family outing that is very popular with birders.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;One of the best short trails is the Humpback Dolphin Trail (an extension of the beachfront promenade) from Flat Rocks to Pollock Beach. Open to walkers, runners and cyclists it is lit up at night, so is great for an evening stroll. Most of the trail is along a raised boardwalk and the high vantage on the dunes means that there are superb views over the rocky coastline from the walkway. Keep your eyes peeled for dolphins, including the trail\u2019s namesake, and a host of sea birds including African black oystercatchers and both Caspian and common terns.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/PE%20NJ%20PE%20Hiking1.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Many of the hiking trails can also be explored on two wheels while the purpose-built Norm Hudlin Mountain-Bike Trails in the Kragga Kamma area offer trails to suit all levels of ability. And then there\u2019s fishing, 4x4, game viewing and a host of other adventures in the city and its environs. But these should do you for starters.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/9140\"&gt;Raggy Charters&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2230\"&gt;Big Blue Ocean Tour&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/1470\"&gt;Port Elizabeth Diving&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3068\"&gt;Sacramento Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3067\"&gt;Roseate Tern Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/3709\"&gt;Humpback Dolphin Trail&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/2128\"&gt;Norm-Hudlin MTB Trail&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2015-1\/PE%20PE%20Roseate%20tern%20Pic%20Lloyd%20Edwards.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9003\" class=\"publisher-2809 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/road-nowhere\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Road to Nowhere&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Road to Nowhere  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Road to Nowhere\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.hsm.co.za\/magazines\/details\/cape-etc' target='_blank' style='background-color: #ffffff' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/capeetclogo.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/McGregor%201.jpg?itok=eKg45VVh\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/road-nowhere\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/road-nowhere\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/road-nowhere&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/McGregor%201.jpg&amp;description=Road to Nowhere\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/road-nowhere\" data-text=\"Road to Nowhere\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/road-nowhere\" data-title=\"Road to Nowhere\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Jade Cooke, Pics Kendall-Leigh Nash\/HSMimages&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It was the ducks\u2019 fault. A snowy-feathered, orange-beaked congregation of them was gathered far too picturesquely around the pond at Lord\u2019s Guest Lodge for us to simply pass by after finishing breakfast. Many snaps of the smartphone camera later, we were running quite behind schedule for the blink-and-you\u2019ll-miss-it McGregor Saturday morning market.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018Don\u2019t be silly!\u2019 admonishes Heidi Muller, our impromptu welcome wagon from the McGregor Tourism office, as we rush on to the village green spilling apologies. \u2018You\u2019re on McGregor time now \u2013 there\u2019s no such thing as late.\u2019 She\u2019s right, of course. All of South Africa\u2019s small towns offer a much-needed return to the slow lane, but McGregor has it down to a fine art.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When we\u2019d arrived the previous evening just before sunset, not a soul was about. Laid out in a neat grid just five streets wide, the town itself took all of 30 minutes to meander around, including stopping to admire all the beautifully preserved Victorian cottages and iceberg roses in every second garden. A tumbleweed floating down Voortrekker Street, the main drag, made me wonder if this wasn\u2019t some elaborate village-wide practical joke. Then, on the next corner, three teenage boys who wouldn\u2019t have looked out of place at a nightclub were racing home-made go-karts down the hill, the anachronism so much more convincing than any marketing spiel about slow living ever could be.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/McGregor%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In comparison to the previous night\u2019s desolation, this morning\u2019s market is practically bustling. In the shadow of the town\u2019s church steeple we load up with home-made lemon cordial, Jerusalem artichokes, tree tomatoes and fresh greens, labneh, p\u00e2t\u00e9, huge bags of pecans, a jar of honeyed almonds and freshly brewed ginger beer. The latter we can\u2019t help but pop open and sip as Heidi tells us how the town, originally called Lady Grey after the Cape governor\u2019s wife, was renamed in 1906 thanks to parishioners of the church we\u2019re standing beside, who wanted to honour their retiring pastor, one Reverend Andrew McGregor.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Since 10 am seems a little indiscreet to be visiting wineries, we do the next best thing: an organic, pressed grape juice tasting at Villagers, a bright, quirky little shop on Voortrekker that also functions as an outlet for Rhebokskraal Olive Estate, which is just outside of town. Pinotage, Cabernet and Hanepoot juice all feature, and you can while away a goodly amount of time with the array of tapenades and olive products available for tasting.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Across the road, Edna Fourie is opening up shop. McGregor is home to its fair share of artists, and its sweet 10-stop art route includes Edna\u2019s gallery. A successful and prolific oil painter, Edna made the decision some years ago to cease exhibiting all over the country, which she felt was diluting the message of her work, and instead launch her exclusive gallery in McGregor. The light-filled space is now home to a permanent display of her work as well as revolving sale pieces, including installation and sculpture.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/McGregor%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A little off the beaten Voortrekker track is Millstone Pottery, where Paul de Jongh can be found at the wheel every day of the week, surrounded by hundreds of his creations. One of few potters in South Africa who wood-fire their work, Paul will happily chat to you about his love for the medium, the beautiful unpredictability of working with fire, and the perfection of a flaw.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Half an hour later, we\u2019ve given up on appearances and are bumping along the dirt road to Lord\u2019s Wines. One of five estates on the relatively small McGregor wine route (the others being Buffalo Creek, Kingsriver, McGregor Winery and Tanagra), Lord\u2019s enjoys a cool climate thanks to its position 500m above sea level, &nbsp;and produces some award-winning pinot noir as a result. We\u2019re lucky enough to be met by owner Jacie Oosthuizen, who treats us to a barrel tasting \u2013 the only downside being that we can\u2019t take any of his delicious oak-aged Shiraz home with us.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Were you to follow the road further, past Lord\u2019s, you\u2019d get ... nowhere. Between 1865 and 1880, work was begun on a road to connect McGregor to Greyton, on the other side of the Boesmanskloof Pass. They didn\u2019t get very far (to put it mildly) before running out of money, and though an attempt was made in the \u201920s to revive the project, it has never been completed. To leave McGregor, you need to do an about-face and head back the way you came, down Voortrekker and along the mountain-flanked road to Robertson. It\u2019s a delightful notion, really, that road to nowhere, and one so fitting with this shy yet bountiful town. McGregor is the end of the road \u2013 at one and the same time a welcoming hearth and an invitation to wander off the beaten path in search of something a little different. If you\u2019re feeling energetic, there is a footpath leading from the unfinished road to a lovely little waterfall, or you can hike the Boesmanskloof Pass over into Greyton.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/McGregor%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;With a wine tasting behind us and rain on the horizon, we opt not to hike today. Heading back into town, one of the busiest and most central attractions is, somewhat incongruously, a spiritual haven. A lovely accommodation option from which to explore the area, Temenos is probably best known for its silent retreats and wellness options, from massage and yoga to the more esoteric jin shin jyutsu and rune reading. The estate occupies an entire block, most of which is dedicated to beautiful gardens of the meandering path variety. Interspersed in the lush foliage are benches for contemplation and \u2013 in typically open-minded Temenos fashion \u2013 places of worship for a variety of religions, including a tiny chapel with blue windows and purple walls called Temore, the inner temple of the heart. After a long soul-restoring wander in the gardens and an hour\u2019s deep tissue massage under the healing hands of Deidre Scott-Rogerson, my own heart\u2019s temple must surely be filled with song.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;So much art and culture can be thirsty work, but if there\u2019s one thing a small town does well, it\u2019s a cosy pub, and McGregor\u2019s Old Post Office doesn\u2019t disappoint. There\u2019s an impressive selection of whiskies (likely a nod to the town\u2019s tenuous Scottish connections) but we opt instead for Saggy Stone, a fruity local craft brew.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018It\u2019s my birthday, you know,\u2019 John, the grey-haired Manchurian proprietor, tells us as we settle on stools, pints in hand. \u2018Let\u2019s drink to that.\u2019&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A swallow.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018Only joking, no it\u2019s not. But maybe we can drink to it not being my birthday. We drink to everythin\u2019 aroun\u2019 here: birthdays, funerals, weddings, divorces, Tuesday...\u2019&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/McGregor%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Drinking may be a fond hobby, but food is taken quite seriously in McGregor. If you\u2019re here for but a weekend, phone ahead to book dinner at Tebaldi\u2019s (attached to Temenos) and Karoux, because in true small-town style, both have extremely limited seating.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The philosophy at the latter is a return to the time when the family table always had space for one more, and the cosy dining room couldn\u2019t be more in keeping with it. Then there\u2019s ex-Capetonian couple Aim\u00e9e van Hecke and Ryan Josten, who run the operation almost single-handedly \u2013 think of them as Karoux\u2019s mom and dad.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u2018Luckily we have a lady in the kitchen who washes the dishes at the end of the night!\u2019 says Aimee, who manages front of house (including waiting on the handful of tables) while Ryan makes the magic happen in the kitchen \u2013 small-town feel, big-city flavour. They have a weekly changing menu, and not just because blackboards are in vogue: every Wednesday, the couple visits the surrounding farms to source the best possible local produce for dinner service Thursday to Monday, which is almost always fully booked.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A generous portion of mussels and a superb duck confit later, I can\u2019t help but compare the lively buzz of Karoux to the deserted streets and shut-up doors of our arrival. As it turns out, most of McGregor had been tucked up at Wahnfried, a private house on the edge of town that functions as a cultural centre, for the Friday night film screening.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;That\u2019s the thing about McGregor. There are no bright lights, no aggressive marketing campaigns, no in-your-face tourism infrastructure. Half the time you can\u2019t even find the town\u2019s denizens. But as you scratch the surface, its layers \u2013 and its people \u2013 start to reveal themselves to you.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If this is the road to nowhere, then nowhere\u2019s where I want to be.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/McGregor%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"771\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;LINGER LONGER&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;STAY&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Surrounded by rolling fynbos as far as the eye can see, with McGregor twinkling in the distance, &lt;strong&gt;Lord\u2019s Guest Lodge&lt;\/strong&gt; still somehow feels like an escape to the Scottish highlands. Choose between the four executive free-standing cottages or book a luxury room in the main house, all of which come standard with fireplaces to keep the winter chill out. If you\u2019d prefer to be in the village proper, the self-catering 26B Van Reenan (the clue is in the name) sleeps five and offers a modern interior, beautiful gardens and a lap pool.&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;023 625 1881, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/lordsguestlodge.co.za\"&gt;http:\/\/lordsguestlodge.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; &lt;\/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;(All accommodation in the area can be booked free of charge through &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.tourismmcgregor.co.za\"&gt;www.tourismmcgregor.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;.) &lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;TASTE&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A boutique wine farm just outside the village,&lt;strong&gt; Tanagra&lt;\/strong&gt;\u2019s real appeal is its \u2018marc\u2019 \u2013 what would be called grappa, if the Italians hadn\u2019t claimed sole rights to the name. German couple Robert and Anette Rosenbach will lead you in a wonderfully relaxed tasting to discover the intricacies of this fiery spirit.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;023 625 1780, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.tanagra-wines.co.za\"&gt;www.tanagra-wines.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;EXPLORE&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The rugged landscape of &lt;strong&gt;Vrolijkheid Nature Reserve&lt;\/strong&gt;, on the road between Robertson and McGregor, is home to 175 bird species, including the jackal buzzard, pale chanting goshawk and the African fish eagle, as well as a number of small buck. Take the fairly flat, three-kilometre Heron Trail to the reserve\u2019s two dams, each of which have a hide, or grab your day pack and tackle the more strenuous 18 km Rooikat Trail through the Elandsberg mountains.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;023 625 1671, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.capenature.co.za\"&gt;www.capenature.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A new addition to the town\u2019s line-up of activities, &lt;strong&gt;guided cycling tours&lt;\/strong&gt; of the surrounding area can now be booked through McGregor Tourism. Routes include the Vrolijkheid Nature Reserve, Old Robertson Road, Rhebokskraal Road, Strykhoogte Pass and McGregor Hills, and you can even hire bikes from the tourism office for a small fee. Or enter the three-day Road2Nowhere mountain bike challenge, from 12 to 14 September 2014.&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.tourismmcgregor.co.za\"&gt;www.tourismmcgregor.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;REVIVE&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Described as \u2018a tranquil haven for the broken-spirited, both human and animal\u2019, &lt;strong&gt;Eseltjiesrus Donkey Sanctuary&lt;\/strong&gt; is home to some 20 rehabilitated equines who will muscle their way into your heart before you know it. Be sure to seek out blonde-maned Dowe Dolla to rest your face on her pillow-soft forelock, before retiring to the on-site restaurant for anything from pancakes to lamb shank.&nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;em&gt;023 625 1593, &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.donkeysanctuary.co.za\"&gt;www.donkeysanctuary.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/apphau5.com\/e-editions\/e-reader\/954\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Cape Etc&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/5533\"&gt;&lt;br&gt;Tanagra Wine and Guest Farm&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/778\"&gt;Vrolijkheid Nature Reserve&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.hsm.co.za\/magazines\/details\/cape-etc\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/CET3_Oct_2014_web_317_379.jpg?itok=4XVZpmV_\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;Cape Etc&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9027\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/new-year%E2%80%99s-resolution-%E2%80%93-be-extra-kind-your-best-friend\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;New Year\u2019s resolution \u2013 be extra kind to your best friend.&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    New Year\u2019s resolution \u2013 be extra kind to your best friend.  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"New Year\u2019s resolution \u2013 be extra kind to your best friend.\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Lennie.jpg?itok=RRUvampW\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/new-year\u2019s-resolution-\u2013-be-extra-kind-your-best-friend\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n friend.\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Try as you may, very few New Year\u2019s resolutions make it past the first few weeks, and almost none survive beyond midyear. We suspect it\u2019s because most of these resolutions are like broccoli. Good for you, but not exactly Christmas pudding!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This year, we have decided to make it a little easier on ourselves. We have chosen a resolution that should not only by be easy to uphold, but fun to boot. Our resolution is to be kind to our best friends. Although, it is perhaps closer to the truth to say: kinder than usual.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We have had these two little mutts for nine years, and over that time they have become an inseparable part of the Nightjar household. Here are a few of our special moments:&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Beach walks are a special treat for these little \u2018mole hunters\u2019 \u2013 just so much sand to chase, or kelp to sniff.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/2%20Lennie%20Walker%20Bay%20Fisherman%27s%20Trail.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Mind you, mountain walks are just as much fun.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/3%20Roxy%20Betty%27s%20Bay.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Not to mention the spring flowers.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/4%20Lennie%20Balloch.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Making sure we are safe from marauding ostriches\u2026&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/4%20Lennie%20Witsand.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;And, of course, lending a hand with the fishing.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/5%20Roxy%20Fishing%204.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Although, sometimes a little help is required.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/6%20Roxy%20Fishing%203.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Hey boss, let's go get another one!&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/7%20Roxy%20Fishing.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;But, all things considered, just cruising along is probably the best of all.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Roxy.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9023\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/south-african-adventurers-set-conquer-antarctic-peak\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;South African Adventurers Set to Conquer Antarctic Peak&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    South African Adventurers Set to Conquer Antarctic Peak  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"South African Adventurers Set to Conquer Antarctic Peak\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Antarctic%201.jpg?itok=UQHoUkQU\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/south-african-adventurers-set-conquer-antarctic-peak\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/south-african-adventurers-set-conquer-antarctic-peak\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/south-african-adventurers-set-conquer-antarctic-peak&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Antarctic%201.jpg&amp;description=South African Adventurers Set to Conquer Antarctic Peak\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/south-african-adventurers-set-conquer-antarctic-peak\" data-text=\"South African Adventurers Set to Conquer Antarctic Peak\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/south-african-adventurers-set-conquer-antarctic-peak\" data-title=\"South African Adventurers Set to Conquer Antarctic Peak\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Jan 2015&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics courtesy &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/theunlimited.co.za\/twinpeaks\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;The Unlimited&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To conquer a mountain that has never been climbed in conditions that are brutally cold \u2013 is it sheer madness or is it inspirational? Whatever your view, in January 2015 it will become a reality for a group of five South Africans when they set out for Antarctica to make history by climbing both Mount Vinson \u2013 the highest peak on the frozen continent \u2013 as well as an unnamed peak that has never been climbed.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Twin Peaks Expedition is the brainchild of the founders of the financial services company The Unlimited; Iain, Zack and Barney Buchan. The father and sons team will be joined by veteran arctic explorer Dr Peter Berning and Ken Watt. The five adventurers will first tackle Mount Vinson, the coldest and most remote of the world-renowned Seven Summits, then take on a virgin peak in Antarctica\u2019s Ellsworth Mountains.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The daunting quest to tackle two Antarctica summits was born during the team\u2019s successful journey to the South Pole two years ago. &nbsp;Iain Buchan explains: \u201cDuring our trek, we knew that we had to return to Antarctica. It is a cruel and harsh environment but within that sits a pristine beauty unlike anywhere on Earth. Trekking to the South Pole is a trial that pushes your mind and body to its limits, but Mount Vinson is the ultimate test. So we have taken up the challenge and decided that whilst we are there, we will really push ourselves by adding an unclimbed peak into the mix too!\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Antarctic%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is this mindset of pushing boundaries that became the foundation on which The Unlimited has been built. Twenty years later, it is a highly successful direct marketing business that is invested in developing leaders. \u201cWe have always been a \u2018show and not tell\u2019 business and hence, we will be forging new pathways on the most extreme continent on Earth. On our trek to the South Pole we learnt that leadership really comes to the fore in such extreme circumstances. When you take yourself out of your comfort zone, that\u2019s when you really stretch and grow. That\u2019s why we are going back \u2013 to force our own personal growth to the next level,\u201d Buchan explains.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In an icy wilderness such as Antarctica, people underestimate the mental strength that is required \u2013 there are no trees, no animals, just endless white ice, average temperatures of -30\u00b0C and 24 hours of daylight. Your physical preparation is the only thing you can control.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Unlimited Twin Peaks Expedition team have therefore taken their fitness very seriously. Through a tough training regime, they are all stronger than ever before. Buchan says: &nbsp;\u201cThis is not a trip where you can build fitness as you climb so the whole team has been training 4 to 5 times a week, pulling 20kg tyres, kettle bell training in the gym and climbing mountains whenever possible. Peter and myself have not been as fit are we are now since we played rugby for UCT in the 1970s! Even with this level of preparation though, we still expect both summits to be a huge challenge for everyone in the team.\u201d &nbsp; &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At 4 892m, Mount Vinson should not be a difficult peak to climb; but the combination of its remoteness, high winds and extremely low temperatures make the peak an incredibly tough climb. Even colder than Mount Everest, the average temperature for Mount Vinson can plummet to around -50\u00b0C and these biting wind-chill temperatures are the greatest threat to climbers.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;\u201cDepending on conditions, the Mount Vinson climb can take anywhere from four days to two weeks. Climbing is slow as the terrain is pocketed with lethal crevasses, so we will have to be roped together all the time. Frequent breaks are essential as we will also be dragging 20kg sledges with our equipment and sufficient provisions for the 14 days,\u201d says Buchan. \u201cThe second peak is expected to take around four days but it will be a very different climb as the terrain is completely unknown, virgin territory.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;According to Steph Bester, CEO of The Unlimited, the company has put its weight behind the expedition as it dovetails with the business ethos. &nbsp;\u201cThis amazing attempt is extreme enough for us to put our name to \u2013 we believe in doing the extraordinary and these adventurers will achieve just that as The Unlimited Twin Peaks Expedition will push the limits of ordinary human endurance,\u201d stated Bester.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Unlimited Twin Peaks Expedition will start on Friday, 26 December 2014 when the team will travel from South Africa to Puntas Arenas in southern Chile. After a compulsory briefing on Antarctica, they will take a six-hour flight to the frozen continent followed by an immediate transfer to the Vinson Base Camp. After a couple of days acclimatising, weather permitting, they will start their ascent on 5 January 2015.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To follow the amazing journey of The Unlimited Twin Peaks Expedition and the regular updates from the team, visit &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.theunlimited.co.za\/twinpeaks\"&gt;www.theunlimited.co.za\/twinpeaks&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n
