src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9022\" class=\"publisher-1944 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/straight-horse%E2%80%99s-mouth\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Straight from the Horse\u2019s Mouth&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Straight from the Horse\u2019s Mouth  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Straight from the Horse\u2019s Mouth\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/The-Intrepid-Explorer-logo2.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Anna%201.jpg?itok=NLxybrEI\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/straight-horse\u2019s-mouth\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/straight-horse\u2019s-mouth\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/straight-horse\u2019s-mouth&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Anna%201.jpg&amp;description=Straight from the Horse\u2019s Mouth\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/straight-horse\u2019s-mouth\" data-text=\"Straight from the Horse\u2019s Mouth\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/straight-horse\u2019s-mouth\" data-title=\"Straight from the Horse\u2019s Mouth\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Dec 2014&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;By Shan Routledge&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Many of us, as children, would\u2019ve wished we could speak to animals: hear the whispers of owls in the night, the frantic chattering of monkeys at play, the solemn wisdom of majestic elephants or just the (hopefully) adoring love of our dog. Slowly we lost this yearning to communicate with our environment and allowed the sounds to fade into the background \u2013 but Anna Breytenbach can hear them loud and clear, and she\u2019s going to deliver their message.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;blockquote&gt;\u201cThe animals often appeal to me for help, but I have to tell them that help isn\u2019t coming.\u201d&lt;\/blockquote&gt;&lt;p&gt;Before I saw Anna\u2019s documentary, &lt;em&gt;The Animal Communicator&lt;\/em&gt;, I was sceptical of the idea. How could she have this ability? But as I watched the film, I was slowly won over to the idea that we have simply forgotten our innate connection with the world around us.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Admittedly, I shed a tear or three as sanctuary owner Jurg Olsen, who had asked Anna for help with his black leopard named \u201cDiablo\u201d (\u201cDevil\u201d in Spanish), broke down in sobs when the animal emerged from his shelter to greet him. There was no way Anna could have known beforehand the information she got from Diablo (who was renamed \u201cSpirit\u201d) about his abusive past, and Olsen was astounded by the difference she was able to make.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;A professional animal communicator, Anna has dedicated her life to bridging the gap between human and non-human communication. Whether it be through communication, guidance or mentoring, her goal is to create increased awareness, empathy, compassion and mutual understanding. The animals have something to say, and Anna is listening.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Anna%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Did you always have this connection with animals?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I spent my high school holidays volunteering at the local vet or animal shelter, so I always had a care and compassion for animals \u2013 but I wasn\u2019t aware of any information passing between us at all. In animal care situations, there was always emotion passing between us, but nothing that would stand out to me as actual data or actual communication.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It was only later in life when I was on a tracking course in America and - because I grew up in South Africa and not in North America - I had no idea what had made the footprints I was looking at. No matter how clear the print in the mud was, I couldn\u2019t identify to which animal it belonged.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;So, the tracking guide said: \u201cJust close your eyes and hold your hand over the print.\u201d I didn\u2019t have any better ideas, so that is what I did \u2013 and as I did, I got this distinct image of quite a pointy sort of dog face and greyer than our jackal at home, but not as red as a fox. I described this to the guide and he said: \u201cYes, that is a coyote.\u201d I promptly asked, \u201cWhat is a coyote?\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;What\u2019s more, this happened at about eight in the morning when I saw this face against the backdrop of a hollowed-out hole in a sandbank; after about two hours of actually physically trailing the tracks, we found the exact spot I had seen in this mental image. The expert trackers were able to determine that the tracks were about two hours old, which meant I had been getting real-time information at eight in the morning. I was actually connecting with that coyote where it was at that present moment. That is when I realised it was a real-life connection.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;It must have been quite a shock to receive such an image?&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Very much so. I had no placing for it in my mind or in my upbringing or in my belief system. If it wasn\u2019t so provable by the actual tracks I was seeing, I might not have had to accept it was real. I honestly would have thought I was going mad and seeing things, but some research proved I wasn\u2019t the only one.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I was then pushed to follow it further and to research telepathic interspecies communication, which led me to study through the Assisi International Animal Institute and follow my intuition and passion.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Anna%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Why do you think you have developed this ability when the rest of humanity has been left so unaware of the connection?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Everyone can do this. Everyone does do this, normally, in respect to other humans. The anomaly telepathy, or intuition, works between people who are very close \u2013 best friends or sibling \u2013 so we can all do it.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If 10 people had all tried to sense that track, they might not all have gotten the same image or received the information in the same way or strength, but they all would have connected with the coyote in some way.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the weekend workshops I run around the world, 100% of participants have success in receiving information from an animal telepathically.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;So anyone can learn to engage in this manner?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Yes, anyone can do it because it is more about remembering than learning; it is part of the blueprint of our minds; it is how our brains were designed. And it is how all the ancient cultures, from which all modern humans derive, have connected with their animals, landscapes and surrounds. It is part of our brain; we just have to place our attention there again and remember to use our skills \u2013 or our sixth sense, so to speak. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;You are very involved in conservation \u2013 this must be a very rewarding use of your talent. With which organisations do you work?&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is both very rewarding and very challenging. There are no organisations with which I work because conservation managers, wildlife managers and park officials don\u2019t believe in telepathic communication. Because they come from the very biological and scientific study of animals, they do not embrace an energetic communication.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;There are some wildlife rescue and rehabilitation centres that are beginning to contact me to assist them, but mostly my &lt;em&gt;pro bono&lt;\/em&gt; work with conservation is with individuals who, when everything else more ordinary has failed, reach out to the telepathic community to try and solve a very serious issue or better understand an animal\u2019s behaviour.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Anna%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019m currently working with a couple of elephants that are trying to break out of various reserves in South Africa \u2013 trying to understand what their traumas are and trying to have the humans hear what they need in order to persuade them to stay. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I work with some re-wilding projects where big cats are rescued from the canned breeding and canned hunting industry, and in some cases are given the opportunity to live wild or semi-wild again. It is a long, dedicated effort on the part of their carers to re-wild them, and there we use telecommunication to try and help educate the lions about how to be safe out in the wild and to manage the process \u2013 check in with them about how they are feeling. It is very difficult work. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I also work with baboons that are under serious threat throughout southern Africa. The authorities on the Cape Peninsula are basically exterminating them, with more than 50 having been killed this year alone. It can be very frustrating and challenging when I\u2019m constantly receiving \u2013 directly from the baboons \u2013 their real feelings of distress and panic and lack of space; that can be challenging because I know nothing is going to change politically or management-wise.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The animals often appeal to me for help, but I have to tell them that help isn\u2019t coming. Quite often it is a bit of a stalemate situation when I hear how animals are feeling and what they need, but the humans to whom I give the feedback don\u2019t care what the animals need. I then have to go back to the animals and say, \u201cSorry, it\u2019s not going to happen\u201d. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Part of the journey of being an animal communicator is having to be very clear within myself about what the animals\u2019 emotions are versus what my emotions may be or my reactions to what they are going through. I have to be very clear that I don\u2019t project onto them or anthropomorphise, and to relay only what they are thinking or feeling, without clouding the picture with my own opinions on the matter.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Part of the training requires you to do a lot of work on yourself \u2013 and always keep working on yourself. I always have to clear the channel I\u2019m in, so that I can be true to the animals\u2019 authentic message \u2013 not even unwittingly clouding it with my judgments and preconceptions. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Anna%205.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Do you get much resistance from other professionals such as conservationists?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;There is still a lot of resistance from park managers and wildlife reserves, mainly because they objectify animals and see them only as resources on an asset register. Most of southern Africa is an industry of breeding and trading wildlife, so they are not really interested in the emotional wellbeing of the animals or their environmental enrichment. They don\u2019t care that when you have to move adult giraffe off of a reserve, there are no trucks big enough to take the males, so they just shoot them and take only the females and the youngsters.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It doesn\u2019t suit wildlife reserves to truly know an animal\u2019s thoughts and feelings, preferences and needs. This would make it more difficult to trade them and treat them purely as resources. It\u2019s what suits the industry, the safaris, sports hunting, human ideas of what would be pleasing to stock a reserve with; it\u2019s what pleases human ideas of rarity such as black springbok and white lions \u2013 all based on human aesthetics and human need, with little regard for the animals.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It is sometimes very difficult to express what animals are thinking or feeling to authorities and people, but I have a moral obligation. If I have heard something from an animal, it is my duty to pass it on unedited. If I\u2019m worried about how I\u2019m going to come across, then it\u2019s me getting in the way of expressing the animal\u2019s authentic truth. If I say less than the full truth to people, then I\u2019m denying the people the opportunity to consider another perspective. Often I\u2019m the \u2018messenger who gets shot\u2019, but that is just the fine print of what comes with my job.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;How do you deal with critics and naysayers?&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;I\u2019m not trying to convert anyone to my way of thinking, so I don\u2019t have to deal with criticism; the science of how this works speaks for itself, and I refer people to that if they question it.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I try and invite people to have their own experience, but I\u2019m not out to try and force anyone into it \u2013 they either want to connect or they don\u2019t. People are scared because it\u2019s not happening in the realm of their five senses, and people fear what they cannot see.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;What is the most interesting thing you have ever been told by an animal?&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Quite recently, I was communicating with baboons that frequently raid a vegetable garden on a farm, and the humans called me in to ask them please to stop. The baboons conveyed they were confused about the fact that they saw humans coming into the vegetable garden, picking the best and the ripest vegetables when they were not hungry, and then leaving with the produce \u2013 which they wouldn\u2019t even eat. The baboons said they followed the humans and saw them taking the produce indoors and putting this wonderful bounty in strange cupboards, leaving it lying around inside. Often, some of that food would go bad before the humans would even eat it, which the baboons thought was very wasteful. I found it very interesting and refreshing to see the baboon perspective on human behaviour. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The cook on the farm admitted to being mildly freaked out by two male baboons watching him as he prepared food for the staff. He would even close the blinds because he was so disturbed, and this sort of corroborated what the baboons had been saying about how they were interested in what was happening to the food. &nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Animal communication is about finding out what the animals\u2019 needs and desires are, what motivates their behaviour \u2013 and then coming up with a compromise so that there can be a peaceful co-existence between animals and humans.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;The Intrepid Explorer&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.intrepidexplorer.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Intrepid%20Cover%20Dec.jpg?itok=fZr7i7kn\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;The Intrepid explorer&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-8704\" class=\"publisher-2745 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/sliver-simplicity\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;A Sliver of Simplicity&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    A Sliver of Simplicity  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"A Sliver of Simplicity\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.aa.co.za\/shop\/aa-traveller' target='_blank' style='background-color: #000000' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/AA-traveller1.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Wild%20Coast%201.jpg?itok=l0AtSptB\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sliver-simplicity\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sliver-simplicity\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sliver-simplicity&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Wild%20Coast%201.jpg&amp;description=A Sliver of Simplicity\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sliver-simplicity\" data-text=\"A Sliver of Simplicity\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/sliver-simplicity\" data-title=\"A Sliver of Simplicity\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Dec 2014&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words &amp; pics Mark Samuel&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In more than 20 years, nothing had changed. Okay, perhaps this time around there were some locals with cellphones here and there hunting for that elusive one bar of signal (mobile phones, thankfully, didn\u2019t exist in the \u201990s). But, besides that, I\u2019d stepped back into one of my barefoot&nbsp;childhood holidays on the Wild Coast.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;More than two decades had passed and the place was still the same: remote, electricity-less (or Eskom-less, at least), gravel-roaded, thatch-hutted and graced with endless unspoilt golden beaches \u2026 All so simple, and yet breathtakingly beautiful. And, like my dad always did, I was&nbsp;sporting a ragged beard that was to become even shaggier during my stay. Not shaving was an unspoken pact my father shared with his mates during our annual Transkei winter holidays back in the day. Now it was my turn to continue the tradition.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This exquisite sliver of Eastern Cape coastline is a region of contrasts. Geographically, it is pure secluded splendour; socio-economically, it is strikingly poor. So, when I heard a small group of locals were involved in a community-run lodge in the heart of the Wild Coast, I had to check it out&nbsp;for myself.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bulungula eco-lodge serves two roles. It\u2019s a rustic, unpretentious spot where South Africans and foreigners alike can immerse themselves in the natural beauty and laidback lifestyle of the region; and it\u2019s a small business that provides opportunities for members of the surrounding community to involve themselves in tourism, earning an income and providing for their families. I certainly didn\u2019t need any more reasons to visit.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;As if materialising from my memory bank right before my eyes, the roads down to the Wild Coast \u2013 at least once you turn off the tar road that heads to Coffee Bay \u2013 are, well, wild. They form a convoluted network of gravel routes that meander past vast tracts of open land, traditional Xhosa huts and kraals, groups of adults and children, goats, dogs, cattle and stout little roaming black pigs. The scenes outside the car window represent a way of life that\u2019s changed little over the years.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Wild%20Coast%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Calling Bulungula a \u2018lodge\u2019 really stretches the definition of the word. Don\u2019t go there expecting chocolates on your pillow at night \u2013 it\u2019s nothing like that. It\u2019s more of a backpackers, blended with a healthy dollop of local-style hospitality. Accommodation takes the form of permanent tents on timber platforms in the coastal forest (just about overlooking the ocean) or traditional dung-floored and thatch-roofed Xhosa huts (each with a single solar-powered electric light), or you can set up your own tent. Ablutions are rudimentary \u2013 indoor compost toilets (which, admittedly, take a degree of getting used to) basins for tooth brushing, hand washing and face splashing, and one of the highlights of my stay \u2013 rocket showers. Your eyebrows are raised, I\u2019m sure. Let\u2019s just say the&nbsp;components include paraffin, matches and toilet paper for ignition, and around seven minutes of hot-water bliss.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Whatever your choice of lodgings, be sure to keep your luggage light, as this place is so idyllically remote the road doesn\u2019t quite reach it. Upon summiting the last of many, many hills on your journey to the coast, you descend into a valley, from where the smudge of a cluster of buildings in the distance is almost out of sight. A fenced-off parking area awaits, where a security guard keeps watch for the duration of your stay. Everything here is perfectly safe, I\u2019m told. It\u2019s then a roughly 700m walk along a grassy track to Bulungula, which is tucked away behind the&nbsp;coastal forest and just up the bank from and overlooking a small tidal estuary. The entire set-up looks northwards along a stretch of golden beach which culminates in towering, grassy hills in the distance, glazed with dark, jagged rocks, against which the fierce ocean swells crash day and night, and have done so for millennia. The scene is classic Wild Coast \u2013 and probably the most fundamental reason anyone should visit.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;You can self-cater, provided your cooler box co-operates. The communal kitchen is open to all guests and you can stow a few perishables in the fridges. Alternatively, buy your meals from the lodge; you tick off which ones you\u2019d like and, come breakfast, lunch or dinnertime, you\u2019ll certainly&nbsp;not go hungry. Drinks can be purchased in the same manner \u2013 it\u2019s effectively an honesty system, with you settling your tab just before you leave. Isn\u2019t that refreshing?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-2\/Wild%20Coast%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At Bulungula, you can keep yourself busy in two ways. Either sign up for one of a multitude of guided activities or head off on your own mission. Our five days were a blend of relaxed (read: lazy) mornings spent watching the waves crash, with coffee and rusks in hand; long beach&nbsp;hikes (with daypacks filled with bananas, peanuts and a few refreshments of the hops variety); swimming in the estuary; and a brave bid to surf the enticing waves in the bay. Day hikes are mesmerising \u2013 the views of remote landscape and wild ocean really are like nowhere else in South Africa (in this case, a promise, not just a turn of phrase).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, letting someone else plan your day for your can also be fun. While the people of Nqileni village have 40% ownership in the lodge itself, the small businesses that offer various activities to the guests are 100% community owned. You can go horse riding, canoeing or fishing, or even try your hand at wood-carving, baking, sewing and cooking traditional dishes. Or, if you\u2019d like some pampering, two of the local women have been trained as masseuses \u2013 the knots in my&nbsp;shoulders really appreciated the treatment! (There\u2019s a small cost involved for each activity you sign up for. I found it was important to ask, as all of the options and arrangement weren\u2019t clear.)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Bulungula is a clich\u00e9d backpackers in many ways \u2013 murals on the walls, djembe drumming in the evenings and a cosmopolitan mix of accents from guests come dinnertime \u2013 but that\u2019s an observation rather than a criticism, as it all fits in so seamlessly in this tucked-away spot and definitely doesn\u2019t feel contrived. The \u2018eco\u2019 in the name is also authentic. Here, it means using less, impacting less, harnessing what\u2019s naturally supplied to us and re-using \u2013 perhaps a notion we all&nbsp;need a little more of in our daily lives.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Wild Coast is a region every South African should visit (well, more than just visit \u2013 explore, adventure in, fall in love with!) But arrive without your ego, without preconceived expectations and get ready to be nudged out of your comfort zone and into a different, simpler way of living.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;hr&gt;&lt;h2&gt;GOOD TO KNOW&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;When to go&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The Wild Coast is an all-year-round destination, however, it can receive a lot of rain during the middle of summer (December and January). Winter is chilly at night, but the days can be picture perfect. Autumn is probably the best time to visit.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Getting there&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Take the Coffee Bay turnoff from the N2, 15km south (on the East London side) of Mthatha. It\u2019s then 50 km on tar, before taking a right turn. Another 16.5km on tar will lead you to a right turn, where about 35km of gravel road begins. From there, it\u2019s best to follow the detailed directions on the Bulungula website. If you drive slowly, you can make the trip in an ordinary 2WD vehicle.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What to take&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Pack relaxed clothing \u2013 a few T-shirts, shorts, a pair of old jeans, flip-flops, trainers and a swimming costume. No one will really care how you dress. And don\u2019t forget some warm clothes for the evenings and early mornings. Add in a towel and a torch. Also take all medication you might&nbsp;need \u2013 there aren\u2019t any shops close by. You can bring your own food and self-cater or enjoy three meals a day supplied by the lodge (prices are very reasonable).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Accommodation&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;At Bulungula you can stay in the permanent safari tents (which have double beds), the Xhosa huts&nbsp;(with a mix of single and\/or double beds) or you can camp (in your own three-person or smaller&nbsp;tent, no camper vehicles permitted).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Make contact&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;To enquire about bookings, or for detailed driving directions, get hold of Bulungula directly. Call 047 577 8900 or 083 391 5525, email &lt;a href=\"mailto:paradise@bulungula.com\"&gt;paradise@bulungula.com&lt;\/a&gt; or check out their website at &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.bulungula.com\"&gt;www.bulungula.com&lt;\/a&gt;.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;hr&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Holiday wheels&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;As if designed with this trip in mind, the new Peugeot 2008 is a blend of sizeable hatch-cum- SUV, with just the right amount of off-road ability. On loan from Peugeot, this spritely petrol derivative got us from Cape Town, down through the rough gravel routes of the Wild Coast, and back, with ease.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;It didn\u2019t complain once, and in fact seemed to come into its own when the tar ended. I flicked the dial on the centre console to \u2018all-terrain\u2019 and let the feisty little crossover do the rest. The 1.6L engine is economical (we averaged 7.3 L\/100km over nearly 3 000km), often covering vast distances at 120 km\/h on cruise control.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Our surfboards sat comfortably on the roof on a set of Thule roof racks that quickly and conveniently attached to the 2008\u2019s steadfast roof rails. There are a selection of racks in the Thule range, so you\u2019re sure to find the ones perfectly designed for your vehicle.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you\u2019re lucky enough to lead a lifestyle of city driving interspersed with regular adventure, this is the car-roof-rack combo for you.&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.peugeot.co.za\"&gt;www.peugeot.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.thule.co.za\"&gt;www.thule.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.aa.co.za\/shop\/aa-traveller\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;AA Traveller&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.aa.co.za\/shop\/aa-traveller\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img class=\"list-img\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Autumn%202014~3_0.jpg?itok=JN9a24Xy\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;      &lt;h2&gt;AA Traveller&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-9015\" class=\"publisher-1337 node node-article clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/slackline-over-victoria-falls\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Slackline Over Victoria Falls &lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Slackline Over Victoria Falls   &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Slackline Over Victoria Falls \" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='' target='_blank' style='background-color: #439bae' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/Magazine%20Strip%20Nightjar%202_0.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%201_0.jpg?itok=_KsvCQvM\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/slackline-over-victoria-falls\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/slackline-over-victoria-falls\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/slackline-over-victoria-falls&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%201_0.jpg&amp;description=Slackline Over Victoria Falls \" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/slackline-over-victoria-falls\" data-text=\"Slackline Over Victoria Falls \" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/slackline-over-victoria-falls\" data-title=\"Slackline Over Victoria Falls \"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Dec 2014&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Reinhard Kleindl, pics Jacques Marais - adidas.com\/outdoor&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The roar is deafening. Chilly clouds of fog waft around me, water is running down my face, collecting on my chin, soaking my T-shirt. Behind me is a wall of people, all full of anticipation. In front of me is a fence of interwoven brushwood. Beyond it, the landscape falls steeply away, into a hazy, black void. The other side is so far away that I can barely make it out.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Carefully, I climb over the fence, walk towards the cliff edge: suddenly, I am face to face with one of the largest waterfalls in the world.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I am in Zimbabwe, a country which is completely alien to me as a resident of the Alps: dry, sandy, vast. Ramrod-straight roads run for endless kilometres through lightly wooded areas, past termite mounds, dried-up riverbeds, small settlements of thatched mud huts and dirt football pitches whose goalposts have no nets. A lot of land for not many people.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Through the heart of this dry landscape flows the Zambezi, Africa\u2019s fourth-longest river, a blue artery.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Then, on the border between Zimbabwe and Zambia, there\u2019s an abyss which seems to appear from nowhere. Over time, Zambezi has formed a broad delta, more like a lake than a river, with countless green islands, before plunging suddenly downwards, over a width of just over a mile. A hundred metres below the water regroups and continues on its way through a vast canyon. The lazy flow has become a raging torrent. And the place where this unceremonious change takes place is considered one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the world: Victoria Falls, Mosi Oa Tunya in the national language, \u201cthe smoke that thunders\u201d.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Be careful what you wish for, as the saying goes. We are two friends who had a dream we couldn\u2019t let go of. A dream that excited and scared us at the same time, because it felt presumptuous; too big; destined to fail. We are Lukas Irmler from Freising and me, Reinhard Kleindl from Graz. Two friends who share the same passion: slacklining, a modern form of tightrope walking. Our dream: to cross the Victoria Falls on an inch-wide webbing of synthetic fibre.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We have been chasing this dream for more than two years. During this time, we have not just studied the Falls, observed watercourses, collected pictures and analysed diagrams of the water levels, but we have also got to know Africa. Lukas had already been here, but this continent was completely new territory for me. I had seen the pictures, knew the facts and figures, but none of that means very much. It was not until I came here and visited the Falls that I started to understand. The kind of people who live here, what makes them tick; different, yet strangely familiar at the same time.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We learned more about the history of the Falls, which had been known to the natives since time immemorial. The explorer David Livingstone became the first European to lay eyes on them, almost 159 years to the day before our quest, describing them as the most beautiful place in Africa. We get all of that. What we can\u2019t understand is why no tightrope walker has ever crossed them before. The Niagara Falls were crossed by high wire artistes as long ago as the 19th century, but the Victoria Falls - never. If we succeeded, we would be the first. The great tightrope walkers of the world have always inspired us; we follow in their footsteps, but in our own unique style.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Now, our dream seems to be within reach: I\u2019m standing on the edge of the canyon, with the Zambezi thundering into the depths in front of me. Next to me hangs our slackline, a rope bridge to the other side. I\u2019m connected to it by a safety rope, the leash my lifeline: if I lose control, it is this rope, the thickness of my finger, that will stop me from falling. Soon I will be crawling out and trying to stand up, so that I can balance across to the other side. The first person ever to do so if I can overcome my fears, my doubts.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I know this feeling. This is not my first highline, as slacklines over canyons are known, and it isn\u2019t even my first project with Lukas Irmler. We have both been involved in this sport for about eight years, helped to make it what it is today, grown up with it. When slacklining came over to Europe, we were both hooked on it to the point of obsession. Since then, we have done highlines in many different countries: Malaysia, Peru, Iran, Russia, South Africa, but in the Alps too: South Tyrol, southern France, even on skyscrapers. But we have never been involved in a project of this order of magnitude. The highline we have stretched across Victoria Falls, after many problems and a great deal of uncertainty, is 91m long and about a hundred metres above the ground. An inch-wide, a thread stretching away into nothingness. Gusts of wind and spray whip into it, setting the line swinging. Do I really want to go out there?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Despite my experience, I always have to fight down these fears and doubts, which are part of the sport, part of what attracts me to it. Whilst my brain is still looking for an exit clause, something in me takes over, calmly prepares me for the task at hand. Fasten the belts. Attach the leash. Steady my breathing. Check the knots, then, sitting down, head out onto the line and peer into the abyss for the first time. The roar of the water mass is breathtaking, my mind is overcome, overwhelmed, gives up all resistance. It\u2019s just sheer determination driving me forward. I shake the slackline, feel the weight of the soaking wet webbing, then I get into my starting position, stand up and begin to walk.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;All of the earlier difficulties are now forgotten: the fact that we weren\u2019t sure whether we were even up to the project, from a technical point of view. The canyon is about a hundred metres wide, almost the length of a football field, but when we fell in love with the project and started planning, only very few people in the world had ever crossed highlines this long. Compared to tightropes, highlines are looser and free to move to the sides, so the level of difficulty increases rapidly in proportion to their length. We didn\u2019t know how we were going to lay the connection across the canyon. All of the methods we had tested out had a range of no more than 60 metres \u2013 nowhere near enough. And ultimately, we had no idea where we were going to fix our slackline. Good anchor points are a matter of life and death in highlining, but would we find a decent rock to set a bolt into? And this was all assuming that we would get permission: the Victoria Falls are in a national park, a UNESCO World Heritage site, and are under specific protection. Would we manage to convince the authorities that we wouldn\u2019t do any damage? The bolts were a particular worry. The fact that we ultimately decided against hooks and were able to fix the line cleanly between two trees was also extremely satisfactory from an aesthetic point of view. This is what outdoor sports should be: they should leave no traces.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\" style=\"border: 0;\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For the first time, I am standing, shakily, above the canyon. Spray gusts at me from the Falls, hitting me in waves. The vision keeps blurring before my eyes. I am well prepared, but not for this. I have done highlines in snow, wind and rain, but I have never experienced anything like this. The visibility is incredibly poor, the line is wet, hard to control. Two steps, three, then I slip. I can\u2019t hold onto the line any longer and the safety leash breaks my fall. Adrenaline is coursing through me, my doubts grow stronger. I have to overcome them! Keep going, once more. I fall several more times before I can cover enough metres to be out of the fog of spray. Suddenly, my vision clears and I am standing right over the middle of the canyon. The void, the boiling masses of water, the abyss beneath my feet \u2013 I am overwhelmed. Then suddenly it all just falls into place. I manage to calm myself down, keep putting one foot in front of the other and an incredible feeling of freedom comes over me. It\u2019s not an adrenaline rush, but an adrenaline flow lasting several minutes, which is like nothing I\u2019ve ever experienced before. I manage to reach the other side. The first crossing is in the bag! But I have fallen several times, which is not what we intended. In highlining, you have to get across the line without falling.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When I get back, I unfasten my harness and hand the safety leash to Lukas. I tell him it feels great, that the cloud of spray isn\u2019t that bad. A little white lie to help him, the kind of thing we often do. He sets off on his first attempt. He falls too. When he reaches the other side and turns back, he falls again, but I can see that he is starting to get into it. It\u2019s my turn again, and now I can feel it too. I almost manage the crossing; just a few tumbles. But the conditions seem to be getting a bit better now. Lukas\u2019s turn again. When he stands up, I can see from his body language that he is extremely nervous. As he fights his way along, metre by metre, all at once I can feel his fighting spirit. He\u2019s going to do it, I really believe it, I\u2019m almost certain. Almost living the thrill with him, I turn out to be right: Lukas is the first to send this incredible highline. When he gets back, he looks almost like he\u2019s having fun. I congratulate him, am a bit jealous but, at the same time, I\u2019m absolutely delighted, as is so often the case. It\u2019s quite clear to me that the project has been a success, now that the unthinkable has been achieved. But for it to be perfect, I have to send the line too. I would be so disappointed if I didn\u2019t. The pressure on me is even greater. Am I going to be able to do it?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;When I get on the line, my movements are a bit wobbly and uncertain. I fight my way out into the middle and suddenly I\u2019m in serious difficulties, I\u2019m standing at such an angle that mentally, I\u2019m already preparing to fall. But something in me won\u2019t give up, putting off the inevitable for a bit longer. And then the hardest part is behind me: I\u2019m standing upright again, but I\u2019m so churned up and shaking so much, my self-confidence has taken such a knock that I just want to throw in the towel. Once again I manage to take control, try to find inner calm, take the next step. I can hardly believe it as I slowly near the end - if I can just avoid making any more mistakes. If I fall in these last few metres, it will all have been for nothing. The next few steps feel to me like an eternity, and then I\u2019m touching the tree. I\u2019ve done it. Only now is it all perfect, only now are we free. We don\u2019t spend a lot of time celebrating, we get back out on the line, but this time there\u2019s no pressure. We do a few tricks, try to make the most of these precious moments with the waterfall. This kind of opportunity only comes once in a lifetime.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We don\u2019t actually realise how lucky we\u2019ve been until the next few days, when the weather really starts to close in. The spray cloud is so dense that there\u2019s simply no point in any further attempts. We take the line down and now the project is definitely over. But we don\u2019t get straight on the boat to come back, we stay at the side of the waterfall for a while, sitting on a rock right next to the main fall and there, above its roar, we suddenly feel a deep calm.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;We decide to call the line \"Nyami Nyami\", after the Zambezi river god. We always felt it should be an African name and we love the carved pendants we found on a market in Victoria Falls, which we have worn around our necks the whole time we were on the line.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%2010.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The next day, as we make our way into Hwange National Park, we start to realise that TV channels and newspapers throughout the world have picked up on our story. We spend a few more days in the bush, in the stunningly beautiful, unfenced Bomani Lodge, and head out into the wilderness a few times with our ranger, Sibs. It does us good to have a bit of down time before we have to throw ourselves back into the whirlwind of interviews and emails. We have encounters with an elephant bull, buffaloes and an enormous cobra \u2013 on foot, not in a jeep \u2013 and later we see a hippopotamus, a cheetah and two lions mating. A visit to a nearby elementary school, where we put up a slackline for the children to try out, is the perfect end to our adventure. They are so enthusiastic about it \u2013 slacklining is addictive! Nobody knows that better than we do.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;In the evenings, around the campfire, we are drunk on the impressions and all the events of the last few days start to fade, leaving just a hazy feeling in the back of our minds. When the time comes to leave, we find it hard. I could lose myself in this state - stay this way forever.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.outdoorsportsteam.com\"&gt;www.outdoorsportsteam.com&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Vic%20Falls%20Highline%2011.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"866\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/managing_authority\/public\/Nightjar%20Cover.jpg?itok=ztFK0obu\" \/&gt;\n            &lt;h2&gt;Nightjar Travel&lt;\/h2&gt;\n        &lt;div class='bio'&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n    \n      &lt;\/div&gt;\n&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n","\n\n&lt;div id=\"node-8948\" class=\"publisher-1968 node node-article node-promoted clearfix content\" about=\"\/magazine\/11-maxims-improve-your-fitness\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;11 Maxims to Improve Your Fitness&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    11 Maxims to Improve Your Fitness  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"11 Maxims to Improve Your Fitness\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.gomulti.co.za' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/gomulti_logo.png\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Maxims.jpg?itok=AAMAMfN-\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/11-maxims-improve-your-fitness\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/11-maxims-improve-your-fitness\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/11-maxims-improve-your-fitness&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Maxims.jpg&amp;description=11 Maxims to Improve Your Fitness\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/11-maxims-improve-your-fitness\" data-text=\"11 Maxims to Improve Your Fitness\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/11-maxims-improve-your-fitness\" data-title=\"11 Maxims to Improve Your Fitness\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Dec 2014&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words Lisa de Speville&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;I love fortune cookies. It\u2019s the frivolous words of wisdom and positive prophesies that I enjoy more than the cookie itself.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;While preparing a special treat for a night-time, orienteering event that I organise, I went in search of pearls; those wise words that motivate and inspire and say it like it is.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;These 11 are my favourites.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. Ask yourself: \u2018Can I give more?\u2019.&lt;\/strong&gt; The answer is usually: Yes. I\u2019m not much in favour of running \u2018til I puke, but there\u2019s something to be said for finishing a race having given it everything.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. Relish bad training runs.&lt;\/strong&gt; Without them it\u2019s difficult to appreciate the good ones. I dread those chest-heaving and legs-dragging runs. They make an appearance when I spend too many hours for days on end at my computer; when I\u2019m not eating right and not hydrating sufficiently and when I\u2019m not running at least four times a week. Eliminating the causal factors is an easy solution to making more sessions good. Right?&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. Believe that you can run farther or faster because you can.&lt;\/strong&gt; I have a rule for ultras. If it is up, walk. If it is flat or down, run. At the 2005 Coastal Challenge in Costa Rica I hit the 52 kilometre stage running \u2013 literally. As the route ran north to south along the beach, it was all flat. I had to run it all \u2013 according to my rules. And I did. The whole way. Bar maybe one kilometre of slight climb on a dirt road. In doing so, I reached a new personal best for distance in one chunk. In adventure racing I see this over and over again \u2013 racers achieving personal records for distance across the disciplines. Yes, you can. And this leads me on to the next gem\u2026&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. Running won\u2019t kill you, you\u2019ll pass out first!&lt;\/strong&gt; Sports scientist Ross Tucker wrote a series of articles on fatigue on The Sports Scientists blog (sportsscientists.com) some years ago. According to Tucker, fatigue (or the slowing down of pace) results from the regulation of performance to balance all the body\u2019s physiological systems, which happens BEFORE any physiological failure can occur. So in theory, I\u2019d conclude that what doesn\u2019t kill you makes you stronger.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. Every day is a good day when you run 30 minutes.&lt;\/strong&gt; That\u2019s all you need. When you\u2019re cranky, tired, irritable or down-in-the-dumps, a run tints the World rosy again.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;6. Run often and run long, but never outrun your joy of running.&lt;\/strong&gt; Event after event, packing and unpacking, weekends that are anything but restful and recuperative and week days of squeezed-in training to prepare for these weekend activities\u2026 This cycle, although fun, can demolish that love for your sport, regardless of discipline. Back off to find and keep that joy.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;7. To be the best runner you can be, start now.&lt;\/strong&gt; Don\u2019t spend the rest of your life wondering. Substitute runner for biker, paddler, adventure racer, orienteer, paddler, mountaineer\u2026 You may not have tomorrow.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;8. We are all runners, some just run faster than others.&lt;\/strong&gt; Regarding adventure racing I often hear, \u201cI\u2019m not fit enough\u201d. I usually answer, \u201cSome run Comrades in 5:30 and others in 10 hours. There\u2019s fit and there\u2019s fast. You don\u2019t need to be fast to reach the finish.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;9. Run when you can, walk if you have to, crawl if you must; just never give up.&lt;\/strong&gt; There are only two reasons for pulling out of a race. One: when you\u2019re badly injured or severely ill. Just being ill is not a good enough reason. Remember that over a multi-day adventure race you can easily rest in the shade of a tree for a few hours or even overnight. It\u2019s amazing what a few hours of rest, food and hydration can do to improve your situation. You will regret it later if you pull out, let your team down and then wake up in the morning feeling like a million bucks. Two: when you\u2019re so far behind the field that the race director ends your race and gives you a lift to the finish. These are the only times. Everything else is an excuse, not a reason.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;10. Everything you need is already inside.&lt;\/strong&gt; Forget fancy-pants, top-of-the-range gear and apparel. These don\u2019t get you up hills or through tough kilometres. You do.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;11. And finally, a lesson I have to re-learn all too often:&lt;\/strong&gt; \u201cAny day that you are too busy to run is a day that you are too busy\u201d. \u2018Nuff said.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;About Lisa de Speville&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;Adventure racing author, athlete and founder of FEAT (Fascinating Expedition ad Adventure Talks) and ar.co.za, Lisa is keenly interested in anything related to outdoor adventure, especially orienteering and trail running.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/em&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source:&nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.gomulti.co.za\/2014\/10\/01\/11-maxims-improve-running-fitness\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Go print&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;Go Multi Magazine&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.gomulti.co.za\/\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.gomulti.co.za&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.twitter.com\/gomulti\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.twitter.com\/gomulti&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.facebook.com\/gomulti\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;www.facebook.com\/gomulti&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt; class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Karoo Back Roads  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Karoo Back Roads\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\/wild_magazine.htm' target='_blank' style='background-color: #b7cb35' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/wild.gif\" \/&gt;\n      &lt;\/a&gt;\n    \n    &lt;div class=\"content clearfix\"&gt;\n              &lt;div class=\"zest-gallery\"&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"stage\"&gt;&lt;img \/&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n          &lt;div class=\"imgs\"&gt;\n                          &lt;img src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/styles\/article_gallery\/public\/images-article\/Back%20roads%201_0.jpg?itok=dC43g3ze\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n                      &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/karoo-back-roads\" data-size=\"medium\" data-annotation=\"none\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;div class=\"fb-like\" data-href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/karoo-back-roads\" data-send=\"false\" data-height=\"20\" data-show-faces=\"false\" data-layout=\"button_count\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;&nbsp;\n          &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/pinterest.com\/pin\/create\/button\/?url=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/karoo-back-roads&amp;media=http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/sites\/default\/files\/images-article\/Back%20roads%201_0.jpg&amp;description=Karoo Back Roads\" class=\"pin-it-button\" count-layout=\"horizontal\"&gt;&lt;img border=\"0\" src=\"\/\/assets.pinterest.com\/images\/PinExt.png\" title=\"Pin It\" \/&gt;&lt;\/a&gt;&nbsp;\n\n          &lt;a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/share\" class=\"twitter-share-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/karoo-back-roads\" data-text=\"Karoo Back Roads\" data-via=\"nightjartravel\" data-count=\"none\"&gt;Tweet&lt;\/a&gt;\n          &nbsp;\n\n          &lt;div class=\"email-button nightjar-email-button\" data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/karoo-back-roads\" data-title=\"Karoo Back Roads\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Dec 2014&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;p&gt;Words and pics Romi Boom&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;On a three-night breakaway to Karoo National Park, you\u2019ll be able to explore its furthest reaches. Game is plentiful and birding is rewarding, but it\u2019s the vastness that will leave you giddy on atmosphere and beauty.&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From the stoep of Embizweni cottage, at sunset, the flat-topped Nuweveld Mountains gradually turned pink, then lilac, then violet. A universe away from city life, the Karoo National Park had been a non-stop visual feast since I\u2019d arrived in the early afternoon. Within minutes I\u2019d spotted Verreaux\u2019s eagles gliding on the thermals, one of the 17 active breeding pairs in the front section of the park.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Venturing deeper into the park towards the Nuweveld 4x4 route, the landscape becomes surprisingly rocky. Ideal terrain for the nimble klipspringers who watched from up close in the pass, but what about the large herds of plains game? How do the red hartebeest, gemsbok, kudu, eland, springbok and zebra manage to tread as carefully as ostriches among the boulders and rocks? The 90km can be driven in a day, but do overnight halfway at Embizwen to relished the isolation, the 180\u00ba views across deserted countryside, the grandeur of the mountain cliffs and crags.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you do the eco trail in an anti-clockwise direction, the roughest section is negotiated on the first day. It\u2019s relatively gentle, grade two, the only real challenge is embedded and shattered stone under your tyres. Although there are a few steep inclines, dips and rock shelves at water crossings, the scenery is more rugged than the track. On day two there\u2019s plenty of time to descend the steep gradients of the mountain and cross the flat plains covered in grassy shrubland. I stopped a lot, enjoyed the spectacle of Karoo korhaan and South African shelduck, and tried, unsuccessfully, to photograph a pale chanting goshawk in flight with a snake dangling from its beak.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Back%20roads%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;From the Nuweveld Loop, the trail diverts into Afsaal Loop and eventually joins up with the Potlekkertjie Loop, a popular drive from the main rest camp. To get in synch with the relaxed pace at Afsaal cottage, I recommend a stay of at least two nights. The waterhole is barely 30 metres from the cottage and the viewing deck is the perfect spot to read, quench your thirst, and wait. First to appear was an ancient leopard tortoise, next two kudus, then four gemsbok. Landing at arm\u2019s length, then flitting to and fro, the cottage\u2019s resident mountain wheatear. Sunsets at Afsaal were quite unlike those at Embizweni. On the open plains, twilight lasted forever, the sky aglow in burnt copper, picking up the flickers of the braai flames.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For serious and amateur birders alike, a few hours with Japie and Ralie Claassen, the gurus from Karoo Birding Safaris who have been birding for 35 years, will enrich your visit to the park. September to November is a good time to enlist their help to identify the seven or eight types of larks then very active in the veld. &nbsp;\u201cThe Karoo long-billed lark, when it is displaying, has to be one of my favourites,\u201d Ralie confessed. \u201cWhen you whistle, the male, who flies along close to the ground, rises up near-vertically 20 metres into the sky, with closed wings, then stalls and dive-bombs downwards, the wings still closed until just before it reaches the ground and continues its horizontal flight. There\u2019s no mistake, it\u2019s saying, \u2018In this part of the world, I am king\u2019.\u201d&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Other LBJs on your wish list might include short-toed rock-thrush, black-eared sparrowlark, southern tchagra and Karoo eremomela. Japie recounted how the rock pipits call for four days immediately after the rains, then they go all silent until after the next downpour. \u201cAnd a Namaqua warbler, if you don\u2019t know where to look, you may hear for a month without finding it.\u201d&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;If you thought one night at Karoo National Park suffices, you\u2019re in for a wonderful surprise.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Back%20roads%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;Trip planner&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Karoo National Park is conveniently located off the N1, near Beaufort West. Reception is open until 19:00.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Accommodation&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Chalets in the rest camp start from R1 000 a night for one or two people, family cottages from R1 500 for one to four people, R290 an additional adult, R145 an additional child. Breakfast at the restaurant is included in the price.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The campsite has 24 stands. From R205 for one or two people, R72 an additional adult, R36 an additional child.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Book on 012-428-9111 or visit &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.sanparks.org\"&gt;www.sanparks.org&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Embizweni Cottage sleeps up to six people in two bedrooms. R857 a night for one to four people, R215 an additional adult, R108 an additional child. Rustic Afsaal has two single beds, R690 a night for one or two people. Both are fully equipped with gas- or solar-powered lights, fridge, hot-water geysers, cooking and braai facilities.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;The small waterhole outside Afsaal plays host to the park\u2019s lion pride, whose territory falls within the orbit of the two cottages. Book through the park\u2019s reception on 023-415-2828.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Birding&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Contact Japie and Ralie Claassen at &lt;a href=\"mailto:karoobirding@beaufortwest.net\"&gt;karoobirding@beaufortwest.net&lt;\/a&gt; to book a half or full day\u2019s birding, either in your own or their vehicle. In the summer outings start at 06:00.&lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Source:&nbsp;&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\/blog.htm?action=view-post&amp;id=4662\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;Wild Magazine&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;a class=\"link-interest\" href=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/node\/766\"&gt;Karoo National Park&lt;\/a&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n      &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.wildcard.co.za\/wild_magazine.htm\" target=\"_blank\"&gt;        &lt;img data-url=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/magazine\/festive-fun-stellies\" data-title=\"Festive Fun in Stellies\"&gt;&lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-date\"&gt;Dec 2014&lt;\/div&gt;\n\n\n\n        &lt;h2&gt;&lt;br&gt;Christmas Feasts&lt;strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;As the country\u2019s Gourmet &amp; Wine Capital, Stellenbosch will be donning its culinary hat for families and friends to swap the traditional turkey and roast for a memorable Christmas meal at one of its numerous restaurants. &nbsp;Time to be merry\u2026&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Stellies%202.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;The new Bistro 13 at Stellenbosch Vineyards&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;R350 for a four course Christmas lunch. Munchkins 12 years and younger get a two course lunch at R100, which includes a gift from Santa. Child minders will be available during lunch. Email reservations@bistro13 or call 021 881 3044. (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.bistro23.co.za\"&gt;www.bistro23.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Makaron Restaurant at the magnificent 5 star Majeka House Boutique Hotel&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Treat your loved ones to Makaron\u2019s exclusive Christmas Eve dinner. This exquisite feast costs R550 per person and includes sumptuous creations such as Compressed Terrine of Christmas Ham, Goose and Cherries, and a decadent Milk &amp; Cookies dessert of eggnog mousse and mince pie ice cream.&nbsp;Email &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@makaronrestaurant.co.za\"&gt;info@makaronrestaurant.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; or call 021 880 1549. (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.makaronrestaurant.co.za\"&gt;www.makaronrestaurant.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;)&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Stellies%203.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"326\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Spier&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Spier will be offering a special Christmas picnic and dinner, but for some real Christmas magic, young and old should head out to the estate for its spellbinding Spier Festival of White Lights on 5 December. This evening is a performance arts procession across the farm, winding through heritage Cape Dutch monuments and led by Spier\u2019s Angel of Light on stilts. It also includes a dazzling display of lights, ranging from fire dancers, sculptures, lanterns and artistic performances and end with a complimentary glass of wine and relaxed tunes at the Spier Hotel. Tickets cost R160 per adults and R60 for children. Email &lt;a href=\"mailto:reservations@spier.co.za\"&gt;reservations@spier.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; or book via &lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.quicket.co.za\"&gt;www.quicket.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;. (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.spier.co.za\"&gt;www.spier.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;)&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;More light will be shed at &lt;strong&gt;Stellenbosch\u2019s annual Festival of Street Lights&lt;\/strong&gt; hosted by the municipality on 7 and 8 December. Bring the kids and be there when the mayor switches on the Christmas lights and pack a picnic and come sing along to your favourite songs during Carols by Candlelight on the opening night.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Stellies%204.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Middelvlei&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;On 14 December, Father Christmas will be making his appearance on his tractor at Middelvlei Wine Estate\u2019s annual Sunset Carols. As the sun sets over the Middelvlei dam guests will be singing carols while their famous Boerebraai is served and Father Christmas delivers the presents. This year\u2019s event costs R175 for Adults and R60 for children and is hosted in benefit of Stellenbosch Youth Outreach.&nbsp;Email &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@middelvlei.co.za\"&gt;info@middelvlei.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; or call 021 883 2565. (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.middelvlei.co.za\"&gt;www.middelvlei.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Other Christmas celebrations worth the drive out to Stellenbosch include the famous &lt;strong&gt;96 Winery Road Restaurant\u2019&lt;\/strong&gt;s Christmas Menu which will be served for dinner on the 24th and for lunch on the 25th at R475 per person (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.96wineryroad.co.za\"&gt;www.96wineryroad.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;). &lt;strong&gt;The Lanzerac Hotel &amp; Spa&lt;\/strong&gt; will also be pushing all the right taste buttons with their gourmet three course Christmas Day Lunch, served up in their elegant Governors Hall Restaurant or on the Terrace at R528 per adult and R265 per child under 11 years of age (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.lanzerac.co.za\"&gt;www.lanzerac.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;).&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Stellies%205.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;h2&gt;New Year\u2019s Parties and Pleasures&nbsp;&lt;\/h2&gt;&lt;p&gt;Whether you want to spent your New Year\u2019s Eve in a funny hat, or swanky cocktail dress, with all your closest family and friends or in a crowd of new faces, Stellenbosch adds pizzazz to the occasion with a variety of attractions to revel in when the clock strikes twelve.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Erinvale Estate Hotel &amp; Spa&lt;\/strong&gt;&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Steering away from the ordinary dinner and dance celebrations, Erinvale in Somerset West will be hosting a unique \u2018Under the African Sky\u2019 New Year\u2019s Party to dazzle guests with delicious appetizers, live cooking stations and a sumptuous array of authentic dishes served straight from traditional black pots. The local four-piece cover band, Shiraz, will add foot stomping entertainment to the evening. Tickets cost R750 person. Email &lt;a href=\"mailto:conf@erinvale.co.za\"&gt;conf@erinvale.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; or call 021 847 1160.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Stellies%206.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"324\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Spier&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Usher in the New Year with a touch of farm-style magic in Spier\u2019s Courtyard. A hearty three course meal will be served on platters at long communal tables for strangers to become friends while tucking into favourites from the fire, such as stokbrood and tender lamb on the spit. Mixed Flava, a six-piece band will serenade a happy crowd. Kids are welcome and will be entertained by friendly minders in the play area, a milk and cookie bar and a movie. Email &lt;a href=\"mailto:reservations@spier.co.za\"&gt;reservations@spier.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; to book your spot.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Lanzerac Hotel &amp; Spa&nbsp;&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;This historic hotel knows how to throw memorable party and on 31 December they will wow guests with a spectacular five course dinner indulgence, when Chef Stephen Fraser treats guests to a festive feast in their Governors Hall Restaurant. This evening of sheer gourmet excellence costs R950 per person and includes a welcome drink and bubbly at midnight. Email &lt;a href=\"mailto:banqueting3@lanzerac.co.za\"&gt;banqueting3@lanzerac.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; or call 021 887 1132.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Stellies%207.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Delvera&lt;\/strong&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Another outing the whole family can enjoy is Delvera\u2019s New Year\u2019s Eve Sunset Hike. It trails from Delvera for 9.75 kms through a Greater Simonsberg Conservancy and Yellowwood forest to the top of Klapmutskop \u2013 just to make it in time for the postcard-pretty sunset over Table Mountain and a celebratory toast. There will be vehicles to transport kids and the not-so-fit to start from the halfway mark. Remember your torch, your picnic basket, something warm to wear and your hiking shoes \u2013 you are climbing a mountain after all! A pair of Hi-Tec hiking shoes will also be up for grabs in a lucky draw. This adventurous treat costs R100 per adult and R50 for kids under 10 years and snacks and cold drinks will be on sale at Delvera\u2019s Trail Centre or book a backpack and picnic from their Simonsberg Caf\u00e9 of you do not want to pack your own nibbles. Email &lt;a href=\"mailto:info@dirtopia.co.za\"&gt;info@dirtopia.co.za&lt;\/a&gt; or call the Trail Centre at 021 884 4752.&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Stellies%208.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Other spectacular New Year\u2019s experiences in and around the City Of Oaks include a lavish, four course New Year\u2019s Eve Dinner at Bodega Restaurant at&lt;strong&gt; Dornier Estate&lt;\/strong&gt; at R455 per head (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.dornier.co.za\"&gt;www.dornier.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;) and a royal six course Food &amp; Wine celebration at &lt;strong&gt;Jordan Estate&lt;\/strong&gt;, with each course paired with an exceptional wine at R1250 per head. This memorable evening also includes oysters and bubbly on arrival and live music to dance the night away (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.jordanwines.co.za\"&gt;www.jordanwines.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;).&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;Although it is the season to be merry, Stellenbosch encourages the responsible use of alcohol for visitors to arrive home safely, so remember to book a taxi with Thrifty for the evening (&lt;a href=\"http:\/\/www.thrifty.co.za\"&gt;www.thrifty.co.za&lt;\/a&gt;).&nbsp;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Stellies%209.jpg\" border=\"0\" width=\"578\" height=\"325\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;For more information on the various Christmas and New Year\u2019s celebrations in Stellenbosch contact Stellenbosch 360 at Tel: 021 883 3584 or swing by at their information centre at 36 Market Street. Also visit the Stellenbosch Wine Routes brand new office at 47 Church Street, where free wifi, good coffee and wines at cellar door prices come standard. Or click on their interactive blog, blog.wineroute.co.za, for the latest festive happenings.&lt;\/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=\"\/sites\/default\/files\/2014-1\/Stellies%2011.jpg\" border=\"0\"&gt;&lt;\/p&gt;      &lt;\/div&gt;\n      \n          &lt;\/div&gt;\n  \n  \n    \n    \n  &lt;div class='author'&gt;\n  \n      \n    \n              &lt;img class=\"list-img\" about=\"\/magazine\/meandering-midlands\" typeof=\"sioc:Item foaf:Document\"&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"title-shim\"&gt;Meandering the Midlands&lt;\/div&gt;\n    &lt;img class=\"section-txt\" src=\"http:\/\/www.nightjartravel.com\/\" alt=\"\" title=\"\" \/&gt;\n    \n  \n  \n    &lt;h1&gt;\n    Meandering the Midlands  &lt;\/h1&gt;\n  &lt;span property=\"dc:title\" content=\"Meandering the Midlands\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;&lt;span property=\"sioc:num_replies\" content=\"0\" datatype=\"xsd:integer\" class=\"rdf-meta element-hidden\"&gt;&lt;\/span&gt;  \n          \n          &lt;a href='http:\/\/www.leisurewheels.co.za\/' target='_blank' style='background-color: #FFFFFF' class='article-strip'&gt;\n        &lt;img &lt;\/div&gt;\n        &lt;\/div&gt;\n            &lt;div class='paging'&gt;\n        &lt;div class=\"mag-shares\"&gt;\n          \n          &lt;div class=\"g-plusone\"
